90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 1 [Page numbering after 4 is incoherent.]

Weather

Many places in SA recorded a dry year for 1959, but in Burra the recording was 9.3 inches, well above the record low of 7.17 inches in 1914.

Burra School Headmaster Mr M.W. Scriven is seeking board for students in 1960.  So far he has enquiries for several first year boys, but others may come in.

Craig Evans of St Dye St Burra North was the district winner in the 13-18 month section of the H.J. Heinz Co. National Baby Contest.  District winners got a £5 prize.

Burra Rural Youth

27 members attended the Zone Christmas Social at Jamestown on 14 December.  Three attended the Clare Social on 22 December.  28 members visited Burra and Heathmont Hospitals with boxed biscuits for patients and to sing Christmas carols.  Supper was provided at Heathmont by Matron and Mr Barnes.  Proceeds of their Christmas dance will buy a Nativity Scene for Market Square.

Burra Rifle Club entertained the Yunta Rifle Club members at their first shoot for 1960.  Due to Yunta’s limited representation it was decided to have a four man team.  Burra won 370 to 318.

The top scorer was Gordon Webster with 93 off the gun.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club begins competitive shooting for 1960 tonight.  In the last practice match the best scorers were J. Brown, W. Barker & M. Mitchell.

Christmas Eve in Burra

Christmas music etc. was relayed around the street through four speakers.  Father Christmas arrived at about 9.10 p.m. and distributed ice creams, bags of sweets and trumpets.  Business houses reported successful Christmas trading generally.

Burra Rural Youth Christmas Eve Dance netted £20-3-0.

Accident.  Fred Atkins broke a bone in his shoulder last week when he fell while working in the ceiling of the Kooringa Methodist Sunday School.  He was knocking out the old plaster ceiling in preparation for a new one and fell 20 feet to the floor.  He also sustained a slight concussion, abrasions and bruising.

Hanson Road.  In the paper of 13 January 1945 it was suggested that there be a new Burra-Hanson Road to meet the Kapunda Road two miles south of Black Springs.  It was suggested that it run along the eastern side of the railway line instead of going past G. Finch’s residence.  On reaching Hanson it would continue past the water tanks on the Whyalla Pipeline and then along the western side of Porter Lagoon to meet the Kapunda Road.  Now fifteen years later the Burra-Hanson section is nearing completion.

Burra Hospital.  Four volunteers planted a couch lawn in front of the hospital last Saturday afternoon.  A sprinkler system had been previously installed to water it.  The workers were E.T. Baulderstone, C.H. Cummins, M. Breen and Dr L.G. Miller.

The Booborowie CWA Christmas Party is reported in ¾ column.

Burra High School staff changes:

Mr J.C. Morrison goes to Wudinna Area School as headmaster.

Mr G. Ireland is leaving.

Mr K.G. Hicks comes from Findon High School.

Miss A.T. Dadleff comes from Adelaide Teachers College

Miss F.A. Schwartz comes one day a week from Gawler Adult Education Centre.

Departures from Burra

Rev. D.G. Haydon & Mrs Haydon with children Barry & Janet left for Broken Hill early this month after a stay of 4¾ years.  Rev. Haydon has been particularly active in youth work and during his term the Redruth and Kooringa circuits were amalgamated to form the Burra Circuit.  He was President of the Burra Cricket Association for two years and led the Kooringa tennis team to victory last season.  Mrs Haydon was President of the Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild and a member of the Church’s House Committee.

The Morrisons are leaving Burra after Colin Morrison had been teaching in the Burra District for 20 years and at BHS for the last three.  Mr J. Colin Morrison has been appointed headmaster at Wudinna Area School.  His BA degree was formally conferred at a ceremony in Adelaide last December.  He is presently the Secretary of the Burra RSL and was a fighter pilot and instructor in WWII, being awarded the AFC.  He played cricket and tennis in Burra.  Mrs Morrison was formerly Miss McWaters of Burra and has played tennis and badminton here.  She was a member of the Kooringa Methodist Guild.  They and there children Heather, Dean and Jane will leave soon for Wudinna.

Mr Grenville Ireland has been Woodwork teacher at Burra for three years, but has now resigned to take on business life in Adelaide.  He was a member of the Lawn Tennis Club and a keen shooter.  Mr & Mrs Ireland have moved to East Glenelg.

Mr & Mrs F.H. Binks-Williams with children Judy and John moved last week to Seacombe Heights.  Mr Binks-Williams was manager of Elder, Smith & Co. at Burra for the last ten years, but has now been moved to the Adelaide Office.

Weather.  Thunderstorms in the past week have filled many dams to the east.  Some graziers had been carting water for months.  The past week has seen temperatures well over the century with no relief at night, but a cool change arrived on Saturday night and rain began to fall at about 9 a.m. Sunday.  Burra scored 41 points to make 57 for the month.  Some places to the east recorded up to 50 points on Sunday and with earlier thunderstorms some have totalled 150 points for the week.

90, 4, 2 February 1960, pages 1 & 6

Burra Swimming Pool Opened
A large crowd attended in perfect weather to see Mr G. Stanley Hawker open the Burra Swimming pool free of debt.  At about 3 p.m. the President of the Committee welcomed all present and thanked all those who had donated cash, materials and labour and announced that the pool could be opened free of debt, due to the recent arrival of a Government subsidy cheque.  There were still things they needed – a filtration plant could be added later.  Mr Topsfield was glad to see the presence of Mr & Mrs R.G. Jeffery (now of Clare), who had been holidaying at Port Broughton.  Mr Jeffery had done a wonderful job as Secretary etc. towards Burra obtaining such a fine asset.  Mr & Mrs Shaw were present too.  Mr Shaw had been the architect for the pool.  Mr Hawker was then asked to open the pool.  Mr Roy Jeffery moved a vote of thanks to Mr Hawker, whom he said had always been ready to assist as MP for the district.

[The editor said that when Mr H. Quirke took over as MP for the district he too had given what assistance he could.]

Mayor Baulderstone also spoke of the wonderful way the pool transformed this section of the creek bank and beautified the whole area.  He listed some who had given much assistance like H.C. Cummins and Keith Spackman.

Mrs Hawker presented the Learn to Swim Campaign Certificates.

The official party had afternoon tea in the Town Hall.  The committee presented Mr Shaw with a silver tray for his services.

[The results of the carnival that followed are then printed.]

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 4

Ron Dewhirst writes with some comments and suggestions about local football:

Years ago we had the formation of Junior Football and over recent years it seems that an ‘in between’ grade is required, but owing to lack of numbers this won’t work.  It could be overcome by having a ‘B’ Grade, which would have no age limits, which appears to be the stumbling block for the present Colts (changed from Juniors).

From the spectator point of view the present six A Grade teams can hardly be considered a great success.  My suggestion is four A Grade and 4 B Grade teams.  Burra, Hallett, Spalding and Booborowie could field A Grade teams.  It seems that Leighton can only function with the assistance of players from other areas and has never had the numbers for a Junior team.

The season would comprise five rounds and two Association matches.

Booborowie would call its B Grade team Leighton – the surplus from Booborowie.

Hallett would call its B Grade team Mt Bryan with the surplus from Hallett’s Redlegs.

Burra would call its B Grade team Redlegs with the surplus from Burra A.

Leighton Oval could be shared with Booborowie Oval.

[He continues of in some detail of where games would be played, the timing of both grades’ matches and some rules about the exclusion of A Grade players from B Grade for finals etc.]

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 5

Burra Town Council, 2 February

The Town Clerk reported on progress with the books of the Corporation.

Treasury wrote from Adelaide about the Local Public Works Scheme and payments made to Council under that scheme.

The scheme had its origins in the 1930s when, in order to relieve unemployment, the Commonwealth and State Governments invited local Government to submit proposals for work to be financed from loans and undertook to pay to those local authorities two-thirds of such amounts as were required to amortise such loans over a ten year period.

Burra Council submitted a proposal to improve Victoria Park at a cost of £400, but due to the outbreak of war no start was made.

After the war the matter was revived in 1946 and after some consideration about changing the proposal to the swimming pool, Treasury was advised by a letter dated 24 July 1946 from the Town Clerk that the Corporation would continue with the original proposal to beautify Victoria Park.  The Commonwealth Government’s approval was obtained and Council was advised that it could proceed, by a letter dated 16 October 1947.

In July 1948 the Council sought to amend the proposals to cover a project costing £1,200 – still in relation to the Recreation Ground [Victoria Park].  It was advised that it could do so if it wished, but the two other Governments’ contributions would remain as much as would amortise £400 of the amount borrowed.

In November 1950 a letter from Council advised that work had been completed, along with an accompanying financial statement signed by the then Mayor, the President of the Burra & District War Memorial Committee and the Town Clerk.  Receipts totalling £800 were forwarded for the contractor F.L. Hogan of Booborowie.

As a consequence half-yearly payments of £15-16-5, being ⅔ of the amount needed to amortise a loan of £400 at 3⅜% p.a. commenced on 17 May 1951 and have continued to be paid each half year since.  (Schedule enclosed.)

An agreement was received from the Fire brigade Board for signature concerning the tenancy and tenders for additions and alterations to the Fire Station.

The SA Government Tourist Bureau forwarded £385 for the swimming pool.

Souvenir Supplement to the ‘Burra Record’

Official opening of the Burra & District Swimming Pool

30 January 1960 at 3 p.m. by Mr G. Stanley Hawker.  [Photos of the pool, Mr Hawker & Mr Roy G. Jeffery.]

The cost of the pool was met by numerous donations of cash, Government subsidy, donated materials and much voluntary labour.  Despite competing with other appeals that raised something like £5,000 during the same period – the Town Hall Supper Room, The Murray Flood Appeal and the War Memorial Oval.

In 1956 it was drawn to the attention of the Burra Progress Association that only 14% of Burra children could swim.  They decided it was time to make that 100%.  Several previous attempts had failed to raise the money for a pool, but they were undeterred.

Approximately 170 people attended a public meeting on 2 March 1956 in Burra Town Hall.  The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone listed the pros and cons and said any committee elected to carry out the project would need to convince Council that it would not become a liability.

Mr H.J. Topsfield outlined the proposed scheme.  Members of the Progress Association had concluded it was too big a project for them and needed district support.  Mr C.A. Brooks as Acting Supervisor of Physical Education spoke strongly in favour and so did Messrs H.C. Cummins, I. Trigwell, R.G. Jeffery and H.J.B. Jennison.

A motion to proceed was passed unanimously and a committee was formed.  It met first on 3 March 1956.  H.J. Topsfield was Chairman and Mr B.E. Gryst of the Savings Bank in Burra was elected Treasurer with R.G. Jeffery, Headmaster of Burra High School as Secretary.  Mr D. Bednall [solicitor] undertook to draft a constitution and rules.  Discussion and public consultation moved on to site selection.  Visits were made to Mt Barker & Nuriootpa pools.  Both those pools were self-supporting.

On 22 March 1956 it was decided that the pool would be 100 feet x 30 feet with a depth ranging from 3 feet to 9 feet.  On 17 April 1956 a subscription list was opened to try to raise £1,000.

A deputation waited on the Council to see whether the Council would apply for a £1,500 Government subsidy and if they would appropriate a site for the pool.  By 15 May 1956 £246-13-6 had been raised and the Government advised that it would grant a subsidy of £1,500.  By 9 June 1956 £400 had been raised.  The army advised that the Drill Hall site would not become available and the present site was then selected.

By early August the fund stood close to £500.

The River Murray floods that year then occurred and this no doubt slowed subscriptions.  Excavation work began on 14 August 1956, but before it could be completed the equipment was needed for emergency work along the flooded river.

By 28 August the fund had reached £572, but meanwhile the Flood Appeal had reached £1,089.

The architect Keith Shaw talked with the Committee and the builders Messrs C. Parker, Bill Robinson, Len Taylor and Bert Cornelius.

By the end of 1956 £800 had been raised for the pool.

In the first three months of 1957 considerable preparatory ground work was done.  The annual meeting in March 1957 saw the fund at £817 and the principal officers were re-elected.

[Photos:

The old Mine Pool.

The site before work started.

Excavation work.

Further preliminary work – boarding up for the concrete.

Mixing concrete: P. Murphy, D. O’Brien & W. Corner.

Wheelbarrowing concrete [M.T. Kellock, L.A. Beinke, J.B. Topsfield & G. Kellock.]

On 2 June 1957 sixty-five men at a working bee gave 312 man-hours of work worth £120.  The first section of the floor was laid.  The second section followed a fortnight later, having been delayed by rain.  The final section was laid on 7 July.

In August 1957 the fund reached £1,007.  A further application for a Government grant of £1,500 was made.  The walls were poured by the end of November and the setting up of the concrete surrounds began.  In February 1958 the walls and floor were sealed.  The pool was slowly filled beginning on 7 February 1958.  The pool was next fenced.  Rural Youth contributed 146 hours of labour in June 1958.  A toddlers’ pool was planned.  Retaining wall and work on planting the slopes etc. followed.  In November 1958 £500 was urgently needed for dressing sheds, kiosk etc. which were estimated to cost £900 to £1,000.  This meant £500 had to be raised to qualify for a £500 subsidy.  Quite quickly a variety of means raised about £270 and foundations were poured and bricks obtained.

[The wading pool was completed on 10 August 1959] On 7 December a working bee painted the wading pool and donations reached over £500.  At the end of the school year in 1958 Mr R.G. Jeffery was transferred to Cleve.

[Although there were no changing rooms at this time] the pool was available for the Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign from 5 to 16 January 1959.  154 children enrolled and 100 gained certificates. The instructors were Messrs Tom Bowden & Grenville Ireland.  Check the timeline in 1958-59.  In this report it gets rather jumbled.  THIS CAN ONLY BE DONE WHEN 1959 HAS BEEN NOTED.

On 22 January 1959 it was decided to appoint a caretaker and to postpone the official opening till the following season when the pool would really be completed.

Lighting for evening sessions was discussed with Electricity Trust Officers and Mr Bert Beinke was enlisted to install it.  The committee was then led by H.J. Topsfield as President and E. Orchard as Secretary.

A working bee called for 24 November 1959 was disappointing and the pool could not be re-opened as early as had been hoped.  On 30 November 1959 it was re-opened after an energetic band had worked painting the outside of the dressing sheds and doing other necessary jobs.  The remaining major job is the installation of electric light and refrigeration to satisfy the demand for cold drinks.

In February 1959 the first Swimming Carnival was held in the new pool.  It was won by Draysey House.

In January 1960 the Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign saw 112 school children gain 204 certificates.  Instructors were Mr L. Pemberton & Miss Judy Kellock.

Prior to the opening floodlights were erected for night swimming and they did an excellent job, though one more on the eastern side will be required when finance permits.

Burra District LCL Meeting at Booborowie

The half-yearly meeting of delegates from Burra LCL was held at Booborowie on the 19 February with a large attendance from across the region.  Mr G.S. Hawker presided.  There was a brilliant address from Senator Clive Hannaford on his visit to America as one of Australia’s delegates to the United Nations.

President G.S. Hawker reported on a quiet political year.  He thought there was too much emphasis on the stabilising effect of secondary industry when three-quarters of export credits came from primary production, especially wool.  Better methods of production and good primary prices for most years since the war have put primary industries on a sounder basis than prior to the 1930s.  These factors have softened the impact of the drought and lower prices.  Secondary industries contribute very little to export income and with rising costs the prospect of their doing so seems remote.  But, their expansion is having an adverse effect on primary industries.

90, 9, 8 March 1960, page 1

Burra Town Council recently approved a plan for the beautification of the creek area near the swimming pool.  A committee of Messrs Baulderstone, W. Lloyd, Cummins and Fullgrabe were elected to investigate and report to Council.

The plan was accepted and work will begin in the winter months.  The plan covers both sides of the creek from the new footbridge to the Jubilee Fountain.  [A very rough plan of the area is printed.]

Between the bridge and the dressing sheds the area is to be planted with lawn and shrubs – to be sustained with waste water from the pool.  Next to the toddlers’ pool will be an area 100 feet wide to be a children’s playground enclosed by a cyclone fence.  Between the playground and the present caravan park sheds the area will be developed as a car park.

On the eastern side of the pool and playground a strip will be planted with lawns and shrubs beneath the large gums with barbecues to be built.

Near the old fountain a natural vehicle entrance presents itself, giving access to the car park, pool and barbecue area.

Only two or three old and dangerous pines would have to be removed and some other trimming would be required.  A new block of conveniences is to be erected near the present caravan park entrance.  The old type of conveniences presently in use would be removed.  The whole area from the car park to the fountain would be ideal for a caravan park.  The eastern bank of the creek is to be planted with trees and shrubs; perhaps on school arbor days.

Obituary.  Rev. David George Longbottom of Burra was born at Jamestown in 1904 [30 November] and died on 22 February after a short illness.  He was a member of the Ironmine Church before joining the Methodist ministry 34 years ago.  He began as a home missionary at Darke Peake Home Mission Station.  He studied at Wesley College and obtained highest results in the Commonwealth in Hebrew and Greek.  He was a humble and conscientious person, possessed of quiet persuasiveness and he won the confidence and support and affection of young people.  He loved astronomy and only recently vacated the chair as Master of Epworth Masonic Lodge.  He is survived by his widow and daughter Joan.  [The death is registered as 27 February at Prospect, residence Manningham.  He is apparently ‘of Burra’ because his parents had a property at Braefoot when he was young.]

Obituary.  V.T.L. Hughes of Mt Bryan East died suddenly on 8 March aged 69, while attending to stock.

Mrs Colin Hughes and her little girl were the only ones at home at the time.  Mr Hughes came to Mt Bryan East about 1907 to work for Messrs Thomas & Gare at Glen View and after a number of years he purchased a small holding and went share farming.  Owing to low wheat prices he sold his farming plant and took casual work as his holding was far too small to make a living on.  He has erected many miles of fencing in the district and up to a few weeks of his death was still engaged in that laborious work.  He was a loyal member of the Mt Bryan East Methodist Church and was a regular worshipper until the church closed a few years ago.  He was a life member of the Mt Bryan East Agricultural Bureau.  He was buried at Hallett Cemetery.  Mrs Hughes predeceased her husband in July 1950.  Six children survive: May Mrs Williams of Wallaroo, Aileen Mrs Modra of Gawler District, Albert of Adelaide, Jean Mrs Don Kessel of Kadina and Colin and Levi both of Mt Bryan East.

[Victor Thomas Levi Hughes born 1 June 1890 at Wonna: died 8 March 1960 Mt Bryan East.]

Burra Rural Youth was acknowledged for helping improve buildings and to run Gala Night Dance and assisting with finance.

President’s Report

Despite the drought the annual show on 10 October 1959 was an outstanding success.  The show was officially opened by Sir Philip McBride KCMG.

The weather was glorious and over 2,000 people attended.

Entries were just short of a record.

The main ring events were good and horses numerous.

A Sanction Dog Show attracted much interest and it was pleasing to see the sheep pavilion comfortably full.

The Rural Youth Sheep Judging Competition was a popular innovation.

Wool entries were well supported, causing congestion in the Agricultural Pavilion.

This prompted the decision to find new accommodation for wool and a new building is being erected for this purpose.  Mr R. Fuss has come forward to help the society erect this building and for this we are most grateful.

The Rural Youth have also been most helpful this year with financial aid and looking after Gala Night arrangements.

Membership remains over 300, a gratifying level and our financial position is sound.

With regret I note the passing of Mr A.T. McWaters, one of our staunchest committeemen, who gave untiring energy to the society.

We thank our secretary Mr T.G. Perry and Miss Hopkins for their assistance and to all those who served on committees or helped in other ways.

Accident/Obituary.  Brian Kenneth Baulderstone, a 19-year-old apprentice carpenter of Firle, was killed near Hanson on Saturday night when the car he was driving overturned.  The car was a Holden sedan and his mother Mrs Nellie Margaret Thompson was a passenger.  They had intended to stay at Burra overnight before proceeding to Terowie the next day.  The noise of the crash was heard by Messrs Barry Eberhard, Kevin Lane and John Bray who were in the area.  When they arrived the car was back on its wheels, but the occupants had been thrown out.  The ambulance and Burra Police were summoned and Mrs Thompson was admitted to Burra Hospital with shock and severe bruising.  The driver was dead when examined by Dr R.B. Pitcher.  Brian and his mother were to have attended the Prize Shoot at Terowie on Sunday.  Other members of the East Marden Club did not learn of the fatality until they arrived at Terowie the next day.  Although the shoot continued the East Marden members withdrew.

90, 14, 19 April 1960, page 1

The Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline will be duplicated, with work starting this year.  The proposals for the year ending 31 December are for new pumps for numbers 1, 2, 3 & 4 pumping stations between Morgan and Robertstown and for booster stations at Spalding, Georgetown, Baroota and Lincoln Gap.  The 1961 works include a major pumping station and a 33-inch concrete-lined steel main to Bald Hill, two miles northwest of Burra and a summit storage of 2 million gallons.  The pumping station at Hanson is planned to lift 12,000 gallons per minute to the Burra tanks and three of a probable four pumping units are listed for early installation.

The Burra to Jamestown section will start in 1962 and will continue through 1963.  Jamestown to Wirrabara commences in 1964 and Wirrabara to Baroota in 1965.  Later the rising main from Morgan to Hanson will be duplicated as will also the main from Baroota to Whyalla.  The total cost will be £12,237,000 and the work will not be completed till 1985.

The Bald Hill storage tanks will be located where the Hundreds of Ayers, Hanson and Kooringa join west of Burra.  From the Burra Tanks the main will pass through the Hundred of Ayers to Booborowie, passing just north of the town and assuring it of reticulated water.  It will then trend northwest through Ayers and almost due north through the Hundred of Reynolds, then northwest to appoint almost due south of Jamestown, where ultimately there will be four 2 million gallon tanks.  Then it will go northwest in an almost direct line to Caltowie and on to Wirrabara, through Germein Gorge to meet the existing main.  Burra should receive Murray water in 1962.

These details from P.H. Quirke MP.

Obituary.  Leonard Melrose Schmidt, second son of Hedwig Wilhelmina Schmidt (nee Bruhn) and her late husband Johannes F.C. Schmidt, was born at Robertstown 10 October 1942.  He lived in the Emu Downs district all his life and followed farming pursuits.  He was a constant member of the Emu Downs Lutheran Church, which he served as a lay reader for 18 years.  In November 1950 he married Elizabeth Joyce Werner.  The deceased enjoyed average good health and his death was unexpected.  On Saturday 12 March he was standing on the local tennis court, apparently enjoying good health and in good spirits, when he suffered a coronary occlusion, collapsed and died in a moment aged 37 years and 5 months.  He leaves his wife Betty and three young children: Christine, Jeffery and Wayne.  He is also survived by his mother, one brother and three sisters and their families.

Burra Ambulance Service

Following the withdrawal of the privately owned ambulance, which has operated in the district for some time, a meeting has been called to discuss the possibility of buying a District Ambulance.  The withdrawal of the ambulance without notice came as a shock to the town’s doctors.  The Mayor was notified on Monday night, but before he could notify those affected, Dr Pitcher called for an ambulance to transfer a patient to Adelaide.  The doctors then discovered there was no ambulance in the town and the Clare ambulance had to be used.  A meeting will be held on 29 April.  An ambulance committee had been formed, but when the offer of a private ambulance was made its work was halted.

Telephone Facilities in Burra were disrupted on the Thursday before Easter when Council employees washed out water tables while unaware that the PMG cable pits were open.  Water entered the pit in front of Elders and ran through the conduit to the pit in front of the District Council Offices.  About 150 telephones were placed out of service until the pits could be pumped out and approximately 1,200 joins were made.  Communications were restored by Friday morning.

Telephone Calls

The Director of Posts and Telegraphs has announced that from 1 May the local telephone area has been greatly enlarged.  Previously the local call area for Burra extended for a circle within a radius a little greater than halfway to Mt Bryan or Hanson.  Now it will extend to Clare and Watervale in the west, to beyond Robertstown in the southeast and beyond Booborowie, Willalo and Hallett in the north.   [A map of the area is printed.]

The local call cost will be 4d.  Trunk call charges will also change.  Eleven different rates will become eight and the minimum charge will be 1/4.

89, 17, 10 May 1960, pages 1 & 10

A Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting was held in the Town Hall last Tuesday night.  Thirty-one people attended to hear the report of the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone. [They are listed.]

Mr Baulderstone expressed his disgust at the attempt by some to arrange the amalgamation of the Town and District Councils.  He said he would oppose this because he did not wish to see the townspeople give away what their ancestors had fought for.  The Town Council gets much abuse about its roads, but Burra is scattered along miles of road, many of them with low rated properties.  The roads are not any worse than in other towns of comparable size, though some footpaths are not as good as they should be.  The town also has quite a number of bridges to maintain and many of them are old.

They had received quite a lot of criticism regarding the main [foot] bridge, which is now almost completed.  They had made mistakes there, but they had been rectified.

The Council has been criticised for removing street trees in some places, but they had planted many in the past five or six years.  Many old trees were unsuitable or were planted in the watertables.  I am confident that for every tree removed twenty or thirty have been planted.

Jubilee Avenue.  The row of trees planted along the creek side of the Burra North Road provides a golden opportunity for beautifying the town and providing a good caravan park area.

The War Memorial Oval is mainly controlled by its committee and they have achieved quite a lot with little public support.  A turf oval would be something to be proud of and I think should be more the responsibility of the Football Club.

The first public meeting in 1956 called for a swimming pool and by 1959 the Education Department was using the pool for its ‘Learn to Swim Campaign’.  I congratulate those few who went ahead with action and not just words.

When the Council decided to raise a loan to buy the Mine area we didn’t receive any objections.  It will cost the ratepayers little, with grazing rights offsetting much of the cost.  The area can also be controlled for rubbish dumping and road metal is available there where previously the Council had to pay a royalty for it.  In addition old mining relics can be preserved and the area developed as a tourist attraction.

With ETSA having taken over the electricity supply, there are more and brighter street lights.

Naming the streets is another idea and with gradual placement of the signs it would cost little.

The cemetery is proving a problem.  It covers a large area and finance is very limited.

Burra is getting a fair share of new buildings and the main street compares most favourably.

The Fire Station has been leased to the Fire Brigade Board for £10 p.a. for ten years with the right of renewal and the Board is now responsible for repairs and improvements, such as those being carried out at present.

The Town Hall had been allowed to get into a bad state of repair.  Until about ten years ago the hall was costing the taxpayers money.  It was then decided to operate the pictures for the benefit of the hall.  Money was borrowed to set this up and now the income has allowed the hall to prosper.  £6,000 has been borrowed for the new supper room, but it is all being paid for by the pictures.

Most of the health budget goes on scavenging.  In recent years this seems to have slipped somewhat.  I would like to see a regular fortnightly collection.  This would mean each ratepayer paying £1 p.a. for the service.

Septic tank systems will have to be mandatory within a few years.

There is now an urgent need to do something about getting a town ambulance.

Last year at the end of June the overdraft of £2,567 was too large.  This year we anticipate ending the financial year with a reduction of at least £1,000 in this.

Answers to questions revealed:

The Town Hall pictures account was in credit

The pictures had paid off the Town Hall mortgage

There is currently no special rate for garbage collection

There is only a partial list of old relics in the town

The question of amalgamation of councils has not come from the District Council

[A question re the cost of the new bridge is garbeled in the paper.]

89, 18, 17 May 1960, page 1

Burra Post Office

Mr C.R. Kelly MHR cut the ribbon on Monday night 9 May to officially declare open the new Burra Post Office.  Local Postmaster Mr O. Tattersall introduced Mr Sullivan, Director of Posts and Telegraphs, who welcomed all to the ceremony.  The building was erected by Taras & Co., Builders.  The CWA ladies provided refreshments in the RSL Hall.  His worship the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone congratulated the PMG on the erection of such a suitable and up-to-date post office in Burra in an ideal situation.  Mr Quirke said he would like to see an extension of the shelter in front of the building to cover people using the private boxes.  In his speech Mr Kelly referred to the history of the town and the Burra Mine and also to the history of its post office.  A post office was established at the Mines in 1847 and the first postmaster was Mr H.M. Buswarra [sic: for H.M. Boswarva].  The town comprised five settlements: Kooringa, Redruth, Aberdeen, Copperhouse and Hampden [sic: for Hampton].  Kooringa was the largest and a post office was established there in 1849 under postmaster Thomas Grant.  In 1858 a peppercorn lease was granted by the mining company to the PMG’s Department.  The old stone post office is thought to have been built in 1860.  In 1942 [sic: actually on 1 December 1939] the name was changed to Burra to save confusion, since the railway station and District Council were already known by that name.  Telegraph facilities were provided at Kooringa in 1860 and a telephone exchange, with two subscribers, was established in 1911 – Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd and Bagot, Shakes & Lewis.  A telephone trunk line to Adelaide was provided on 1 April 1920.  Today there are more than 300 subscribers connected to the Burra Exchange and two rural automatic exchanges at Gum Creek and Hanson are controlled from Burra.  From 1 May last the local call service area of Burra has been greatly extended.  In the past year the Burra Post Office handled:

Postal articles	591,655

Telegrams	5,614

Trunk calls	125,281

Local calls	145,431

The new building has an area of 16,000 square feet and cost £17,500.

The old building will accommodate telecommunications equipment and the telephone exchange.  At present there are 32 people on the staff of the PMG at Burra and the present postmaster Mr O.A. Tattersall has held the position since 1950.  [Photo of Mr Kelly cutting the ribbon.]

89, 18, 17 May 1960, pages 1 & 10

River Murray Water

The Government Public Works Committee took evidence at Burra Town Hall on Friday concerning the supply of water to Burra and districts further north, from the duplication of the Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline.  Representatives of Burra Town and District Councils gave evidence.  Mr Shannon MP chaired the meeting and outlines the project to supply water to Whyalla BHP Steel Works.

Part of the planning provided for large storages, the first of which is at Burra, from Hanson, planned for 1961.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone said that although Burra had a good water supply its quality was not suitable for hot water systems – especially at such places as the hospital.  Mr Shannon said that whether the supply would be all Murray water or a mixture of Murray and local water would be purely an economic decision; a shandy could be dearer than straight River Murray water.  If a shandy were chosen the ratio would be fixed.  Cr Ashby (Hallett DC) said Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie had no permanent water supply.  Their elevation could prove troublesome and expensive.  He felt that a special rate to cover supply costs would probably be acceptable – though ratepayers had not yet been asked this.  The cost of carted water at Terowie was presently 25/- per 1,000 gallons.  Mr Shannon said landowners along the area within one mile either side of the pipeline would be rated whether they used the water or not.  Mr Shannon also thought that landowners a couple of miles away would not be denied access if they laid their own pipes.  Burra will definitely be supplied.

89, 20, 31 May 1960, page 1

CWA Antique & Art Exhibition

To launch the building fund for their new rooms a committee convened by Mrs A. Tennant with Mrs M. Ashton as Secretary staged a magnificent exhibition of curios, pictures and things of historical interest in Burra Town Hall on Friday 27 May.  The event was opened by Lady Swift who is the daughter of Burra CWA’s foundation Vice-President, the late Mrs John Tennant.  The funds raised will be spent on a CWA building to be erected on land given by the Warnes Family in memory of the late Mary Jane Warnes, Burra Branch foundation President.  Mrs H. Jennison moved the vote of thanks.  The SA National Gallery provided 14 pictures, the Advertiser gave screens, Myers donated carpets and John Martin provided ropes and stanchions.

Burra mining days were represented by relics of mining and by pictures by Gill and Goodhart, arranged by Mrs A. Tennant assisted by Mr L. Bence.

The antique display included period furniture, china, glass, silverware and jewellery.  A wedding table setting was arranged by Mrs Rex Warnes and Mrs R.B. Pitcher.  Mrs H.L. Riggs and Mrs J. Hill arranged a Victorian drawing room on the stage.  An early Victorian table was arranged by Mrs G.S. Hawker and Mrs J.R. Barker.  Mrs L.G. Miller was responsible for a children’s party setting.  Mrs L. Bence, Mrs A. Bence and Mrs C. O’Connor organised an oriental display.  Mr R. Fuss provided articles relevant to Burra’s mining days including a beer pump and a collection of malachite.  [Considerably more detail is printed.]

[The exhibition raised a little over £180.]

Obituary.  From Perth Elder’s Weekly 12 May 1960.

Mr Frederick William Pohlner of Bencubbin district of Western Australia died on 30 April aged 66 following a short illness.  He was born at Hallett SA and was one of a family of ten children.  He joined the AIF in 1914 and later transferred to the Australian Flying Corps.  After the war he returned to farming with his father near Peterborough and later took land of his own at Copley in 1922, selling it in 1926 to come to WA.  He was a keen sportsman and played golf and was greatly interested in the affairs of the local football and cricket clubs.  He is survived by a widow and a daughter.

[Born William Fredrich Godfrey Pohlner 29 March 1894 Hallett.]

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 1

Hallett Hall Supper Rooms

Through the generous gift of Mrs A.G. Owen-Smyth new supper rooms at Hallett Institute were opened on 11 June.  The large supper room is fully furnished with tubular steel tables and chairs and the kitchen is compact and fitted with modern facilities.  There is a large cream brick fireplace in the supper room above which is a bronze plaque indicating that the room was built as a tribute to Sir John Melrose of Ulooloo in recognition of his practical support over many years.  The design of the new rooms is by Glover and Pointer, architects and construction was by E.J. Affolter & Son.  Mrs Owen-Smyth declared the building open.

[Two photos: Mrs Owen-Smyth opening the door and an interior shot.]

[Mrs A.G. Owen-Smyth was a daughter of Sir John Melrose.]

Obituary.  Mr Johannes Alwin Heinrich died at Tanunda on 31 May.  He was born at Baldina 17 April 1884, the eldest son of Gottlieb Wilhelm Heinrich and Anna Emilie nee Hetzel.  He was baptised at Baldina 18 May 1884 and confirmed at Immanuel College at Point Pass in 1897.  He had lived in the Apoinga District from about 1909, only moving to Tanunda three weeks before his death.  On 14 September 1911 he married Mathilde Maria Heinrich who died 18 April 1943 and on 30 September 1949 he married Mrs Hilda Maria Eckernann.  He took a keen interest in church and civic affairs and was church treasurer for 44 years and a frequent delegate to synods.  He is survived by a wife, son, and grandson, two stepsons, three brothers and four sisters.

Local History

Last April Frank Bitmead of the Adult Education Department of the University of Adelaide visited Burra and was struck with the atmosphere of the town.  He has now suggested a one day conference to be held in Burra in October.  He is willing to bring speakers, exhibits etc. from Adelaide and to arrange a full program if 30 people are willing to attend and pay a fee of about £1 each.  The Town Council endorses the idea. Weather-Season

Rainfall to date for 1960 is 1349 points.  Most of the district has received about ten inches for the year and soils were getting very wet, but recent fine days and frosty nights have permitted some drying out to allow seeding operations.  Crops have germinated well enough, though some areas are waterlogged and some early sown crops are infested with weeds.  Pastures are generally looking well.

Obituary.  Gertrude Blanche Goss was born in Burra on 4 May 1872, the eldest of six children of the late Mr & Mrs Isaac Goss.  Her father was a carpenter and builder, who in the early days of Broken Hill Mines took his family there.  Miss Goss was an organist at one of the Methodist Churches there and it was there she met and married the late Edgar Tiver of Burra in 1895.  After marriage they settled at Oodla Wirra where Mr Tiver was a signaller for the SAR.  Mrs Tiver was organist there at the little wood and iron Methodist Church, with her own little organ, which was carried into the church for the service and is still in her home at Hallett.  Mr Tiver was the Sunday school superintendent and local preacher.  In 1904 Mr & Mrs Tiver and their three eldest children moves to the Hallett District where she lived until last year when in February she moved to Adelaide in the face of advanced age and failing health.  She died there peacefully on 10 June, leaving seven children, twenty-one grandchildren and twenty-five great grandchildren.  Her husband had died 22 years earlier.

[Gertrude Blanche Goss born 4 May 1872 North Adelaide: died 10 June 1960 Kent Town, residence Hallett.]

P.H. Quirk MP writes following the Premier’s announcement about the duplication of the Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline.  It is likely the new pipeline will follow the route of the original.  The first route proposed would increase the cost of the large main by £3,000,000 and incur additional pumping costs of £75,000 p.a.  Plans are being drawn up which will provide water to Burra and over the first proposed route to Booborowie.  Pipelines like the one for Burra and Booborowie are built with extension in mind.  Residents further north should waste no time in preparing a petition for water so that the pipeline is built to sufficient capacity to take future loading.

Obituary.  Mr & Mrs Rex Pickering had paused for a picnic during a Sunday drive when Mr Pickering suddenly collapsed.  He was aged 42 and came to Burra when aged 17.  He was instrumental in the opening of the local branch of Oates Ltd, with which firm he has been connected for 25 years.  At his death he was a Director of the firm as well as the Branch Manager.

[Rex John Pickering born 14 June 1918 at Semaphore: died 7 August 1960 at Mongolata, residence Burra North.]

Burra RSL Ball was held at the Burra Town Hall on 12 August, preceded by a pre-ball party at the RSL Hall hosted by Vice-President Mr E.C. Pietsch and Mrs Pietsch due to the ill health of President Mr G.J. Kelly and Mrs Kelly.  Bad weather and appalling road conditions deterred some from attending.

Booborowie Church of England revived their annual ball after a five year lapse and it proved a great success on Friday 5 August.  Nett proceeds were £86-12-6.  [Three photographs.]

SAR has advised that it considers the present warning device at the Bon Accord railway crossing to be quite adequate.

Farrell Flat Golf

A meeting was held on 1 August to consider re-opening the Farrell Flat Golf Course.  A committee was formed to implement the decision to do so.

Burra Town Council has received advice from the Executors of the estate of the late Clare Ethel Gare of a legacy of £399-15-0 for improvements to the Burra Town Hall.

Theft.  A safe containing c. £25 in cash and various papers was stolen from the Burra Motor Co. on Thursday night.  The safe was recovered by police at Hanson on Sunday.  Papers from the safe were found scattered over a wide area and the safe drawer was about two miles from Hanson on the Farrell Flat Road.  The opened safe was found about a mile this side of Hanson on a side road.  The rear door of Aldam’s garage was also forced, but the burglars found nothing worth taking.

Weather.  Burra had a week of wind, hail and snow with falls recorded each day to a total of 134 points.  Thursday was bitterly cold with a heavy fall of hail followed by a light fall of snow in Burra, but heavier falls between Mt Bryan and Hallett, especially on the hills.  The afternoon temperature in Burra was 36°F.  The Burra Creek ran strongly for the fourth time this season and flowed over the Pig and Whistle crossing for the first time in a number of years.  [Photos of the Pig and Whistle crossing and the St Just Street Ford.]

Many district roads are impassable and the Burra-Hallett and the Hanson-Farrell Flat roads are damaged with washaways and potholes.  The main road at Cobb & Co.’s Corner was submerged on Saturday morning and the Clare Farrell Flat road was also under water for some distance.

89, 33, 30 August 1960, page 1

Burra Hospital

The annual report showed the Board managed to balance its budget for 1959-60 despite two pay rises, increasing commodity costs and a drop of 750 occupied bed days, when it was read at the meeting in Burra Town Hall on Monday 23 August.

Ratepayers contributed on the following basis:

Burra Town Council	£410

Burra Burra District Council	£1,380

Hallett District Council	£340

Robertstown District Council	£190

Chairman A.D. Radford said the fall in patient numbers meant a fall in revenue of £2,250.  Salaries and wages account for more than 50% of expenses.  The scatter of hospital buildings means more domestic staff are required.  Fees were raised in March, which will benefit the coming year.  Fluorescent lighting was installed in the Men’s and Women’s Wards, which considerably brightened up the wards and recently the hospital and Sisters’ quarters were treated for termite extermination at a cost of £150.

Lawns have been sown in front of the Wing and the Nurses and Sisters’ Home and about 30 trees planted.

[Presumably ‘Wing’ refers to the Maternity Wing.]

The Women’s Organisations have again been active and have handed over £550.  This assisted in renovations to the Sisters’ Quarters at a cost of £1,200 – for which Government subsidy has been promised.

The Hospital Auxiliary has also rendered valuable service, especially in repairing bed linen etc.

Since the close of the financial year the hospital has received a bequest of £399-15-0 from the estate of [the late Mrs Clare Ethel Gare].  This will be devoted to capital improvements and so attract a two for one subsidy.

P.H .Quirke MP writes regarding plans to extend electricity supplies over the northern part of his electorate by the single wire earth return system. (SWER)

A 33,000 V line from Jamestown to Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie is needed to serve the area north and south of such a line.  Country to the east of the Hundred of Anne is receiving supply from SWER lines radiating from the Burra system.

The Hundred on Mannanarie and part of the Hundred of Belalie north of Jamestown will be supplied from Caltowie – operations are expected to begin in March 1965.  Yongala could be supplied from this source.

The Hundred of Belalie south of Jamestown should get a service scheduled in October 1964 together with part of the Hundred of Reynolds.

Spalding stages 1 & 2 are due for commencement in 1963 with stage 3 to follow.

The Hundred of Ayers has three areas.  The Burra-Hallett scheme supplies the east and south areas and is due for completion this year.

Booborowie will serve two groups north and south of the town, scheduled for 1963 and 1964 respectively.  ETSA is currently investigating how best to provide the Hundreds of Whyte, Anne and Terowie and an answer is expected in about three months.

The Mayor reported visiting the Mine Area, the Caravan Park and the Swimming Pool with Mr Pollnitz of the Government Tourist Bureau with Councillors Cornelius and Finch and the Town Clerk.  Mr Pollnitz suggested asking the RAA to send an officer to devise a long term plan for the Caravan Park.  Mine access roads need grading and shafts need to be made safe.

‘Burra-ite’ writes wondering why the fact that there is a bitumen road now between Adelaide and Burra is not better publicised.  In the past few months many people, including some members of Government Departments have come to Burra via Black Springs, apparently unaware that the sealed road exists.  Signage is also a problem.  At the southern entrance to the town the sign to Adelaide still points to Black Springs and on the new road near Brown’s the sign points to Broken Hill via Burra North so that traffic bypasses Burra.

Accident.  Cheryl Anne Paynter fell from a moving car between Hanson and Burra on Sunday.  Cheryl was 10 yesterday and spent her birthday in Burra Hospital with a fractured skull and abrasions.  She was a passenger in a car driven by Theodore Paynter of Oaklands.  It is thought the door flew open when the car hit a bump.  Her condition yesterday was satisfactory.

The Burra Show was held on Saturday last.  The day began with windy conditions, but improved.  Gate Takings were up and entries were on a par with previous records.  The wool show was the most outstanding ever.  Official guests included the Hon. D.N. Brookman & Mrs Brookman, Sir Lyell & Lady McEwin and Mr & Mrs P.H. Quirke.

The new Wool Pavilion displayed 116 fleeces.

Mr Brookman opened the show.  [His speech is reported.]

Mr Brookman also cut a large ribbon to open the new Wool Pavilion and was presented with a key donated by Mr R. Fuss, to serve as a memento of the occasion.

The Burra Rural Youth Club greatly aided the show; firstly by providing and arranging a display of rural products in the lower pavilion and secondly by providing stewards for most sections of the show.

The club also arranged the Sheep Judging Competition and at night ran a successful dance in the Main Hall, which added £38 to the Society’s funds.  During the year the club raises funds for the Show Society and assists in the maintenance of buildings etc.

[Results are printed on pages 1 & 4.

Personal interest.  R. Fuss donated the trophy for the greatest number of staged exhibits in the Flower Section.  He is also listed as one of the winners in the Flower Section – details of which are not printed.]

Bowling Season Opens.  About 100 people including some 60 bowlers attended the opening of the new season by Mr J.M. Gebhardt near the Marston Memorial Entrance.  The opening marks the 40th anniversary of the Burra Bowling Club and it was thus appropriate that the son of the Club’s first President (Mr Albert Gebhardt) should have accepted the invitation to open the new season.

The Associate’s President Mrs Syd Pearce rolled the first kitty and Club Patron Mr Eddie Finch delivered the first bowl and Mrs Baulderstone raised the Club Pennant.

Burra Mayor E.T. Baulderstone announces an appeal to raise £200 for the purchase and installation of traffic lights to protect the children’s crossing between the Town Hall and the new footbridge.

J. Carpenter on behalf of the TPI Association thanks Burra for raising £96-12-3 from their badge day, plus £2-2-0 from H.B. Riggs.

Burra Amateur Swimming Club

Burra can be proud of its swimming pool, officially opened last January; four years after a small band of enthusiasts were told it was impossible.  However, the apathy displayed towards the AGM called for last Thursday suggests it may not take the next step to form a swimming club to promote swimming and diving, conduct carnivals and assist with the running of the pool so that it does not become the liability the Mayor was so anxious to avoid on the night of the public meeting of 2 March 1956.  The public is urged to attend the meeting now called for Monday 31 October to form a Swimming Club in Burra.

The Annual Catholic Fete was a most successful function with the financial results expected to eclipse previous years.

The Saddleworth Show last weekend was successful with some 2,200 attending.

Burra & District War Memorial Committee held its AGM on 26 September.

D. Halliday gave the President’s Report.

Last year in conjunction with the Burra Football Club the Committee decided to build new dressing rooms with better amenities.  The first stage has been completed.  This year the second stage was completed.  The first step was the erection of the verandah by F.M .Pearce & Sons and Don Halliday at a cost of c. £88.  The Football Club financed the concrete floors, repairs to walls and the installation of an 80 gallon hot water unit, showers and seating.  Work was carried out by Messrs James, Parker, Halliday and Hirschausen to the extent of £219.  During the year frames were made and fitted as protection for the lower windows.  E. Finch donated the required bird netting and R. Fuss carried out the work gratis.  Water pressure improved when E & WS laid a new main from Paxton Street [sic: for Terrace] to the corner of the oval.  A one inch polythene water pipe was laid across the oval to connect with this, so making provision for the watering of the oval.  Mr E. Baulderstone experimented with watering and showed that two or more sprinklers can now be used successfully.  A new scoreboard was erected.

[Of which details are given.]

Elected were: President, D.A. Halliday; Senior Vice-President, P.J. Byrnes [sic: for Byrne]; Secretary, H.E. Kowald and Treasurer, M.W. Scriven.

[Financial statement printed.]

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 5 [Misnumbered 9]

Redbanks Sports Day

[This report offered the first indication that the event was organised by the Small Bore Rifle Club.]

Have you ever been to Redbanks Picnic Grounds c. 10 miles east of Burra?

The Baldina Creek runs past the grounds on the south side.

The grounds are ideal for sports and barbecues.

Kookaburras are numerous and the clear running water adds to the beauty of the scene.

In the first season of the Small bore Club the purchase of the Old Drill Hall by the PMG Department forced them to remove all club gear and erect a suitable clubhouse on the range itself.  The club had and still has no funds and this activity was only possible through several persons being prepared to act as guarantors at the bank.

The [range] area has been beautified by working bees.

It is with a view to raising some money that this sports day etc. has been organised for 5 November.

Among the attractions it has been arranged for several go-karts to be present and for demonstrations of powered model aircraft.  There will be a publican’s booth and an ice cream and cool drinks stall.  Fireworks will be on sale for those wishing to join in the evening.

Burra Show

At the opening of the 86th Burra Show on 8 October the Hon. D.N. Brookman Minister for Agriculture also opened the new Wool Pavilion.

[The 1960Show was actually the 68th Show not the 86th.  The mistake arises from not deducting the years in which no show was held.]

There is no doubt the Show received a boost from the excellent wool and sheep sections.  The ability to house wool exhibits in the one pavilion helped the presentation of the other sections.

The Show Committee wish to extend their thanks to all who contributed to the success of the venture.  Many weeks of patient work on the part of Mr Fuss and members who helped him, together with the capable urging of Mr Herb. Riggs and his committee were well rewarded.

Local stores in the town contributed with the display of wool and wool products in their windows.

Opening of the Wool Pavilion.

Burra Amateur Swimming Club was formed at a meeting of about 30 people on 31 October.  It was decided to disband the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee and form the Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club.  H.J. Topsfield was elected first President.  The Swimming Pool Committee had a credit balance of £355.

Also elected were: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; Vice-President, A.L. Beinke; Secretary, Allan Ireland and Treasurer, K. Hicks.

The Club will apply for affiliation with the SA Amateur Swimming Association.

A minute of appreciation was recorded for the untiring efforts of the Secretary and Treasurer of the Swimming Pool Committee Mr Ted Orchard.

The report of the Swimming Pool Committee said:

The pool was officially opened by Mr G. Stanley Hawker 31 January 1960.

Voluntary hours given to the completion of the pool were 1,154.

The formation of a swimming club affiliated with the Amateur Swimming Association would allow swimmers’ times to be recognised and would stimulate competitive swimming.

Special tribute must be paid to Mr R.G. Jeffery for his untiring effort in the initial stages of the construction of the pool and to Mr Ted Orchard for his efficiency as Secretary-Treasurer.

Explosives

A quantity of explosives that had been stored for about 20 years in Burra was determined to be dangerous and has been destroyed under the supervision of the Chief Inspector of the department of Chemistry in Adelaide.  Approximately 3½ pounds of gelignite and one pound of blasting powder with fuses and detonators was involved.  Sergeant McGrath warned people that stored explosives can become highly dangerous and people should only obtain what they need and not store it at all.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

The official opening of the Small Bore Range was held on Saturday despite adverse weather conditions.  The SA and Australian Champions attended and the first possible for this range was fired by C. Lewis of Ramco over 25 yards.  About 70 people attended.  Captain of the Burra Club Mr R. Angel welcomed visitors.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone performed the official opening.  Afternoon tea followed.

Of the seven trophies being competed for on the day the SA Champion Mrs Barbara Pain won four, the Australian Champion Mr John Murphy won two and C. Lewis of the Morgan Club won one.

But as any one shooter could only claim one range trophy Mrs Pain had to concede the 75 yard trophy to V. Pfitzner of Pt Augusta West Club and she kept only the grand aggregate trophy and presented the 100 yard trophy to Mike Thomas, while the best Burra Club score in Night Aggregate went to J. Brown.

Mr Murphy retained only the afternoon aggregate trophy and gave the 50 yard trophy to Milton Mitchell.  Mr C. Lewis, who was best over 25 yards, presented his trophy to the highest Burra scorer in R. Angel.

Tuesday night’s best scorers were W. Corner, A. Angel and M .Mitchell.

Characteristics of the paper for 1960

In general there is a satisfactory coverage of local news, though the paper is beginning to carry material directly relevant to nearby towns as well.  Hallett in particular gets a considerable coverage, with District Council reports for example.  Some articles fail initially to make clear which town is being reported.

There is some evidence of careless editing with jumbled print not always being corrected in time or even referred to in the next issue so that it might be clarified.

Almost all the news except sport appears on page one.  Photographs put in an occasional appearance, but as yet remain a week at least after the event.

Sports as always get a great deal of space.  District Council reports are extensive, but not always very informative.  A long list of letters received conveys no real information.  Even an explanation that the letter concerned  a particular road or building etc. is useless if it fails to say what the concern was.

Note that this summary has generally ignored events reported from other towns in the district.

Page 1

Entirely devoted to news and photos of local event or people are not uncommon, though somewhat delayed.

Page 2

Advertisements for sales, entertainment, public notices and the like.

Page 3

Often a continuation of page 2 content with some large advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by advertisements of considerable size.  Most are two columns wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) in depth or larger.  News here is dominated by sports results.  District Councils are also reported at length here.  CWA news is significant and the activities of the schools get good coverage.  News of any sort rarely exceeds 1½ of the 6 columns.  One page usually carried a ‘Cash Column’.  This was essentially very brief advertisements of items for sale.

Burra High School Headmaster’s Report for 1960 (The 48th Report)

Enrolment in 1960 was 122; up 6 on 1959’s record.  Only 4 left during the year.  There were 8 in the Leaving Class.

[He then goes on at some length to thank his staff, the High school Council, the Parents & Friends Association, the Ministers of Religion, bus drivers and students.]

The school has striven, beyond the resources of time and staff, to provide for the less academically capable by providing subjects outside of the matriculation route: Shorthand, Typewriting, Home Science, Needlework, Drawing and Woodwork.  Public Examination results last year were very good.  In Leaving the three students won certificates with 90% passes in subjects taken.  In Intermediate there were 14 certificates and three others with six subjects each out of the 22 entrants.  All told our students got 9 credits and a 77% subject pass rate.

Sports continue to feature with weekly house matches, a Swimming Carnival in February and an Annual Sports Day in April.  Burra was doing well with the handicap system in the Mid Northern High School Sports at Riverton in May.  At lunch we were coming second, but rain turned the oval into an impossible morass and hopes were thwarted.  Virtual flood conditions washed out the series of football and basketball matches with Clare and Balaklava.

In July the Leaving Class went to Adelaide to see Richard III and in August the Senior School and some Second Year students went to Clare to see The Merchant of Venice.  The Annual Ball in September was a highlight with record takings of £149.  An Arbor Day in July replaced Visiting Day and most of the trees and shrubs planted are doing well.  A new classroom unit was added in the year and awaits the painters, so it should be ready for use in 1961.  Acquisitions in the year have included a new refrigerator in the Home Sciences room, new floor coverings in the Library, a new motor mower, remodelling of the Library and £100 worth of books.

Adult education classes in Dressmaking and Woodwork continued.

Two items of unfinished business are the site for the new school and the issue of a Hanson bus.

[Tenders for the bus are called on page 1 of this paper.]

At the end of 1960 Miss Shirley Crouch (Home Science) goes to Adelaide and Mr Kowald to Angaston.

J.R. O’Sullivan, Director of Posts and Telegraphs writes in response to a letter by R. Fuss in the paper of 13 December 1960, in which Mr Fuss thanks the Fire Brigade and others who helped extinguish the fire on his property, ‘But no thanks to the Telephone Exchange.’  Mr Fuss has refused to supply any details which would assist the department investigations into the implied failure.  There is no record of a fire call from the service of Mr Fuss.  A query was received from Burra 233 at 12.10 p.m. on Saturday 10 December asking whether the exchange had heard about the fire over the hill and the caller was connected with the Fire Officer at Burra 183 and the officer then activated the fire siren.  The postmaster also received a letter from another subscriber explaining that a call in connection with the fire from the extension telephone of his service was not effective as he had not switched the extension switch at his house to the correct position.  The postmaster has no further knowledge of the case, but should Mr Fuss care to furnish any information of the alleged failure by staff I would be pleased to have further investigations made.  In the absence of such I can only assure Mr Fuss acted under a misapprehension which unfortunately has brought unwarranted discredit on the exchange staff.

90, 4, 31 Jan. 1961, page 7

Obituary.  Mrs M.A. Jefferies late of Burra died 27 January at her residence in Colonel Light Gardens aged 92 [93].  She came to Burra in 1870 with her parents and spent all her girlhood in the town.  She went first to Mr Kat’s School and later to the Public School.  Her father, the late Mr Simpson, we believe drove the first train from Burra to Hallett when the line ended there.  When refreshment rooms were opened at Burra Mr & Mrs Simpson had charge of them.  Later they took the refreshment rooms at Hamley Bridge and it was there she met and married Albert Jefferies, who was in the SAR.  After the marriage they moved to Wallaroo for five years and then to Adelaide.  Mr Jefferies then left the railways and they ran a shop at Reynella.  In 1912 they purchased a farm at Mt Bryan and were there until Mr Jefferies died.  Mrs Jefferies then moved to Burra with her daughter Joyce and in 1956 to Adelaide where her three daughters reside.  She is survived by her three daughters and one son as well as ten grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren.  Mr Frank Jefferies still lives on the farm.

[Born Mary Ann Simpson (known as Mollie) 10 August 1868: died 27 January 1961 Reade Park.]

Grain Silos.  Tenders have been called for the erection of a 300,000 bushel silo at Farrell Flat.  A meeting of about 200 local wheat growers at Hanson on Wednesday failed to convince the Chairman of the Bulk Handling Board that Hanson was a more central point.  It is understood that growers in the Gum Creek-Farrell Flat area would fill the silo before growers further north and east would start reaping, as they are normally 2-3 weeks later.

After Farrell Flat, the next silo planned is at Pt Pirie with 16 cells.  It is expected erection of a complete coverage of silos throughout the state will take at least four years.

Public Meeting on Decentralization

Thirty-four people attended the public meeting at the Burra Town Hall on 20 February.  The meeting was to pass on suggestions about industry for the town.  With population dwindling what could be done in Burra was the question.  The Mayor’s own suggestion was the concrete trade – posts and bricks, many of which are used in the district and further north.  Another suggestion was crushed metal and another the development of mineral resources within the ‘Eastern’ country. Other suggestions touched on meat works and a cannery, Mongolata goldfield, clay, pottery and bricks and small scale machinery.  Questions of cheaper electricity and water were raised and the question was asked about how much and whether the Government would pay for decentralization.

Ron Dewhirst writes a long letter running about 1¼ columns suggesting that following the north Eastern Football League’s decision not to admit Aberdeen to the ‘A’ Grade and to continue with a League of four teams, the best solution would be for a ‘B’ Grade competition or a Colts competition.  Two ‘A’ Grade teams is more than one town could maintain.  When he first came to the district Booborowie had three and then for several years it had two and so did Burra and Spalding, but population has fallen with young people going to the city and all three towns have difficulty fielding one strong team.  A strong competition could not have been sustained with two teams in one town.  He does not believe four teams too few for a league and most country leagues have only four teams.  He feels ‘B’ Grade would be a better solution than Colts teams.  With a Colt age limit of 18 a lad reaching 18 is deprived of a game if he is not quite good enough for the ‘A’ team.  A ‘B’ team would solve this problem (or a Colts team without age limit).  The possibility of interchange between ‘A’ & ‘B’ teams would also make ‘A’ team players look to their laurels.

Obituary.  Mr Michael Breen, formerly the Secretary/Manager of the Burra Hospital and Secretary of the Burra Racing Club, has died in Auckland New Zealand.  He resigned from these positions in the latter part of 1960 to return to Norfolk Island.  He had just arrived ‘home’ and was settling in when death occurred.  Earlier he had been Secretary of the Woomera Town Board for 8 years, retiring in 1958 from a position like that of a town mayor, town clerk, editor of the local paper Gibber-Gabber, supervisor of civic amenities, registrar of burials and curator of the cemetery.  He held a BEc, BA and Dip. Public Administration from Sydney University.  Mr H. Foote said Mr Breen loved his pet galah and paid a large sum of money to get it to New Zealand, but on arrival was advised that because of some technicality it could not land and he had to leave it with the coxswain of the boat.

90, 13, 4 Apr. 1961, page 8

Ron Dewhirst writes about the new Mid North Football Association arrangements.  He is sorry to see so many Burra players from last year’s premiership side deserting their team instead of defending their team’s honour this year.  He maintains that Burra cannot field two ‘A’ Grade teams.  Each team needs at least 25 players to account for injuries, sickness etc.  Burra has won about three premierships in 25 years – hardly an indication it can field two ‘A’ Grade teams of the strength to repeat last year’s performance.  At any rate the new team has yet to be cleared by NEFA and as we were not recognised by the SA League last year they cannot rule over our own league.  If clearances are not granted (and he thinks they should not be) they would have to appeal to the National Council – a time consuming thing.  The players should reconsider and stick to their former team.

E.T. Baulderstone writes concerning the Burra War Memorial Oval, pointing out that neither the football nor the cricket nor any other club has any ownership of the facilities; the oval is the property of the ratepayers of Burra.  An improvement committee is appointed annually and in ten years has done a magnificent job in providing facilities with very little support from sporting bodies etc.  The next project is to improve the grassing of the oval and watering of the playing field.

He writes that the town cannot maintain more than one oval and he clearly regrets the tendency of some to drift away from the oval to play their sport elsewhere.  He calls for unity behind using the Burra Oval.

Mr W.F. Johns, formerly a Burra grazier at ‘Studholme’, has designed a special motor cycle for terrain and cross-country areas and for slow tedious mustering duties.  Produced by the Nippon Gakki Co. Ltd of Japan, they were introduced to SA stock firms last week and were demonstrated in Adelaide.  Mr Johns said the idea came to him when attending to sheep on ‘Studholme’ on unsuitable machines.  He had a knowledge of military vehicles, gained during the war.  Nippon Gakki were prepared to build machines for testing before getting larger orders.  The result is the Liberty Yamaha Ranch Model with high clearance mudguards, upswept exhaust pipes to avoid rocks etc. duplex reinforced frame and heavy duty suspension front and rear in telescopic assembly and five gears, allowing extensive use at low speeds.  Dalgety’s are the distributors.

Burra Town Council received a deputation on Monday night last week of representatives of the Burra Primary School, concerned about the dangers of crossing the main road.  The Mayor said the Council was sympathetic, but in the end the whole thing would depend on the Commissioner of Highways.  The deputation said their purpose was to get, if possible, a pedestrian crossing connecting the new bridge across the Burra Creek and the Town Hall.  The Welfare Club had sought action some time ago.  The Highways Department had inspected the area and given the distance of the crossing from the school, they could only suggest flashing lights.

It had been understood that monitors would be required, but this is not necessary on advice from the Minister of Roads, Mr Jude.  It was decided to go ahead and the Welfare Club had £200 in hand, but the Minister of Education advised that the sum could not be used for this purpose and so a move to press for a pedestrian crossing was considered.

Mr Stockman pointed out that a crossing could be used by other than school children and in the summer period by people going to and from the swimming pool.

It was pointed out that a pedestrian crossing would compel motorists to stop if any pedestrian was using the crossing, whereas flashing lights would merely warn motorists of the possibility of children crossing and slow them down to 15 m.p.h., but as the school was half a mile away motorists could not be compelled to observe the 15 m.p.h. speed limit.  It could be enforced past the playground, but that would not help much.  A pedestrian crossing could be set up by the Council with the permission of the Commissioner of Highways and it needed a prohibition of parking for 30 ft either side.

After discussion the Council decided to apply for a pedestrian crossing.

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting.  Thirty attended.  The Mayor E.T. Baulderstone revealed a reduction in the Council’s overdraft from £1,200 to £300 in the last 12 months.  Record grant money had been received.  Owing to the large number of creeks in the town bridges were costly to maintain and through grant money it had been possible to reconstruct the Smelts Road Bridge and also that on the Eastern Road near Mr H. White’s.  The cemetery came in for much criticism, but care of graves was the responsibility of the people and for the paths, of the Council.

There were many parks in the town and a good beautification scheme could be submitted.  The Caravan Park is now obsolete as far as parks of today are concerned.  A plan for a new park has been adopted and it is hoped a pound for pound subsidy can be obtained for the coming year.  It had been hoped to open the mine area as a tourist spot in March or April this year, but this had not been possible.  A public meeting was called, but with only five or six people attending, it was not known whether people in the town were in favour.

Street lighting appears to be OK.  The War Memorial Committee continues to work at the oval and a new basketball court is being erected.  The Small Bore Club has improved the area on the south of the wall and thanks go to them for the effort.

The Mayor was proud of the financial care, which had reduced the overdraft from £1,200 to £300 this year.

Burra CWA had a proud day on Friday 30 June when its new Rest Rooms were opened in memory of the late Mary Warnes.  Before this the branch has never owned their own rooms.  A large crowd gathered in Chapel Street for the opening and 15 of the 16 branches in the Warnes Group were represented.  Seven other branches were also represented. Seven foundation members of Burra branch were present: Mesdames

H. Wardle	G. Leaney	A.T. McWaters

E. Jettner	A.L. Kellock	__ Hogan Sen.

A. Marchant

The Mayor and Mayoress of Burra and the Architect Mr H.M. Jackman & Mrs Jackman were among the official guests.  Burra President Mrs H.J.B. Jennison welcomed the guests and said the rooms had been erected as a memorial to Mary Warnes as founder of the CWA in SA.  The Burra Branch had never had a home of its own, though it had had many ‘homes’ including the Town Hall where they had been very happy.  At the last AGM it was decided it was time to build a home of their own.  The site chosen was judged ideal, close to the shopping area.  Negotiations commenced with Mr L. Gordon and at that stage the Warnes Family presented the branch with the necessary finance to make the purchase.  Considerable funds were on hand and a building committee was formed.  When a likely looking plan had been developed Mrs A. Tennant arranged with Mr Jackman to draw up the plans at no cost to the branch.  The tender of A.L. Clode and Son was accepted for the construction and portions of it were sub-let.  The building was due for completion by 20 June and the opening was hurried a little because Mrs Dolling and Mrs Tennant were going away in early July.  Furnishings etc. were not quite completed.  Mrs Dolling was called on to perform the opening and in doing so recalled the youthful experiences of Mrs Warnes, who had learned the meaning of loneliness and formed a desire to form the CWA in SA, having read of its work interstate.  Now 80 Rest Rooms are owned by the CWA and many more are rented throughout the state.  Mr Rex Warnes said it was a proud moment for him as he unveiled the plaque in memory of his mother.  An inspection of the interior was followed by afternoon tea.

Mr Nash also spoke of the way Communist Russia was able to dominate and control Eastern Europe and he feared the same fate for Australia with respect to Communist China.  Supporting the LCL with preferences was the lesser of two evils he said.

Burra LCL Women’s Branch held its AGM on 7 July in the Institute Supper Room.  Elected were: President, Mrs R.B. Pitcher; Vice-Presidents, Mrs G.S. Hawker, Mrs A.L. Kellock & Mrs J. Stevens; Secretary, Mrs J.W. Riggs and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.  The Premier Sir Thomas Playford, Lady Playford and the Hon. W.W. Robinson were welcomed.  Sir Thomas addressed the meeting, stressing SA’s progress since WWII and continuing advances in the South East and at Whyalla.

Pascoe’s Barber Shop has closed after 73 years.  In 1888 the late R.D. Pascoe began business in the shop now occupied by Messrs R.A. Bevan & Son and later moved to a portion of that now occupied by Bence’s Ltd.  In 1910 the premises now housing the Burra Radio & Electrical Service were taken over and one portion used as a barber shop and the other as a newsagency.  It was at this time that Mr J. (Joe) Pascoe commenced his trade with his father and brother, the late Mr Claude Pascoe.  Another brother, Frank, ran the newsagency and the late Mr O. (Twist) Ockenden was in charge of a branch of the saloon at Aberdeen.  In 1946 following the death of Mr R.D. Pascoe ‘Joe’ carried on the business on his own until five or six weeks ago when ill health caused him to retire and close the hairdressing section of the business.  One interesting feature, which has gradually faded over the years, was the pigeonholes of shaving mugs and brushes.  Years ago the business formed a Shavers’ Club with a membership fee of one shilling a week.  Each member had his own mug and brush in one of the pigeonholes and for the one shilling fee he would be shaved as often as he presented himself during the week.  At one stage there were 184 mugs and brushes.  Going back a year or two ‘Joe’ said haircuts were 6d and shaves 3d and with three chairs in operation it would have been a quiet Friday to have fewer than 40 shaves to do.  Joe still has the razor he used when he first commenced work and though considerably worn down, it could still be used today.  All this has changed with the advent of the safety razor and later the electric razor.  Another well known feature was the collection of sheep photos, which covered the entire four walls.  The collection dates back to 1910 when the late Mr L. Gebhardt of Mokota brought in the first photo to hang in the shop.  Other stud breeders followed suit and after a time it amounted to a very fine collection indeed.
