Booborowie Robbery.  A possible clue to the robbery of Dinham Bros. at Booborowie is the finding of oxy-acetylene cutting equipment and a cash box near Porter’s Lagoon. The oxy equipment was stolen from the SA Harbour’s Board at Pt Adelaide about a month ago.  Investigation continues.

Basketball Court.  A meeting at the Burra Town Hall on Thursday night considered floodlighting for the basketball court and the Memorial Oval.  It is believed the cost would be about £150-£200. Burra Hospital Annual Meeting 28 August

R.K .Pearse presented a comprehensive report.

Financially for the year the average daily cost per in-patient £4-1-0 (£4-5-7 in 1959-60) and for out-patients was 17/-.  Prompt payment of accounts attracts a rebate of 5/- per day and this has proved attractive.  No payment of accounts is the Board’s greatest difficulty and the Board urges all to join a Hospital Benefits Scheme.

During the year there were 428 patients, which averaged 11.9 compared with 11 in 1959-60.  There were 692 out-patients and 67 births.  The hospital greatly benefits from support of the community and a list of donations received is attached.  This year we are particularly grateful for a bequest from the estate of the late Clare Ethel Gare of £399-15-0.  The cropping program reached 90 acres despite a late start and we are grateful to all concerned.  We hope to double or treble this next year.  [Mr Pearse then lists a host of minor repairs and improvements.]

The use of the town’s hard water has a very detrimental effect on the hot water system and the boiler had to be replaced.  The Board decided to install a 50,000 gallon tank to catch all rain water, increasing the capacity to 130,000 gallons and this has been completed and will enable the usage of rain water only in the hot water system, which weekly uses 2,500 gallons.  Major improvements planned are air-conditioning in the Nursery, a new switchboard and rewiring of the hospital.  (Already commenced.)  Also, modernisation of the laundry, a toilet in the domestic quarters, a buzzer system and improvements to the grounds.

Staffing has improved and Matron L. Fyfe has proved very efficient and co-operative and we are lucky to have someone of her conscientiousness and ability.  The Board expresses its appreciation of all nurses and domestic staff.  Last December Mr M .Breen BA BEc Dip PA, who had been our secretary/manager for 18 months and who was responsible for putting our books in order, resigned to retire to Norfolk Island and it was with deep regret that we learned of his death only two months later.  Mr Harold Foote was appointed secretary/manager and has the full confidence of the Board.

The Ladies’ Auxiliary continues to give valuable assistance and the hospital is indebted to them.  The Burra & District Fund Raising Committee has been active and handed over cheques to the value of £459.  We are also thankful for the Burra Record for making available space for publicity for the hospital.

Burra Racing Club held its AGM and discussed the need for more members when only two members other than the committee attended.  Elected: Patron, Andrew Tennant; President, Mr G. Gask.  [Photo printed.]

Many district residents have been circularised and issued with membership tickets and the committee hopes for greater district support.  The President said he was concerned about the deficit of £205, but hoped with fewer expenses this year the situation would improve. The smaller clubs generally were finding it hard to carry on and Burra is unfortunate in being too far away to draw horses from either the northern areas or from the Upper Murray.  The situation for Burra is not the best.   It is hoped to have the Northern Racing Association’s mobile starting gates at the March meeting.  There are 96 nominations for the September meeting.

Mr John Hammer, ANZ Bank accountant at Burra for four years, has been transferred to Mt Barker.  He has been in the district for 12 years, having transferred here in 1942 and joining the Air Force a year later.  He returned in 1946.  After five years in Adelaide he returned in 1957.  He has been active in town affairs and sport.  He is the President of the Lawn Tennis Club and Secretary/Treasurer of the Air Force Association and a member of the Golf Club. Sir Walter Duncan will retire as Director on the Head Office Board of Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. Ltd on 30 September.  He will also retire as Chairman of the Adelaide Board, but continue as a director. 91, 40, 10 Oct. 1961, pages 1 & 5

Burra Show 1961

The very successful show for 1961 was opened by Mr R.C. Gosse, President of the Royal Agricultural Society.  Despite entries being down in some sections, the total of 2681was a record.  The tractor driving competition, tried for the first time, created much interest.

The weather was a little warm, but nearly perfect.

Sideshows were disappointingly few this year because there were eight shows on the same day.  The tiny tots, as a result, were not really catered for, except for pony coach rides.

There were some excellent displays in the Industrial Stands, though overall fewer than last year.

The ring events as usual kept the interest till late afternoon.

Gate takings amounted to £241.

[Personal interest: At the opening there was an apology from Mr R. Fuss, a member of the Committee.]

Mr Rex Warnes, as President of the Burra Show, asked Mr Gosse to open it.  Mr Gosse commented on hoe important Burra had been in the past with copper, but now it was rather the gold of the Golden Fleece.  The district has become renowned as the cradle of the SA Merino Industry.  He regretted that all too few of the district’s fleeces were entered in the Royal Adelaide Show and hoped for better in the future.

The Tractor Driving Contest was the first to be held at a country show in SA.  The winner was R. Gillett with 99 points, followed by Les Warnes with 97 – in the fastest time of 3 minutes 14 seconds.

In photography the best black and white entry was by Rev. R.S. Jenner and the best colour transparency by K. Horsnell.

In poultry the Grand Champions Bird of the show was exhibited by R.D. Hall.

Champion Budgerigar was by M. George.

There was a good display of Jerseys in the cattle section.

Champion Cow: M.C. Garrard.  Champion Bull: D.C. Rowley.

In Cooking the aggregate points prize went to Mrs F.C. Stolte.

In Flowers the Champion Pansy was entered by C.R.E. Simon.

[Rest of results next issue.  Prizes were not individually listed.]

The Anthropological Society of SA visited Burra on the holiday weekend with Society President Mr N.B. Tindale of the SA Museum.  They visited the miners’ dugouts, the old mine, had a buffet lunch the next day at Baldina and on Monday with the permission of Mr Ted Rooke visited the Aboriginal rock carvings on his property. The Burra Mine Area is to be opened as a tourist resort for Burra by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz on Friday 17 November.  The Town Council through the Mayor Mr Baulderstone has been working on the idea of ‘selling’ the mine as a tourist area for some time. 91, 46, 21 Nov. 1961, page 1

Burra Mine Area opened as a Tourist Resort

On Friday a large gathering of local and district residents attended the opening of the Burra Mine area as a Tourist Resort by Mr P.F. Pollnitz, Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau.  It took place at the gate on the eastern side of the mine area.  Also present were the Town Mayor & Mrs Baulderstone and Mr P.H. Quirke MP with Mrs Quirke.  The Burra Town Clerk Mr R.W. Fullgrabe introduced the Mayor who welcomed guests.  The Mayor said the Council had brochures printed giving a brief history of the Mine and its workings, to give visitors an idea of what they were inspecting.  In 1845 the Burra Mine had prevented SA from going bankrupt and the importance of this fact makes it essential that every effort be made to preserve these old workings.  Ex-Councillor H.C. Cummins had first suggested ‘selling’ the mine to visitors as a tourist resort, but up to that time not much thought had been given to the idea and the Mine had mainly been used as a rubbish dump site.  Mr Baulderstone said he soon fell in with the idea, as he realised what a wonderful venture it could prove.  Later he had the opportunity of showing Mr Polnitz over the site and from his enthusiasm had been much heartened.  The response to a public meeting to discuss the matter was disheartening, but he and his Councillors had battled on and though they had aimed to open it in March, it had not been ready until now.  He thanked former Burra High School Headmaster Mr Murray scrivener for writing the history used in the brochure.  He also thanked Mr P.H. Quirke for tracing facts used in it, Mr McGrath for his reproduction of photos and Mr S. Sleader for lending the same.  The Burra Record was thanked for printing it.  There was still much to be done.

Through the efforts of Mr Rex Warnes the Royal Agricultural and Horticultural Society has agreed to return the Old Jinker to be preserved on the Mine Property and this would be part of the Museum collection.

Mr Pollnitz then opened the site.  He said other countries went to much more trouble to ‘sell’ their historical attractions and we should also.  Burra needed to encourage people to stay in the town to see the attractions.  He would encourage the formation of a museum as mentioned by the Mayor.

Mr Quirke moved a vote of thanks and spoke of the amount of information and other material available for such a museum project.  [Photo of the Mine in working condition: probably taken in 1869 just before conversion to open cut operation.]

Llewellyn Herbert Piggott of Porter’s Lagoon had a party on 19 November to celebrate his 90th birthday.  He was born at Watervale in 1871 to Richard and Eliza Piggott.  His parents settled at Clarendon in 1853 and about 1869 moved to Watervale where Richard Piggott was employed on property associated with the names of Duncan and Hughes.  Some of his children attended Stanley Grammar School established by Mr Coles.  In 1875 the family moved by wagon to Morchard where virgin land was taken up.  Here Herbert began farming with his father and continued when he and his parents moved to Booleroo Centre about 1892.  His father died in 1895 and in 1904 Herbert married Annie, eldest daughter of Richard and Christina Dunstan of Booleroo Centre.  He and other farmers of the area carted their wheat through picturesque Telowie Gorge to Port Germein – some 29 miles.  In 1911 he and his family moved to Porter’s Lagoon where he has resided ever since.  His two brothers and three sisters all lived to be over 80, but are now deceased: Robert (Wistow), Sidney (Lameroo), Mrs Sanders (Booleroo Centre), Mrs Nancarrow (Glenelg) and Mrs Sargent (Crystal Brook).  Of his seven children, five survive: Bert (Porter’s Lagoon), Tom (Clare), Myra Mrs Ross Reed (St Georges), Elvy Mrs Glen Krummel (Eudunda) and Lily Mrs Henshaw (Ormond, Melbourne).  Mabel and Jean are deceased.  Some 70 people attended the celebrations and Mrs Piggott responded capably on behalf of her husband.  [He died 15 June 1964 Riverton, residence Farrell Flat and his wife died 28 April 1972 at Clare aged 92.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1961

In a number of ways it is disappointing.  Coverage extends to Spalding and Riverton, so there is less on Burra, but that is not the principal concern.  Articles frequently fail to identify which town they are about, at least not until you are well into them.  An example is an article headed ‘Swimming Pool Competition Completed,’ which does not indicate it is about Riverton until almost half a column into the report.  Another example informs us that Mrs King has been appointed a Senior Assistant without telling the reader at which school.

Typographical errors with jumbled lines, incorrect spacing or omitted words or lines are all too common.

Most of the news (other than sport) is on page one and photographs are a welcome, if occasional, addition.  Some news extends to other pages, but sport dominates there, though even the sport is not consistently reported.

The CWA gets particularly good coverage and as usual football is extensively reported.  Coverage of other sports is not very consistent; no doubt reflecting the inconsistency of the clubs’ publicity officers.  District Council meetings are generally well covered, but little of the information is of interest at this distance in time.

A sitting Councillor died without comment in the paper.

A welcome feature was the inclusion of some local photographs, though they were a week or two after the event by the time the plates got back for printing.

Note that this summary has generally ignored events reported from Riverton, Spalding or Saddleworth.

Page 1

Entirely devoted to news and photos of local event or people are not uncommon, though somewhat delayed.

Page 2

Advertisements for sales, entertainment, public notices and the like.

Page 3

Often a continuation of page 2 content with some large advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by advertisements of considerable size.  Most are two columns wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) in depth or larger.  News here is dominated by sports results.  ‘The Christian Message’ is a regular column of fluctuating size.  CWA news is significant and the activities of the schools get good coverage.  News of any sort rarely exceeds 1½ of the 6 columns.

Geraldton Subterranean Clover has been a big success in many areas of Spalding, Jamestown and Burra Districts.  It has outclassed Dwalganup.  Its low growth is a drawback in weedy paddocks.  It thrives in areas with 16-19 inches of rain and is more lime tolerant than Dwalganup.

Burra RSL.  Annual Report of President H. Cornelius

Members have not given the club the support needed for it to continue.  A few willing members who are overworked are making all the effort.  Weather forced the Anzac Service to be held in the clubrooms and it was again conducted by the Ministers Fraternal.  Fortunately conditions afterwards improved and allowed the march to take place. Obituary.  Mrs George Parker was born at Stony Gap in 1869, the eldest daughter of the late Mr & Mrs Joseph Flower.  She was educated at Stony Gap and in 1893 married Mr George Parker.  After three years of marriage they moved to Copperhouse where they spent 23 years share-farming, shearing and contracting.  There was a family of six: four daughters and two sons, of whom five survive.  The youngest son, Joe, died as a result of an accident in 1925.  In 1916 Mr Parker bought a property at Booborowie and the family moved there until his death in 1946.  Mrs Parker then came to live in Queen Street in Burra where she lived alone until in the last five or six years of failing health she was forced to share her home life with daughter, Mrs H. Cornelius of Burra and Mrs Herb Collins of Booborowie.  She died at Burra Hospital on 8 January after an illness of nine weeks.  She leaves four daughters and one son: Vida Mrs Jack Pens (Burra), Mill Mrs Herbert Cornelius (Booborowie) [sic], Cecil (Queensland), Cass Mrs Oliver Earle (Swan Hill) and Lill Mrs H. Cornelius (Burra).

[Mill (Mildred) was really Mrs William Herbert Collins]

Burra Hospital Cropping Scheme.  The result of 194 bags was below target, but useful and a satisfactory result considering the unfavourable season.  Land is required now for the 1962 season.

Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline.  The SA Government is considering laying a 12 mile portion of the pipeline on the bed of Spencer Gulf.  If feasible this would cut the length by 56 miles of the 223 miles.  The suggestion would be to run from Pt Germein to Point Lowly at a maximum depth of 75 ft.  Three-quarters of this length is exposed at low tide.  The new pipe will be of 42 inches diameter for more than half its length and is expected to have a capacity of five times that of the original pipeline opened in 1944 at a cost of £2,750,000.  A work camp has been established at Spalding for the Hanson to Bundaleer section, on which work will start this month.  Duplication will take several years.

The Heliothis Grub poses a threat to lucerne seed crops in the next few weeks.  The moth has become more prevalent lately after a long period of little change.  Recommended control is 2 ounces of actual DDT (8 oz of 25 p.m. DDT) to the acre.  One spray gives one week’s protection at this time of the year.

Weather.  Hail storms.  A wild storm struck Mt Bryan about 4 p.m. on Friday in a confined strip.  Golf ball sized hail and 136 points of rain fell in 40 minutes accompanied by high winds which wrecked two sections of the wheat stack shed and hurled them through telephone lines and wrapped them around one of the large steel poles which was then levelled with ground, but which saved the hotel from being damaged by the flying debris.  Some of the 8 inch by 8 inch uprights were snapped off like carrots and twisted iron and broken timber littered the highway.  Telephone services to the north were cut.  A large tree near the station fell and cut railway control lines.  Hail broke windows and skylights and tore gardens to shreds.  Colin Lloyd, who was working at Mt Bryan, brought in some of the hail which would barely fit into the neck of a two pint thermos flask.  The creek north of the town came down and stranded a number of travellers.  At the top end of the creek Mr H. Griffen’s property received 3 inches with damage to fences etc.  Burra had a less severe hail storm at about 3 a.m. on Saturday.

Obituary.  Richard (Dick) Crang died in an Adelaide Hospital 24 January.  He spent five years in Burra at Elder, Smith & Co.  He joined Elders in 1932 at Wentworth NSW where he was born 49 years ago.  He came to Burra in 1935 and enlisted from here in June 1940 in the 2/7 Field Regiment AIF.  After the war he opened Elder’s Kingscote Branch and from 1947 to 1951 was manager at Pt Augusta.  He then spent five years as a Branch Inspector before opening Elder’s Alice Springs Branch in 1956.  Ill health forced a transfer to Adelaide twelve months ago.  He is survived by a widow and two sons, Bill and Richard.

[Born 24 June 1912 Wentworth NSW.]

92, 5, 6 Feb. 1962, page 1

Council Amalgamation was discussed at a meeting between the Burra Town and District Councils on 31 January following a petition from 300 ratepayers.  It was resolved that the Councils separately discuss the issues and there be another joint meeting 21 February.  Mr Baulderstone said the issue arose from a petition of ratepayers, but he personally felt from 15 successive years’ experience that the Town Council was too small.  The Council had reached its limit in rate revenue and the population had declined.  Rate revenue is three times that of thirty years ago, but administration [costs] are five time that of thirty years ago.  Money on administration could be saved by amalgamation.  He could not see why the two Councils could not work together.  The District Council than asked a series of questions:

What is the rate revenue?

What percentage of the ratepayers is represented by the 300 petitioners?

How many miles of road are there in the Town Council area?

How is the income spent?

Does the Council work on Ward Accounts?

Is money raised in a ward spent in the ward?

What is the percentage of administrative costs against rate revenue?

Town Council members felt they needed to discuss matters further in their own chamber.

DC Chairman A.D. Radford felt amalgamation would be a step in the right direction, though the opinion of Councillors in both Councils was divided. If amalgamation was desired there would be many problems to overcome and a series of meetings would be needed.

Burra Town Council met on 12 February to discuss the amalgamation with the District Council.  Most Councillors felt that the loss of town status and of the leadership of a Mayor and Mayoress would be an important deciding factor.  The expression of the ratepayers who signed the petition, giving reasons for the amalgamation would be sought.  It was felt much more discussion between the two Councils would be needed before the actual facts for and against any amalgamation could be laid before the ratepayers.  The Mayor protested against the long delay in repairing the footpath in front of his home; it having been ripped up by a Government Department and now has been sealed at his own expense.  He also objected to pine trees cut down and dumped along Mr Brian Riggs’ fence that should have been removed months ago.  The Town Council resolved to meet fortnightly instead of monthly, on the first and third Mondays of the month.

Burra Burra Show Inc.  Mr Rex. Warnes was re-elected President at the Annual Meeting.

Tribute was paid to Mr R. Fuss, Life Member of the Society, for his efforts in making additions and repairs and maintenance.

Mr Warnes reported a successful show on 7 October 1961 in perfect weather.  Gate takings were £241 and there was £41-15-0 from a ball run by the Rural Youth Club.  Entries numbered 2681, a record.  The tractor driving contest, held for the first time at a country show, proved successful.  Membership is steady, but the financial position is not quite as good as previously.

‘Once again Mr Robert Fuss has been a tower of strength to us with his work.  He saves us a considerable amount of money and is forever willing to keep things in order.  Through his efforts I can report the additions of a Casualty Room and a President’s Room.  Both proved an acquisition at the Show.  Mr Fuss was also instrumental in bringing the staging positions in the main pavilion up to date.  This caused a much better display of exhibits.  He also did numerous other jobs to benefit the Society, including the watering of trees which were presented by Mrs Stanley Hawker in front of the main buildings.  We are proud to have Mr Fuss as a Life Member.’

I regret to record the death of Mr Edwin Finch and Mr John Kellock who both did much solid work for the society.

Elected: Patron, G.S. Hawker; President, Rex C. Warnes; Vice-Presidents, Messrs B.A. Riggs & C.F. Pearce.

[R. Fuss was on the Produce Committee.]

Burra High School is celebrating its Golden Jubilee this year.  The Headmaster Mr R.V. Mueller recounts some of its highlights.  [In the summaries that follow references to sports achievements and prizes awarded have been omitted.  They have generally appeared when they occurred.]

1913

The school officially opened 20 January 1913 with J.W. Statton as Assistant in charge and with 30 pupils.  Pictures chosen by Mr V. Pavia arrived and the library began with 42 books.  A basketball was purchased.  Inspector T. Cole recommended a table be obtained for the teacher.  Late in the year a cupboard was supplied.

1914

Dorothy Pederson, Isobel Rosewall and Ella Harris applied to be Junior Teachers.  Senior Cadets were taken in the Drill Hall by a Military Officer.  A medal presented by Mr Crewes was won by Fred Scholz and Frank Riggs won a scholarship to Roseworthy Agricultural College.  A seaside picnic was held at Semaphore.  On 5 October it was recorded that due to the bad season many children left to help at home.

1915

Mr Statton enlisted and was replaced by the head teacher John T. Johnson, with Frank Thomas Assistant in Charge.  A note records: ‘As a Junior Commercial Class has been formed, a typewriter is needed, but we have had no success in obtaining one.’

Cliff Flower topped the Primary division with 92%.  He later died whilst Headmaster of Mt Gambier High School and his memory was much revered by Inspector A.O. McPherson.  On 5 August there was a short address on the Anniversary of the Declaration of War.  H. Collins won the Scholarship to Roseworthy and Fred Scholz entered the Junior Commercial Exam.  The year ended with an enrolment of 14 – many having left due to hardship.

1916

The Head Teacher Mr J. Mundy with John Biddle Assistant in Charge.  Enrolment was 29.  There was a measles epidemic in the year.  Clifford Flower passed six subjects with one credit in the Junior Class and Josephine West topped the Primary Class.  (To be continued.)

Burra High School.  The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller

1917

The year opened with 23 students and a new football and basketball were ordered.  Seven students attended a Boy Scout Rally in Adelaide and the school celebrated Violet Day on 6 July.  On 21 August snow fell between 8 and 11 a.m.  Hazel Edwards got 5 subjects in the Junior Commercial Class.  Josephine West topped Junior Public and Grace Lloyd topped the Primary Class.

1918

The Head Teacher was R. Hitchcox with J. Biddle Assistant in Charge & Lois Jones Assistant.

There were 20 in 1st year, 7 in Commercial, 2 in Junior Public and 2 in Senior Commercial.  Commercial Classes were formed to encourage parents to keep children at school.  Application was made to the Education Department for the formation of a High School Council, but this was refused.  On 12 November three earth tremors were felt.

1919

J. Biddle was Assistant in Charge.  The school was closed for some time due to the influenza epidemic.  On 14 March the school took part in the opening of RSL Club Rooms.  On 2 April there was a Welcome Home to Nurses and Soldiers.  The Hon. John Lewis presented the school with gymnasium apparatus.  On 19 July Peace Celebrations were held and Peace Medals distributed.  The school assembled to see Prime Minister Hughes pass through the Burra Railway Station on the way home from the Peace Conference and they were given a half-holiday.

1920

School opened on 19 January with 26 on the roll, but only 19 presented.  Later in the year the possibility of school closure was raised.  Mr James Reed presented a Model Ship to the school, the sale of which had raised a large sum for patriotic funds.  @3 March Sir Ross Smith and party arrived and a half-holiday was declared.  On 3 July the school closed for a fortnight in honour of the visit to SA of the Prince of Wales.

1921

Twenty-five students started the year.  On 6 April the school closed for the laying of the foundation stone of the Fallen Soldiers’ Memorial by Governor Sir Archibald Weigall. 1922

John Biddle was Assistant in Charge with Edna Grosvenor newly appointed and enrolment was 44.  An Old Scholars Assoc. was inaugurated.  On 21 September all classes went to the top of the hill to observe the solar eclipse.

Burra Primary School Committee held its Annual Meeting.  Elected: Chairman, M.G .Stockman and Secretary-Treasurer, D. Bannister.

Staff changes since Christmas:

Mrs Sladden, Miss Coventry and Mrs Sullivan have left, and Miss Reed, Miss Longford and Mr King have come.

There are seven teachers for seven classes.

Report for the past year:

Education Week passed off very well.  A sports day on the oval again replaced the annual picnic.  Visiting Day was held in conjunction with the High School and Arbor Day was held in winter.  The land between the Drill Hall and the School has at last been transferred to the Education Department and can now be developed as a playing area.  A sick bay has been built in the central part of the school and furnished by the Welfare Club.  All rooms now have efficient lighting for dull days.  Nothing has yet eventuated from a deputation and discussions regarding a crossing near the Town Hall.  At present two white lines make a crossing.  The school’s new roof was a godsend during this summer’s storms.  We are pushing for a Primary School toilet block on the east side of the school.  In the year sporting equipment has been purchased and a Christmas party was held in each class.  A school uniform has been selected with colours of grey and blue.

The Anzac Service at Burra on Sunday saw a smaller attendance this year.  Before the service the Pt Pirie Piper’s Band played at the Burra Hospital between 12 and 1 p.m. At the service at the Memorial 86 ex-service personnel were on parade led by Burra RSL President H. Cornelius.  Rev. R.S. Jenner gave the address, which is printed in just less than 2 columns.  The march went from the RSL Building up Commercial Street to Kangaroo Street and returned to the Memorial.  W. Kotz & M. Burt were pallbearers.  Wreaths were placed by H. Cornelius (for the RSL), T.R. Rogers (for the Air Force Assoc.), Mr Arnold Heinrich (for Demobilised Soldiers), W. Carpenter (for the Fathers’ Assoc.), Mayor E.T. Baulderstone (for the Town Council) and Chairman A.D. Radford (for the District Council).  Flag attendants were H.L. Riggs and J. Lockett.  There was an evening service at St Mary’s conducted by Rev. T. Drought and a collection for Legacy.  He also conducted an Anzac Service at Booborowie Hall on Sunday at 3 p.m. with a lesson read by local RSL President Barry Dinham.

Dr Steele was a driving force behind many of the changes.

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting

Mr Baulderstone welcomed an unusually large attendance of 55.  After he had introduced the items of business, he accepted the motion of Mr H.C. Cummins that competitive tennis be permissible (upon written application to the Corporation) between 1 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Sundays.  Mr H. Jennison spoke against it – being opposed in principle.  Mr F. Reed spoke in support – mainly citing the financial benefits to the club and through that to the town.  Mr Cummins also spoke in support and it was passed 28 to 18.

The Burra Amateur Swimming Club had been running the pool without a lease and the Mayor felt a lease desirable and so Council had one drawn up to run from 1962 to 1972.  Mr H. Cornelius moved the lease be granted.  This was seconded by T.G. Perry and carried.

A lease for the Burra North Playground was also carried.

Mr Baulderstone appealed for questions to be asked about the amalgamation of the Councils, rather than as street gossip.  He also challenged the view heard in the street that the town was going backwards.  He did not agree.  In the last few years there had been significant improvements at the racecourse, the showgrounds, playground, basketball courts, oval, small bore range, the Post office, the swimming pool and the hospital.  Some progress in the past year had been stifled through lack of money.  Council had sought £1,200 for the school road, but had got only £700.  Numerous bridges needed repair or renewal and again the Kangaroo Street Bridge needed £500, but the grant was for £300, leaving the Council to meet the gap, as it had to for the school road.  The cemetery is old and hard to maintain and permission is being sought to remove headstones.  Tree planting had been encouraged and it is unfortunate that some of the CWA Avenue on the approach to the town had to be removed by the Highways Department to re-form the road.  Burra was a beautiful town, but lends itself to further beautification, especially along the creek and around the pool area.  He had plans in mind to achieve this together with a Caravan Park area.  Street lighting is now quite satisfactory.  The attendance at pictures had declined, but it was still a paying proposition.  The £6,000 borrowed to renovate the Town Hall was covered by a special rate of 4d, but interest and repayments come from the pictures and the rate is merely security.  A bequest from the late Mrs Gare enabled the Town Hall stage to be modified and renovated.  The erratic dumping of rubbish at the mine is causing trouble and needs the Council’s attention in the coming year.

(To be continued.)

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting: Report continued from last week.

The Mayor said he felt bitter that after the 1961 ratepayers’ meeting rumours circulated that about £1,000 repaid to the Council by the Police Department had not been accounted for and ratepayers had been misled.  This money (£961-5-4) was received on 29 June 1960 and the amount of £493-13-7 due to the Pictures account and £467-12-1 to the general account and this appeared in the 1960-61 balance.  Neither he nor his Council had anything to hide and as Chairman of the Finance Committee for ten years he could answer any question put forward.

[Check this statement because if, as it seems to imply, the sum received was divided between the two accounts, it doesn’t quite add up.]

On Council amalgamation he reported two meetings with the District Council, but after discussion neither he nor his Council could see any major gains in rates or administration and therefore had decided against it.  He thanked Councillors and others including Mrs Baulderstone.

Mr S.J. Woollacott expressed dissatisfaction on the views about the amalgamation, stating he had spent many hours gathering the petition.

Cr Cornelius said he had originally been in favour, but after consultation could see no gains and changed his mind.  Mr Baulderstone said it had been ‘harped’ on for some years and although he had been in favour, he would not support it at this time.

Mr Woollacott also felt that more should be spent on premises owned by him considering the rates he paid.

[Check.  Presumably he meant of services like roads and footpaths adjacent to his properties.]

Mr Jennison commented on the unsightly sandbags used for the traffic island in Market Square.

The Mayor said it was hoped the Highways Department would do something towards implementing a plan that had been approved.

A.J. Bruce commented on the unfit state of the ladies’ conveniences near the Fire Station.  The Mayor agreed, but blamed the travelling public.  Mrs S. Scroop supported this view.

Mr J.G. Carpenter wanted the eradication of noxious weeds enforced.

Mr R. Jennison thought the Aberdeen Playground was in a sad state and Mr W.H. Lloyd (Committeeman) said the swings were in a sorry state, but some new equipment had been added.  There were also questions on cemetery upkeep.

Mr D.T. Jacka, in commenting on town progress, said 24 new homes had been built in Burra since the war.

Mr R.M. Reed asked about the whereabouts of funds donated for school crossing lights that had not eventuated.  The Mayor blamed the previous Town Clerk for inaction here [and for lack of action on cleaning water-tables.]

Dr Pitcher supported the Mayor, saying they had been led to believe there were complications involved, but recent discussions with the Highways Department suggested there would not be difficulties and the matter was being taken up again.  Mr Woollacott queried the competence of the Council in blaming the former Town Clerk for inadequacies and Mr Baulderstone said he would not stand again and so give the town a chance to install a capable Council.

Mr Jennison proposed a vote of thanks to the Mayor and hoped Mr Baulderstone would reconsider his decision regarding a further term as Mayor.

Jennison’s Tyre Service is 40 years old today.  Mr H.J.B. Jennison opened the business on 22 May 1922 as a tyre retailer and repairer.  Years ago tyres had to be ordered from overseas with waiting periods of six months.  Now the stock held can supply most needs for cars, tractors and farm machinery. 1931

The staff was E.A. Haese Headmaster, Beryl Dunstan, Olive Prior, Mabel Dunstan & H. Robinson.  On 7 March in a cricket match against Clare Alan Phillips, a left handed bowler took four wickets from four successive balls.  The Government was considering closing country high schools and on 21 July a deputation from Burra High School Council waited on the Minister of Education at Parliament House.

1932

There were no staff changes.  Enrolment was 57.  On 13 February a working bee was organised for improving the Mine Pool.  A path was cut to the edge of the pool and dressing sheds and a safety fence were later erected.  A cricket pitch was prepared for the girls.  On 26 April Lyall Turner broke his arm when he fell from his horse while riding to school.

(To be continued.)

Willalo Hall.  A recent meeting of the committee decided to install a lighting plant and to renovate and paint the exterior.  A social afternoon, which was held on 25 May to raise funds, resulted in £52.

Weather.  This week there were further general falls in which Burra recorded 118 points.

There was a heavy downpour on Saturday at 11 p.m. just as patrons left the pictures and rain reduced attendance at the RSL Ball on Friday night too.

Polio Vaccinations were given to 256 persons at the Burra Hospital on Friday.  (58 attended for their 1st, 155 for their 2nd and 43 for their 3rd.)

Burra Town Council

Burra Badminton Club was granted hire of the hall at 6/- with the club to remove and replace seats and make good any breakages, but the club will not take preference over any person or body desirous of hiring the hall on that night.

A letter is to be written to ETSA protesting over their use of the parklands at Burra North as a depot for poles, water carts etc.

Donors for school crossing lights will be reimbursed, as the Council will not be installing lights.

The SA Symphony Orchestra will be invited to play in the Burra Town Hall.

P.H. Quirke supplied information about plans for the district schools.

Booborowie: Funds have been approved for paving and fencing.

Black Springs: A scheme for connecting the new toilets to a septic system is in hand.  The Department of Mines is to provide a suitable windmill and overhead tank.

Burra: A detailed plan and estimates for a site-works scheme including paving, drainage and retaining wall is being prepared for the approval of funds.

85, 24, 19 June 1962, page 1

Burra Burra DC has appointed Messrs P.G. Rehn & Associates as Weed Inspectors for the district in an effort to strengthen weed control and elimination.

Burra Primary School will host a conference on Friday 22 June for 35 teachers from as far north as Yunta and Olary and south to Manoora as well as from the Pt Pirie District.  It will be directed by Mid-North Inspector Mr A.E. Wood.  Assistant Superintendent of Rural Schools Mr K. Polkinghorne will open it.  Tow Inspectors from Kenya will also attend.

Burra Racing Club.  After eleven years as President of the Club, Mr Gerald Gask will resign after the race meeting on 25 June.  He is resigning this and other industry positions to be eligible for election to the Adelaide Racing Club Committee.

Shoe Repairer needed in Burra.  Burra Traders feel it is necessary that an attempt be made to have a shoe repairer in Burra following the closure of the Shoe Repair Shop.  Mr P.J. Byrne of Byrne’s Shoe Store has been approached to try to locate a suitable man and the RSL is also being contacted.  It is understood a rental house could be made available to a person prepared to act in this capacity.

Hallett Golf Club was opened by President Mr C. Lucas on 5 May.  It is a 9 hole par 68 course and is playing particularly well.  There is a membership of 40 odd.

Burra High School.  A list of first enrolments is printed.  (1913)

[Personal interest: the list includes Aubrey O. Fuss and Eric Russell Fuss.]

The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1933

Staff was E.A. Haese Headmaster, Beryl Dunstan, Olive Prior and Mabel Dunstan.

B. Dunstan was transferred early in the year to be replaced by Marie Coghlan.  The enrolment was 52.

The school owned two typewriters.  On 7 June J. Gibbs addressed the school on the dried fruits industry.  On 6 September the school went to Balaklava for the combined sports using Hill’s bus, Thomas’s buckboard, Fuss’s lorry and Hutchinson’s and the Headmaster’s cars.  A mass meeting of parents was held to hear the report from a delegation to the Minister of Education concerning fees for High School students.  The school was divided into two ‘Houses’ for the first time.

1934

The staff was E.A. Haese, Doris Parry, Olive Prior and Beryl Waterhouse.  On 15 March it is noted there had been no homework for the previous two weeks because of the excessively hot weather.  Mr Haese was transferred to Peterborough and Mr T. Charlesworth was appointed from the start of second term.  On 13 July the Minister of Education Hon. S.W. Jefferies, accompanied by the district MP visited the school.  This was the first year that an end of year banquet was mentioned.

Annual Catholic Ball at the Burra Town Hall on Friday drew a fair crowd.  The sumptuous supper followed a somewhat unenjoyable period on the dance floor. 85, 25, 26 June 1962, page 8

Burra CWA held its AGM and Secretary Mrs F. Scroop reported a good year.

Membership was 80 and average attendance was 24.

In 1961 the new CWA rooms were opened and dedicated to a much loved pioneer of the CWA, Mrs Mary Warnes.  They were opened 30 June by Mrs Dolling OBE and the memorial plaque was unveiled by Mr Rex Warnes, the eldest son of the late Mrs Warnes. The CWA again catered for the race luncheon in September.  At the International Day Mr A.L. Clode presented on behalf of himself and family a very lovely polished table in memory of his late wife, who had been an active and good CWA worker.  Also the rooms received their new toilet floor covering and a large green and yellow blind for the western window.  Mrs Ralph Murray was the guest speaker.  CWA also catered for the race meeting on 21 March.  The branch catered for several weddings as well in the year.  Thanks are also due to the Trustees of the late Mrs Warnes for donating the land on which the branch is built and to Mr Jackman for drawing up the plans.

Revs T.G. Drought & Richard S. Jenner write calling on the Town Council to call a public meeting for the purpose of holding a Home and Family Week in Burra, as had been done elsewhere in SA.  The idea would be to promote Education in Marriage, Parenthood and Family Relationships.

Burra High School.  The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1937

W.E. Richards was Headmaster with L.A. Braddock, C.R. Isom, H. Simonds and Albert Swanson (Junior Teacher).  A Parents & Friends Association was established for the first time – 30 attended.  School uniforms were introduced.  There was a special assembly on 11 May to celebrate the Coronation of King George VI.  Mr Davidson relieved for two months during Miss Isom’s illness.  Burra hosted the Mid North Sports (which had to be postponed due to rain) and Burra won for only the second time.  (The previous win had been in 1929.)

1938

W.E. Richards was Headmaster with Lloyd Draysey, Marjorie Koehne, Marjory Edington and Beresford Pitman.  Enrolment was 68.  On 1 October a wireless and amplifier were presented to the school when the Minister of Education Hon. S. Jefferies and the Director of Education W.J. Adey attended.

[The money for the purchase had come from a combination of Departmental, School Council and Seaside Committee funds.]

Burra Bowling Club.  President S.J. Woollacott’s report.

The year has been a social and financial success.  There were 71 members last year and 69 this year.  The Blue Team won the pennant in the North Eastern Association, but in the Mid North Association both teams finished near the bottom.  The Easter Tournament was a great success.

[He continues after discussing the club games and tournaments.]

Three things now need our attention:

The present toilet facilities are an embarrassment and a completely new block is required.

The clubroom requires lining.

Some feel that external lighting is required.

The toilets would cost £400 to £500 and one Night Tournament would cover the £20 interest charge.

The death during the year of their oldest member Mr E. Finch was greatly regretted.  He had been a foundation member and a past patron.

[The report concludes with thanks to committee members and a number of individuals.]

Mr & Mrs F. Jefferies were farewelled at the Mt Bryan Memorial Hall recently when locals filled the place to capacity.  Mr T. Quinn chaired the meeting.  Mr & Mrs Jefferies had been strong supporters of the community for 40 to 50 years.  Mrs Jefferies had been President of the Mt Bryan CWA and of the [Warnes] Group.  Both Mr & Mrs Jefferies had supported the Hall.  Mr Jefferies had been a member of the Agricultural Bureau for 40 years and had served two terms as President, four as Vice-President, 12 years as Secretary and 10 years as a committeeman.  A presentation of an envelope containing notes and silver was made.  There were several items, including Rev. Bell playing the bones to the accompaniment of the piano.  Dancing and supper completed the evening.

Burra Burra DC Weed Control Program is getting under way.  The main aspects of the program following the appointment of Mr Ian Fry of P.G. Rehn & Associates as Weeds Officer are:

Control of roadside weeds

Control of weeds on Council property and on Crown Lands

Control of weeds on private property

Mr Fry is concerned to remove reservoirs of seed wherever they lie.  The first step is a circular that has been sent out to ratepayers asking them to list weeds on their property and what steps are normally taken to control them.  Mr Fry has begun a survey of the district.

Burra High School Jubilee Celebrations

Many old scholars will be returning for the planned events.  Celebrations begin at 12.55 p.m. on Thursday with a Back to School event.  Guides for old scholars will be H.J.B. Jennison, T. Perry, D. Field, M. Stockman, Mesdames M. Kellock, A. Benger & C. Neill.  A back to school class will be conducted by former headmaster Mr L. Carthew.  The Mayor will welcome visitors at the new tennis courts and Mr A.K. Statton, Superintendent of High Schools will address the assembly and unveil a plaque to open the area for future use.  Visits will be made to various areas of the school.  Speakers at the Birthday Celebrations will include Mr J.P. Biddle (Headmaster 1916-22), A.B. Riggs (Past President of the High School Council), K. Horsnell (Headmaster of the Primary School) and Mr J.W. Statton (First Headmaster).  Old scholars will present a concert in the evening at which speakers will include Dr D.M. Steele, H.J.B. Jennison and Brian Riggs (deputising for his father).  On Friday sporting contests between old and present scholars have been arranged.  The Golden Jubilee Ball will be held in the evening.

Obituary.  Well known Farrell Flat grazier Mr Douglas McCloud Short died at Burra 23 July.  He was born at Deniliquin NSW in 1890 and came to SA with his parents as a young boy and attended Morphett Vale School.  His father has taken up farming at Penfield and later on property now the Parafield Aerodrome.  As a young man he carted hay by horse wagon to chaff mills at Enfield and Port Adelaide.  He was a keen footballer; winning medals at Salisbury.  In 1915 he married Dulcie Neal of Salisbury and in the 1920s they came to Farrell Flat where he was a farmer and later a sheep dealer.  He is survived by his wife, two sons and three daughters: Jack & Ken (Farrell Flat), Melva Mrs Berryman (Adelaide), Nancy Mrs L. Simpson (Farrell Flat) and Joan Mrs K. Cooper (Farrell Flat).

Burra Jubilee Benevolent Society held its AGM.  Though there had been only one meeting for the year, the society has not been inactive.  We secured a wheelchair and now have two located in the Burra Hospital and available to anyone in the district who may need them (free). Burra High School.  The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1949

The staff was as for 1948 except that Rae T. Blesing replaced Alma Hill.  The enrolment was 66.

The Minister for Education Mr R. Rudall and the Director of Education Mr E. Mander-Jones visited the school and discussed the schoolyard, the building of new laboratories, painting of the school and the erection of new classrooms, but the Minister did not promise much.  On 29 April the students visited Adelaide by train (three of them for the first time).  Two new classrooms were opened by Mr [illegible] Walker, Inspector of Technical Schools.

1950

The staff were H.O. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John G. Deer, Rae F. Blesing, Ronald E. Walker and Nancy Hannaford.  Enrolments were 62.  Painters moved in to repaint the school in May.  New septic tank lavatories were installed.  A polio epidemic discouraged any indoor functions.  The Parents & Friends Assoc. presented an Encyclopaedia Britannica worth £93.

1951

The staff was the same as for 1950 except that Margaret Miller replaced Nancy Hannaford.  Enrolment was 65.  Two houses were bought for staff members by the Education Department.  Buses were complained about – one was very cold in winter and hot and dusty in summer.  The other was so small it had to make two journeys morning and night.

1952

Staff were H.O. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John Deer, Clare Milazzo, Ronald Walker and Helen Inglis.  Enrolment was 66.  The underground tank became polluted with dead rats and pigeon manure.  ‘It is believed that when the tanks were emptied recently six dead rats were removed and approximately 61 buckets of pigeon manure.’

Trees were planted in honour of old scholars who had made the supreme sacrifice.  Mr S. Woollacott presented the honour roll.

Burra High School.  Jubilee Celebrations

On Thursday there was an inspection of present classes at work, a ‘back to school’ class and the opening of the new sports area, followed by a concert at night in the Town Hall.

The Headmaster Mr R. Mueller greeted visitors and organised them into seven groups to visit the school.  [Guides as per list last week.]  The back-yo-school class assembled at the rear of the school and marched with the aid of drummer Norrie Baynes to the tennis courts where the teacher was Mr L. Carthew.  [The ‘pupils are listed.]

Five of those attending were from the 1913 class.  Others attending were Mr Joe Statton (the first headmaster), Mr Biddle, Mr Haese and Mr Murray Scriven; all former headmasters.  Mr L.W. Gare, one of the 1913 class, moved a vote of thanks.  From here there was a move to the new sports area and despite a bleak day with gusty winds and a shower or two, the crowd persisted.  [Official guests are listed.]  The Mayor Mr Baulderstone welcomed visitors and Mr Mueller also welcomed them to the school.  He particularly welcomed Mr Statton (Superintendent of High Schools).  Mr Jennison, in his speech as Chairman of the High School Council, said 100 old scholars had enlisted in WWII and eleven had died in that conflict.  The Parents & Friends, Association had raised £1,434-10-0 in the last five years, and today’s project, though not yet completed, would cost £1,200, split equally between the Parents & Friends’ Association and the Department.  It was only a week or two ago that the signal to proceed had come through and much was due to the efforts of Messrs Hirschausen Bros and D.A. Halliday that so much of it had already been accomplished.  Mr A.K. Statton then opened the new sports area.

Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club held its AGM.

Mr E. Orchard said the club was formed in lieu of the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee at the start of the 1960-61 season and affiliated with the SA Amateur Swimming Association for the 1961-62 season.  The last season was the club’s first serious season of competitive swimming and it was very satisfying to run out winners of the Eric Tilbrook shield in the triangular competition with Clare and Spalding.  This led to the formation recently of the Mid North Amateur Swimming Association of which Burra, Clare and Spalding are the foundation members.  In the past year a lease was obtained from the Burra Town Council and includes 60 ft beyond the present northern boundary to allow room for a barbecue and other entertainment facilities.  Over £200 was spent for cabinets for the PA system, stop watches and a filing cabinet.  In addition to inter-club competition, the two main functions are the Learn to Swim Campaign in the school holidays and the annual open carnival.  Recently the ladies have formed an auxiliary and so far they have added over £40 to funds.  Funds are needed to install a filtration and chlorination plant at an estimated cost of about £4,500 – fortunately subsidised pound for pound by the SA Government Tourist Bureau.

Fortunately we have a plentiful supply of cheap clear water, which needs to be changed more frequently in the hot weather, but this will push up costs as we exceed our water allowance and the filtration plant is needed, especially if Burra’s water supply should change to Murray water.  Thanks are due to Mr Bill Broad as caretaker, following the resignation of Dave Tanswell.  Mr Allan Ireland has had to resign as Secretary on being transferred to Jamestown.

Obituary.  Mrs Joe McIntyre formerly of Booborowie died at Port Pirie on 11 September.  She came to Booborowie in 1912 with her mother, two sisters and a brother, as one of the original settlers on the North Booborowie Estate when it was allotted for closer settlement and apart from a brief period lived in Booborowie for the rest of her life.  She married Mr Joe McIntyre and they moved to Yarcowie, but on her mother’s death Mr & Mrs McIntyre moved back to Booborowie and carried on the farm for a number of years.  She was known in Booborowie and district as Lil Jones and was a gifted pianist and vocalist, giving her time at many charitable functions during WWI and was organist for a number of years at the Catholic Church.  With failing health she went to live with her son and daughter in Port Pirie about twelve months ago.  She is survived by a son, Jock and daughter, Margaret as well as by two sisters and five grandchildren.

[Born Mary Lillian Jones 28 October 1886 Gladstone: died 11 September 1962 Solomontown.]

The Vice-Regal Visit of Sir Edric & Lady Bastyan went smoothly last Friday.  The hospital and school were visited and there was a Civic Ball in the evening.  In the afternoon Sir Edric visited the Mine while Lady Bastyan was entertained by the CWA.  Prior to the Ball, Sir Edric paid a visit to the RSL.  The Town Council entertained the visitors at the Kooringa Hotel for luncheon.  At the hospital the Governor met staff, the Board of Management and patients.  In the latter group were: Miss A. Simmons (who with her family owned land near Ulooloo gold fields), Mrs Ellery (who with her husband was a drover in Queensland), Mrs R. Steele, Mrs G. Dollman Jnr, Mrs R. Cullen, Miss S. Murphy (late of England), Mr L. Hirschausen, Mr Leo Wilson, Mr G.E. Phillips, Mr S. Sanderson (retired farmer of Gum Creek), Mr George Goodridge (of Mt Bryan), Mr B.H.K. Dunstan (grazier of Mt Bryan East, whose father was first postmaster at Mt Bryan) and Mr Gordon Fenton (Boer War veteran, fought in WWI and tried to enlist for WWII.  He rode in the Coronation Procession of Edward VI [sic: for VII] in 1903).

At the school the visitors saw classes at work, with the Governor visiting grades VII, VI, & V, while Lady Bastyan visited grades I to IV.  After that the school assembled in the Primary Yard together with the High School, where they were addressed by the Governor.  [His address is printed on page 5.]

From the school Lady Bastyan went to the CWA Room where she was net by the Mayoress Mrs Baulderstone.  Representatives of ladies’ organisations in the district attended.  The Governor meanwhile inspected the old Burra Mine area and afternoon tea followed at the Mayor’s Parlour.  The Governor’s visit to the RSL was brief, but he had the chance to meet representatives of the Burra, Farrell Flat, Booborowie and Hallett sub-branches.

Door takings at the Civic Ball amounted to £100.

The Koo-owie Clearing Sale is reported.

Remembrance Day was observed at the schools, where Mr B.A. Riggs represented the RSL and addressed the assembly and recited the ode.  There was an impressive ceremony at the War Memorial on Sunday when wreaths were laid by H. Cornelius for the RSL, T. Rogers for the AFA & RAN, the Mayor for the Town Council, Cr M. Kellock for the DC and V. Preiss for the Pensioners’ League.

Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd celebrated 75 years of sales at Burra.  They began on 25 November 1887 with their first monthly sale at the Bon Accord Yards.  25,000 sheep and 300 cattle were advertised; 15,000 of them from Paratoo.  At the time Liston, Shakes & Co. held sales monthly at Young’s Yards and Morris, Sandland & Barritt also operated at the Bon accord Yards.  On 16 November 1962 the combined agents will yard 22,000 sheep.  Now Elders have merged with Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. Ltd.  The record yarding for SA occurred when Elder’s yarded 44,000 sheep and 750 cattle on 27 September 1895.

Obituary.  Mr Keith Nivien [sic: for Vivian] Jones died at Jamestown Hospital 3 November.  He was born in Burra almost 38 years ago, the younger son of Mrs C.R. and the late Mr W.T. Jones and spent most of his life in Hallett.  He served for over two years in the AIF in WWII and on his discharge married Miss Irene Morris of Norwood.  They made their home at Hallett.  Keith took an interest in the town and district and was a member of the School Committee for many years and a prominent member of the Bowling Club and Football Club.  At his death he was engaged in his own business as a general contractor and wood merchant.  He is survived by a widow, daughter Heather, son Geoffrey, mother Mrs C.R. Jones of Hallett, brother Ray Jones of Melbourne and sister Mrs B. Smith of Booborowie North.

[Keith Vivian Jones born 14 November 1924 Redruth: died 2 November 1962 Jamestown, residence Hallett.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1962.

Generally there was a fair coverage of Burra and District.  The areas beyond Farrell Flat and Booborowie have generally not been noted.  Type-setting seems to have been rather better, with fewer inaccuracies.

Photographs became much more common, bur blocks were not prepared locally and so they are often a week or even more later than the story.

Page 1.

News – Local, but ranging from Riverton to Spalding.

Page 2.

Smaller advertisements especially sales, local government notices and local entertainment and social events.

Page 3.

A mixture of larger advertisements and overflow of page 2 type of material.  Sometimes room for a little news.

Pages 4-6.

Dominated by sports news mixed with a little other stuff.  More than half the page is large advertisements.

Page 7.

‘Cash Column’ advertisements – though this can wander to other pages.  Large advertisements and a little news.

Page 8.

Large advertisements and perhaps two columns of sport news or news of local clubs and associations.  The schools get considerable coverage, including those of Riverton and Spalding.

Sometimes there is an extra page or even two.

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 1

Weather.  December 1962 was the wettest on record with district falls ranging from 2 inches to 6 inches.  Burra had rain from the Sunday before Christmas to the following Sunday.  Christmas day was wet and cold and many people sat around fires.  Burra rain: 24th 18 points, 25th 0, 26th 124, 27th 30, 28th 64, 29th 151, 30th 0, 31st 58 points for a total of 445 points for the week and 456 for the month.  The previous wettest December was 426 points in 1929. The yearly total was 20.11 inches for 1962; about 2 inches above average.

This rain damaged wheat crops, where some grain gas shot in the heat.  Some bagged wheat has also shot and will need to be re-bagged.  Considerable reaping is yet to be done and damage there is yet to be assessed.  From Burra to Saddleworth farmers report bleaching of wheat, with one bag in nine lost on account of weight.  In the pastoral country the rain was welcomed.  Some areas had not had significant rain for three or four years.  Falls to the 31 December: Oakbank 525 points, Pine Valley 411, Kia Ora 340, Poonunda 584, Oakvale 561, Woolgangi 480 and Koomooloo 402.  Practically all dams are full.  [Photo of the St Just Street Ford in flood.]

The merry-go-round did not operate in the afternoon due to rain.  The Rural Youth Dance did well and raised £26 for Rally Funds this year.

Floods.  The creek through West Ward overflowed twice during the December rains.  On 28 December following 133 points in 20 minutes and secondly on 30 December when 58 points fell in 30 minutes.  Debris from the first flood and trees growing in the creek made the second flooding worse.  Water ran down Commercial Street 6 inches deep and then flowed down the full width of Thames Street.  Some damage was done to businesses in Commercial Street.

Obituary.  Harold Vivian Lord was the eldest son of the late Mr & Mrs J.V. Lord and was born at Burra in 1888.  He spent his early life at the Barrier in the early days of prospecting and mining at Thackaringa, Silverton, Daydream, Broken Hill and Pinnacles.  He lived on Silverdale, a pastoral property owned by his father, which was later incorporated into ‘Thackaringa’ Station, a family holding still occupied by his nephews.  He was educated at Prince Alfred College and the SA School of Mines in wool-classing.  After a short while at his father’s southern home at Sandergrove, he took over management of Pine Valley Station east of Burra and actively ran this property for forty years and at his death was the owner within the interests of J.V. Lord & Sons.  He introduced deep boring to the east country, sinking Cockatoo Bore to 680 ft.  As partner in J.V. Lord & Sons he had an interest too in Kalkaroo, Oakvale, Lord’s Well and Balah and was consultant for his sister’s property Eureka NSW and a director of the family’s pastoral companies at Yardea in the northwest and Tresant in the South East of SA.

[Died 1 December 1962 Unley Park.  The birth does not appear on SA Births CD.]

Burra High School Speech Night and 50th Annual Report.

In the last year the school celebrated it Golden Jubilee, had a Vice-Regal Visit and was host for the combined High Schools Sports Day.

The year opened with an enrolment of 146: made up of 77 boys and 69 girls and we expect it to be 160 in 1963.  If staff permits we will make a second 1st Year Class.  The only staffing changes in 1962 were the resignation of Junior Teacher Kym Horsnell and the arrival of J. Murphy from England.  Now we say farewell to Mr Sladden and Mr Hillman; the former to Gawler and the latter to Henley High.

Religious Instruction continues to run smoothly.

Last year I reported the Education Department agreed to rent the area southwest of the school and to make available a subsidy and to grant £135 for initial ground formation.  This has allowed the completion of two tennis courts (also two basketball courts) and two half cricket pitches in the last year and the grassing of the area for athletics, football and softball, together with a water reticulation system.  Backstops are now planned for the courts at the front of the school.

The Parents & Friends’ Association has continued its good work and catered very well at the school’s sports day and also the combined schools’ sports, when they catered for 300 adults and 700 students.  £100 was raised. At the Jubilee Ball the gross takings were £160.  The Jubilee Birthday Party was also organised.  The Jubilee ‘Statton’ playing area will be a memorial to their effort to mark the school’s 50th birthday.

Improvements this year have concentrated on improving the playing facilities.  56 girls can now be absorbed in basketball at a time, compared with 14 previously.  Cricket and tennis facilities have also increased.  On Arbor Day trees were planted. This year the asphalt paving area was resurfaced, a gas stove installed and two new £4,000 buses for the Hallett & Hanson runs arrived.  A new £5,000 laboratory is to be commenced in January 1963.

RSL Annual Report 1962

Attendance has been just enough to keep the branch open.  During the year two sets of indoor bowls were procured with money left by the estate of the late Mrs Sara Gare, which made for many happy evenings for the Ladies’ Auxiliary.  On Anzac Day the march and parade was led by the Port Pirie Pipers’ Band and the evening service was held in St Mary’s.  Eighteen members attended.  Remembrance Day was observed with the usual service at the Memorial in Market Square.  Held on a Sunday when a number of members were absent, it drew only sixteen of them.  The Ministers’ Fraternal did not reply to the invitation this time and the President read Mr Bean’s Requiem instead.  The annual ball was successful thanks to the Ladies’ auxiliary in particular.  Forty-six members attended the annual dinner, with visitors also from headquarters, Saddleworth, Jamestown, Farrell Flat and Hallett.  It was very successful from a social point of view.  The Christmas party was a small event, but most enjoyable.   The Burra RSL continues to support two Legacy wards – largely from money from bottles collected by people of the district.  The Governor, Sir Edric Bastyan paid a visit on 9 November and shook hands with each of the approximately 60 members present.

Burra Mine.  Vandals have continued to move survey pegs at the Mine and so disrupt the Mines Department research at the site and causing extra cost. The test work is continuing.  Equipment using induced polarisation has been used.  Electrical pulses are polarised by ore pockets and the degree of polarisation can indicate the metals present.  Drilling is also continuing, though problem with sand falls and the need to cement sections have delayed this work.

Obituary.  Rev. Albert Bell, Secretary of the Home Mission Department.

A photo in the Home Mission Office taken thirty years ago shows a Federal Inland Mission vehicle in front of Parliament House Canberra and Albert Bell is pointing to the legend on the bonnet of the Didge Truck – ‘Derby to Sydney via the Granites’.  One is not surprised that Rev. Albert Bell should have been the first to cross Australia between those two points in a motor vehicle.  He was born at Hetton Down, County Durham, UK, on 29 December 1896 and migrated to WA where he entered the service of the Methodist Church.  The WA Home Mission Department appointed him a missioner to Kojonup in the far South East agricultural and pastoral area of WA in 1928.  The mission had only been established in the north of WA for three years when Rev. Bell volunteered to go there in 1930 and was appointed to the Kimberley Patrol.  He had an area of nearly 100,000 square miles and was at Derby in ‘the wet’ and at Wyndham in ‘the dry’.  At Wyndham he established a debating society with an average attendance of 100 and basketball and athletic clubs flourished under his infectious enthusiasm.  In eight years Rev. Bell made the Methodist Mission there widely known and respected.  He then came south in 1938 and married Ivison Holliday of Victor Harbor on 19 February 1938 and they enjoyed a wonderful partnership for twenty-five years and one day.  There was a honeymoon voyage to England in the sailing ship Pommern via Cape Horn.  On returning to Australia he became pastor to the Port Adelaide Central Methodist Mission and assistant to the late Rev. A.D. McCutcheon for eleven years.  In 1948 he applied for ministerial status and was ordained with status retrospective to 1938.  From 1950 he served circuits at Angaston, Red Hill and Hallett-Terowie, where he was beginning his fifth year.  He was an artilleryman in the Imperial Forces in WWI and spent ten months as a POW.  He was a member of the RSL and Treasurer of the Hallett Sub-branch, a Vice-President of the Cricket Club and Chaplain to the local Lodge of Freemasons, a member of the Hallett Institute and of the Bowling Club.  He was a forthright preacher whose sermons were original and arresting.

[Born 29 December 1896 Hetton Down, Co. Durham, UK: died 20 February 1963, Hallett.]

Koonoona Stud celebrates its centenary with its annual Field Day on Thursday. It was founded by Hon. Walter Duffield and Mr T.S. Porter with 50 selected ewes from ‘Hill River’ and rams from Mount Crawford.  It remained in the same ownership till 1875 when Mr Porter retired and was replaced by Col. F. Makin.  When Mr Duffield died in 1880 the trustees of the estate administered the property till 1918, when it was sold to the beneficiaries and the then manager, Mr W.G .Hawkes.  The name was changed then to Koonoona Proprietors.  Mr Hawkes retired in 1930 and his son, Mr Glen Hawkes, acquired an interest as Managing Director, which position he held till his death in 1961.  The present Managing Director is Mr R.K. Pearse, who first came to Koonoona in 1938 as a jackeroo and returned as manager in 1952.  The present overseer is Mr R. Osborne.  The first Field Day (then called an Inspection Day) was held in 1946.  Koonoona was the first SA stud to fly rams to the Sydney Sheep Show and the first SA stud to sell a ram in Sydney for 1,000 guineas.  Since 1910 it has been a closed stud, producing a particularly even type of sheep that have proved their worth in all states and New Zealand with a reputation for heavy wool cutting ability.  It comprises 22,600 acres and presently carries 16,000 sheep.

Burra Primary School Committee

After 14 years on the committee and 11 as chairman, Mr Stockman felt he should hand on to someone else.  Elected: Chairman D.H. Field and Secretary-Treasurer, D.F. Bannister.

Retiring Chairman, M.G. Stockman, presented the 88th report.

The staff position changed with the transfer of Mr King.  Two replacement teachers, Mr Pope and Miss Ronan gave us the full staff for a Class III school and allowed the Head Teacher Mr Horsnell the freedom to do his administrative duties.  The highlight of the year was the Vice-Regal visit of Sir Edric and Lady Bastyan.  The sports day at the oval was very successful.  Visiting Day drew many parents and friends.  Arbor Day was held at the beginning of winter and a variety of trees were planted.  We have not been able to get a school crossing sign or flashing lights, as the Highways Department will not sanction these when the school is not adjacent to the road.  The most they will sanction is the NSC sign and red flags and these were duly erected by the Town Council.  We are keeping the matter in mind if the Road Traffic Act is changed.  Tenders should soon be called for a new block of lavatories for Primary School use, for the asphalting of the balance of the yard on the eastern side, the fencing of the new Drill Hall block, which has been added to the playing area and a retaining wall and backstop for the tennis courts. Membership was 54 and average attendance 29.  During the year various items of sporting equipment were bought and a reading laboratory and other teaching aids and a cupboard and bed for the sick bay.

The report on the year noted the near completion of the Jubilee Sports Area.  The Association provided luncheon at the Sports Day at the racecourse for the first time.  It was also associated with the Inter High School Sports and the Jubilee Celebrations.  The annual High School Ball this year took £159-11-3.  £500 was donated to the Jubilee Committee for the Sports Area and this attracted a Departmental subsidy.  Thanks go to W. Mr & Mrs Jim Prior of Hallett celebrated their Golden Wedding with a dinner for 150 people at the Hallett institute on Saturday 6 April.  In 1918 Jim married Miss Ruby Brown at Broken Hill at the first motorised wedding there.  [If this was their golden wedding they should have been married in 1913!]  The couple moved to SA when their daughter Elva was three weeks old.  In the 1920s Jim, known as ‘Nigger’ played football and cricket for Hallett and more recently he was runner-up in the singles bowls championship.  He has always been a strong supporter of the athletics clubs in the district.  Mr Pryor thanked the many friends he had in the district over 46 years there [suggesting he arrived in 1917.]  The cake for the occasion was made by daughter Elva, Mrs Backshall of Mt Barker WA.  Joyce, Mrs L.H. Aldridge and her husband were also present from WA.  [Details of this event extend for 2 columns with 2 photographs: one of the couple and one of Mr A.G. Owen-Smyth proposing a toast.]

Mr E.A. (Curly) Wohling & Mrs Wohling are leaving Burra today after Mr Wohling has spent 64 years in the town, while Mrs Wohling was born here 73 years ago.  They will live with their son Ken and his wife Pat at Maylands.  Mr Wohling was born at She-Oak Log 80 years ago and was educated at Lindley (between Morgan and Florieton) and came to Burra at the age of 16 when he began to work on Redcliffe Station.  This was then owned by Messrs Scott & Son and from there he went to Braefoot owned by Mr Henry Scott.  After a spell of several years in Victoria he returned to Braefoot where a Mr Hill had taken over.  His work comprised shearing, farming, blacksmithing and sheep work etc.  His sporting interests included football, cricket and cycling.  Fifty-three years ago he married Miss Laura Lihou and they have lived in Burra ever since.  Mr Wohling commenced work as a barman at the Burra Hotel when Mr Carl Heinrich was the proprietor and has seen many changes there over 38 years.  When Mr Tom and Miss E.A. Scovell took over the Commercial Hotel Mr Wohling went there for 13 years before retiring.  Mr Wohling recalled riding against the cyclists Jack Richards (the first man to sell cars in Burra), Syd Grivell, Charlie Waldie [sic: Wardle?], ‘Pop’ Gardner, Albert & Bill Lomman (still riding), Harry & Oliver Baynes, Bill Bartel, Jim Bradley, J.D. ‘Duncan’ Kelly, Tommy Hogart and Alf & Albert McWaters.  His best distance was the half mile and most races were at Victoria Park.  He recalls playing football when Aberdeen and Kooringa played in snow and Aberdeen 0.5 defeated Kooringa 0.3.  When working at Woolgangi and Bungunya he would ride his bike into Burra on Saturday morning to play football and return on Sunday.

Burra High School.  Work has begun on a new £5,500 laboratory at the school and a new classroom.  Work should be completed within six weeks, though the plumbing requirements may delay opening for a time.  The new classroom promised for 1964 is ahead of schedule.  The old small laboratory is due for conversion to a staff room.  The Jubilee Plaque will be mounted on a cairn of local slag stone at the entrance to the new tennis courts on the Statton Sports Area.

Anzac Services and parades were held at Burra, Riverton, Saddleworth, Booborowie and Hallett on Sunday.  The weather at Burra was perfect for the March and Service at the Memorial in Market Square at which Rev. T.G. Drought and Rev. R.S. Jenner officiated.  Thirty-six members of the local RSL took part in the march, led by the Port Pirie Pipers’ Band, which also played at the Burra Hospital from 1-2 p.m.  Wreaths were laid by Vice-President H. Cornelius for the RSL, President T.R. Rogers for the Air Force Association,  A.C. Heinrich for Demobilised Soldiers, E.T. Baulderstone for the Town Council and T.G. Perry as District Clerk for the DC.  The public attendance was poor.

Weather.  General rains throughout the district have delivered 2-3 inches in the past week.  242 points were recorded in Burra and 384 for May.  World’s End received 331 for May and just over 2 inches for the week.  The ground is now wet and rain causes run-off.  Porter’s Lagoon was filling strongly on Sunday and all dams in the area are full.  Farmers need two or three weeks of fine weather now for weed control and seeding.  Star thistles are a problem in fallow and clover is growing rapidly.  In sheep fly strike is widespread.

Burra Silo.  Work on the new silo at the railway station was begun just after Easter and is progressing satisfactorily.

The Methodist Executive Committee of Laymen, led by H.J.B. Jennison, drew 350 people to the Church Family Dinner to hear about the Circuit Planned Giving Program.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone chaired the meeting.  Mr S.J. Woollacott told the history of Methodism in the community.  Services were held first here in 1847 and few communities in SA could boast almost 120 years of service to the community.  Other speakers were H.J.B. Jennison, F.W. Aitken and M.R. Humphrys.  The final speaker was Rev. R.S. Jenner.

Obituary.  Ben Dunstan of Mt Bryan East died at Burra Hospital 3 June aged 87.  He had been President of the Mt Bryan Agricultural Bureau for many years and was a life member.  He was also President of the Mt Bryan East Fire Fighting Association; a member of the Oddfellows and Masonic Lodges and of the Liberal and Country League, and was very interested in politics.  He was the first scholar (of 7) enrolled at the Mt Bryan East School when it opened in 1885 under the tuition of Mr Whittington.  His knowledge of the early days of the district’s settlement was second to none.  In his youth he was a keen cricketer.  He had charge of the Mt Bryan East Post Office till it closed a few years ago.  His wife died in 1957.  The only children were Mr Jack Dunstan of Mylor and Mr Hugh Dunstan of Whyte Yarcowie.  There is one granddaughter.  [Benjamin Hugh Knuckey Dunstan born 28 August 1875 Redruth: died 3 June 1963 Burra, residence Mt Bryan East.]

Rev. Father Laurence Joseph Quinn aged 31 was ordained on Saturday at St Joseph’s in Burra by the Bishop of Pt Pirie, the Most Rev. Dr Bryan Gallagher.  It is the first ordination in Burra after 81 years of St Joseph’s existence.  About 250 attended the two hour service at 9.30 a.m. and 140 attended a reception afterwards in the RSL Hall. Father Quinn is the second son of Mr & Mrs J.T. Quinn of Mt Bryan.  On Sunday Fr Quinn offered his first Mass and Benediction to a congregation of about 320 members of the parish.  Before entering the seminary six and a half years ago Father Quinn studied Latin to matriculation standard in one year (instead of the usual four).  He was tutored in this by Fr Hughes.

The Grand Elephant Race

Messrs Bence and Flaherty raced elephants from Ashton’s Circus down Commercial Street at 5.15 p.m. on Tuesday.  The aim was to raise funds for new toilets at the oval.  Sahib Bence drew Jahore and Sahib Flaherty drew Jumbo.  There was a preliminary canter from Jennison’s Garage to the Post Office, where the race proper began.  In the run back to the garage Jumbo looked like an easy winner at first, but Sahib Bence drew big Jahore to the outside and with more courage than control went on to win by four lengths.  Sahib Bence’s descent over Jahore’s head and down its trunk was most undignified, but can be excused on the grounds of youthful exuberance and the flush of victory.  The collection for the event amounted to £23-12-0.

Weather.  Rain for the week fell practically every day and for Burra totalled 205 points.  The Burra Creek ran strongly and deposited quite a load of rubbish at the Pig and Whistle Crossing.  The Young Street Ford was closed, but a car was caught in the water and came to rest against the concrete pillar of the old footbridge.  The occupants of the car climbed to the roof and awaited help.  Mr S. Irlam later towed it out of the creek.  Mr R. Sandercock’s garage took off in Saturday afternoon’s strong wind.  The wind lifted it neatly, leaving Mrs Sandercock’s car standing in the open without damage.

Other falls for the week included 226 points at Mt Bryan, 195 at Booborowie and 317 at Farrell Flat.

Floodwaters from the property of D.H. Adams and properties to the west caused a large volume of water to cross the bitumen road about 150 yards north of Mr Adam’s home on Saturday evening.  A large bank of sand and silt was deposited across the road.  Mr Adams and Mr Colin Pfitzner hauled a number of cars out with a tractor until Constable P. Logan closed the road.  At 9 a.m. Sunday the Council grader cleared the obstruction and the road, though still flooded, was re-opened.  Floodwaters also crossed the road from Coghill Creek near the town where two and a half feet of water stopped traffic for many hours.  Other district roads have been damaged.
