Burra Town Council

Council intends to reclaim a portion of the cemetery.

For some time now the question of reclaiming a portion of the cemetery has been debated by Council.  Although the period of the leases of 99 years has expired on the majority of blocks in the central portion of the cemetery, certain legal questions needed to be checked and permission obtained from the attorney General.  This has now been completed and Council is now prepared to clear and reclaim this part of the cemetery.  This is required because at the average rate of burials the cemetery will be filled in two or three years.  Any person holding a block with an unexpired lease in this area is asked to contact the Town Clerk, Mr Holness – the block numbers to be cleared are listed elsewhere in this paper.  As well as making more blocks available, this move will also make the area clean and tidy.

[Page 2 had a list of block numbers involved: 542 to 699, 704 to 753 and 758 to 1,271.]

Burra Wheat Silo.  After difficult work due to cold, wet and windy conditions during construction the concrete gang completed their job last Thursday.  Other gangs will now complete the roofing, windows, machinery etc.

M & BHA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs H. Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Odgers & Bannister; Secretary, Mrs McGee; Assistant Secretary, Mrs R. Thamm and Treasurer, Mrs Barry.

The report showed an average attendance at meetings of 12.  Clinic attendance was 513 for an average of 43 per month.  Many thanks to the CWA for agreeing to sell the M & BHA part of their land on which a temporary Housing trust home will be placed and established as a Clinic Centre and meeting room.  To help finance the new room a street stall in April raised £32.  [This building later became a private home and was eventually demolished in 2008.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM 17 July and elected: Patron, Guy Dollman; President, D. Jacka; Vice-Presidents, Messrs J.B. Topsfield & C. Leslie Phillips; Secretary, Mr Darrell Field, Treasurer, B. Riggs and Greens Manager, W.G. Terry.

Plans for the immediate future include lighting the two northern greens (with cost to be considered) and the lining of the men’s section of the clubhouse with Gyprock.  The President reported a very active year in which Burra Gold won the pennant in the Mid North Association and the Blue team were runners-up in the North Eastern association.  Associate Members were a tower of strength and donated £250 to the improvement debenture fund and gave great help in the Easter Tournament.  Membership was 61 plus 12 night members.  The debenture scheme to finance a new toilet block was oversubscribed.  General finances are sound.

Burra CWA had Mrs Hallion of Bumbunga, President and Secretary of the Warnes Group, as speaker for its July meeting. Burra Hospital.  86th Annual Report of the Chairman to 30 June 1963.

The hospital is in a sound financial position.

The overdraft has been reduced from £5,369 at 30 June 1960 to the present figure of £2,292.  There is £2,595 in our Maintenance Reserve and £3,019 in the Donations Account and £418 in the Building Fund.  The year’s operations had a surplus of £1,791.  The improvement has been due to a greater number of patients and an increase in the number of patients in a Hospital Benefits Fund, which has greatly reduced bad debts.  The Board has plans to build four new private rooms, a duty room and a secretary’s office.  A master plan for future improvements is being worked out.  Daily patient numbers rose from average 10.1 in 1962-63 to 14.9.  [Sic: but presumably this must be to 14.9 in 1962-63.]  Outpatients rose from 430 to 454.  Births fell to 59.

[Acknowledgement was given to the Women’s Auxiliary and the Fund Raising Committee.]

Last year the cropping program raised £583.  Seasonal conditions have not permitted any seeding this year.  Improvements this year have been new cupboards, a new electric bell system, new mattresses, blankets and chairs and a range of new fittings and furnishings.  The surrounds were also improved.  Matron Fyfe and Secretary H.L. Foote continue to offer excellent and efficient service, as do the rest of the staff.  Over 900 polio injections were given in the year.

E.W. Dunhill

Andrew King & Heather Bellman at Chamberlain Field Day at Saddleworth.

Mr E.W. Dunhill (89) has completed 72 years of service as a lay preacher – a record unequalled in the Methodist Church in Australia.  Mr Dunhill was born at Kersbrook in SA and in his early life went to WA.  He married there in 1908 and returned to SA in 1909, taking up residence in Burra in 1915.  He carried on business as a blacksmith for 65 years until he was 83.  He took his first church service at the age of 16 years 11 months.  He was the first person in Australia to hold a certificate recognising 60 years service as a lay preacher.  He was also active in Sunday school work for many years and was Sunday School Superintendent for 37 years.

Burra & District Swimming Club.  The President’s Annual Report by E. Orchard reveals a very successful season for 1962-63.  Burra retained the Eric Tilbrook Shield.  The annual club carnival in February attracted record entries.  Vacation Swimming Classes were very popular.  With the need to install filtration plant fees were raised and takings for the year reached £485.  There is a credit balance of £500. Contractors should start work within two weeks and be finished by the start of the 1963-64 season.  During the year Secretary David Clarkson was transferred to Eudunda and was replaced by Mr Roger Jenkins.

Burra Show

There were a record number of entries at 2,600 and the show was a great success despite the day starting out with light showers and a cold south-easterly wind.  Conditions improved later.  The gate takings were £190 and about 2,800 attended.  The Central Command Band attended and was much appreciated.  The British Trade Commissioner visited and was impressed by the standard generally and by that of the cooking in particular.

The Flower Section was outstanding this year.

Horses in Action were the centre of keen competition and of much interest; as usual.

Sideshows were better this year with several tents new to the area.  The small merry-go-round was popular with tiny tots and the bucking horses with the older ones.

Rural Youth Club had a very original collection of noxious weeds.

Industrial displays may have been down in numbers, but were comprehensive and up-to-date.

President Mr Rex Warnes welcomed visitors and the Band and called on Brigadier W.W. Wearne to open the show.

Results for Art & Photography, Birds, Cattle, Cookery & Dogs are printed, with the other sections to follow in the next issue.

Burra Hospital

Plans for a new private room wing have been drawn up and examined by the Board last week.  The plans are for four private rooms, matron’s office and a secretary-manager’s office.  The building would make the hospital more compact and easier to run.  The cost of the new proposal is estimated at £15,000.  Government subsidy is available on a two for one basis and an appeal has been launched to raise the £5,000 needed.  It would be a continuation of the present Women’s Ward, extending out and beyond the men’s yard, with a verandah.  It would have an entrance hall between it and the Women’s Ward.  It would harmonise aesthetically with the Women’s Ward and would improve the overall ‘semmetry’ [sic] of the hospital with a balanced frontage and common entrance for visitors.

Donations to date: £372-10-0.

The Masonic Lodge installed Bro. J.W. Riggs as Worshipful Master of the Kooringa Masonic Lodge on Wednesday 23 October.  A ball followed in Burra Town Hall.

St Mary’s Church was packed on Sunday for services conducted by Bishop the Rt Rev. Donald Redding, who had been Rector in Burra from 1933-39.  The service began with the dedication of two new stained glass windows given by Lady Swift and Mr Andrew Tennant in memory of their mother the late Mrs Margaret Barr Tennant.  Those windows are in the church porch.  Sir Brian Swift and his daughter Mrs Andrew Tennant and Mr & Mrs John Barker were the donors of windows in the porch.  Mr Andrew Tennant unveiled the windows as the Bishop dedicated them.  The service continued after all had returned to their seats and twenty-four candidates from Burra, Booborowie, Mt Bryan, Hallett and Farrell Flat were confirmed.  A splendid supper in the church hall allowed many old acquaintances to be renewed with the Bishop.  The portion in red needs clarification

Characteristics of the paper for 1963

This year was something of a mixed bag.  Sometimes it seems reasonably comprehensive, but at other times it is rather thin on local news.  Almost all the news is carried on page 1 except for sports results, which dominate the rest of the paper.  Pictures appear regularly, but as the blocks were not made locally, the pictures are at least a week later than the events.

Page 1

News: ranging from Hallett-Terowie to Tiverton-Tarlee.

Pages 2 & 3

Smaller advertisements dominate – sales, public notices, coming events, entertainment, films, tenders and smaller business advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by larger advertisements – mostly local.

News is dominated by sports and occupies perhaps two of the seven columns.

Somewhere in the mix, but wandering from page to page, is a ‘Cash Column’ of small advertisements similar to classified ads.

Note: The volume numbers are chaotic.

Volume 86 runs from 8 January to 26 February

The issue on 5 March is Volume 37

Volume 86 then continues from 12 March to 23 July

It is followed by Volume 80 from 30 July to 1 October

Volume 85 runs from 8 October to the end of the year.

This in turn creates chaos with the numbering of issues.

Burra Carols by Candlelight raised £120 for Freedom From Hunger.  It was held at the War Memorial Oval on 22 December.  Attendance was c. 750.  5AD Radio compere Charles Norton was MC and R.V. Mueller led the Burra & District Choral Society.  After 9.30 p.m. gusty winds and a few spots of rain slightly marred the otherwise very successful occasion.  The Mayor Mr Baulderstone donated the soft drinks’ profit to the cause and he also delivered his Christmas message.  Mrs Odgers of the Catholic Church suggested the idea and the Methodist and Anglican Churches eagerly responded.  Father Hughes, Rector Drought and Rev. Jenner worked together on the planning committee.  The Mayor made the point that this coming together of Catholic and Protestant effort was a significant point in the town’s history.  The combined choir had been practising for some weeks under the High School Headmaster Mr Mueller.

Mr E.T. Baulderstone has a bumper crop of onions this year in his Quarry Street garden.  On an area of just less than a square chain he produced three tons, equivalent to 30 tons per acre, when 20 tons per acre is considered a good rate.

Burra Hospital Building Appeal has reached £5,182-13-8.

Burra Youth Club camp at the Gorge on Sunday had to cope with a temperature of 108°F and a similar temperature was reached on Monday.

Weather.  The year ended with only 115 points for the last three months, to make it the driest final quarter for 75 years.

Photo.  SA Police Band and Mounted Cadre in a procession in Commercial Street to Memorial Oval on 6 December for Sports Day to raise funds for a new toilet block and to turf the oval.

Burra High School held its Speech Night in the Burra Town Hall on 17 December.  Headmaster R. Mueller delivered his annual report.

The enrolment in January was 151, up 7 on 1962.  First Year numbers were lower, but retention was better in the upper years.  First Year 53, Second Year 56, Intermediate 26 and Leaving 16.  In 1965 c. 170 are expected – an increase due to an anticipated increase in Intermediate to 40.  Numbers are expected to plateau briefly and then decline slightly in 1966.  In 1963 Mr J. Sladden and Mr R. Hillman were transferred and in 1964 Mr T. O’Connor came from Salisbury High and Mr J. Ayliffe and Miss M. Callier came from Teachers’ College.  Mr W. Standing and Miss B. Hogan were appointed Junior Teachers.  During the year Mrs Bogisch resigned and was replaced by Mrs Aistrope from Riverton to handle Home Science.  At the end of this year Miss Lawes and Mr McElroy will be transferred and Junior Teachers Barbara Hogan and Bill Standing will attend Teachers’ College in 1964.

Rev. Jenner and his wife are also leaving and we thank them for taking 90 students each week for Religious Instruction.  Rector Drought and Father Hughes are also thanked.

The High School Council has kept the machinery going without having a particularly busy year.

The Parents & Friends’ Association continues to be efficiently run and the completion of the sports area in front of the school is the culmination of one of their major projects.

In sports the outstanding event of the year was the winning of the Open Shield (the Ohlmeyer Shield) at the Mid North Combined High schools Sports Day.  Burra also got the highest points for the Handicap Shield, but the rules prevent the holding of both shields in the same year.

A school excursion of over 300 miles was in part a reward for this effort.  Places visited included Para and Warren Reservoirs, Mt Crawford Pine Forest, Mannum, Murray Bridge and Mt Lofty.

In February the whole school travelled by train to see the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh.  Other successful occasions were the Annual Swimming Carnival, Sports Day, Prefects’ Induction, Arbor Day and Visiting Day.

The Intermediate and Leaving classes travelled to Adelaide and Clare to see performances of plays they were studying.  Leaving Teaching Scholarships were awarded to:

Peter Benger	Barry Carpenter	Kerry Costello

Raelene Hirschausen	Claire Kellock	Margaret Murphy

Pam Zanker

For the second year the school magazine has been printed out of the school.

In 1962 134 subjects were passed in the Intermediate.  (The highest number previously had been 111.)  Leaving passes were the second highest ever.  Keith Neill had the best Leaving results with six subjects and Barbara Hogan with five.  In Intermediate Peter Benger passed 8 subjects and was awarded the A.B .Riggs Prize and Patricia Ryan passed seven subjects.

[Mr Mueller then went on to discuss the non-Publicly Examined Subjects to be offered in 2nd and 3rd Year and their internal assessment.  He thought the Intermediate would fall into disuse with the new Leaving and Matriculation Exams to come into operation from 1966.]

Burra is not going to have these new courses in 1964, but will do so in the next few years.

In 1958 the enrolment was 70 and next year we expect 170.  This has meant a number of new buildings.  In the last year a modern laboratory and a classroom were added.  There are now six classrooms, Home Science and Woodwork Centres, a Science Laboratory, a Typing room and an assembly hall.  The old laboratory will soon be converted to a staff room.  The area around the new rooms is yet to be paved.  The toilets have been enlarged and improved.  The old tennis courts have been extended, resurfaced and fenced this year.  A fence was also erected around the lawn and 80ft of seating was provided.  The school now has four basketball courts instead of one, four tennis courts instead of two and two new practice cricket pitches.  The graded area has been sown and watered and has greatly improved facilities for athletics training, softball and football in the future.

New buses have been provided for the students.  The increase in numbers has seen the appointment of more specialist teachers and a sound range of subjects and Leaving subjects no longer have to be combined with other classes as in the past.

Burra Silos

The new wheat silo at Burra Railway Station took its first grain on 9 December 1963 and filled within seven days.  Heavy intakes began on 13 December and by the 20th the capacity of 100,000 bushels had been reached.  [Daily intake figures are printed.]  Since then there has been direct loading via the conveyor to the rail trucks, which elevates the grain at 70 tons per hour.  Trucks carrying 40 tons can be loaded in 15 minutes.  [This doesn’t seem to conform to the rate cited.]  Inferior wheat still has to be bagged and stacked.  With silos filled throughout the country there is not the storage space to separate hard and FAQ wheat and this will cost growers 3d to 4d per bushel on their hard wheat.  At Burra only 12,000 bushels have been able to be taken and trucked directly as hard wheat, with the rest taken as FAQ.  Wheat came first from the early harvest areas of Peterborough, Yarcowie and beyond Spalding and this meant that some Burra District wheat had to go to silos at Farrell Flat, Saddleworth, or even Wallaroo and Adelaide.  The Burra silo has taken 200,000 bushels so far this season, with some 20,000 still to come.  Photo of loading wheat into a railway truck.

Weather.  A severe storm struck Burra last Wednesday afternoon and deposited up to an inch of rain in fifteen minutes.  Most shopkeepers suffered some stock damage when gutters failed to cope with the flow, but little water entered tanks, as most was lost over the edge of gutters.  Some shops and homes lost roofing iron and many homes suffered damage to floor coverings when water entered houses.  The Burra Hospital had water through it and suffered minor damage, though much cleaning up was required.  Burra officially recorded 68 points in the storm and 94 points for the day.  Some properties recorded up to 150 points.

Lightning caused many fires.  Most were extinguished almost at once, but two or three acres were burnt in some places.  Across the town reported falls varied from 150 points on the west side to 50 on the east.

Trevor Richardson in his school bus loaded with children was in the midst of it when the storm broke along Johnson’s Creek with hail and flying tree branches.  At its peak the bus was being blown along in second gear with its engine off.  He had stopped to clear debris from the road.  Just after crossing a creek to join the old Adelaide Road a great wall of water came down it.  Princess Royal shearing shed lost its verandah, which was carried some 500-600 yards.

Photographs: two photos show Johnson’s Creek area before and after the storm.

In that area dozens of large gum trees were uprooted and smashed to pieces.  Others were stripped of every leaf, twig and branch, leaving only the main trunk.  The destruction was in a strip along the creek for a mile with another line of it running over the hills towards the homestead and another leading west.

[This would seem to be describing a tornado.]

Obituary.  Dr D. McDonald Steele died recently aged 78.  He was the first President of the Burra High School Council.  He came to Burra after graduating in 1909 and practised here for over 30 years.  He took great interest in the welfare of Burra High School and was President of the High School Council for 26 years.  He was also interested in golf, tennis and bowls in Burra.  Since retiring to Adelaide he often visited the district in connection with his Koo-owie Stud and it was only last year that he finally relinquished his interest in that property, when it was sold to Barton Hill Proprietors.  In 1962 he was to have been a guest speaker at a High School Jubilee function, but was prevented by illness from attending.  He did attend the High School speech night in 1962 in December and gave an interesting address.  At the recent High School swimming Carnival, at which Steele House won the cup, a minute’s silence was observed.  He is survived by a widow and two sons, Dr D.M. Steele of Strathalbyn and Mr J.R. Steele and also by one daughter Mrs George Mollard-Humphrys.  He was cremated at Centennial Park after a service at St Matthew’s Church.

[The paper then reprints Dr Steele’s views on education from the History of Burra High School.  He was answering a view of a Professor who deplored wasting money educating the masses.  Dr Steele said: ‘It might be dangerous to educate the masses, but personally, he felt it right to give the boys and girls every chance, this was a duty parents owed the child and the nation.’]

[David McDonald Steele born 9 January 1886, East Adelaide: died 25 February 1964, Adelaide, residence Tusmore.]

Burra Mine

Officers of the Department of Mines are hampered in their testing and searching at the mine by incomplete records of the old workings and they are seeking any help available.  Having used drilling and induced polarisation, they are now using the geochemical method, but are hampered by a lack of factual information in the mine workings below the open cut.  If any local or former resident of Burra has any old plans or reports etc. they would be gratefully received.  They would particularly like any first hand knowledge of the two diamond drill test holes put down in the vicinity of the open cut in about 1900.  One was completed in 1897 and the other early in 1900, but the exact locations are not known.  Details from a log book would be valuable.  It would be wonderful if findings warranted the opening of operations in the area.  Geochemical prospecting relies on the changes in the composition of overlying soils caused by the decay of the bedrock.  Soil movement and ground water movement mean the minerals sought are in trace element proportions.

Obituary.  Mr William George Terry, who died suddenly at his home in Burra North on 31 March, was born at Broken Hill 7 January 1902.  He was the eldest son of Mr & Mrs William Terry and moved to Burra in 1911 when Mr Terry Sen. became manager of Sturt Vale Station.  He completed his schooling at Gawler and returned to work at Sturt Vale before taking work with the District Council.  Later he joined the tailoring staff of the late E.C. Hammond, whose business he acquired in 1930 and which he continued in until 1962.  He was active in the town’s sporting activities and in community affairs.  He was a keen bowler and was Burra Bowling Club’s singles champion several times.  He was instrumental in forming the North Eastern Bowling Association and skippered a mixed rink at the recent Easter Tournament to second place, only a few hours before his death.  He was secretary of the Burra Racing Club for some time before ill health forced him to retire.  He is survived by his widow Edith nee Harris, son Jim of Sydney and daughter Val. Mrs John Taylor of Tarlee.  There are four grandchildren.  His two surviving brothers are Jack of Burra and Tom of Adelaide.

Obituary.  Mr A.G. (Tom) Heinrich died 23 April.  He was a well-known farmer and grazier.  He died at Ru Rua Hospital in North Adelaide aged 73.  He was born 16 October 1890 at the Heinrich Homestead of Dutton’s Trough.  He received his early education at World’s End Creek School and later attended Point Pass College for UNREADABLE and was confirmed at Immanuel Lutheran Church, Point Pass by the late Pastor G.T. UNREADABLE.  Having spent all his life on the family homestead, Mr Heinrich took over the property from his parents.  In 1930 he married Miss Melva Riesson who died in 1934.  On 24 June 1937 he married Miss Rosa Wittwer at St Peter’s church, Point Pass.  They had seven children.  In his youth he played cricket for World’s End and football for Apoinga, but his great love was rifle shooting and he took an active interest in the Burra Rifle Club, winning many trophies, including Club champion and the Baldina Trophy for yearly aggregate as recently as 1955.  He represented Burra with other members in the big shoots in Sydney in the late 1930s.  He was a foundation member of the Burra Small Bore Club and active in the early years of its existence.   He served a term as Chairman of the Burra Primary School Committee.  He is survived by his wife and children: Cynthia, Annette Mrs Paul Sabel (of Hope Vale Lutheran Mission in Queensland), Graham, Maxine, Delrose, Kathlynn and Stephney.  The funeral cortege of more than 100 cars attended the funeral at St Peter’s Cemetery, Point Pass.

[Anton Gotthelf Heinrich born 16 October 1890 near Burra: died 23 March 1964 North Adelaide, residence Burra.]

The accident occurred five miles north of Redbanks about 9.30 p.m. on Tuesday night. Mothers & Babies’ Health Association.  Lady Bonython opened the new clinic on 27 April.  The building required a further £270 to be free of debt.  Lady Bonython is State President of the M & BHA.  Upon arrival she was entertained at luncheon at the Kooringa Hotel.  The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone attended the opening, despite being the only male present.  Local Association President Mrs R.B. Jennison welcomed the visitor and called on Lady Bonython to open the door.  It is seven years since clinic services opened in Burra and the number of mothers and babies using the service has increased every year.  Mrs Jennison said she could not mention the individual names of the many who had helped, but she did single out Mr Baulderstone who made the Mayor’s Parlour available for the clinic and Mr [R.] Fuss, without whose help, advice and labour it would have been practically impossible to open the building.  The aid of the CWA has also been greatly appreciated, along with the husbands of the committee members.  The M & BHA now has 84 buildings.  It had started in 1909, when it was called ‘The School for Mothers’.  It was started by Dr Helen Mayo with some helpers because she was appalled at the infant mortality rate, which was then over 70 per 1,000 births.  Last year it was 18.67.

Mr John D. Murphy will retire from the ANZ on 7 May.  He is manager of the branch at 394 Collins Street, Melbourne and retires after 43 years’ service, having joined the Bank of Australasia in 1921 at Kooringa, as a country boy from Oakbank SA.  In WWII he served in the Middle East and New Guinea.  He became a sub-inspector in 1947 and served briefly in Wellington, New Zealand, in that year also.  He held a number of executive positions in Melbourne and Sydney 1947-54 before becoming Senior Administrative Officer, General Manager’s Office, Melbourne, in 1955.  He has been manager of his present branch since 1958.  He married Miss Lila Thomas of Burra.

ETSA intends to build a modern office and depot in Burra, with a permanent maintenance staff and a small construction gang stationed here.  ETSA has been operating in the district from Clare, but growth of services in this area has led to the decision to establish a depot for line maintenance and minor construction work.  It will serve the area from Ulooloo almost to Morgan in the southeast and will include Hallett, Booborowie, Hanson, Burra and Robertstown.  It will maintain two major transmission lines providing power to the Upper Murray.

Accident/Obituary.  Three people died when two cars collided near Hallett on Sunday evening.  Of three people injured, one is in a critical condition, another is serious and the third is satisfactory.  The accident occurred about one mile south of Hallett.  A sedan car driven by H.R. Edwards of Cockburn was travelling north and collided with a car driven by Leo K. Collins of Olary, travelling south.  In Mr Collins’ car there were four passengers and of them Mrs E.D. Gurr died almost immediately.  From the other car Mr Edwards died shortly after being admitted to Burra Hospital and Mr Collins also died in the Burra Hospital.  All three of the deceased suffered multiple injuries, including fractured skulls.  Wayne Gurr (13) received head injuries and Deidre UNREADABLE of Nailsworth is in a critical condition.  Both were transferred to Adelaide yesterday.  Deidre suffered head injuries and fractured legs.  Sheryl Turner of Clearview suffered lacerations, but is in a satisfactory condition.  The accident was attended by Constable R.F. Heath of Hallett, Constable A. Conroy and Constable K. Watts of Burra.  Sgt S. Swaine and Constable P. Black of the Accident Investigation Squad from Adelaide have also attended.

[Doreen Eleanor Gurr died 24 May 1964 Hallett, residence Olary, aged 39.

Leo Keith Collins died 24 May 1964 Burra, residence Olary, aged 29.

Horace Reginald Edwards born 17 September 1907 Tarcowie: died 24 May 1964 Burra, residence Cockburn.]

Mr Howard Griffen of Mt Bryan has developed a fleece weighing table.  The table measures 10 ft x 5 ft and weighs up to 30 lb.  It has been under test at the Agricultural Research Station Trangie and results suggest it would be a sound purchase where fleece measurement was an integral part of the breeding program.  Tests show it to be as accurate as a standard balance, allowing for the fact that some locks will fall through when a fleece is thrown onto the table – the difference from the pan weight being between nil and 0.2 lb.  Overall it was accurate and simplified the board boy’s routine.  A NSW firm has agreed to manufacture the table.

Obituary.  Mr Ralph Thomas, well-known grazier of the Eastern Pastoral District, died on 22 May.  He was born at Tooralie north-east of Burra 15 April 1891 and died at the Royal Adelaide Hospital aged 73.  He was educated at Mt Bryan East and served in WWI.  He married Miss Tryphosa Thamm at Redruth Methodist Church 26 January 1921.  He lived at Mt Bryan East and served on the Hallett District Council for some years.  He then moved ‘out East’ where he remained until his death.  He is survived by his wife and children: Linda (Mrs Jones), Ida (Mrs Afford), Stuart and Bert.  There are 11 grandchildren.  He was buried at Burra Cemetery on 25 May.  Burra RSL Members conducted a ceremony of remembrance.

[George Ralph Thomas born 15 April 1891 Hundred of Wonna: died 22 May 1964, Adelaide, residence Hogback Station.]

Burra Memorial Oval.  The bore has progressed from 80 ft to 170 ft and it is intended to stop at 175 ft.  A test at 95 ft made 400 gallons.  A test on Wednesday last at 115 ft made 1,000 gallons, with the static level of water at 45 ft from the surface.  A test at 145 ft yielded 1,200 to 1,300 gallons per hour.  On Monday morning a test at 100 ft yielded UNREADABLE with the bore then at 160 ft and in the afternoon it was making 2,000 gallons per hour and with water of reasonable quality.

Burra Hospital.  Sir Lyell McEwin, the Chief Secretary, visited the Hospital on Friday afternoon.  He was met by the Board Chairman Mr R.K. Pearse.  He was accompanied by Messrs John Gebhardt and A.D. Radford.  They inspected the new building, the walls of which should be completed this week and also the kitchen, which is being converted from coke cooking to gas and the pantry, which is due to be enlarged to cope with more patients.  Sister Leader, a triple certificated Sister from WA, is due to begin work here from mid-July.

Accident.  A semi-trailer rolled onto its side in Market Square on Sunday when its load shifted.  The driver Mr J.L. Carroll of Prospect did a good job in managing to avoid the War Memorial when the load of pre-fabricated huts, destined for Moree in NSW, shifted as he turned from Commercial Street into Market Square heading north.  The driver was not injured.  Numerous people took photos. A crane arrived from Adelaide on Monday morning to unload the vehicle and right it.  The vehicle was driven off once it regained its wheels with damage of only £30-£40.  Damage to the huts was also slight and it is thought that spectators damaged more roses than the accident itself.  Alan Baulderstone removed a dozen or more to save them and 19 of the 48 are still standing.

Obituary.  Mr Arthur James Prior died at the Repatriation General Hospital Springbank, Adelaide 26 June aged 76.  He was born at Burra North on 11 July 1887 of parents who were both born in Burra. His father was the late Elijah Thomas Prior who was born in 1861 and his mother nee Elizabeth Owens was born in 1857 and lived to 93, dying in Adelaide in 1950.  He father was one of the original Burra miners and she was born and lived for some years in the old miners’ dugouts in the banks of the Burra Creek.  Mr Arthur Prior lived for many years in the district and later in Burra itself.  Before WWI he worked on farming and station properties in the Burra, Mt Bryan and Gumbowie districts and was employed for a number of years by the late Mr John Collins of Collinsville.  He enlisted in WWI and served in France with the 48th Battalion.  He was wounded in the Bullecourt Campaign and was taken prisoner by the Germans.  He spent almost two years as a POW and suffered great hardships.  After the war he returned to the Burra district with his brother Gilbert, who had been wounded on the same day and in the same battle in France, but who had been repatriated to Australia some time before him.  He took up farming as a soldier settler in the Springbank area and at Hanson and was successful until selling out just before WWII.  For some years Mr Prior than conducted a confectionery business in Market Square in the premises now occupied by Mr Alan Baulderstone.  After selling that premises he went into retirement in Adelaide for about 12 years.  He never married.  He is survived by four sisters and three brothers.  [Arthur James Jubilee Prior born 11 July 1887 Aberdeen SA: died 26 June 1964 Daw Park, residence Kilkenny.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM on 15 July in most inclement weather. The President Mr Dudley Jacka took the chair.  Members stood as a mark of respect for the late A.L. President’s Report

The past year has been most active and successful.

Membership is c. 61 full members, as it has been for the past three years.

During the year we farewelled Peter Pritchard and Keith Horsnell and two night members in Errol Hood and Ron McCann.  The club was shaken by the sudden death of George Terry, an excellent bowler, coach and greens manager.  He would have been made the 1st Life Member at the next general meeting of the club.  The club team won the Premiership in the North Eastern Association and players in the Mid North Association also did well.  This year the club room has been painted and had new lining and a new glass front.  Thanks go to Stan

Woollacott and Bert Wardle for making this possible.  The telephone has also been installed.  The support of the Associates has continued to be a great help.  Alan Benger’s work as gardener has been much appreciated.

River Murray Water for Burra

The Minister of Lands Hon P.H. Quirke has informed us that cabinet has approved the extension of Murray water to Burra and Booborowie.  There will be a pumping station near Hanson with three pumps and total power of 165 BHP.  There will by 44,000 ft of 10 inch AC pumping main along the main road adjacent to the railway line leading to the existing Burra Tanks.  The scheme is based on an annual consumption of 60 million gallons.  The Booborowie scheme will supply the town and some farmlands that have petitioned for supplies, but some farms are too high to be supplied.  There will be 33,600 ft of 8 inch AC feeder main from the Morgan-Whyalla pipeline to the township with 46,800 ft of 6 inch, 4 inch and 3 inch AC reticulation main at an estimated cost of £50,000.  Provision is made for an 8 inch spur main eastwards to supply a future service tank.

Miss Judy Field has passed the final examination of the Nurses Board of SA, coming 3rd in the state, claiming three credits and a gold medal.  She is at the RAH and will complete her training in September.

[Photo at her 21st birthday party at Burra RSL Hall.]

Miss Beverley Phillips, daughter of Mr & Mrs K.R. Phillips of Mt Bryan also passed her final nurses exam.  She is at the QEH.

Mr Harold Raymond and his ‘Gloombusters’ will present their final show at Booborowie on 12 August.  He has been touring and entertaining for some 40 years throughout the country and will now confine his work to the city.  Mr Raymond was honoured with an MBE by the late King George VI.  He has travelled over 700,000 miles to present upwards of 7,000 shows and has raised many thousands of pounds for his cause.

[He raised money for the Blind, Deaf & Dumb Children’s Home at Brighton; later called Townsend House.]

Cricket.  A meeting at Willogoleche on Wednesday night of delegates of five clubs of the Mokota Association decided to form a Junior Association.  The clubs represented were Hallett, Booborowie, Spalding, Burra and Leighton.  Matches will be played in conjunction with ‘A’ Grade teams and the rules of the Senior Association will apply.  For the new Association: Patron, Michael Hawker; President, M. Carmody; Vice-President, H. Black and Secretary, J. Costello.  Juniors must be under 15 years of age on 1 September to be eligible to play.  The minimum age is at the discretion of the club.  Burra will field two teams to be known as Burra Footballers and Koonaburra.

Burra Cemetery

For many years the condition of the cemetery has caused the Council concern and has been the subject of much criticism.  Legal issues have hampered Council action.  There has been a long wait for approval to reclaim and level a portion of the area.  Much research had to be done into particulars of leases, dates of burials etc. and many letters were sent to the concerning authorities.  Moves for the central portion of the cemetery to be levelled commenced six years ago and approval to carry out the work has finally been given.  Tracing lessees of blocks or members of the family concerned, calling for objections and so on has taken all that time.  Last week the Council, with the use of District Council plant, commenced the levelling work.  Large shrubs, large trees, broken and crumbling mounds, have been removed and the area flattened.  There is a large heap of rubbish to be burnet and the headstones removed will be placed along the boundary wall.  A vast improvement is already evident.  The 99 year leases on the blocks in this area had already expired.  New laws grant the period of 50 years only for the lease of these blocks.

Tally-Hi Shearing.  Vin Parks, Field Officer with the Australian Wool Board is conducting two shearing schools in the district this week.  They are arranged in conjunction with the Department of Agriculture to teach professional shearers the Tally-Hi method of shearing developed by the Wool Board.

Obituary.  Mr William Garden Gunn died 4 August at the Burra hospital.  He was born at Birkenhead and his father was Harbour Master at Pt Adelaide.  The family attended Port Adelaide Presbyterian Church for many years.  As a lad he went to Victoria to learn farming and returned to SA with his then employer, to live at Mundalla in the South East.  He bought his first property at Booborowie over forty years ago and developed virgin land into a most productive farm for Hunter River Lucerne seed growing.  He gradually increased his acreage and became so well known that orders for his seed came from interstate as well as locally.  He also had a small Friesian Herd.  He was a member of Willalo Methodist Church and a trustee for 32 years.  He is survived by a widow, Rachel Gunn of Melbourne.  [Born William Garden Gunn 26 February 1887 Birkenhead SA: died William Gardner Gunn 4 August 1964 Burra, residence Booborowie.  Since a wife Areta Lizzie Grace nee Chantrill died in 1945, his widow must be a second wife.]

Football.  Ray (Jimmy) James of Burra has won the G. Gilles Trophy for 1964 for gaining highest points in ‘B’ Grade football. Mr E.W. Dunhill of Burra North completed 73 years of service as a Local Preacher in the Methodist Church on 20 September.  This is a record unparalleled in Australia.  Mr Dunhill was born at Kersbrook and in early life went to WA.  He married there in 1908 and returned to SA in 1909.  He took up residence in Burra in 1915 and carried on a business as a blacksmith for 45 years, relinquishing it only five years ago at the age of 83*.  Mr Dunhill was the first man in Australia to receive a certificate recognising 60 years of service to the Church as a Lay Preacher.  He has also given long service in Sunday school work, with 37 years as Superintendent.  The President of Conference sent a letter of congratulations to Mr Dunhill, who will be 90 on 19 October.

[Clearly this does not accord with his being 90 in October.]

Obituary.  Alfred Stanley Barrett

Mr Barrett was born at Goodwood in 1887.  He was a member of the gifted Barrett family which conducted many evangelical meetings throughout the state.  When he joined his brothers he played the music at their meetings and the elder brothers gave the messages.  He became a Home Missionary and worked on Home Mission Stations where his practical help in building Churches was appreciated.  He was received into the Ministry in 1919 and ordained in 1923.  He worked in churches in the following circuits: Penong, Lameroo, Tailem Bend, Kulpara, Tumby Bay, Broken Hill, Minlaton, Nairne, Burra, Quorn and Woodside.  He married Miss Alice Whitbread on 20 August 1914.  His wife greatly assisted in the ministry.  Ill health forced his retirement, but he continued to do the work of his ministry through writing.  The funeral service was held in Redruth Methodist Church on Saturday and was conducted by the President of the Sa Conference Rev. B.H. Phillips, assisted by Chairman of the District Rev. C.F. Wells and the local minister Rev. M.A. Lind.

[Born 29 January 1887 Goodwood: died 17 September 1964 Burra.  He had been the minister for the Burra-Redruth Circuit 1943-47.]

Weather.  Further general soaking rains of between one and two inches have made this one of the best Septembers for years.  On the inside country crops have been progressing very favourably.  Over the weekend Burra recorded 81 points and rain continued on Monday.  Many areas close to the town received up to 150 points.  Mt Bryan East recorded 165 and Farrell Flat 132.  To the east Woolgangi received 131, Baldina 130, Pine Valley 116, Quondong 134, Old Koomooloo 150, Balah 94 and Mongolata 175 and still raining there heavily.

Kooringa Methodist Church will celebrate the Golden Jubilee of the present building next Sunday 4 October.  Rev. G.C. Hutchinson, a former minister of the Kooringa Church, will return as guest speaker.  He was stationed at Burra 1933-36.  The first Wesleyan Methodist church was built on the present site in 1847 by Rev. John Harcourt and enlarged under Rev. H.A. Wilson who was in charge 1854-58.  A gallery was added in the time of Rev. R.C. Flockhart, who followed Rev. Wilson.  The building served for 66 years before being replaced in 1914 under the direction of Rev. J.H. Nield.  A capacity crowd of 400 filled the church to commence the three day celebration of its opening.  Guests at the time included the President of the SA Conference, Rev. G. Hall, the Rev. Samuel Knight (a former minister), Rev. Henry Howard (a notable preacher from Pirie St Methodist Church, Adelaide) and His Honour the Chief Justice, Sir Samuel Way, whose father was a Primitive Methodist Minister in Burra.

Obituary.  William Henry Lloyd died 7 September 1964.  He was born at Erskine in 1889 and came with his parents to the Ironmine district and took up a property for farming.  He has remained there ever since.  He married Ivy Flower 28 July 1917.  He was a tower of strength in the Ironmine and Redruth Methodist Churches, serving in many ways.  For 26 years he was Superintendent of the Sunday school and a leader in young people’s organisations.  He was Secretary of the Ironmine Trust until he retired to Burra and he served many times as Circuit Steward.  He was a life member of the Burra Show Society and President of the Burra Show Committee and of the Burra Library Committee.  He was a member of the Masonic Lodge.  He leaves a widow and two children: Mr Ray Lloyd and Meryl, Mrs R.J. White.

[Born 17 September 1888 Erskine: died 7 September 1964 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

Kooringa Methodist Church Golden Jubilee

Members past and present filled the church on Sunday 4 October for the Jubilee Service.  The Resident Minister Rev. M.A. Lind conducted the morning service.  In 1914 the late Rev. J.C .Jennison had read the Old Testament Lesson and at the Jubilee his grandson Mr Ray Jennison read the lesson in his stead.  Sir Philip McBride, who was the first bridegroom married in the present building, read the New Testament Lesson.  The guest preacher was the Rev. G.C. Hutchinson, ex-President of the Methodist Conference and Kooringa Minister from 1933-36.

Mr & Mrs Robert Broad acted as Host and Hostess at the luncheon.  Mr Broad is Trust Secretary.  The ladies of the church catered for 160 guests.  The afternoon was a great time for reunion.  Among the large congregation for the Evening Service were Rev. R. Jenner, the immediate past minister and his family and Rev. M.S. Martin and his family.  The Jubilee of the building was also the Kooringa Church’s 118th Anniversary.  The guest speaker again gave the address.  Supper followed in the hall.

Daisy Kennedy and Mr A.L. Kennedy

This brother and sister returned to Burra for a visit, having left the town in 1895.  Daisy was born at the Commercial Hotel in 1893.

‘She was to become the world’s greatest violinist of her day.’

She went abroad for her training and stayed overseas, although she made a number of triumphant tours of Australia after 1914.  The family lived in a house in Kangaroo Street (now occupied by Mr & Mrs M.W. Eberhard and family).  She also had a look at the school where her father was headmaster from 1892 to 1895.  Her brother Mr A.L. Kennedy, who accompanied her, was one of Mawson’s companions on his Antarctic journeys.  Later he surveyed the vast area of the Kimberley in WA and became one of Australia’s leading geologists and mineralogists.  The pair spent an hour visiting their old home in Kangaroo Street, where they met Mrs Eberhard’s mother, Mrs Quinn, who had been at school with A.L. Kennedy.  Daisy Kennedy was first married to the great pianist Benna Mosceiwitsh and then to John Drinkwater, the English poet, writer and playwright.  She now lives in London and her brother in WA.

[Of the six Kennedy children, only Daisy Fowler Kennedy was born in Burra (Kooringa) 16 January 1893.  Alexander Lorimer Kennedy had been born 23 April 1889 at Woodside.]

Burra Show 1964

The show last Saturday was opened by the Governor Sir Edric Bastyan.  Attendance was about 2,000 and the gate takings were £179, only about £10 below 1963 despite a showery morning and a persistently wet afternoon.  Previous rain meant the grounds were probably the wettest ever underfoot.  Despite this the crowds came and ring events and other activities continued.  The SA Police Band made a small contribution at the opening, but was otherwise prevented from performing by the rain and returned to the city at about 3 p.m.  The Governor opened the show at about 12.45 p.m.  He arrived in the morning and stayed at the Commercial Hotel, due to the changed arrangements because of the weather.  There he was surprised to find himself speaking Arabic with Mr Rasheed.  After the Governor’s speech [which is printed] the band played The Song of Australia and the official party then adjourned for luncheon.  After lunch the Governor toured all the exhibits and watched some of the ring events.

Industrial displays occupied more space than for many years.

Side shows were more numerous, but patronage was quiet due to the rain.

The Schools’ Display was a fine effort and Rural Youth had a display on Bush Fire Prevention.

Young’s Caterers of Melrose did an excellent job with the catering.

The Rural Youth Club organised a dance in the pavilion in the evening and door takings were £22.

[Judges’ comments on each section are then printed.]

St Mary’s Anglican Church

The organ in St Mary’s was installed in 1904 when provision was made to add several ranks of pipes, or ‘stops’ so complete the tonal range.  To date this has not been done, but now the Rector Rev. G.D. Sibly has been able to purchase a second hand rank to complete the ‘Great Organ’.  These pipes will be installed this week.  Rev. Sibly hopes to be able to announce that the £75 cost has been donated.  £20 has already been received.  Organist Dr J.V. Peters will give a recital for the 116th Patronal Festival of the parish next Sunday.

Kindergarten Day in Burra, 13 November

Last Friday the Hon. Sir Bruce Ross LLB officially opened the newly registered Kindergarten in the morning and in the afternoon the Christmas Tree Carnival in the Town Hall.  The functions were well attended and the District Ladies’ Organisations raised £190.  The official party at the Kindergarten comprised: Sir Bruce Ross & Lady Ross; Mrs R.B. Pitcher, President of the Burra Branch; Miss Mellor, Superintendent of Kindergartens; The Mayor & Mayoress, Mr & Mrs E.T. Baulderstone; Mr Rex Warnes & Mrs Warnes; Mr L.A. Beinke President of the Burra Air Force Association and Mr G.R. Finch, Chairman of Burra Burra DC.  [The punctuation makes it unclear whether Rex Warnes or L.A. Beinke was President of the AFA, but I am not aware Rex Warnes was in the RAAF.]

Mrs Pitcher welcomed the guests.  She thanked Mrs J. Carpenter for her great effort in getting the Kindergarten started and the Air Force Association for granting a 20 year lease at £1 p.a.  Sir Bruce Ross said Mrs Carpenter had started the effort with a small band of children in the Methodist Church Hall and as interest grew it was decided to join the Kindergarten Union, which was done on 1 April 1964.  The Kindergarten began with half day periods, but now two afternoons have been added and no less than 43 young children attend.  He unveiled a plaque and opened the door.  Sir Bruce said the first Kindergarten had been founded in SA in 1906 and by 1945 there were still only 10, but now there were 119.  Sir Bruce Ross also opened the Christmas Tree Carnival in the Town Hall.  The best exhibit was the entry of the ‘Eastern Dorcas Society’.  [Photo in 87, 47 (3) 24 Nov. 1964.]  Takings for the day amounted to £190.  [Kindergarten or Christmas Tree: or are they the same thing as far as the money goes?

Mr Wayne Dodds is slowly recovering from his fall.  He suffered concussion, a fractured pelvis and ankle, a punctured bladder and broke all his left ribs.

Mr J.R. Barker of Baldina has found an interesting item on his property.  It was a pile of thin plastic 12-15 ft across and 2 ft high and far too heavy to lift.  Attached to either end was a solid round cylinder and to one of them a long nylon rope was fixed.  It appears likely to have been a large tethered balloon, perhaps 100 ft across, which has escaped from somewhere.  So far no one has reported seeing it in flight.

The Old Jinker.  The SA Government Tourist Bureau has advised the Town Council that a subsidy of £230 has been granted towards the cost of housing the old jinker at the Burra Mine. Burra Hospital

Last Friday afternoon the Hon. Sir Lyell McEwin opened the new building at the Burra Hospital.  The Vice-Chairman of the Hospital Board Mr Eric Ashby introduced the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone, who extended a welcome to Sir Lyell.  The Mayor said that Burra had played an important part in the economy of SA for almost 120 years, first through the days of the copper mine and later with the sheep industry.  The Mayor also welcomed Mr G. Gilfillan, Matron Croeser and two Hospital Inspectors, Messrs O’Donnell & Kelly.  He also welcomed the presence of Miss Siegele who took up duties at the Hospital in 1924 and was appointed Matron six months later.  She held the position for ten years.  Mrs Peak and the Misses G. & E. Williams were representatives of pioneer families.  Mrs Peal and Miss Gertrude Williams were daughters of Mrs E.C. Williams nee Kathryn Watson, the first fully trained nurse at the Hospital, who came from England in 1876.  Other Hospitals were also represented at the opening.

Mr Ron Pearse spoke as Chairman of the Hospital Board.  He said Sir Lyell had been the obvious choice to open the building, not just because he was Chief Secretary and Minister of Health, but also because he had taken a personal interest in the Hospital.

Sir Lyell recalled earlier visits as the work was in progress and visits too when Dr Steele was in the town and the hospital faced drainage problems and all sorts of embarrassments. Out of these troubles had emerged the most attractive development seen today.  Burra was one of about three places which had started a hospital before any assistance was available from Government.  [He went on to recount how Government had moved from a pound for pound subsidy to a two pound for one pound subsidy and that subsidies now also covered furnishings and other items, which had only gained such recognition in recent years.]

Sir Lyell went on to praise the development plan for the Hospital and of course the Government policies supporting hospitals generally and their equipment.  He had words of praise for the contractor Mr Mass and the architect Messrs Stapledon [sic] & Michael.  He also had praise for the staff and the Women’s auxiliary and the Board of Management.

Mr Glen Finch moved a vote of thanks to Sit Lyell, which was seconded by Dr L.G. Miller.

Mr Pearse then handed Mrs John Gebhardt and Mrs Andrew Tennant Honorary Life Membership Certificates.

Obituary.  Bridget Teresa Preiss died 3 April aged 94.  She was born 19 December 1870, the daughter of the late Matthew & Ellen Clarke of Pekina.  She was the eldest of a family of eight, all of whom predeceased her.  She married Charles William Preiss on 12 April 1893.  There were nine children, of whom Lawrence Vincent died in infancy.  The family lived at Spalding, Pekina, Yongala and Carrieton before finally settling at Burra.  Bridget Teresa Preiss lived in Paxton Square for 53 years.  For 46 years she was the honorary caretaker of St Joseph’s Church, which was her second home.  [See also 86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 7.  Born and married as Bridget Clark, but had children as Bridget Teresa, Bridget Theresea and Bridget Theresia Preiss.  Born 19 December 1870 South Rhine SA.]

Burra High School Speech Night

Headmaster R. Mueller’s Report for 1964.

The School re-opened with an enrolment of 185, up 34 on 1963.  This is due to the retention of students in the upper school, possibly influenced by the raising of the school leaving age to 15.  It is likely the future enrolment will fluctuate around the 200 mark.  Staff changes: Miss N. Lawes resigned to change her name to McElroy.  Mr B. McElroy transferred to Gilles Plains.  Miss A. Aistrope moved to Adelaide.  Miss E. McCabe went overseas and Miss B. Hogan and Mr W. Standing were appointed to Teachers’ College.  Mr K. Hicks was transferred to Nuriootpa during the year.  Mr R. Wright came from Gladstone, Mr I. Norton from Salisbury, Mr E. Johns & Miss L. Briggs were appointed from Teachers’ College. Local, Miss P. Zanker, was appointed a Junior Teacher.  Mr Heywood from Streaky Bay replaced Mr Hicks.  This year we have been informed that Senior Master Mr O’ Connor, is moving to Peterborough.  Miss Callier is moving to Darwin.  Mr Johns is also being transferred.  Miss Zanker moves to Teachers’ College.  I am being transferred to Naracoorte.  Replacements for 1965 will be Mr Farrow as Headmaster from AHS, Mr Brand from Peterborough as Senior Master and Mr Morris as Junior Assistant.

The High School Council has given the school sound support under Mr Jennison’s leadership.

The Parent & Friends’ Association has been very active.  They provided afternoon tea for Sports Day and arranged a most successful Ball (profit £100).  Tomorrow they will provide a sit-down banquet in this hall for over 200.  £200 has been spent on library books and physical education equipment.  The prefects have set a high standard of conduct and served the school well.

The successful Swimming Carnival was won by Steele House.

There was a whole school excursion to Renmark via Truro, Blanchetown, Waikerie, Kingston, Berri and Morgan.  Many people are thanked for the provision of transport.

The variety evening performance in the Town Hall was an innovation, which proved very successful and raised over £30 for the magazine fund.  Many parents and friends took advantage of the visiting day.

The Intermediate Class visited Clare to see a performance of The Merchant of Venice.

Last week an Advertiser tennis coaching school was run on the school’s tennis courts.

Clubs were introduced this year: public speaking, Red Cross, gymnastics, motor mechanics, musical appreciation, athletics, clay modelling and dramatics.

Burra won the Handicap Shield at the Inter-High School Sports.

The school won £40 from the Savings Bank Award.

Various speakers addressed the school about employment prospects.  A new tennis wall has been erected on the Statton Sports Area and a large area asphalted for playing space.  The newly developed playing ground is covering well with grass.  Books worth £170 have been added to the library and £100 worth of physical equipment has been purchased.  A new record player has been purchased.  Some improvements have been made to toilets and others await completion.  Approval has been given to convert the old laboratory to a staff room, but so far this has not happened.  Other approvals have been for a new change room, a chain wire boundary fence and repainting.

PEB results in 1963 were outstanding with an 88% Leaving subject pass rate and 84% for Intermediate subjects.  In Leaving 14 of the 15 candidates gained certificates and in Intermediate 15 of the 22.  Dianne Wood is congratulated for obtaining a Continuation Exhibition and the A.B. Riggs Award.

The beneficiaries of the estate of the late Dr David MacDonald Steele have made available the income from the sum of £250 to be awarded to the Dux of the School or for any other purpose designated by the High School Council on the recommendation of the Headmaster.  For this year £12 is made available with £6 for the Dux and £6 for the library (the latter being subsidised pound for pound).

Obituary.  Roy William Lloyd died suddenly 25 November.  He was born at Erskine 10 May 1895 to pioneering Methodist parents who instilled in him and all their children the great wealth of Christian character.  Roy came to this district as a child with his parents, who took up the property known as Braefoot.  He began his education at Erskine and finished it at Copperhouse.  He was deeply respected in the community.  In WWI he enlisted in the AIF and served in the 32nd Battalion in France and Belgium and on his return took up a Soldiers’ Settlement Farm at Flagstaff.  On March 16 ‘of that year’ [sic: for 1927] he married Annie May Morgan in the Ironmine Methodist Church.  Roy Lloyd had that rare gift of dependability and was often selected as a spokesman.  His leadership was noticeable in his WWI service and in WWI, in which he gave service in the VDC. The Methodist Church, especially at Ironmine pays tribute to his unassuming service.  He gave great support to the interests of young people and supported also the RSL.  He contributed a unique service to the community through his gift of water divining and over 100 bores and windmills stand as a memorial to this gift.  He is survived by his widow and four children: Colin, Mary Mrs Don White, Claire Mrs Athol Tiver and Donald.  There are eight grandchildren.

[Born 10 May 1895 Hundred of Morgan.]

Burra Hospital

The speech made by Mr R. Pearse, Chairman of the Board, at the opening of the new hospital building, is printed.

He thanked the staff for handling all the inconveniences during building operations without complaint.  The District Council and its employees also provided unpaid help.  The Town Council attended to cleaning of the footpaths and streets associated with the building.  The doctors also spent much time giving aid and advice.  The Board members and the Secretary Mr H. Foote also contributed a great deal of time and effort.  The architects are commended for blending the new building in with the old.  The public also had a huge role to play by contributing £5,000 between 29 October and 16 December 1963.  Further contributions would be welcome because over the past 12 months costs have increased between 20 & 25%.  Mr Pearse then said a few words on the history of the hospital.  The first hospital [Bleak House] was built by the mining company, just the other side of the old power house.  In 1876 the Burra Hospital was formed in what had been the original Burra hotel, then owned by the licensee Mr Alfred Barker.  (Mr John Barker is a grandson and the only family representative in the district today.)  Later Men’s and Women’s Wards were added, followed by a theatre block and some private rooms.  Later still, through the courtesy of Mr James Gallagher, an Isolation Block was added. (His child was the first patient there.)  In 1924 the Maternity Wing was added.  A major plan for redevelopment was formulated in 1953 and the Nurses’ Home was erected.  This plan’s other aspects were not proceeded with and the present Board thought it rather too big for the present needs of the district and the cost would have been excessive.  The present building is stage one of three of the new plan for redevelopment.  Next the pantry will be modernised.  The aim is to reduce the number of levels in the hospital.  We want to alter the theatre block and casualty to place all on one level, except for the Maternity Wing.

Mrs Alice Peak & Miss Gertrude Williams attended the hospital opening and reported on Nurse Catherine Watson, who was the first fully trained nurse at the Burra Hospital.  She came from England on the Oaklands in 1876 as a nurse, attending on one of the passengers.  She had intended to return, but instead agreed to go to Burra.  She found conditions primitive at the converted hotel that was the hospital.  Her first meal was on the end of the kitchen table, from a tin plate and pannikin, while the cook did the washing up at the other end.  She soon managed to introduce china for staff and patients.  Rubbish was emptied into a disused shaft on the grounds.  She was bothered by the continuous noise from the ore crushers, but the mines closed down soon after she arrived.  Equipment was minimal and at least one man’s leg was amputated using the meat saw from the kitchen.  Operations were performed on the counter of the old bar.  A typhoid epidemic struck while the railway was being extended to Terowie and so many patients arrived that they had to be accommodated on the floor of the old bar.  The cook had no idea of an invalid diet and provided a thick Scotch broth for the typhoid patients.  Nurse Watson sent the orderly to fetch the doctor.  The orderly was Mr William Wilson, who had resigned from the Police Department and helped Nurse Watson with the male patients.  He held the position for about 20 years until retiring.  Changes came gradually.  The bar was converted to a Women’s Ward.  The long room became the Men’s Ward.  The smaller rooms were assigned to domestic uses.  After two years Nurse Watson decided not to return to the Royal Berkshire Hospital in Reading, where she had been trained.  She married C.C. Williams.  Soon after this the Hospital purchased its first surgical instruments and Dr Brummitt came and took her to see them.  She was delighted at this advance in the treatment of the sick.

Characteristics of the 1964 paper.

The paper had a standard size of 8 pages of 7 columns, with occasional supplements, but more usually extra material was accommodated by expanding the paper to 10 or even 12 pages.  These expanded issues often had very confusing numbering of the pages.

Most news was carried on page 1 with sport a big part of subsequent pages.  Another feature of other pages was the printing of reports from district towns – Spalding, Farrell Flat and Booborowie in particular, but sometimes from Riverton and Saddleworth.  Spalding was more regularly represented than others.

The layout of the paper was less regular than in earlier years.  The suggested page usage is therefore more approximate than in some years.  Coverage of Burra news seems to be quite reasonable.

Page 1

News

Page 2

Sales advertisements and public notices.  Smaller advertisements. The Cash Column with its smaller classified type of advertisements may appear here, but migrated to almost any of the other pages except page 1.

Page 3

This could be a continuation of page 2 or may be dominated by larger advertisements.  News usually occupies less than one column.

Pages 4-8

Most advertisements are larger; generally at least two columns wide and two inches or more in depth.  News on these pages is usually two to three columns in total and is dominated by sport and/or reports from other parts of the wider district.  Occasionally there are full page advertisements.

Photographs of local events have become more common.  This year some accompany the news reports; rather than being a week or more later.  Some still lag the event.

Photographs are still not included every week, however.

R. Fuss of Burra North reports a strange and interesting visitor at the weekend – a porcupine or hedgehog.  Ian Barry and Chris Bevan were playing in the yard and saw it sunning itself in front of the wood shed, where it seems to have established itself.  It appeared several times throughout the day. St Andrew’s Anglican Church at Mt Bryan held services on Sunday to celebrate its Golden Jubilee. Rural Dean of Clare Rev. S.M. Smith and Rev. G.D. Sibly of Burra officiated.  A lych-gate has been erected as part of the beautification of the grounds.  [The newly erected Lych-gate is pictured.]  The land for the church was given by W.A. Gebhardt.  He and Mr H.L. Hatherly were the first Wardens of the Church.  The foundation stone was laid and dedication services were conducted by the Broughton Archdeacon Bussell.  The building and furniture cost £650 and the debt of £150 was paid off on 4 February 1921.  The consecration was not carried out till 1933.  This was the second church built in the parish.  (The Black Springs Church was purchased from the Methodists.)  There are two stained glass windows in the Sanctuary.*  One is in memory of Andrew Barker Hooper, who died 28 November 1914.  The altar cross and candlesticks were given by the UNREADABLE Family at Eudunda.  The Sanctuary hangings and altar linen were made and given by Mrs Bloyd (the wife of the Parish Rector in 1915) and Mrs Hatherly.  Several items of furniture have since been added: pews in 1960.  It has twice been renovated; in 1935 at a cost of £95 and in 1958-59 at a cost of £375.  Pine trees planted in the grounds are in memory of parishioners who went to WWI.  The lych-gate and stone path were added in 1964.  The Church is past of the Parish of Burra, which is in the Arch-Deaconry of the Broughton, within the Diocese of Adelaide.  It is anticipated that the Deanery of Broughton will be ceded to strengthen the Diocese of Willochra in 1966.  Present Wardens are G.S. Hawker, People’s Warden from 1949 and M. Collins, Priest’s Warden from 1960.  Rectors of Burra Since St Andrew’s was built have been:

Burra Swimming Pool

The Town Council is concerned that several items connected with the filtration plant have not been completed.  The filtration plant began operation on 22 December 1963, but negotiations with the contractor continued to May 1964 with no result.  Then the Council still did not know why the whole thing had not been finalised.  The Club advised the Council that it owed the contractor £496 or 10% of the initial cost.  This meant the Club could not claim £900 of subsidy from the Tourist Bureau because things were not up to scratch and the E & WS would not give a certificate of satisfaction.  Despite repeated visits and specific requests nothing was done and at the December Council meeting it was decided to give until 21 January to have work commenced.  On 18 January a Council meeting resolved to tell the contractor that if work was not completed within 14 days they would have the job completed and debit the cost to him.  This follows legal advice through the Municipal Association.  It should be noted that the problem is not with the actual filtration process, which is quite normal, but refers to ancillary work like cement work, pipe diameter etc.

Burra Sewerage Scheme

Don Wilson Chief Inspector of the Central Board of Health has outlined a sewerage system to serve the main business section of Burra.  It could be operation as early as 1966.  Mr Wilson visited Burra on Wednesday and with the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and Town Clerk W.A. Holness, inspected the shopping area, which has most problems regarding the installation of septic toilets and hand-washing facilities.  A meeting of the Local Board of Health discussed ways and means of overcoming this problem.  Mr Wilson outlined a scheme to provide 50-60 premises with a full sewerage system at a comparatively low cost per owner.  The plan would have one sewerage pipeline commencing at the Post Office Exchange building and extending round to the vicinity of Dr Miller’s residence.  A second would commence at the rear of Jennison’s used car lot and extend along Commercial Street to the main creek, taking in all businesses on the south side of Market Square.  These pipes would connect with a treatment plant on the bank of the creek and effluent could possibly be used for the establishment of trees and shrubs etc.  A similar scheme recently installed for the whole of Berri cost £25,000.  At Berri the effluent is being used on the golf links.  There is no likelihood of unpleasant odours from the treatment plant.  Soakage pits and septic tanks would not be needed on the properties concerned.  It is unlikely that if it were decided on, it could be in operation before January 1966.  Once this scheme was decided upon the installation of septic tanks would become compulsory, without exception throughout Burra, unless connected to the sewerage drain.  Depending on demand the Council is likely to term this phase 1, with other areas perhaps eventually added to the service.  The Central Board of health would handle the survey, designs, plans and estimates of cost, at no charge to Burra.

Arthur Jordan.  An article from the Gawler Bunyip of about 12 months earlier is reprinted.

Arthur D. Jordan of Gawler is 90 today.  One of his most vivid recollections is likely to be the day, 78 years ago, that he climbed the Smelters’ Chimney at Burra.  The young ‘Art’ Jordan shinned up the 85 ft stack with townspeople looking on.  Since then he has become a citizen of Gawler and a Life Member of the Gawler Jockey Club.  He managed A. Sheard’s Essex House in Gawler for 25 years and had his own drapery business for 27 years in the store occupied by Gordon Ames.  He was Secretary of the Gawler Chess Club during its active years.  He was born in Clare.  [Born at Kooringa: see below.]

[A couple of verses of the poem When Arthur Climbed the Chimney are printed.]

[See Burra Record 57, 45, 10 Nov. 1936, page 3: Memories of Burra by Elizabeth A. Ward.  Arthur Jordan was the son of the late J.D. Jordan, watchmaker, of Kooringa.  Arthur Dawson Jordan born 8 March 1873 Kooringa: died 28 October 1965, Gawler.]

Fire.  On Sunday afternoon a bushfire began south of Clare and burned on area of some 50 to 60 square miles, devastating country between Clare, Mintaro, Farrell Flat and Hill River. A number of homes were destroyed along with many outbuildings and haystacks, sheep, cattle and miles of fencing.  The fire was brought under control in the early hours of Monday morning.  Patrols are still watching hot spots for potential outbreaks.

Weather.  A freak windstorm on Sunday afternoon caused the collapse of a large implement shed on Mr Gordon Webster’s property at Springbank.  In the process a utility was blown across the yard into the house fence, which was flattened by the impact.

Swimming.  The Open Swimming Carnival at Burra on Sunday was not well attended due to the extreme heat.  Some also left when new of the fire between Clare and Farrell Flat was received.  The carnival itself went relatively well.  For Burra Garry Hirschausen, Sandra Williams and Jill Eberhard gained trophies.

Burra RSL held its AGM on 19 February.  The meeting was well attended.  Elected: President, H. Cornelius; Vice-Presidents, T. Rogers & A. Benger; Secretary, J. Murphy and Treasurer, B. Kotz.

The President reported a very quiet year with a very small committee and the General Committee doubles as the House Committee.  There were 10 general meetings and 10 committee meetings.  53 were on parade for the Anzac Parade with the service conducted by Rev. Lind and the march led by the Pt Pirie Pipers’ Band.  19 members attended the evening service at the Kooringa Methodist Church.  Remembrance Day was observed on 11 November.  The Burra Primary and High Schools attended.  121 crosses were planted in memory of the fallen.  The annual ball was a success.  The Annual Dinner was held on 12 December and was attended by 40 locals and 18 visitors.  Successful badge days were held for Legacy, Myrtle Bank, Anzac Day and Poppy Day Appeals.  The branch continues to support two Legacy Wards with the money for that coming from bottles left at the club rooms.  Bert Samuels left the town during the year.  We provided funeral escorts for the late Ralph Thomas and Roy Lloyd.

Indoor bowls have been a success on Tuesday evenings.  Bowls games were played on Anzac Day.  The Ladies Auxiliary again provided great support at activities throughout the year.

Vandals struck the Burra Swimming Pool on Friday night and dumped many items into the pool, including tables, chairs, trestles, poles lifebuoys and a steel grating weighing half a hundredweight.

Weather.  January and February 1965 have been the driest two months on record in Burra, with a registration of nil.  This equals the records of February-March 1893 and December-January 1905-06.

Mt Bryan Methodist Church held its harvest festival on Sunday 28 February.  A dedication service was held when Mr Horrie Edwards and family presented a lectern and Bible to the church in memory of their late husband and father.  Mr Edwards had been a local preacher in the circuit for over 40 years.  He was a member of the Order of Knights and Sunday school Superintendent for many years at the old church.  Mr George Goodridge and Mrs Crew presented to the church an engraved music stand in memory of Mrs Goodridge who started teaching in the Sunday school of the old church when she was 17 and continued till she moved to Ironmine in 1906.  She then taught there for five years.  She married in 1911 and again took a Sunday school class and with her brother Horrie worked in the Sunday school till the church closed in 1939.  Both Mr Edwards and Mrs Goodridge also worked in the Town Church and Sunday school for many years.

Fire.  The large fire on Sunday 21 February gave Farrell Flat an uneasy time.  Strong southwest winds and a temperature in excess of 100°F blew the flames from Mintaro towards Farrell Flat.  Several times men fighting the fire were in danger of being trapped in pockets of fire.  Units managed to check the fire three miles south of the town and a wind change swept it northeast* until it was checked at the stone wall on the Clare-Farrell Flat Road.  There were heavy losses of sheep, fodder and fencing.

[* The description suggests it was swept northwest rather than northeast.]

A subsidy was available for preparing the lunch room for use as an art room as well as the addition of heaters to another room, the renovating of school drums and the grassing of the oval. Bowls

Burra hosted the Champion of Champions matches on Saturday.  62 bowlers contested the title.  The final in the rinks competition saw Clare White (Alick Byrne, Max Hand, G. Tilbrook & Ray Leak) defeat Clare Red.  In the singles final Harold Crump of Burra was defeated by Gerry McDermid of Auburn.

Les Phillips Vice-President of Burra Club welcomed guests and A.J. Cornish [perhaps: not very clear] President of the Mid North Association also welcomed contenders.  A fine luncheon was served at the RSL Hall and morning and afternoon teas at the clubhouse.  Last Thursday Harold Crump won the Burra Club Championship for the second year in succession, with Edgar Pietsch as runner-up.  He also skippered the leading rink in the teams’ event – Burra Green, which won the 1964-65 Mid North Association Pennant.

Swimming.  Twelve members of the Burra & District Club took part in the age group Championships at the Olympic Pool in Adelaide and gained great experience.  Peter Broderick was in the final for 8 and Under 55 yards freestyle and Rosemary Ryan was 3rd in the 12 and Under 3 m diving.

Burra Red Cross Badge Day on Friday last raised £33.

Burra Primary School Committee: Annual Report.  Chairman K.W. White.

Mr D. Zanker was elected Chairman in 1964 and served very actively until his transfer from the district.  Headmaster Mr Horsnell was transferred at the end of Term 1, to be succeeded by Mr I. Auhl.  Both headmasters have given strong support to the committee.  A picture evening with Gilbert Valley Camera Club in April raised £10-17-6.  Arbor Day was successfully held in July.  School Sports were keenly contested at the War Memorial Oval.  The Committee helped in completing the new cricket pitch and in getting power lines removed where they crossed the new area and water has now been laid on.  Entrance gates in the oval fence were fitted to allow direct access.  The proposed resurfacing of the tennis courts and provision of backstops is in abeyance.  The approach to the school has been made safer with the co-operation of the Town Council.

CWA Country Woman of the Year

Mrs Bruce Stockman, who was nominated in this state-wide contest by the Hanson Branch, was declared the winner of the Warnes’ Group section on Friday night.
