National Trust

Mr Andrew Tennant has donated Dower’s shop in Market Square to the Trust.  There is also a donation of £50 towards renovations.  The building is of solid stone.  It will be used as a museum.  The old jinker from the mine has been housed on a site adjacent to the building.  The housing for the jinker consists of roofing only and was subsidised by the Tourist Bureau.

Burra Caravan Park.  At present this is only a camping area, but the matter will be discussed at the next Council meeting.

SA Annual Merino Field Days drew interest from all around Australia.  WA graziers were particularly interested.  An East Bungaree ram went to Northampton WA for 2,000 guineas.  A Koonoona stud ram went to F. Mosey of Robertstown for 1,500 guineas.  W.B. Ashby & Sons sold a ram to WA for 2,000 guineas.  Crowds were a record.

Burra Burra Show Inc.

Report of President Mr Rex Warnes

The last show was on 12 October 1964.  Conditions were shocking.  It poured with rain from morning to late afternoon, marring what deserved to be a record day.  Gate takings were down £30.  The Governor Sir Edric Bastyan and Lady Bastyan attended and his Excellency opened the show in heavy rain, making light of the circumstances.  After lunch he toured the soggy grounds and inspected the exhibits.  The Police Force Band attended, but rain prevented them from playing after lunch and they left.  Exhibits were of a high standard and numbered 2629.  Membership has fallen by 30 and this needs to be rectified.  Generous donated [from people who were listed] have helped to reduce the society’s overdraft.  Young’s Caterers of Melrose did an efficient job.  During the year death removed some staunch supporters in the persons of Mr W.H. Lloyd (a Past President), Mr C.T. Beckwith and Mr M.A. Radford.  Mr Lloyd and Mr Beckwith were both Honorary Life Members.

[The usual thanks to stewards and committees follows.]

Elected were: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; President, M.G. Stockman and Vice-Presidents, Rex C. Warnes & B.A. Riggs.  The next show will be held on 9 October 1965.

[Personal interest: R. Fuss was on the Produce Committee.]

Accidents

On the Thursday before Easter a car rolled over in Murkaby Lane about 30 miles east of Burra.  The driver was unhurt.

On Good Friday at 2.30 a.m. a car rolled over 3 miles north of Mt Bryan.  No one was hurt, but the car was a write off.

On Easter Monday a car overturned on the Burra-Booborowie Road.  Again the car was written off, but the driver was uninjured.

At 4.30 a.m. on Tuesday a car overturned on the Burra-Mt Bryan Road near the racecourse.  The driver escaped without a scratch, but the car was extensively damaged.

On Thursday morning a collision occurred between a utility and a truck at Cobb & Co.’s Corner.  No one was hurt, but the utility was badly damaged.

Burra CWA held a picnic at the Gorge for their April meeting.

Burra Town Council has decided to enclose the northern section of the jinker shelter to house mine relics or material associated with the jinker. Some old bullock yokes have already been donated.  A call is made for other items.

Anzac Day in Burra.  Rev. G.D. Sibly conducted the service on Sunday at the War Memorial.  The Marananga Band and about 40 ex-servicemen took part in a march before the service.  Wreaths were laid by H. Cornelius for the RSL, T.R. Rogers for the AFA, Arnold Heinrich for the Demobilised Soldiers, W. Carpenter for the Fathers’ Association, E.T. Baulderstone for the Town Council and G.R. Finch for the District Council.

This year’s church service was held at St Mary’s, conducted by Rev. G.D. Sibly.  The Mayor and Mayoress attended, with President H. Cornelius of the RSL and 14 ex-servicemen.  The Burra Choral Society, conducted by M.D. Ebsary, led the music and the occasional sermon was by Rev. M.A. Lind of the Burra Methodist Circuit.  More than 200 people attended and supper followed in the Parish Hall.

Obituary.  Albert Gustav Blieschke of Farrell Flat died at Burra Hospital 13 April aged 73.  He was the son of the late Mr & Mrs Henry Blieschke and was born at Melrose 23 July 1891.  On 9 May 1922 he married Miss Gertrude Gersch of Kilkerran and began farming at Booleroo Centre.  Later in 1928 he farmed at Edillilie on Eyre Peninsula and in 1948 moved with his family to farm three miles north of Farrell Flat.  He retired in 1964 to live in Farrell Flat.  He is survived by his widow and two sons: Ron of Farrell Flat and Eric of Leigh Creek.

Burra Town Council Elections

E.T. Baulderstone was re-elected for the twelfth consecutive year in Council.  This also means he has been 20 consecutive years in Council.  He first took his seat for East Ward in July 1946 and became Mayor in July 1954.

Mr T.H. Woollacott served 14 years as Mayor, but in two periods 1931-37 and 1940-46.

[This is in fact only 12½ years.  Until 1936 elections were for a calendar year and the term of office ran from December to November.  Subsequently the term was for the financial year July-June.  T.H. Woollacott was elected in December 1931 and effectively served as Mayor in 1932, 1933, 1934, 1935, 1936 and half of 1937 and later for 39/40, 40/41, 41/42, 42/43, 43/44, 44/45 & 45/46.]

E.W. Crewes was Mayor for 11 years in three periods.  [1900-02, 1914-19 & 1921-22.]

When nominations closed on Friday:

Cr R.J. Jeffery was returned for North Ward, Cr C.L. Phillips for West Ward and Mr Ken Williams replaces Cr R. Broad in East Ward.

Decimal Currency

With the Commonwealth Mint busy making the decimal coinage, they cannot manufacture more pennies and half-pennies.  These are in short supply, it is believed because people think they will be able to make a profit on them after decimal currency comes in.  This is not so; half-pennies, pennies and threepences will only be exchanged in multiples of sixpence, which have exact equivalents to multiples of five cents.

Burra Stockowners’ Association met at the RSL Hall on Thursday to discuss the proposed reserved price for wool scheme and the narrowing of existing stock routes.  Elected: President, H.C. Radford and Vice-President, Don Lord.  On the question of stock routes the meeting decided to recommend to the Burra Burra DC:

King or Florieton S.R. be reduced to 3 chains for its entire length.

The Eastern S.R. be reduced to 10 chains as far as Baldina Creek and from the west to 3 chains.

The Baldina-Robertstown S.R. be reduced to 3 chains.

Redbanks Reserve be declared a dedicated reserve under the Burra Burra DC.

State President J.W. Andre, P.A. McBride of the Australian Wool Board and R.J. McCauley, Treasurer of the Association gave interesting addresses on the reserve price scheme, pointing out the advantages and disadvantages.

The Government has agreed in principle if the woolgrowers agree at a referendum.  The Wool Industry Conference has recommended the woolgrowers would contribute £20 million over 8 years.  The agreement is now for £30 million over 7 years.  The money would come from a levy not exceeding 3% of the gross proceeds of wool sold.

This money would cover:

Their contribution to the scheme’s capital.

Commitments for the promotion of wool.

Commitments for wool research.

Robberies in Burra

On Sunday night three Burra businesses were broken into and goods to total values of £800 were stolen.

Mr Ken Murphy’s Burra Gift Shop, J. Hill’s Burra Menswear Store and the Burra Motor Co. were all robbed.  From Mr Murphy’s the thieves took 20 wrist watches, 40 rings, brooches, necklets, pens and other items as well as razors and electric hair clippers and Pall Mall cigarettes.  About £200 worth of clothing was taken from Mr Hill’s shop and Burra motor Co. lost a small amount of change from the till.  The breakings were noticed by Mr R. Webb who was going for a daily paper at about 7.30 a.m. and by Mr M. Beinke.

The Bishop of Polynesia Dr J.C. Vockler will visit St Mary’s on Thursday 24 June.  The local Methodist Church will join with the Anglicans in this special Burra Missionary Rally.

Mr O.A. Tattersall, Burra Postmaster, retired last week in his 51st year of service with the Department.  He entered the service in 1914.  He began his term at Burra on 18 August 1965 [sic] and completed it on 26 May 1965.

[Correction 88, 23 (2), 15 June 1965, page 4 to: began his term at Burra 18 August 1950.]

Mr & Mrs Tattersall have had a new home built on Smelts Road, opposite the oval, for their retirement.  A farewell was held in the Post Office on Tuesday 25 May for Mr Tattersall and for ex-postman P.S. Bampton, who has retired through illness.  [Those present are listed.]

Papal Honour for Burra’s Parish Priest

The Most Rev. B. Gallagher DD, Bishop of Port Pirie, has received news from the Apostolic Delegation in Sydney that Pope Paul VI has created Patrick Valentine Hughes a domestic Prelate with the title of Monsignor.  Monsignor Hughes was born in Victoria and educated at Christian Brothers in Geelong.  He studied for the priesthood in Europe: in Ireland and Rome. He was ordained at St John Lateran Basilica in Rome in 1926.  He is also an Arts graduate of Melbourne University.  He has worked in the northern part of SA, notably at Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Peterborough, Carrieton and Renmark.  He has been at Burra for 15 years.  This is the first occasion when this parish has been tended by a Monsignor.

Accident.  On Thursday a 10-year-old cyclist travelling north on the Mt Bryan Road got something caught in his wheel, causing him to swerve suddenly into the path of an oncoming semi-trailer loaded with 30 head of cattle.  The semi-trailer driver was quick to react and swerved off the road, colliding with a telegraph pole.  The boy ran into the rear of the trailer and suffered bruising and slight concussion.  Sgt Teague and Constable K. Terry of Burra attended the scene and praised the driver for his effort, which had averted a more serious result.  PMG linesmen soon repaired the damaged lines.

Break-ins.  For the second time in five weeks the shop of Mr K.J. Murphy has been broken into.  Fancy goods, cigarettes, tobacco and razor blades have been stolen.  The theft took place on Saturday night.  Entry was obtained to Burra Meat Stores as well, but nothing was stolen.  The value of cigarettes and tobacco taken was £120-£130 and losses in all were c. £180.

Man Lost at Thistlebeds

Two inexperienced shooters got into trouble at Thistlebeds-Baldina area on Sunday when one became lost.  Hendrick Westerlaken (26) and Gunther Fromel (28) were five miles from Thistlebeds when the latter became lost about 10 a.m.  After searching for his friend Westerlaken sought help at Thistlebeds at about 5 p.m.  F-C Watts, R. Moreland, W. Corner, Constable Terry and Jim Brown of Baldina searched till midnight.  Mr Kellock searched on horseback until dawn and others joined the search on Monday.  Mr M. Tiver used his plane to help at 11 a.m. on Monday.  Fromel was found at 12.40 p.m., having spent the night in Mr G. Lomman’s crutching shed.  The men were questioned at Burra Police Station concerning trespassing and shooting on the properties concerned.

Burra Town Council.  The Mayor’s Report 1964-65

The Council budgeted for a debit of £1,700 for the year and finished at approximately that amount.  Over the past three years the Council has expended over £3,000 on new plant and is now reaping the benefit.  The main improvement this year has been the erection of a new toilet block opposite the Town Hall.  The Council has agreed to clean up the creek area and develop a park which together with the swimming pool and proposed Caravan Park will create a real beauty spot for the town.

The Memorial Oval Committee has been financed to the extent of £500 to help with water reticulation.  The cemetery is nor a credit to the town and if looked after should not get into the condition it previously was in.  Thank go to the DC for grading etc. at the cemetery.

The old jinker has been housed in the main street.  Some ratepayers may think this a waste of money, but it is possibly the only one of its kind in Australia and a relic of early days in Australia.  It fits in well with the developing park and the National Trust building in the vicinity.

A spraying program has been effective in managing water tables.  Progress on eliminating horehound has been made, but it is slow.

The Council passed a vote of gratitude for the outstanding work in public affairs and town progress by the Mayor and Mayoress.

Mr Roy Sellars of Burra North has completed 60 years as a shearing shed worker.  He first began work in 1905 on Mt Bryan Station of Mr Charles Bowman.  Over the years the property has been split up, but in the past week Mr Sellars has been working in the same shed – presently owned by A.B. & B.A. Riggs on their ‘Kabymur’ property.  It is thought the property is almost 100 years old.  Roy is at present pressing bales for Messrs Riggs exactly 60 years after he first slept there and over the years has pressed bales in most woolsheds east of Burra and in many parts of the State.  The ink from branding the bales gave him the nick name ‘Inky’ and many who would not know Roy Sellars know ‘Inky’ Sellars.  It would be interesting to know how many bales he has pressed in 60 years.

The Burra Fire Brigade

The chief officer of the SA Fire Brigades Board has had discussions with the Mayor Mr Baulderstone, the Councillors and the Town Clerk re the town brigade.  It was decided some facts needed to be publicised.

The Burra Fire Brigade is part of the Auxiliary Fire Service maintained by the Board to afford fire protection to certain country centres where the Fire Brigades Act Applies.

It is manned by an Auxiliary Foreman and Auxiliary Fireman, who have permanent employment in the town and who are available to answer fire calls on a 24 hour basis.

Auxiliary Firemen needed to be fit and undergo a medical examination when they join.  They are provided with uniforms and equipment and must attend drills and instruction as required.

They are expected to devote a reasonable proportion of their time to the Brigade and take their turn of duty at the station as required.

They receive an annual retainer payable monthly plus 15/- per hour or part thereof when at fires or cleaning up afterwards.  The Foreman gets £130 p.a., the Firemen £100 and the Standby £25.

The retainer is payable for the first three months of sickness.

Auxiliary Firemen are covered by Workmen’s Compensation for death or accident while on duty.

Absence due to holidays from his permanent job does not interfere with his retainer.

Accident/Obituary.  On Friday 10 September at about 5.15 p.m. a car with three young men in it crashed at Burra North.  The car with the three, who had been working on the new railway line at Olary, failed to take the bend at the Bon Accord Bridge and landed upside down in the creek.  The vehicle caught alight and incinerated the occupants.  Local police and the Accident Investigation Squad carried out enquiries.  The vehicle was a try top Land Rover.  The deceased were Graham Trevor Jackson (23) of La Trobe St, Blair Athol (driver)

Hugh McEvoy (22) of Olary – a Scottish migrant of about 12 months

Allan Howe (17) of Elizabeth Field.

Kooringa Methodist Church celebrates its Anniversary next Sunday.  The first Methodist service in Burra was probably conducted in the home of John Chapman, a dugout in the Burra Creek.  Services continued there till the first chapel was built in 1847.  The people were given permission to build provided it was opened free of debt.  It cost £250.  The present building is only 51 years old.  Rev. Vivian Secombe will be guest preacher on Sunday.  He was appointed to the Kooringa Circuit in 1939 and served for two years.

Burra & District Swimming Pool

Only seven persons attended a public meeting to discuss the future management of the pool and this included the Mayor and two Councillors.  The others were two members of the Swimming Club and one newcomer to the town.  Discussion disclosed the view that the control of the pool by the Burra & District Swimming Club resulted in the needs of the competitive swimmer being placed before the needs of the public and casual swimmers.  A resolution was passed that a recommendation be made at the Swimming Club’s AGM that the management and control of the pool be vested with the Corporation and the Club concentrate on running competitive swimming.

Burra Show was held on Saturday in fine weather and drew a record number of entries and a record gate taking of £258.  Mr Res Warnes, as President of the Royal Agricultural and Horticultural Society, opened the show.  The day dawned with misty rain, but soon cleared to a fine day.  The Flower Pavilion looked a picture. The display of school work was excellent.  Grain and fodder, fruit and vegetables, cooking, needlework and Youth Club displays combined well.  The strong support of exhibitors from the Clare District was evident throughout.  There was a good variety of sideshows.  Samson the Strongman proved the most popular of the tent shows.  Young’s Caterers of Melrose again did a good job.  Local and visiting businesses provided a variety of machinery merchandise and vehicles.  Quite a good crowd attended the dance in the main pavilion at night, when door takings amounted to £50.  The Cascades Band provided the music for this event arranged by the Rural Youth Club.

Accident.  A Volkswagen sedan driven by Mr Carl Lawrence of Campbelltown collided with a Holden sedan driven by David Phillips of Burra at about 8 p.m. on Friday 8 October about 5 miles south of Hallett at Shattock’s Corner.  The Holden rolled over and the driver and his passengers, Angela Ryan and Mrs Joan Barrett, both of Burra, were admitted to the Burra Hospital.  Mrs Barrett was transferred to Adelaide Hospital the next day, it is believed with a shattered ankle.  Both vehicles were extensively damaged.

Accident.  On Thursday a car driven by Kingsley Broad of Peterborough overturned near the junction of the Black Springs and Adelaide Roads about a mile outside Burra.  The car skidded on loose gravel.  The driver’s two daughters were passengers.  Rosemary (6) suffered lacerations and a fractured left leg.  Deborah (5) sustained lacerations and shock.  The three occupants were admitted to the Hospital and damage to the car was estimated at c. £300.

Burra Mine

The Burra Mine was inspected on Friday by Mr S. Bevan the minister of Mines, Mr T.A. Barnes the Director of Mines, the Deputy Director Mr Parkin and the Senior Geologist Mr Nixon.  The Minister said the Mines Department had been carrying out extensive geological, Geophysical and Geochemical surveys of the district for several years, coupled with a drilling program.  This had established substantial ‘leavings’ of oxidised copper in and north of the old open cut.  It is estimated to comprise over one million tons of low grade oxidised copper.  Trial recovery from parcels of the material by Australian Mineral Development Laboratories had been encouraging.  The interest of major exploration companies was being invited and if further work confirms the Mine Department’s findings an industry would be established at Burra to recover the copper.  This would involve open cut mining and the removal of overburden and oxidised copper to at least 100 ft below the present water level in the old open cut, followed by acid leaching of the ore to recover copper concentrate in a treatment plant.  Employment for over 50 men would last from 5 to 10 years.  Also several targets for deeper drilling had been suggested and any company selected for the project would be required to continue vigorous and substantial exploration, which if successful could lead to a major mining operation.  Mr Baulderstone and Mr Finch were very interested in the tour of inspection and appreciated the action of the Minister in including them and the Town & District Councils in the inspection.

Peter Maynard was riding his bicycle on the main road near the Mine entrance on Monday 11 October when he encountered a 4 ft 6 inch snake.  The startled snake attempted to strike Peter on the leg, but only left two small marks on his boot about one inch below the top.  Peter was saved by his ‘Beatle boots’.

Miss G.M. Jordan, whose brother is renowned for climbing the Smelts’ Chimney, visited Burra this week from Broken Hill after an absence of 67 years.  She went to Broken Hill in 1898, having attended Burra School.  She later became a teacher and at her retirement was a headmistress.  Mr Jordan, now 92, is presently in the Hutchinson Hospital, Gawler.  Miss Jordan resides in Sydney and is staying in Gawler for the time being.

[Gertrude Mary Jordan 1882-1973.  Her brother, Arthur Dawson Jordan died 28 October 1965.]

St Mary’s Guild held a very successful Musicale in the Town Hall on Tuesday.  It was organised by the Guild President Mrs Arthur Wright and over 150 people enjoyed the program by Mrs Joyce Thomas and other Adelaide artists.  In the official party were the Rector & Mrs Sibly, Rt Rev. Monsignor P. Hughes, The Mayor and Mrs Baulderstone, Mrs Thomas (pianist), Mrs Moss (Contralto), Mrs Drew (Soprano) and Mrs Oaten (Elocutionist).  The delightful afternoon raised £95, which will be shared between Guild funds and the Mitchell River Aboriginal Mission.

The new Tally-Hi Shearing Technique triumphed when an Australian Wool Board shearing instructor Kevin Sarre achieved a world record 346 sheep in a day, using the technique at ‘Batesworth’, Penshurst, Victoria.  (In 7 hours 48 minutes.)  This is a world record for Merino sheep using narrow combs.  A team of three shearers managed 824 sheep.  The previous record for Merinos was 329 sheep in 7 hours 4 minutes.

The Stolen Bale of Wool from P.J. Thomas’s property at World’s End has been recovered.  Mr L.C. Phillips of Koonoona found it on the side of the Burra-Black Springs Road near Black Springs.

Burra Mine

In response to a question from the Hon. R.A. Geddes, the Minister of Mines Hon. S.C. Bevan has assured him that if a lease is let on the Burra Mine ‘a condition of the lease will be that the company will not merely hold the lease without performing work for some specific reason. Burra Caravan Park will receive up to £1,500 subsidy provided all works and claims were completed by 31 March 1966.  The amenities block should be completed by early February to serve 16 stands for caravans.

Burra Hospital has received a £5,552-14-7 bequest from the estate of the late Miss A. Collins.  This attracts a two for one subsidy from the Government, making it worth £16,658-3-9. Dogs Attack Sheep.  In the past week in the district 15 sheep have been killed and 100 mauled by dogs.  One dog was destroyed on Friday night, but more sheep were killed and mauled on Saturday night, proving that more than one dog has been involved.  Sergeant Teague is investigating and warns dog owners they can be held responsible for loss or injury caused to stock.  Uncontrolled dogs in any paddock etc. can be destroyed if worrying stock or in any paddock etc. where stock has recently been worried.

Weather.  In the past week 55 points of rain fell and reports in the district range from 80-90 points.  It is too late to do much good.

Accident.  A truck overturned at Hanson on Friday night.  It was owned by G.H. Adams, carrier of Camden Gardens and driven by James G. Beckett of Thebarton and was heading for Broken Hill.  The driver was dazzled by on-coming lights at the sharp turn and in avoiding the approaching car, rolled his vehicle.  The driver and passenger, A.S. Jones of Thebarton, escaped with minor injuries, but damage to the truck and its load is estimated at £1,000.

St Mary’s Organ Recital

On Sunday 14 November a concert celebrated the anniversary of the installation of the pipe organ.  Dr J.V. Peters, University of Adelaide Organist and Senior Lecturer of the Elder Conservatorium of Music, played the organ.  Over 150 people attended.  Scripture readings and prayers accompanied the music.   Music included three pieces by Samuel Wesley, a voluntary by William Walond and Henry Purcell’s Trumpet Tune & Air.  The Rector, Rev. G.D. Sibly, gave an address on the history of pipe organs and traced the origins of the St Mary’s instrument.  It was decided on 20 January 1901, after much discussion, to purchase a pipe organ costing not more than £350.  The instrument was dedicated and opened by the rector, Rev. Wightwick, on 22 October 1901.  Dr Harold Davies of the Elder Conservatorium played at the dedication.  The organ has 588 pipes ranging from 16 ft to 2 inches.  The second part of Dr Peter’s recital comprised music pf J.S. Bach: three chorale preludes and the Prelude and Fugue in G. major.

Cricket.  The Mokota Cricket Association honoured its new life members at a dinner in the Booborowie Hotel on 1 December.  Life Membership was conferred on Messrs Kitch Miller, Ken Deer, Bill Ashby, Ken Gill and A.L. Collins.  President J. McMahon presided. Mr Ken Deer was Association secretary and a long term player.  Kitch Miller played in the early matches and in Association teams, including a game on the Adelaide Oval when the Queen visited and met the players in 1954.  Mr Bill Ashby had a long association with the game as an administrator.  He was wicket keeper in Association matches for a long time.  Ken Gill was a fine batsman for Spalding and the first to score a double century in carnival matches in Adelaide and held the record for an opening partnership of 236.  Under his captaincy Mokota won three successive carnivals from 1953-55.  A.L. Collins made many centuries and his astute handling of the Mt Bryan team kept them on top for many years.

Miss Judith Field, daughter of Mr & Mrs Darrell Field of Burra, has had a most successful nursing career.  Last July, while nursing at Royal Adelaide Hospital, she obtained three credits and a gold medal in her examinations.  In the past year at Queen Victoria Maternity Hospital she topped the State in the Nurses’ Board Midwifery Examination.  She will marry Mr Kevin Pope on 18 December and hopes to continue nursing wherever Mr Pope serves as a school teacher.

Burra School Libraries

Following the success of the appeal for library funds, strong representations had to be made to the Education department to have the promise of subsidies honoured in full.  Upon realising that the general public was involved, the Education Department agreed to honour the promise and books are being purchased to the full value of £2,000.  The Department has also agreed to proceed with the necessary alterations to the library rooms as soon as possible.  The Appeal Committee is not satisfied that, after some delay and discussion, the Department is fully supporting and granting all requests made.  A large proportion of the indexing and cataloguing of library books has been completed and hours have been spent covering books.  The final cost of the libraries will be in the region of £7,000.  The sum raised in the appeal for book funds was £1,100.

Burra High School.  A group of 44 First & Second Year students had a recreation weekend camp at Parnanga National Fitness Council Camp at O’Sullivan’s Beach near Adelaide.  The group with the Headmaster, Miss D. Jones and Mr K. Schwartz travelled by train to Adelaide and then by hired coach.  The weekend was a tremendous success.

The 1965-66 Harvest has been delayed by rain and though the Burra silos took their first delivery on 24 November, only about 20,000 bushels have since come in. Mr Graham Heinrich for example at Worlds’ End reaped an 8-9 bag crop, but this year only a 3 bag crop.  The late rains evidently did more good than was expected and many farmers are reporting better results than they had feared.

The Burra Swimming Pool.  Letter from E.T. Baulderstone.

He explains that for the last few years the pool has been administered by the Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club, which has had a lot of difficulties in doing so.  At the recent AGM it was decided to ask the Corporation to take over the administration.  The Council saw the possibility of the pool not functioning and realised its importance in teaching young people to swim and in the relaxation and enjoyment it offered citizens.  The Corporation also considered the amount of effort and capital invested and so decided to accede to the request and to take over the administration.  The Council advertised for an attendant, but so far without success.  Finally the late Mr D. Morrison agreed to help, but unfortunately he fell ill and was confined to hospital.  Mr & Mrs W. Holness have opened the pool at weekends and some afternoons, but due to a lot of undue criticism do not feel inclined to continue.

[Mr Baulderstone says he does not blame them.]

The pool is in excellent condition, but will have to stay closed until we can get an attendant or attendants.  In conclusion he thanks, on behalf of the young people in particular who have enjoyed their swimming in the last two weeks, to thank Mr & Mrs Holness for their kind gesture.

Burra Swimming Pool is still without an attendant following the illness and subsequent death of Mr D. Morrison, who had been appointed caretaker on a five day basis with someone else to open it at weekends.  Mr G. Baulderstone opened it on Saturday and Sunday.  A public meeting is called for 2.30 p.m.  tomorrow (Wednesday) to discuss the possibility of a roster system.  The attendant opens the pool and handles the sale of drinks etc.  A standard of discipline must also be enforced.  Without an attendant the pool will have to remain closed.

Burra High School Speech Night was held in the Burra Town Hall on 14 December.  S.L. Tregenza, retired Principal of Brighton High School was the guest speaker.  The Hon. Member for Burra, P.H. Quirke, also attended.  Mrs Tregenza presented the prizes and Mr Quirke presented certificates and trophies to the boys and Mrs Quirke did the same to the girls.  Mr Darrell Field as Chairman of the High School Council was in the chair.

The headmaster Mr R.M. Farrow reported on the year:

We have recently seen the election in Mr Field of only the fourth Chairman of the High School Council.  This is a fine record of service for chairmen over such a long period.  Both Mr A.B. Riggs and Mr H.J.B. Jennison, past chairmen, are present and the latter only retired after 18 years of service and 12 as chairman.  Their wives also served long periods as members of the Council as well as on the Parents & Friends’ Association.

[Mr Farrow also welcomed the Mayor & Mayoress, Mr Finch Chairman of the DC and Mr Auhl, Headmaster of the Primary School and Mrs Auhl, as well as the religious instructors.]

Last year’s public examinations resulted in the awarding of 24 Intermediate Certificates and the completion of two others.  Four Leaving Certificates were gained and one was completed.  Three others were gained in the Supplementary Examinations.  Lynette Robinson and Denise Griffen won Intermediate Exhibitions and Eleanor Miller and Gregory Short gained Continuation Scholarships.

This year the club period has continued and sport has continued to play its vital role with inter-house matches and inter-school exchanges against Balaklava and Clare High Schools, while matches against Riverton will be played tomorrow. In the Inter-High School Sports Day Burra won the E.E. Williams Handicap Shield for the second successive year and only narrowly missed the Championship Shield.

The swimming carnival in March was an outstanding success.

In September 36 Intermediate and Leaving students accompanied by Miss Jones, Miss Briggs, Mr Morris and myself undertook a ten day tour to Sydney and Canberra – a very exciting and worthwhile trip and recently a party of 44 First and Second Year students had a recreational weekend at the Parnanga National Fitness Council Camp at O’Sullivan’s Beach, at which Mrs Jones, Mr Ayliffe, Mr Schwartz and Mr Hayward were energetic leaders.

The parent bodies have been very helpful and valuable.  Traditions such as the annual ball and the banquet always receive 100% support.  The banquet is to be held this coming Thursday.

Money has been set aside for the erection of changing rooms and the installation of fans in the iron rooms.  Subsidy will be granted when funds become available.  The Association has also provided additional furnishings for the sick room and crockery and an electric urn for what is still only a temporary staff room.

The High School Council in conjunction with the Primary School Committee has done excellent work and this has made successful representations to the Education Department to purchase land in front of the school.  The Council also supported my moves to have pathways in front of the school repaired.

Other moves, which I anticipate will come to fruition soon, are for the remodelling of the toilets and headmaster’s office, paving of the yard and the provision of proper staff facilities.  The school still lacks many of the desirable features that modern education needs for effectiveness.

One innovation this year was an open night when teachers were available for interview by parents who were also invited to visit classrooms as they saw fit.

For a long time the High school has followed the traditional academic courses leading to Intermediate and Leaving Public Examinations.  I am pleased, if a little apprehensive that next year we are to have an alternative course leading to an internal Intermediate Certificate.  This should cater for a large percentage of students, while still giving the enlightenment which we claim an education should do.

In spite of all the promise here; I still fear the problem of the closed mind.  There is an absence in the district at large and in the school itself of an academic climate.  There is little point in the school trying to open up the mind of the child unless firstly he is encouraged and inspired by at least some other lively minds and worthwhile intellectual pursuits outside of school and unless there is some opportunity to continue his intellectual growth once he has left school.

[Mr Farrow then developed this theme at some length.  He went on to speak of the donors of prizes and trophies and to thank those who organised the hall.  He spoke also of the House system and wished departing students well.]

Staff changes: Mr Ayliffe has transferred to Norwood High School and Miss E.J. Newman of Findon High School has been appointed Senior Mistress at Burra.

Characteristics of the paper in 1965

A fair coverage for Burra, but a lot on outlying areas like Hallett, Spalding and Farrell Flat.

Page 1

Dominated by news, but this is by no means confined to Burra news.

Pages 2 & 3

Large advertisements and public notices and sales and these often extend to page 3.  There may be some news also on page 3.

Pages 4, 5 & 6

Half at least is advertising.  As far as news is concerned these pages are dominated by sports results.  Other prominent features are reports of Annual General Meetings of clubs and other organisations such as church organisations and the CWA along with some reports of their meetings.

Page 7

The ‘Cash Column’ is often here, though it sometimes appears elsewhere and shares space with other items typical of pages 4, 5 & 6.

Page 8

Advertising and a large section of 50 and 25 years ago in the paper, along with news from other districts.  The reports from past years can also wander onto other pages.

Pages 9 & 10

These extra pages sometimes appear and continue the style of pages 4, 5 & 6.

Supplements are not uncommon, but vary in size and are sometimes single-sided.

Burra CWA building is now free of debt.  Treasurer Mrs H. Crump made the last payment to the Savings Bank after the last meeting.  It is hoped a new fence will soon be erected between the CWA property and those of the M&BHA and Mr & Mrs P. Byles.

A minute of appreciation was recorded for the effort of Mrs Phillips in hiring out crockery over recent years.   This has raised almost £80, but will now be discontinued due to the time and effort required.  Following the Christmas meeting the branch has gone into recess until 17 March.

Elders-GM.  After a stay of 6½ years the Chief Clerk at Burra Mr R.N. Jenkins has been transferred to Bordertown.  While in Burra ‘Jenks’ has been associated with the football, tennis and table tennis.  He was also for a time secretary of the Swimming Club and a member of the Rural Youth Club.  He is replaced by Mr G.J. Timmins of Strathalbyn.

From Alice Springs, after a stay of several years, Mr Ray Kotz transfers to Gawler later this month.

The Learn to Swim Campaign has about 160 children taking part at Burra.  This is about 30 fewer than in 1965, but on a par with 1964.

Jack Kellaway (82) of Croydon has renewed his subscription to the paper and says most of his family worked in the old Burra Mine at some time or other.  His grandfather, William Kellaway, came out from Cornwall about 106 years ago and worked in the mine.

Burra Silos have received an intake closer to normal than had been expected, with about 175,000 bushels up to yesterday.  This compares with 190,000 bushels taken to the same time in the 1964-65 season.  The quality has been good.

Fires.  The Farrell Flat area has had two fires recently.

On 30 December 20-30 acres of grass and some fencing was burnt when fire broke out just north of the town.

On 7 and 8 January there were fires near Lodge Hill.

Accident/Obituaries.

Over the New Year weekend five young people were killed in a light plane crash at Canopus Station east of Burra.  The pilot was Russell Tiver (23) the son of Mr & Mrs M.H. Tiver of Burra.  He had been conducting sight-seeing tours over the 400,000 acre property, owned by Mr W.G. Snell, when the accident occurred.  The passengers were:

David Stanley Radford (15) and William John Radford (12) who were the only children of David Radford of Canegrass Station.  And also Janne Elizabeth Daniel (16) and Peter John Daniel (13) who were the only children of Mr & Mrs S.D. Daniel of Kulpara.

A private funeral was conducted at Burra Cemetery for Mr Tiver and for the others private services were held in Adelaide.

[Russell Gordon Tiver born 8 July 1942 Abberton Park, Burra: died 1 January 1966 Canopus Station.]

89, 3, 25 January 1966 page 3

Burra Mine

Exploration rights for the Burra Mine have been let.  Drilling will start within a few days. The Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan announced this today.  The rights have been granted to Mines Exploration Pty Ltd on behalf of Broken Hill South Ltd, North Broken Hill Ltd, Electrolitic Zinc Co. of Australia Ltd and McPhar Geophysics Ltd.  Exploration work by the Department of Mines has shown that redevelopment of low grade oxidised ore in the old mine was a sound economic proposal and that further exploration for primary ore near the old workings was worth while.  Mines Exploration Pty Ltd represented a predominantly Australian group.  The company would expend a large sum in further testing of the low grade oxidised ore and also the deep ore deposits.  A decision on whether it would be economic to establish a mining treatment project for oxidised ore can be expected within twelve months.

Decimal Currency

The Burra Post Office is well organised to handle the change to decimal currency on 14 February.

Letters for one ounce will then cost 4 c.

Each additional ounce will cost 3 c.

Aerograms will cost 9 c.

Airmail letters to Europe will be 25 c. per half-ounce.

A three-minute telephone call to Adelaide will be 40 c. at day rates and 30 c. for evening rates.

Decimal currency postage stamps will be available from 7 February, but must not be used before 14 February.

In this week the stamps will only be available in full sheets or booklets of 15.

Obituary.  Mr Willie (Bill) Voumard died on Thursday night aged 90.  [There was also a death notice on page 2.]

He was born in Berne, Switzerland, 19 October 1875 and came to Australia aged 6.*  The family came to live at Copperhouse and moved into Burra when he was aged 9.  He died in the house that had been his home for 81 years.  In early life he worked on a number of eastern pastoral properties.  He was an enthusiastic cyclist and on many occasions would ride 50 or 60 miles from his place of employment to a sports meeting and then compete in events.  He won a number of medals and trophies and on one such occasion won a 50 mile race in a little over two hours.  He continued to ride his bike in Burra up to the time of his death.  In 1906 he married Florence Minetta Brandt and they had eight children before she died in 1924.  He then left the ‘Eastern’ Country and came to work in Burra for the Burra Town Council until retiring some years ago.  In 1927 he married Clara Ellen McLennan who died in 1957.  He is survived by Fred, Ruby (Mrs Jack Rowe), Jack, Lance, Jean (Mrs Murray Opperman), May (Mrs Joff Parkes), Ida (Mrs Norman Hyde) and Edna (Mrs Jack O’Keefe).

[William Voumard died 10 February 1966, Burra.]

[*A correction was printed 89, 7, 22 February 1966, page 4.  Mrs M.A. Taylor of Burra North has advised that the late Mr W. Voumard came to Australia in 1876 aged 6 months not 6 years.  Mrs Taylor is a sister to Mr Voumard and was born at Copperhouse 27 April 1878.]

89, 9, 8 March 1966 page 5

Burra Branch of the National Trust of SA: Letter to the Editor

Burra is a unique town and this is often more apparent to visitors than to the locals.  Its history lies not so much in written records as in its buildings and walls, its Cornish cottages and its place names.  [A discussion of some of these places then follows.]

The National Trust Branch was formed because a number of people felt that the preservation of Burra’s fascinating past could not much longer be left merely to chance, especially with the possibility of renewed mining and the expansion which could result.  Items of historical interest are scattered in homes and sheds and are hidden in places where they could be forgotten.  The Trust aims to collect such items and to house them in a proper building where they can be preserved and made available to all our people, visitors and tourists and to our children as a record that can be seen and touched.  Other towns in SA with a much smaller role in the history of the state have begun to preserve their past and we are sure the people of Burra and District will also want to preserve their own history.

If there is a symbol of Burra it surely is Johnny Green.

Your donation can help our efforts to do this, whether with money or historical items.  The aim is to raise $1,600 to set up the museum.

‘Dollar Bill’ educational comic strip.  Bill is buying 12 oranges for 40 c. and 1 lb of grapes for 25 c.

Kooringa in 1866 from the SA Gazetteer of 1867.

Kooringa is a postal township on the Burra Creek about 50 miles from Kapunda and has daily communication with Adelaide by mail coach to Kapunda and thence by rail to Adelaide.  It is situated on very irregular ground, broken by fissures and watercourses.  The situation and creek divide the township, which is scattered over a considerable area.  There is no corporation or district council, though efforts are being made to obtain the former.  It has an Institute, post office, money order office and telegraph station.  It is surrounded by a chain of undulating hills in many parts of which copper is found along with promising specimens of silver and lead ore – this in addition to the Burra Burra Mine.

While there are no rivers near Kooringa there are the Burra, Baldina and Gum Creeks – but in summer only waterholes can be relied upon.  Kooringa has no mills, but there is a brewery and candle manufacturer.  It is principally a mining and pastoral centre with a few sections under wheat cultivation.

On addition to the Burra Burra Mine there are the All Nations Mine, Flinders Mine, Scrubbers Camp Mine, Kingston Mine and Karkulto Mine.  The two former are worked by a Melbourne Company who are sanguine of success.  Scrubbers Mine is about 28 miles north and a main lode is expected to be struck soon.  Kingston Mine is a further 7 miles northeast.  Karkulto Mine is owned by the SA Mining Association and is 15 miles southeast of Kooringa.  It principally produces iron ore used in smelting copper.  The nearest places are:

Redruth, 1 mile northwest

Hampton, 1½ miles northeast

Copperhouse, 2 miles west

Sod Hut, 8 miles along the Adelaide Road.

The nearest townships are Mintaro and Clare, with which there is communication by Rounsevell’s Coach.  Though Kooringa has no benevolent asylum, a benevolent association has been active for the relief of the poor.  There is a hospital built by the SA Mining Association expressly for the accommodation of their miners, but accessible to the poorer classes on obtaining the permission of the mining authorities.

Hotels in Kooringa are the Burra, Miners’ Arms and the Pig and Whistle.

There is a National Bank branch, a public pound and a Masonic Lodge, Oddfellows’ Lodge and a Foresters Court.  The population of Kooringa, Redruth, Aberdeen and Hampton is about 3,100 with about 460 houses, but of these about 120 are uninhabited.  A corporation would remedy many of the evils.  The approaches to the cemetery are extremely bad and even dangerous.  In crossing creeks and water courses the remains of the dead have more than once been precipitated to the ground.  The present road between Kooringa and Redruth is extremely bad.  The Burra Electoral District is represented in the Legislative Assembly by J.B .Neales and A. McCullock [sic].

Burra Show Society

Annual Report of the President, M. Stockman.

Burra show was held on 9 October in ideal fine cool weather.	It was very successful with gate takings of £258 – a record for many years.  Immediate Past President Mr Rex Warnes, who is also President of the Royal Adelaide Show, opened our show.

Horses in action had a record 548 entries.  Mr Roy Jeffrey had the marathon job of judging this section.  We must consider having two rings going at once to reduce the time this year.

The number of entries in the sheep section continues to disappoint.

Wool was well represented.

I regret to report the deaths of two valuable supporters: Mr J.R. Field who was a member of the finance committee for a number of years and Mr Roy W. Lloyd who was a head steward and exhibitor for many years.

Thanks also go to Mr Bob Fuss for his ongoing work in altering fixtures and undertaking repairs.  He has been doing this for years and we hope will do so for many more.

Thanks also go to our secretaries Mr & Mrs Barry Taylor and the society will be the poorer for their transfer to another district and, of course, thanks go to the Vice-Presidents and the committee.

Burra Primary School, Annual Parents’ Meeting

Last year 40 attended.  This year was closer to average with just 19, even though 129 families are represented in the school.  This is disappointing.

Elected: Chairman, Mr R. Moreland; Secretary-Treasurer, Mr D. Bannister.

In the past year the new school oval was sown and is now in an excellent condition.  Goal posts will be erected next week.  Sports Day 1965 was held on the War Memorial Oval and was a great success.  Arbor Day was held on 13 August when John Riggs was guest speaker.  The Passing Out Parade was held on 16 December, when R. Moreland and Mrs Carpenter presented the prizes.  Following discussions with ETSA and the Public Buildings Department a new power line has been laid and rewiring of the school is about to commence.  This will allow more lights and heaters.  Four fans have been purchased for the wooden rooms.  All subsidies have now been granted for the library and we can now go ahead with the final setting up of the library.  The school is to be repainted at the end of April at a cost of $11,000.  A grant of $3,000 from the Highways Department will allow all access roads to be sealed.  The grounds in front of the school are in the process of being transferred to the Education Department with the aid of the Town Council.

Burra RSL President (H. Cornelius) Annual Report

The Anzac Parade and Service were held as usual.  Attendance was somewhat marred due to the parade the following day in Adelaide.  Rev. G.D. Sibly conducted the service.  The Marananga Band led the march and supplied the music for the service.  The evening service was held in St Mary’s and was conducted by Revs Sibly and Lind.  Rev. Sibly also conducted the Remembrance Day Service on 11 November.  David Marshall’s Band from Morgan supplied music for our annual ball.  This was successful despite heavy rain with thunder and lightning and a power failure during the preceding cocktail party.  Badges were sold for Anzac, Legacy, Myrtle Bank and Poppy Day.  On each occasion $40 to $50 was taken.  We continue to support two Legacy wards.  Two of our members left the town during the year: Herb. Riggs, a WWI digger and W. (Bill) Kotz, A WWII digger.  Two diggers died during the period: Les. Hirschausen and Les. James.

[The usual thanks were extended to the committee members, the Ladies’ Auxiliary etc.]

Burra 100 Years Ago.  (Continued from last week.)

Redruth or Aberdeen is a small mining township in the Hundred of Kooringa.  It adjoins the Burra Mine on the eastern side of Burra Creek.  On the western side is a small township called Aberdeen.

[This messy description is in the original.]

The two are united by an excellent stone bridge with one arch and a span of 60 feet.

[This is incorrect: while there were probably stone abutments, the bridge was of timber and by 1879 the decay of the wood caused its replacement with a steel structure.]

The towns are supplies with water from wells about 30 feet deep on the surrounding hills.  Redruth is chiefly occupied by miners from the Burra Mine and smelters from the Kooringa Smelting Works.  There is a mine, the Bon Accord, not now working, adjoining the Burra Mine, and although large sums have been spent no copper has been found over the Burra Burra Mine boundary, though within a few yards of that boundary some of the richest ore raised ahs been discovered.

Communication with Hampton (½ mile), Kooringa (1 mile) and Copperhouse (1½ miles) in by rough bush roads and with Adelaide by four-wheeled coach via Kapunda and thence by rail.  There is one hospital for miners’ use only, supported by the mine.

Hotels are in Redruth, the Bushman’s Home and the Court House and in Aberdeen, the Smelters’ Home and the White Hart, recently transferred from Copperhouse.

[This ‘transfer’ has no support elsewhere.  The archaeological survey when the Ludgvan Street deviation was put in during the late 1980s reported the following points about the White Hart:

Allotments 147 & 148 of Aberdeen were sold September 1849 from Morehead & Young to William Spargo for £20.

Spargo erected a dwelling house and brewery.

13 March 1851 Spargo sold the site to John Magor for £200.  The conveyance is dated 16 July 1852.  The issue of a liquor license [in 1852] suggests the White Hart was constructed by then.

The report then traces the ownership of the property and of the licence to its demise as a hotel.  Mrs Mary Mowatt was the last licensee.

She surrendered the licence in 1892, but apparently left in 1888 to run the Old Lion in North Adelaide.

The owner in 1888 was Mrs Mary Ann Reed who died in 1889 and the property then vested in her son Richard Reed.

An advertisement in the ‘Burra Record’ 18 November 1887 says it is being conducted as a Temperance Hotel, suggesting that Mrs Mowatt had left by then and the hotel licence was no longer active.

References to its operation as a temperance hotel continue through to at least 1894.

The same paper records the destruction of the building by fire 14 March 1916, when it is said to be owned by James Reed and to have then been used as the home of Mrs A. Sara and also in part to have housed the Boy Scouts.  James Reed was a son of Richard Reed.

Mrs A. Sara (1859-1931) was the widow of George Sara (1839-1903) and a sister to James Reed.]

There are more hotels in these towns than in Kooringa because there the land is on leasehold from the mining company and the landlord will not allow more than three hotels.  In Redruth and Aberdeen they are built on freehold land.

The surrounding country is undulating and hilly.  All timber within 20 miles has been cut and used on the mine.  Not a tree can be seen within five miles and beyond that only on long purchased property.

Redruth contains a commodious court house, a well-built gaol (the furthest north) capable of accommodating 30 prisoners, and a police station.  It also contains a Wesleyan, a German Lutheran and a Primitive Methodist Chapel.  There is a private licensed school of nearly 100 scholars.

Burra Burra DC

The installation of a second-hand crusher should result in improved open surface roads in the district.

The resultant materials are more easily consolidated prior to the application of bitumen.  This has been seen in the Burra School approaches and sections of Smelts Road.

The Council investigated the use of a grid-roller, but this left two-inch stones embedded in the surface.  Initially the results were good, but subsequent grading saw this larger material ripped from the surface.  Trials using a ‘rock-buster’ also proved unsatisfactory.  A unit available at Penola proved to be the answer.  At Penola it was a fixture, but it has now been made mobile.  This second-hand crusher with modifications has been obtained for $7,000.  A new crusher of this type would cost $20,000 to$ 24,000.  Depending on the size of the stone required it can produce from 200 to 400 yards per day.  [The report goes on to give further details of its operation.]

Burra National Trust held its AGM at Burra Town Hall on 5 April.  Elected: President, A. Tennant; Vice-President, S.J. Woollacott; Treasurer, Miss Marcia Tiver and Secretary, Miss Mary Woollacott.

The Trust is still collecting items and donations for its Market Square Museum project.  The appeal will close on 29 April, with the opening of the museum scheduled for late September.

The President’s Report

The Trust wishes to see Paxton Square preserved and made enquiries about taking over from the Lewis Trust.  This revealed that it would be likely to involved long and costly legal proceedings and so further action has been deferred indefinitely.  The Trust appreciates the moving of the jinker to its present central site.

Dower’s old shop was purchased by the President for $1,000 and presented to the National Trust Burra Branch free of encumbrances.  The title is held by Headquarters, but control of the building and its maintenance rests with the Burra Branch.  The cost of repairs has been $1,186.  This is much more than anticipated, but involved repairs common to old buildings to most of the guttering and the complete replastering of the front room.  A wall was removed to make a good-sized room for display.  The three other rooms have not yet had work done on them and in time they will need replastering and new floors due to termite damage.  Headquarters loaned $420 for repairs (to be paid back without interest).  The appeal for funds so far has realised $895.80 of the $1,600 aimed for.

Some gifts for display have been received for which the Trust is appreciative.

Trust Headquarters feels that the dugouts are in such a poor state of repair that maintenance is beyond the present finances of the branch.  Headquarters is also addressing the old Reformatory and is contacting the appropriate authorities to prevent demolition.

Redruth Methodist Church

Last Sunday the Rev. H. Alvey dedicated the new electronic Hammond organ to the memory of the late Edwin and Hilda Finch.  He was assisted by Rev. M. Lind.  The organ was presented to the church by the sons of the deceased, Norman and Murray Finch.  The organist, Mrs J. Oates, brought out the full capabilities of the organ in a first class manner.  The occasion was the culmination of the church’s 115th Anniversary celebrations.  Rev. Alvey was the guest speaker, having been the circuit minister 1924-27.  At the public meeting last night he presented his informative address on Burra – its Mines and Methodism, which he had presented first to the Methodist Historical Society in 1960.

Obituary.  The late A.B. Riggs.

Mr Alf Riggs was born in Burra 26 March 1881 and was engaged in the pastoral industry, while also taking a very active part in civic affairs.  After his education at Burra School he took the position of book-keeper with Drew & Crewes before joining his father and brothers on their Murkaby property east of Burra.  In 1913 he married Miss Myrtle Fuss of Aberdeen and they lived first at Murkaby before moving to Burra North in 1919 and in 1924 to his later residence on Smelts Road.  In 1924 he was also made a JP.  He was a Town Councillor for North Ward for several years before becoming Mayor for 1929-30.  He was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board and active in the Redruth Methodist Church, being a Circuit Steward.  He maintained a keen interest in the pastoral industry and was a member of the Stockowners’ Association of SA.  He was made a life member of the Agricultural Bureau and was an active committeeman of the Burra Show Society, and had also held the presidency.  He was actively associated with the sheep dog trials when they were held in Burra.  Mr Riggs had great interest in Burra Primary and High Schools.  He was a member of the Primary School Committee and later of the High School Council, of which he was Chairman for several terms.  Riggs House at BHS is named after him, in recognition of his years of service.  He was interested in most of the town’s sports, but most particularly in rifle shooting.  During WWII he was a member of the Fathers’ Association and secretary of the committee that farewelled servicemen.  He was a keen Freemason and was Master of all the Kooringa Lodges as well as treasurer for many years.  He was also a keen reader and served on the Committee of the Burra Library, where he was granted Life Membership.  He is survived by a widow, two daughters and one son.

[Alfred Benjamin Riggs born 26 March 1881 Mullaby: died 24 April 1866 Burra North.

Daughters, Mavis Jean and Lois and son, Brian Alfred.]

Burra Silo

The new grain silo now under construction at Burra North will enable bulk barley to be handled in the coming season.  Although this second silo at Burra is intended primarily for wheat, it will accept barley for direct trucking during the coming season.  Two grades can be accepted – one in each cell, but this will only be prior to the commencement of the wheat intake or during a break in the wheat harvest.  Work has been going on for some time.  Pouring of the cells began at 7.30 a.m. yesterday.

The rest of column 1 is unreadable

Once pouring begins it is necessary to continue in 12-hour shifts with 25 men employed on each shift.  The large mixer handles half a cubic yard of mix every three minutes.  The forming, about four feet high all round the complete shape of the silo, is automatically lifted in a working cycle of three-quarters of an inch every four minutes.  About 30 hydraulic jacks are attached to the one inch rods, which continue up through the walls, forming part of the reinforcing.  Parallel reinforcing rods are also placed every five inches for the first 50-60 feet and then every three inches, reverting to every five inches near the top.  The concrete is tipped from the hopper into a holding bin and is distributed manually around the forming using a wheelbarrow and then consolidated with a vibrator.  Given good conditions 15 to 16 feet can be poured in a 12-hour shift.

The contracting party is C.H. Martin Ltd.  When completed the silo will hold 111,000 bushels of grain.

Burra Caravan Park was officially opened on Friday morning by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz, in fine, but very windy conditions.  Mr Pollnitz said the first class facilities would bring added prosperity to the town.

C.P. Mountford, the noted anthropologist, was born in Hallett and educated there until the age of 11.  Mr Mountford passed through Burra on Friday on his way to inspect some cave paintings in a remote part of Wilpena Pound.  As a colleague of Mr Pollnitz he was present also at the opening of the caravan park.  He describes himself as an amateur anthropologist, but has spent forty years in study and practical research.  One of his best-known books is entitled Brown Men and Red Sand.

Burra Town Council intends to beautify the Burra Creek area between the Red Bridge and the northern end of the caravan park, by planting additional trees and/or shrubs.

Burra & District Ambulance Association has decided to apply to the St John Council for a subsidy on a new ambulance.  The present ambulance is considered inadequate.  It would be retained as a mobile first aid room as its trade in value is negligible.  It has completed c. 25,000 miles.  The Association also feels it is time for the erection of a worthy building.  A membership drive will also be held.

Aberdeen Basketball Club organised an entertainment at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night with Eddie white’s Band from Adelaide and with TV personality Ernie Sigley as guest artist.  315 people attended.  Car troubles delayed Me Sigley’s arrival, but be compensated by performing for the entire evening instead of for a much shorter period.  The evening was a success.

Messrs H.L. Cullen & Son will complete 17 years on the Eastern Mail Run when the contract with the PMG expires at the end of the month.  They have covered nearly 350,000 miles on the 376 mile trip each week.  Added to that is the general carrying of many more thousands of miles.  In the earlier days the route was a mere track and occasionally the truck was bogged down to its tray.  Despite this there has been only one occasion when the run was not completed in the three day schedule of Friday to Sunday.  On that occasion they were not back until the following Thursday.  On the 376 mile trip there are only five ramps, but over 100 gates to open and close.  Mr Cullen will continue his general carrying business, but from Friday the mail run will be operated by Mr I.T. Allen.

Mr B.G. Dangerfield, Tree Advisory Officer for the Botanic Gardens, inspected the Burra Creek area from the Red Bridge to the Caravan Park.  He has recommended the removal of 25 pines because they are growing too close together and the thinning will allow each to achieve a better shape.  Their loss should be compensated by replanting with variations in species at strategic points.  He has recommended planting 7 red gums, 9 red ironbarks, 3 SA bluegums.  Rather surprisingly he also recommended planting 10 pepper trees to act as screens hiding the ugly rear of buildings and sheds.  Three kurrajongs were recommended for shade in the parking area at the swimming pool and four claret ashes for shade in the lawned areas.  He also recommended two more weeping willows.

Mr A.J. Hill (Joff) began as Assistant District Clerk with the BBDC in 1936 and later became Town Clerk and Chief Administrative Officer of Northcote in Victoria.  He was educated at Burra and apart from five years in the RAAF has pursued a career in Municipal Government.  After the war Mr Hill resumed work with the BBDC before moving to the position of Treasurer and Accountant with the city of Williamstown in Victoria.  After nine years in this capacity he accepted the position of Town Clerk with the Kyabram Borough Council and after eighteen months moved to Northcote as Deputy Town Clerk, a position he has held for the past ten years.  While living in Burra, Joff was well known as a keen tennis player and was a popular member of the Kooringa Football Team.

Weather.

Sunday’s weather was dominated by gale force winds, but also featured rain, hail and snow.  East of the ranges it was dust that accompanied the wind.  Early on Sunday night light snow fell in Burra with heavier falls at Booborowie North and Hallett.  Light rain fell on Monday and the post office registered 33 points to 9 a.m.  At Princess Royal 58 points fell.  By Tuesday morning falls of up to one inch were reported from Hanson, Farrell Flat and Koonoona.  Mongolata reported 33 points and Baldina 38.  Mt Bryan East received 63.

St Mary’s Music Recital on Sunday last was held in icy conditions and only about 35 people braved the weather.  [The program is reviewed.]  The collection has brought the total to within a few dollars of the $400 target for improving the church’s surroundings.

Burra Mine

The Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan, in response to a question in Parliament said that exploration work at Burra Mine was continuing.  At present there were two percussion drills operating in and around the open cut and a diamond drill south of the open cut.  A fourth (diamond) drill is on a site about a mile south and is awaiting a crew to continue.  Metallurgical work is also continuing on the problem of extracting the copper from the oxidised leavings.

The Minister also assured the Hon. R.A. Geddes that not only was the company exploring to ascertain whether copper in commercial quantities could be found, but under the terms of the lease the company will be finally treating the proven low grade ore and extracting copper from the mullock that will be left.

Members of the Gem & Mineral Section of the Weapons Research Establishment Institute will hold a field day at the Burra Mine.  Extensive notes have been prepared for the group on the history of the area – much of the material from Rev. Harry Alvey now living in Payneham.  About 100 people are expected to participate in the inspection of the mine area.

Thefts.  For the second time since the start of July articles have been stolen from a station sedan garaged at the Bon Accord Hotel.  On Saturday the car was broken into and a new tyre stolen.  Early in July the items stolen included a spare wheel and tyre, a car jack, wheel-brace, transistor radio and an umbrella.  The vehicle is owned by the licensee Mr F.K. Thurgood.

Booborowie Methodists & Anglicans will hold a joint service at the Anglican Church on Sunday 28 August.  Spalding Methodist Circuit Minister Rev. David Pill will read the lesson.  The address will be given by Rev. Keith Seaman of the Central Methodist Mission, who will speak on the work of the Christian Television Association.

Burra Sewerage Scheme.  Mr D. Wilson of the Central Board of health paid a visit to Burra in the week and advised on progress of the communal drainage scheme for sewage in Burra’s main street area.  Plans and specifications would be made available to the Town Council within a month, he said.

Burra High School held a successful Ball in Burra Town Hall on Friday 19 August.  It was organised by the Parents & Friends’ Association.  Door takings exceeded $200.  Music was provided by a seven-piece orchestra from the city.

St Mary’s Church, Burra, Sunday 21 August

Almost 400 people attended special services.  At 10 a.m. a procession entered the church for the dedication of the sanctuary lamp.  Among those entering were the designer of the lamp, Neville Rohlach, the Sub-Deacon for the service the Rector Rev. Geoffrey Dean Sibly and the Bishop the Rt Rev. Donald Redding.  The lamp had been hung and wired by Messrs B. & M. Beinke and was dedicated by Bishop Redding in memory of John Robert Field.

The lamp was then switched on and will glow all the year except for Good Friday and Holy Saturday.

A service of the Sacrament of Confirmation followed.  [Those received into the church are listed.]

The solemn Eucharist followed with almost 200 communicants.  After that the Historic Room was opened by Mrs John Jacka of ‘Myola’ Gum Creek.  Bishop Redding dedicated the room, which is intended as a memorial to former parish priests of Burra Parish.  A plaque above the doorway records main events.  Among other historic items are photographs of all the former priests and details of the church buildings and of that proposed for Burra North (but never built).

The church grounds have recently been renovated and the toilets rebuilt.

A luncheon followed.

A hand-woven scarf made by Mr Jack Clemson in Burra Hospital was presented to Bishop Redding.  Special thanks were expressed to Dr J.V. Peters who came to play the organ and to the choir of Hillcrest and their choirmaster John Symons and to Mr & Mrs Frank Reed for hosting the choir.  In all over 70 people had contributed to making the day a success and a remarkable occasion in St Mary’s history.

The Market Square Museum Opening

Proceedings began with a small procession of horse drawn vehicles and Mr Les Warnes in his Newton Bennet car c. 1910 vintage.  Mr Bob Radford drove the governess cart from Princess Royal, Mal Kellock drove a buggy and Mr Arnold Heinrich drove a cart.  [Official guests were as listed in last week’s paper.]

Several people spoke before Mr Shard declared the Museum open.

Mr Baulderstone said that for quite a while the old jinker had been parked in a corner of the Wayville Showgrounds and had been returned to Burra through the efforts of the Town Council, to be housed now near the National Trust Museum.

Mr Tennant said that Mr H.C .Morphett, a past president of the National Trust had come to Burra in about 1963 and following his visit a meeting was called to see if a branch could be formed here.  The museum was a modest beginning to look after items of past years before they were lost forever.  Mr Tennant thanked all those who had donated items.  Mr Shard spoke of the National Trust in general and its expanding role in the preservation of the past.  Afternoon tea in the Town Hall followed an inspection of the Museum.

Fire

A fire broke our just before 6 a.m. in the home of Mr & Mrs R. Spackman in Chapel Street.  Mr & Mrs Spackman were awakened by the smell of smoke and saw flames coming from the back bedroom where their six-year-old son Peter was sleeping.  He escaped with slight burns to his head.  Mr Spackman attempted to extinguish the fire with a garden hose while Mrs Spackman was getting four other children out of the house.  (Two of the boys were not at home at the time.)  The fire brigade saved the front area of the house, which was not insured.  Damage is estimated at c. $1,500.  The cause of the fire is unknown.  Many locals have given donations of clothing etc. and money has been given by the Burra Benevolent Fund and the PMG Distress Fund.  Mrs D. Carpenter of Burra North has provided temporary accommodation.  The adjoining home of Mr & Mrs W.H .Wahlert was saved, but suffered extensive smoke damage.

Legislative Council

The death of the Hon. C.C. Dudley Octoman has caused a by-election for the Northern District next Saturday 29 October.  [In the advertising article for the Liberal Party a neat constitutional history is given of the Legislative Council over the preceding century or so.]

1836-42	The control of the colony was largely in the hands of the Governor with the Board of Colonization Commissioners in control of emigration and revenues from the sale of land.

1842	SA became a Crown Colony with the Governor controlling the administration, aided by a seven-man nominated Council.

1851	The Council was changed to 16 elected members and 8 nominated members.

1857	Responsible Government was granted with a bicameral system using the secret ballot for the first time.  From 1857 to 1882 the Legislative Council comprised 18 members elected on a property qualification and returned by the whole province.

1882-1902	The 24 members were returned from 4 districts.

1902	The Legislative Council was reduced to 18 members.

1915-1966	The Legislative Council comprised 20 members.  The state was divided into three Country and two Metropolitan Districts, each returning four members.  (Northern, Midland, Southern Districts in the Country and Central No. 1 and Central No. 2 for the city.)

The Northern District is vast, stretching from Renmark to Port Lincoln and to the Northern Territory border and from the western to the eastern borders.  It covers nine House of Assembly electorates.

The four members are elected for six year terms, with half retiring usually every three years.

Membership is restricted to:

British subject for at least 30 years and resident in SA for 3 years.

Voters must be either owners of a freehold estate of clear value $100, leaseholders of an estate of clear annual value of $40 on a lease for at least three years or with right of purchase.

Or be a registered proprietor of a Crown Lease on which improvements value at least $100.

Or be an inhabitant occupying a dwelling house.  (i.e. anyone paying rent.)

Or be a returned serviceman or woman.

Be aged at least 21 years (unless entitled under the serviceman or woman provision.)

Voting is not compulsory.

Had Mr Playford been returned at the last election the vote would have been extended to spouses of those entitled to vote.

[The article is inserted by the Liberal Party and authorised by P.H .Quirke MP and ends by urging a vote for Arthur Whyte, the Liberal Candidate.]

Burra Pictures

The Secretary of the Burra Pictures Committee Mr A.R. Graham reports on a severe decline in attendance.  The operation has been making a loss for the past twelve months except for a few nights.  The cost of running is c. $40 a show, but on some nights receipts have been as low as $16 and on a number of nights in the range $20-$25. The secretary seeks any suggestions, as he would like to see the pictures continue, but this cannot be done with continued losses.

Burra CWA, the first branch in SA, has celebrated its 40th birthday, having been established by the late Mrs I.J. Warnes in 1926.

The CWA now has some 13,000 members.

At the Burra celebrations on Friday seven of the foundation members were present when Mrs E.T. Baulderstone was host to a largely attended birthday party in the RSL Hall.  This meeting was also the branch’s ‘National Day’ meeting, with Mexico as the subject for 1966.

89, 48, 6 December 1966 page 1

Weather

November was very dry and farmers were preparing to harvest grain following several centuries.  The eastern pastoral areas have been in drought.  It began to rain on Wednesday and continued through the week with falls of from 3 to 5 inches.

Until Saturday night the rain had been fairly light, but constant with only a few heavy showers.  Thundery conditions on Saturday and Sunday brought much heavier falls and run-off resulting in some washaways and damage to fencing.  Some water catchments to the east were replenished, but not to the same extend as in the inside country.  Most wheat seems to be standing the wet quite well with only a few reports of ‘shooting’.

Some barley and oats crops have been badly affected.  Considerable sheep losses have been reported due to the sudden change in temperatures and crowding in the corners of paddocks, leading to smothering.  Losses of up to 300 and perhaps more have been mentioned.  Overall these have been the best pastoral rains for years.

During the week Booborowie reported 343 points, Hallett 362, Mt Bryan 451, Burra 384, World’s End 327 and Mt Bryan East 431.  To the east Balah got 212, Braemar 379, Woolgangi 309, Redcliffe 500, Koomooloo 290, Pine Valley, 358, Old Koomooloo 300, Glenora 359, Thistlebeds 448, Baldina 480 and Mallett 400.

Burra Swimming Pool has had some minor repairs and will be ready to open again in a day or two.  It is to be open every night when practicable in the swimming season.

Burra Primary School has announced that through the generosity of Mr Andrew Tennant an annual prize will be awarded in perpetuity to the Dux of the school each year.  A sum has been invested to yield approximately $20 p.a.  The award will go to the student with best results in the Progress Certificate Examination.

Burra Town Council will sponsor trial runs of salvaging paper waste through the town.  A suggestion has been made that any income so derived should go towards replacing the badly worn floor in the Town Hall.

Burra Silos wheat intake is expected to reach 300,000 bushels this season.  The first load from V.G. & M.K. Simpson of Mt Bryan was delivered on 29 November.  The wheat has been of good quality despite the rains in December and has averaged 62 lb per bushel.  The 264, 324 bushels received to Monday is the greatest intake since bulk receivals at Burra.  The second silo has contributed to this.  Very little local wheat has gone elsewhere and very little from outside the district has been delivered at Burra.  Both silos were filled to capacity on 3 January.

Learn to Swim Campaign.  At Burra 140-160 youngsters are receiving instruction.  About 70 of them are taking part for the first time.  Mr Paul Tattersall is being assisted by Miss Rosemary Reed and Russell Nicholls.  Miss Sue Murphy will join them next week.

Seat Belts.  New cars registered after 1 January 1967 must be fitted with seat belts for the driver and one front seat passenger.

Swimming.  The first night of the Inter-Club Carnival between Spalding, Clare and Burra was held at Clare on Friday night.  Clare came first followed by Burra and Spalding.  The next round is at Burra on 27 January.
