Burra High School: Headmaster’s Report for 1966

The Headmaster welcomed Mr & Mrs Baulderstone and the guest speaker Dr Southgate & Mrs Southgate and other guests.  He regretted the death in the year of Mr [A.B.] Riggs, one of the House Patrons and a former Chairman of the High School Council.

The year began with 170 students, slightly down on 1965, due mainly to a very small Leaving Class.  Numbers should be steady for some time to come and the emphasis in coming years will be on lengthening the time at school.  1965 produced the most successful Leaving Class ever, with 18 Certificates and a Commonwealth Open Entrance Scholarship won by Denise Griffen.  The Intermediate results were unfortunately far less satisfactory.

The school is in the process of being painted and structural alterations have been made to the Headmaster’s Office, the Library and the Home Science Room.  At last a comfortable and roomy staff room has been provided.  Portions of the yard were repaved and the toilets remodelled.  Thanks to the Parents & Friends’ Association changing rooms on the playing fields were completed and put to use.

Prefects were inducted in March and the Parents & Friends’ Association Annual Ball was held at the end of Term 2.  Arbor Day was celebrated in July by planting trees along the Burra Creek.

Two special religious services were conducted – a combined Methodist and Anglican Easter Assembly, and a Valedictory Service for the second successive year was held in St Mary’s last Sunday evening.

In October the Director of Education, Mr Mander Jones, visited and after opening the new Primary School Library, he addressed the High School Students and reviewed a display of work in the school hall and saw the excellent range of new library books.

Open Night was again held at the start of Term 2, but this year fewer parents came along.

Sport has again played an important part in the school, with a very successful Sports Day in April.  Steele House won the Swimming Cup in March.

At the Inter-High School Sports Day at Kapunda, Burra was successful in retaining the Handicap Shield.  Inter-school winter sports matches were contested against Balaklava and Riverton High Schools (but the less said of the results the better).  Summer sports will be played against Riverton tomorrow.

Another highlight of the year was the tour by 32 senior students and four teachers to Tasmania in September.  Unfortunately the planned camp at Melrose 10 days ago for the Junior School had to be cancelled due to wet weather.  It has been postponed to February.

The club period changed this year.  In Term 1 the lesson was given over to cultural activities such as drama, musical appreciation, singing and art work.  In Term 2 the whole school engaged in debating and public speaking.

Future changes.  The Intermediate Examination is to be abandoned, with no external examination staged by the Education Department at that level either.  It is also probable that the Alternative Course will be extended into the Leaving year.  It remains to be seen how many students will wish to study a PEB type course where there will be no external examination until Leaving level and how many will take the High Schools Alternative Course.  The nature of the gap between the two courses is also as yet unknown.

Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships will be available, awarded on the results of a special mid-year examination (held for the first time this year).  Two of our students gained one this year: Christine Reincke & Shirley Crew – both of them are leaving Burra.

[The Headmaster then discussed the problem of student boredom, their wandering the streets at night and their lack of manners.  He went on to the usual acknowledgement of the work of the Parents & Friends’ Association, the High School Council, the High School staff and the religious instructors.]

Accident/Obituary.  Retired grazier Mr Donald Roy McInnes aged 75 of ‘Donara’ Hallett, was killed instantly in a level crossing smash on Thursday.  He was travelling in a car, which was struck at a level crossing between Mt Bryan and Hallett at about 8.45 a.m. by a goods train travelling south.  He had been going to collect the daily paper from a roadside delivery box.  The RSL funeral was arranged by the Hallett Sub-branch for Friday afternoon.  130-140 cars formed the cortege.  Mr McInnis was born in the Hawker District and transferred to Gulnare as a share farmer in 1914.  He enlisted in the First AIF from Spalding.  He was wounded in action in France and returned home, purchasing a property at Hallett in 1919.  He married Miss Clara Scholz.  He worked hard and established his four sons on the land.  In his early days he was a keen and active member of Hallett Tennis Club and a follower of the football team.  Later in life he was interested in bowls.  ‘Donara’ Stud was established in 1945 on the original property, but later in 1958 it was transferred to the old ‘Cartapoo’ property, which still remains the registered stud of ‘Donara’.  Mr McInnis was a keen judge of sheep and was very astute when it came to their value.  He enjoyed a success in the show ring as well as stud breeding in general.  He was a foundation member of Hallett RSL and was about to retire to Adelaide.

[Born 24 December 1892 Willow Plains: died 12 January 1967 near Hallett, residence Donara Station.]

Burra National Trust met at the Mayor’s Parlour on Wednesday and discussed the future of the Redruth Gaol.  The building stands on 8 acres of Crown Land and until recently was the property of the Gaols & Prisons Department.  The Lands Department has agreed to give the Wardenship of the building and grounds to a local body.  The Burra Town Council and the National Trust have both been interested in preserving and partially restoring this fine example of early SA architecture.  It has long been an attraction to tourists and without any local authority having responsibility for it has been subject to an increasing amount of vandalism.  The meeting decided it was best regarded as a joint undertaking of the National Trust and Council.  The Council should be the body to approach the Lands Department and it was also in the best position to approach the Tourist Bureau for financial help.  The fate of other historic buildings in the town came under discussion.  Tourist interest in the town is rapidly increasing.  Burra is fortunate not to have become subject to ruthless changes and remains a rare example of a town whose history can readily be traced by any exploring visitor.  Its tourist potential is great, but is only gradually being realised.

The Gaol was erected in 1852 at a cost of £3040 and occupied in 1853.  It was the first Gaol outside of Adelaide and served the whole of the north for many years.  It could hold about 30 prisoners.  The first gaoler was Mr Thomas Perry, who was paid £168 p.a.  There was also a turnkey and a warder.  ‘It remained a Gaol well into this century when for a few years it became a Girls’ Reformatory.’

[This information is incorrect.  The Gaol was built in 1856 and operated until 1894.  In 1897 it was refurbished as a Girls’ Reformatory and had this role until 1922.]

Old Burra Photographs

Mr R. Noye has sent to this office some photographs of Burra and the Burra Mine taken in 1905.  While rummaging through the old blacksmith’s shop in Riverton, belonging to Mr Scholz, he came across nearly 200 dry plates.  Mr Scholz had taken these photographs in 1905 and the plates were in excellent condition.  A number of them show Burra and the Mine.  Views include Graves’ Shaft, Johnny Green, Market Square, the treeless Burra Creek, the Open Cut, the Ballast Quarry and a general panorama of Kooringa.  This discovery followed a hint obtained by Mr Noye of their whereabouts.  He is making a collection as a keen photographer and researcher into early photography, for the Public Library of SA.  He would welcome any dry plates or old prints for copying.  Copies will be made available to the National Trust.

Decimal Currency.  Today is the first anniversary of decimal currency.  The public has made many complaints about the continued use of £.s.d. in advertising, but from 1 August no contract entered into in £.s.d. will be enforceable.  75% of business machines have been converted and more than 75% of monetary transactions are done in decimal currency.  Nearly all business machines will have been converted by 1 August.  Most 3d pieces and half-pennies and pennies will have been returned to banks by then (though they remain legal tender for amount in multiples of 5c. (6d).  One of the biggest conversions yet to be completed is that of 100,000 price computing petrol pumps in 30,000 sites around Australia.

Historical Maps found at Steelton

When the old Steelton Post Office was demolished Mr V.R. Schmaal found some old maps and charts.  The old building was on the Marrabel-Waterloo Road and was built over 100 years ago.  It served as a post office until eight or ten years ago.  It was the former home of the late Mr H.G. Parker, who was the former postmaster and District Council Overseer.  He was also the District Clerk of the old Waterloo DC.  When it became unsafe in recent years, the owner, Mr B.T. Schmaal, decided to demolish it.  On receiving advice of the discovery Messrs A.E. Bannear, R.J. Noye and D.S. Overton visited Mr V.R. Schmaal and took over the historical documents.  A large SA Directory of 1915, which for many years was used as a door stop, was also taken over.

The collection comprises one lithograph map and five hand-drawn maps.  The lithograph shows the area in SA cultivated for wheat in the years 1870-1882 and the average yield per acre.  In 1870, the year the railway came to Saddleworth, the Saddleworth DC has 16,282 acres of wheat yielding 14 bushels per acre.  In the 1870s the Council area was 39,680 acres.  For the 13 years 1870-1882 the average wheat yield overall was 8 bushels per acre, which was amongst the highest in SA.  Three hand-drawn maps were prepared by the late F.G. Richardson, licensed surveyor, in 1871 & 1877 and dealt with changes to Government Reserves.  They are on linen.

The other two maps are the most interesting and are of Emuville and the Midland Road District.  The map of Emuville is a certified copy drawn in 1883 and recalls the early mining era and its effect on the Black Springs area.  In 1846 a well-known brewer, David Cudmore, built the Emuville Hotel alongside Emu Springs and the Government trough about two miles northeast of Black Springs.  The troughs are still in existence, but the hotel is a heap of rubble.  Cudmore stayed only a short while, as he inherited a small fortune in Ireland.

Thomas Tapley took over and dispensed drinks to the thirsty teamsters working between Burra and Kapunda for the next seven years.  The hotel was at the junction of three roads to Burra and would have done a roaring trade in beer and hard liquor.

About 1850 the Karkulta Mine, a few miles north of the hotel, was expected to become another Burra Mine and two towns were laid out near the springs.  One was Glandore [sic: for Glendore] (now known as Black Springs) and the other, right adjacent to the Emu Hotel was Emuville, comprising 36 blocks of one to four acres; laid out by Edmund Bowman.  However, the Karkulta Mine proved a disappointment and today Emuville is just a name on the map.

The other map of 1875 shows the roads under the care of the Midlands Road Board – an area extending from Pt Wakefield to Morgan and from Kapunda to Burra and it clears up much of the doubt which exists about the routes of the early roads.  At this time the main road to Burra was the ‘Middle Road’ via Kapunda, Hamilton, Waterloo and Black Springs.  The other route was via the ‘West Road’, which in a general way followed the modern bitumen road.  ‘Morris Bridge’ on the Saddleworth-Steelton Road was constructed by the Road Board and named after its secretary.  One variation shows that in 1875 the route south of Riverton went through the small settlement of Navan, east of the present bitumen.  The discovery of these maps brings home the importance of preserving such relics before they are lost forever or are snapped up by hungry antique dealers.

Mobile Kitchen Destroyed by Fire.

A party comprising Gordon Wooton, Stan Beinke, Jimmie Taylor, Trevor Baker, Bob Taylor and Jack Stannard are part of a Highway’s Department gang road making 100 miles north of Yunta.  On Tuesday last week, with temperature about 118°F they were transferring the camp and machinery from Wertaloona to Curnamona.  The 18 ft x 20 ft [sic:!] caravan kitchen, which accommodated twelve men at meal times, caught fire about four miles south of Frome Downs.  The ‘train’ of vehicles was turned into the wind and an attempt was made to extinguish the fire, but all that could be saved of the kitchen was the bottled gas container.  The truck and smaller van were not damaged, but all the food, furniture and utensils were lost.  The cook, Jack Stannard, lost a deal of personal belongings.  The roads in these areas of drift sand and watercourses will enable large numbers of cattle to be transported from the northern areas to Frome Downs by road.  Temperatures like Tuesday’s have been experienced for a week and for the preceding four days a severe dust storm had raged.

Burra Camera Club will get a 10-year lease on the old dressing rooms at the Town Hall.  Two enthusiastic members began work and two walls have been removed for the renovation of the main meeting room.  The room will be available for hire to others.

Burra Hospital will benefit from the proceeds of a social function at Booborowie last Friday, organised by Fiebig Motors.  Compere was Rory Jay of Adelaide.  The music was provided by two local bands: Dominos and Woodpeckers.

Halbury School students visited Burra last Friday.  The President of the Burra National Trust Mr Stan Woollacott showed the party over the Museum, after which they visited the Bon Accord Shaft and Engineer’s Shop, at the invitation of Mr Joe Edwards.  They then went on to the Mine area, the old Redruth Gaol and other places of interest.  Mr Ian Auhl outlined the story of the Mine and of the historic buildings.  Teamsters from Burra were often bogged near Halbury en route to Pt Wakefield and later a corduroy road of split pine logs was laid across this boggy section.  Some 40 adults accompanied the students and some of the farmers among them said the old bullock tracks across their properties are still well defined, as wheat does not grow as tall along the 100-year-old tracks as in the rest of the crop.

Burra High School.  Thirty-four students and seven teachers enjoyed a school camp and trek up Mt Remarkable at the weekend at a camp, which had been postponed because of heavy rain at the end of 1966.  Luncheon was taken at the summit of the climb.  The camp was a great success.

The general account shows a credit balance of $439.34 and the Benevolent Fund has a credit of $437.43.  Elected were: Patron, Reg Warnes; President, E. Pietsch; Vice-President, A. Burra Burra Show Inc. AGM

The date for this year’s show will be 7 October.

M.G. Stockman was re-elected President for a third term.  Mr Rex Stockman was elected Senior Vice-President and Mr R. Mason is the Junior Vice-President.  G. Stanley Hawker is the Patron.  The distribution of electricity on the grounds has to be reorganised because of the unsafe condition of existing poles.  A sub-committee will go into the matter and various other matters relating to improving the show were considered.  It was decided to ask the minister of Agriculture Mr Bywaters to open the 1967 show, or failing him, Mr C.R. Kelly MHR.  A minute of appreciation was recorded for the services of Mr H.J.B. Jennison over a long period.  He had earlier indicated he would like to retire from the committee in favour of a younger member.

The President reported a successful 1966 show, held in perfect weather with a total of 2,450 entries.  Horses in Action remained a highlight.  Numbers were down on the previous year’s record, but quality was much in evidence.  Wool entries were up with the best types in the district.  The Sheep Pavilion was nicely filled and young breeders are to be commended for entering.

The Flower Pavilion was a picture despite some rough weather in the days leading up to the show.  Mrs Scroop and Mr R. Fuss are congratulated on the painting of the walls and tables.

District schools produced a fine display.  Industrial displays were numerous and comprehensive.  The Agricultural Pavilion was well filled with quality produce.  Dog and goat entries were of a high standard and poultry and birds were well represented as usual.

The death during the year of Mr A.B. Riggs is the loss of a valued member.  He was a life member and past president who did a great deal to support the show over many years.  Thanks to the new secretaries Mr & Mrs A. Graham, who learned fast and did a fine job.

Financially the show was a success and the overdraft is being slowly reduced.

Saddleworth & District Historical Society has acquired a thrashing roller donated by Otto Pfitzner and his son Roy of Tarnma.  Over 100 years ago some German settlers of Friedrichswalde (Tarnma since 1918) felled a huge red gum 23 feet long and over 4 feet in diameter.  In its green state Mr Bob Noye has estimated it weighed ten tons and seven tons when dry.  For months they worked on the log chipping away about five tons with hand tools to leave the two ton roller we see today.  It is a long tapered object with fluted sides.  It was fastened to a pole at its pointed end and rolled in a circle by two horses harnessed to a spindle on the larger end.  Large quantities of wheat could be threshed with a fraction of the effort of hand flailing.  Wally and Darryl Baldwin transported the item to Saddleworth, where it will be treated with preservative and mounted on a concrete base by the Institute.

Stud Merino Field Days.  The annual round of Field Days will commence on 3 April at Para Glen Stud near Gawler and work north.  [Arrangements for the week are printed.]

Burra Town Council will take action shortly to recover outstanding rates.  The total rate income of Council is $19,789, of which $1,208 is in arrears.  The District Council has a rate income of c. $57,000 and is only $1,511 in arrears – mostly connected with estate dealings taking longer than normal to settle.

Ambulance Depot.  Following the purchase of a second ambulance for the Burra District the question of a suitable building to house the vehicles has been discussed on various occasions.  Now the Burra & District Association has invited the District EFS to join in the construction of a suitable Ambulance & EFS building to house both organisations and provide facilities for their crews.  Before this decision the Association had decided to draw up plans and specifications for an ambulance building and get estimates.  The most favoured site is on Council land adjacent to Richards Garage at Burra North.  Some financial assistance is anticipated from St John’s Brigade Headquarters.  It is felt that Civil Defence needs might be considered at the same time and an invitation has been extended to Mr Nicholls of the Civil Defence Department to address a public meeting on the matter.

St Mary’s Anglican Church

After years of discussion a big transfer of area from the Diocese of Adelaide to the Diocese of Willochra will take place on 1 April 1967.  The result will treble the number of priests and communicants in the Diocese of Willochra.  The enlarged Diocese will cover over 75% of SA, but will have less than 10% of the state’s population.  The area includes Yorke and Eyre Peninsulas, the Mid North and North of SA.  The occasion will be marked in Burra by a special service on 7 April to which leaders of all Christian denominations are invited.  The Bishop of Willochra Dr T. Jones will be tendered a Liturgical Reception in St Mary’s and Dr J.V. Peters will play the organ.  He has composed a special Introit to be used and the Quire of St Nicholas is coming from Adelaide to lead the singing.

Burra Primary School Committee: Chairman Ron Moreland’s Report

The work on the school roads was started on schedule and with very satisfactory results.  Sports day was a great success and the Welfare Club ran a successful stall.  Arbor Day saw trees planted on the oval and in front of the school.  On 28 October the new library was opened by the Director of Education Mr E. Mander Jones.  The passing out parade was held on 15 December with Mr Farrow, Headmaster of the High School.  For the second year in succession we have had a teacher transferred within a week of commencing first term.  This is most undesirable, but answers from the Department have been neither helpful nor very satisfactory.  The long process of painting the building inside and out has resulted in a work of credit to the painters.  The creek through the oval is now ready to be levelled over thanks to donors of filling.  Halbury School Committee, teachers, pupils and parents visited on 3 March.  During the year we lost the services of Secretary Mr D. Bannister and we were fortunate that Mr L. Moore, manager of the Savings Bank, filled the position.  The Andrew Tennant Award is the first award the Primary School has received.  It was an award of $400 on which the amount is about $20 p.a.  The first award has gone to Ann Brak.

District Main Roads.  Announcement by S.C. Bevan, Minister of Roads.

Construction and sealing of the Spalding-Burra Road is not scheduled before 1970-71 because of the need to complete construction and sealing of the Clare-Hanson section of the Lochiel-Burra main road 46, which has commenced and is programmed for completion 1969-71.

Burra-Morgan Road should be upgraded to ‘open-surface’ standard beginning 1967-68.

National Route 23 to Broken Hill presently is the Tarlee-Clare-Jamestown-Peterborough road, but the best route would be Riverton-Saddleworth-Burra, which is shorter.  Route 23 signs will be re-allocated to it within the next three weeks.

Hanson Field Day.  The Hanson Agricultural Bureau organised this function on Thursday 30 March.  Five machinery firms were represented: Ferguson, Shearer, Chamberlain, Ford and International and also John Deer Tractors.  Hanson CWA catered for 120 at a light luncheon in the Hanson Hall.  Proceeds will aid the Burra Hospital.  The location of the demonstrations was at Tom Rogers, just west of Hanson.  Demonstrations were held in very windy and dusty conditions.  In the afternoon Mr Hal Bannister demonstrated the latest techniques in bulk handling of super.  The use of bulk super has increased in the past six years from 1.1% to 34%.

Accident/Obituary.  On Easter weekend Peter Wurst of Saddleworth aged 22 was killed in an accident on the Marrabel-Eudunda Road when the car he was driving collided head on with another about five miles from Eudunda.  Peter was a police officer returning to duty in Adelaide, via Eudunda.  He was educated at Saddleworth Primary School and Riverton High School, after which he worked at postal delivery for a number of years before doing farm work with his father.  He was also employed by A.W. Vater & Co. before joining the SA Police Force about two years ago.  He was a prominent player in the Saddleworth-Marrabel United ‘A’ Grade football and played tennis for Saddleworth.  He was a foundation member and instructor of Saddleworth Pony Club and was training for the SA Mounted Police.  He was a leader in the Midland Civil Defence Rescue Parties and active in the EFS.  He was also active in the Saddleworth Show and for several years, even at his young age, was chief steward of the Swine Section.  He was a member of the Saddleworth Buffalo Lodge.

[Peter James Wurst died 25 March 1967 near Hampden, residence Saddleworth aged 22.]

Burra on TV

On Thursday last a film crew from National Television recorded the historical sites of Burra.  Well known Sydney cameraman Mr John Kingsford-Smith (nephew of Sir Charles) was in charge.  He has been the cameraman for the National TV series ‘Australian Heritage’.  Mr Ian Auhl provided the local historical background notes.  Mr Arthur Hiles, Secretary of the National Trust in Adelaide, had negotiated the choice of Burra on behalf of the Burra District National Trust.  Although the final film will run for only about five minutes, a great deal will be packed into the period.  It was shot in colour so it would not become dated when colour TV is introduced in a few years.  Mr Kingsford Smith decided the outstanding feature of the town compared with other Australian historical sites was the masonry of its old buildings.  He said he was astonished that with its tourist features Burra was so little known, even in SA.  The film will be shown on 38 stations of the ABC from time to time and will help to put Burra on the tourist map.  It is hoped to have it ready for TV within a month.

Fires

Three night fires have occurred in a fortnight in Burra.

On Saturday the brigade extinguished a blazing tree, which had been removed from Chapel Street some weeks earlier and dumped further along.

On Thursday night the old wood and iron toilet in the southeast corner of the Memorial Oval burnt down.

Yesterday morning the hedge at the home of Mr Bert Wardle in Mt Pleasant Road needed attention.

[‘Mrs Maggs’ column on page 7 adds that Mr & Mrs Wardle slept right through the excitement at their property.]

None of the fires caused any serious damage.

Accident/Obituary.  Dudley Harold Garrard aged 32 of Booborowie died at Curnamona Station on Monday last week [17 April]. CWA.  The Annual Warnes Group Conference was held at Burra Town Hall on Wednesday 26 April.  Group President Mrs W. Klem of Black Springs introduced the President of the Burra Branch Mrs Baulderstone who welcomed all.  Members decided to continue with the Group Objective of training a pre-school teacher for the children at Musgrave Park on the Northwest Aboriginal Reserve.  Mr K. Martin, Research officer for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, gave an interesting address on the works undertaken by his Department.  Mrs L.J. Burton, Hon. State secretary of the CWA, spoke on branch activities and aspects of CWA work.  As guest speaker Miss Ruth Gibson took UNESCO’s Campaign Against Illiteracy as her topic.  Thirteen tables of handicrafts were staged by branches and winners were auburn and Riverton who both had 39½ points.  Mrs Klem was re-elected President and she named Mrs G. Harding of Black Springs as her Secretary, Miss F. Pattulo of Clare was re-elected Handcraft Secretary.  A trading table convened by the Mt Bryan Group raised $43.42 for the Musgrave Park Fund.

The Northern Regional Red Cross Conference was held at Jamestown.  Mrs Roy Jeffery of Burra was elected new Regional President with Mrs John Murray of Hallett as her deputy and Mrs E. Teague of Burra as Secretary.

‘Basin Farm’ the well-known property of Mr A.C. & Mrs J.R. Ford was passed in at auction in the RSL Hall Burra on 28 April, but later sold for an undisclosed figure to K.R. Phillips Pty Ltd of ‘The Gums’, Burra.

Burra Sub-Branch of the ALP held its AGM on 26 April.  Elected were President, Jack Phelan; Vice-Presidents, W. Carpenter & V. Preiss and Secretary Mr Ben Kotz.  The guest speaker Senator Drury gave an informative address on the forthcoming Federal Referendums (27 May) urging a YES vote to both parts.  One part breaks the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate.  The other part relates to changing Section 127 of the Constitution to allow Aborigines to be counted as citizens.

Mr & Mrs H. Shakeshaft were given a farewell presentation by rhe Burra Camera Club on Monday 24 April in their new (but unfinished) accommodation at the Town Hall.

Kooringa Flood

This occurred on 8 June and destroyed much property and the loss of a life.  On Whitsunday at about 3 p.m. it grew very dark in the southeast and there were occasional peals of thunder till 6.15 p.m. when a terrific peal broke as if over the mine.  Rail and hail fell in torrents and continued till about 10 p.m. when the heaviest weather passed to the northwest, but the rain continued.  About 3 in the morning huts in the bank were washed in and inhabitants driven out.  About 11 a.m. the Smelting Company’s bridge was washed away and in succession every bridge across the creek.  (They were all wooden bridges in 1851.)  Where the homeless will shelter is a puzzle.  A great many heaps of ore are lost and worst of all one life.  William Box aged 45, a widower with three children: the eldest aged 5 and the youngest a baby in arms, was killed.  His housekeeper says she went to bed about 11 p.m., but the baby was troublesome and she was worried about the floodwaters.  She awoke him and after putting her and the children in a higher house in the bank of the creek, he and a neighbour began removing the furniture.  By 2 a.m. the water was about two feet deep in the hut and while they were removing an article the roof fell in, knocking his comrade on the face.  He managed to crawl away, but Box was thrown onto his back with a large quantity of material on him, so he could not move.  It was daylight before he was got out and the body was taken to the nearest hotel [The Miners’ Arms: now the Burra] to await an inquest.  He apparently had about £400 in the hut.  There are few huts remaining, chiefly near the [old] cemetery.  In Kooringa shops were swamped with the street a complete river.  Last night the street was more than three feet deep by the post office.  A quantity of flour was destroyed and flour was selling for 58/- a bag.  The Smelting Works were stopped for want of fuel.  [It was later rumoured that the £400 had been recovered.]

Decimal Currency

Australia’s dual currency period will end on 1 August 1967.  From that date £.s.d. will have no legal standing.  All retailing must be in dollars and cents and all contracts must be dollars and cents to have any legal standing.  The exception to this is in wills, which will not be invalid simply because it is made out in terms of £.s.d.

The ‘Murdered by a German’ Tombstone

The Burra tombstone which has perhaps aroused most interest reads:

ERECTED

HIS BROTHER SEAMEN

TO THE MEMORY OF

JOHN SMITH

OF LONDON AGED 20 YEARS

WHO WAS MURDERED

BY A GERMAN

IN THE TOWNSHIP OF KOORINGA

ON CHRISTMAS EVE

1849

‘Murders in the mining town were not altogether uncommon.’

Burra in 1849 had a population of some 4,000 and was a roaring town of eleven inns with hard drinking bullockies and hard working miners in crude dugout homes in the banks of Burra Creek, of an incredible mixture of wild Irish teamsters, of hard drinking and hard fighting Cornishmen, tough Welsh and German smelters and an even more incredible mixture of the dialects from every part of Wales, Scotland and Cornwall according to a visitor of 1849.  Christmas Eve was traditionally a time for letting off steam in the mining town.  Christmas Eve was one of the few holidays granted by SAMA.  Bare-fisted fights and traditional Cornish wrestling matches took place each year, generally behind the one-storied Miners’ Arms Hotel (now the Burra Hotel in Market Square).  Sometimes as many as 500 miners came to watch the action.  Fights would be coming off all the afternoon and evening, a ring formed and kept by three policemen, powerless to do anything but watch for fair play.  There was no 6 o’clock closing and often no Sunday closing.  It is no wonder the gaol behind the Redruth Police Station had to be enlarged and a new one built in 1856.  Violence was always possible on such occasions and on Christmas Eve 1849 it led to murder.

Mr W. (Bill) R. Marchant, son of the late Jack Marchant of Hanson, returned recently to Burra and visited the cemetery.  He was following up a hunch that his great-uncle Mr T.B. Marchant aged 33 of Mannanarie, who was killed in a fall from a horse in 1854, while riding from Mannanarie to Burra, might be buried in the Burra Cemetery.  He found the grave and headstone of his great-uncle and noted that unusually for a headstone the name was preceded by ‘Mr’.  He also noticed the John Smith headstone and decided to look up the story.

The SA Government Gazette of January 1850 records that a murder lately occurred at Kooringa, committed by a German named Gottlieb Kiernall.  The deceased was a runaway sailor from the Macedon and he came to the German’s house and asked for a light for his pipe.  A lighted candle was handed to him, but being intoxicated he let it fall and it went out.  He insisted on another light, which was refused and the door closed.  He forced it open using threatening language to the German, who then threw a stool at him and then several items were thrown by both sides.  The German then suddenly picked up an axe and struck Smith on the head and repeated the blow, killing Smith almost instantly.  The case was investigated by Mr Lane, who committed Kiernall for trial.

This was held in Adelaide 1 March 1850.

The SA Register newspaper reported that the judge in summing up said it was a sad case and the jury would have to consider what motive the prisoner had.  There appeared to be great provocation.  The deceased had thrown stones and threatened or attempted to set fire to the prisoner’s home.  The jury had to consider how far the provocation reduced the sentence.  After twenty minutes the jury returned a verdict of manslaughter.  The judge agreed with the verdict and sentenced Kiernall to be transported beyond the seas for seven years.  This meant to be sent to the Penal Settlement in Tasmania.

Weather.  On Tuesday a severe thunderstorm brought two inches and more of rain and hail in a short time to an area east of Burra.  The area was north of the west end of Princess Royal and the massive run-off went east rather than towards Burra.  Mr George Woodman said that for the short time it took to fall the whole side of the range looked like a moving mass of water.  At Klaebe’s Creek near Studholme a wall of water at least four feet high crossed the spillway.  At Pine Creek crossing where 5 ft pipes have recently been installed the flow was 2 ft above the roadway.  A vast sheet of water and hailstones swept across the road at the four mile corner and through the property of Mrs J. Rooke.  Deep Creek and the Baldina Crossing were flooded when water from Mullaby area cascaded down.  At Mrs V. Bruce’s ‘Armonda’ Mr R. Alderson reported a fall of 140 points in less than 50 minutes.  Roof guttering could not cope and very little of it went into tanks.  He reports a lot of fencing is down and a lot of rubbish and old tyres etc. deposited by the receding water.  The property gained a lot of silt.  During the height of the flooding the Morgan and Eastern Roads were cut and the school bus and other vehicles were held up for some time.  All dams in the area were filled and several burst, causing a further rush of muddy liquid.  At one stage along the main road hail was stacked up two feet high against the netting fence.

Princess Royal recorded 80 points, Mrs J. Rooke 104, Armonda 140, Baldina 70, Mongolata 17 and J. Oates 7.

West of Burra there were isolated heavy falls.  J. Lockett at Springbank gauged 112 and Old Koonoona 53, but Burra recorded a mere 9 points.

Mr R.J. Noye of Saddleworth writes an article on the rise and fall of the Apoinga Smelters.

A small piece of cast iron handed in to Saddleworth District Historical Society has proved to be one of the few remaining links with this pioneer local industry.  It is part of an ingot mould from the Apoinga Smelter, which flourished and then died over 100 years ago.

After the discovery of copper at Burra in 1845 a never ending stream of laden bullock drays wound its way to Port Adelaide.  At the wharves it was auctioned and most was purchased by the Swansea (England) [sic] Smelters.  With little or no competition the mines were not receiving a fair price for their ore.  The SA smelter was to be one of the answers to this lack of competition.  The first smelting attempt at Burra failed miserably and some years passed before the town had its own efficient works.  Meanwhile some South Australians with overseas experience and their own patented copper refining process were attracted to the dense forest of peppermint gums then at Tothill’s Scrub about 20 miles south of Burra.  This was an ideal fuel for their smelting furnaces, which at their peak used 150 loads of wood a week.  These men, Penny and Owen, began planning as early as 1847 and in June 1848 they were ready for building to commence and drays carrying fire bricks, clay and ironwork left Adelaide for Tothill’s Scrub.  Batches of Burra ore were bought and in January 1849 the furnaces produced their first batch of molten copper.  The single stage process was claimed to produce copper as tough and fine as any made overseas using up to seven processes.  Later that year works at Burra and Yatala near Pt Adelaide came into production.  Initial difficulties were overcome and by March 1849 a ton of copper per day was being produced.

This was increased to 50 tons per week by 1851. By then the works supported a village of 100 people living in c. 30 houses with a post office, hotel, blacksmith, shoemaker and general store.  Apoinga seemed set for a rosy future.  The discovery of gold in Victoria dealt a staggering blow.  Almost every able man rushed to Victoria to make (as he thought) his fortune.  Production at Burra fell and the Burra Smelter closed down.  The reduced production was sufficient to keep Apoinga going.  Penny’s men wanted to leave, but they were under contract and he held them to it.  They dealt with this very effectively.  When the slag was drawn off they ensured a generous amount of good copper went with it.  Expenses thus remained high, but production of copper fell.  The works were forced to close and the men rushed to the gold fields.  Some years later when the works were re-opened for a short period a huge lump of solid copper was found at the bottom of the furnace and it took eighteen bullocks to drag it out.

Today sheep graze over the site and all that remains is the slag heap and a scattering of firebricks, still bearing the imprint of a long forgotten brick maker called Ramsay.  The ranges to the east and west are still heavily timbered.  The only remaining building in the village is the hotel, fairly sound considering its age.  Today it is empty.  A few more years will see the last remnants of the Apoinga post office’s mud walls dissolved away.  More permanent are twisted jagged lumps of slag to remind us of a remarkable, but shot-lived era of colonial enterprise.

More could be told of Mr Penny and his fear of escaped convicts and his petition for police protection and the challenge to his patent by the mighty Patent Smelting Co.

Weather

Hailstones from the storm a fortnight ago were still intact after fourteen days.  Large volumes of hailstones washed up against fences and collected in watercourses.  The survival of the hail was first noticed by Messrs Richard Riggs and Brian Woodman when repairing sections of damaged fencing on the property of B.A. Riggs at the end of last week; some 8-10 days after the storm.  Some hail remained where it had been washed along the fencing with silt.  The main area, however, still to be seen, is around the edge of a dam on P.J. Thomas’s property adjoining that of Mr Riggs.  During the week a large tin of hail was brought in by Bruce Woodman and many people observed its contents at the Record office.  Mr Riggs also had a container of them till Monday.  Inspection yesterday at 1.30 p.m. found quite a large mass of the hailstones still present at the water’s edge.  Though the top was covered by a slight layer of silt, the whole mass is fully exposed to the weather and a handful of singular crystal ice particles was easily obtained.  A phone call to the Bureau of Meteorology confirmed that this was an uncommon event and the temperature would have to be constantly 40°F or below for them to have survived for so long.  Also in the debris from the flood Messrs Riggs & Woodman found a large number of frogs, toads and small snakes up to two feet long.  The hailstones look like being there for some time yet.

Obituary.  Mrs Alice Barrett died 26 June 1967.  She was the wife of Rev. A. Stanley Barrett and came from the Whitbread family of Mallala.  She had been a tower of strength to her late husband, especially during his early ministry on the West Coast.  With her husband, she raised a large amount of money for the wider church through their musical abilities with the chimes of bells.  Her husband was forced to retire prematurely due to ill health and together they spent their retirement in Burra.

Decimal Currency.  From today the dual currency period ends; six months earlier than originally contemplated.  From today all sales, contracts and legal documents must be in dollars and cents.  All payments must be in terms of dollars and cents.  Advertisers are urged to drop the use of £.s.d from today.  Old notes and coins remain legal tender for the payment of amounts expressed in dollars and cents.  Halfpennies, pennies and threepences can be used in lots worth six pence, which is equivalent to 5 cents.  Old coins are being replaced.  The vast majority of accounting, and adding machines and cash registers have already been converted.  Petrol pumps and scale conversion is just over 50%.  (Petrol pumps are at about 60 %.)

Mr John Robert Barker marked the 50th anniversary of his elected as a Trustee of the Church of St Mary the Virgin on 7 August.  This is the longest anyone has held this position in the local church.  The family has a long association with the church, both in England and Australia and has always taken a keen interest in all church affairs.  His late father William Pitt Barker was also a Trustee of St Mary’s.  Mr Barker is a widower who lives with his two step-daughters, Priscilla and Catherine Brown at the Baldina Homestead.  To commemorate the occasion Mrs Sibly entertained Mr Barker and the other Trustees at the Rectory on Sunday.

Accident.  On Saturday night Mr Peter Fiebig and Miss Marilyn Anderson were travelling to the Clare ‘Drive-in’ [Cinema] when just after the Farrell Flat railway crossing they were confronted by a car on the wrong side of the road.  At the last minute Peter swung right and his car was just clipped by the other vehicle causing it to overturn.  Both young people escaped with bruises and a shaking.  Mr & Mrs Thurgood of the Bon Accord Hotel were following close behind and also had to swerve off the road to avoid the oncoming car, which did not stop.

The Burra to Adelaide Cycle Race was held last Saturday.  It was won by 56-year-old Keith Thurgood for the second time.  He had previously won it in 1935 and until 1967 the race had never been won twice by the same rider.  The route started in Burra, went five miles towards Mt Bryan and returned via Burra and the Main Adelaide Road to Elizabeth and on to the finish at Modbury via Golden Grove Road.  Riders faced a fierce head wind for much of the way.  Results:

K. Thurgood (14 minutes)

I. Hennig (14 minutes)

The fastest time was by K. Smoker of Whyalla in 4 hours 18 minutes and he was also the first country rider to finish.

Lutheran Church.  The amalgamation of the United Evangelical Lutheran Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church became effective on 1 January 1967.  Parishes have been re-aligned and congregations united where both churches existed in the same town.  An amalgamation took place between Clare and Blyth.  As a result a number of churches were closed.  In SA fifteen closed in January.  Some of the closed churches became halls, some were sold to other denominations and some that were moveable were transferred to areas where no Lutheran congregations existed.  Yesterday morning a timber-framed asbestos church 44 ft by 18 ft plus the front porch was moved by Low Loaders Ltd from Hansen [sic] Road Woodville Gardens to Burra.  It arrived in good shape and was positioned on a block of land on the corner of Morehead Street and the road leading to the old Reformatory.  [Actually the corner of Ludgvan and Tregony Streets.]  Two men managed to unload and set the building in position in four hours.  Furnishings had already been redistributed, so the Burra congregation is seeking necessary items from other closed churches and some fine donations have already been received.  The Burra congregation numbers only about twenty at present and is part of the Clare-Blyth Parish served by Pastor H.H. Schmidt of Blyth.  Services are held fortnightly and up ti now have been in St Mary’s Parish Hall.  The new building should be ready for use in about eight weeks.

Rev. P.N. Potter, President of the Methodist Conference of SA, visited Burra last Wednesday.  160 guests welcomed him and his wife at the Redruth Hall where he met the Chairman of the Middle District, Rev. W. Stafford & Mrs Stafford.  Also in the official party were Rev. & Mrs Lind, Mr & Mrs B.P. Thamm and Mr R.M. Farrow who acted as MC.  Mr Thamm as Senior Circuit Steward welcomed the guests and the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone also extended a welcome on behalf of the Town Council.  Rev. Stafford briefly explained the workings of the Middle District and Rev. Potter gave an address.  He had been stationed in Burra some 26 years ago.  Rev. Potter’s address was on Church Union.  It is hoped a Union of Presbyterian, Congregational and Methodist Churches will be finalised by 1971.  There are about 24 united parishes at present.  He also spoke on the need to adapt forms of worship for the young and for some new twentieth century hymns.

Burra History: According to a ‘women’s weekly paper’ of 14 June 1967 in an article by Bill Beatty.

In 1845 when the colony was only seven years old and on the verge of ruin a child gathering wildflowers brought news of a patch of pretty blue ground in a valley called Burra Burra, near where she lived.  Her father investigated and found traces of copper, then worth a king’s ransom. Miners were brought from Wales, Spaniards and mules from South America and for the next twenty years 1,000 men were employed on a twenty-four hour shift that yielded copper worth millions of dollars.  Today they are a memory and the Burra is a centre of a farming and pastoral area.

Ian Auhl writes commenting on the article.

While it is true that the Burra Mine did save the young colony from ruin, the other aspects of the above article are wrong.  The colony was nine years old not seven.  The mine opened on 29 September 1845 with the firing of the first blast and closed on 29 September 1877 with the dismissal, with a day’s notice, of 360 men employed.  The mine thus had a life of 32 years rather than 20.  Miners came largely from Cornwall rather than Wales, though Welshmen came later to work in the smelting works of the English & Australian Copper Co.  The story of the discovery seems to have been confused with that of the Kapunda Mine three years before.  Copper was discovered at Burra by the shepherds Streair and Pickett.  Streair was working for James Stein who held a pastoral lease along the creek when he found copper near the southern boundary of what is now Section 2 of the Hundred of Kooringa.  He kept quiet about it and in June 1845 tried to sell his secret in Adelaide.  An Adelaide mining syndicate refused to give him £6 for it.  He went to the Rundle Street shop of Bunce & Thomson, where he sold the information to Bunce for £8. Streair then fades out of the story.  A company formed under George Kingston (later Sir George) went to investigate the claim and while there heard of another discovery further up the Burra Creek by a shepherd called Thomas Pickett who worked for William Robinson on his ‘Gum Creek’ lease.  Pickett had a hut near a spring on Diprose Creek and its ruins are still to be seen on the north bank a little east of the junction of the roads from Kooringa and Aberdeen to Morgan.  Neither of the shepherds was married or had wildflower-picking children.  Pickett was driving to his hut with provisions from Gum Creek when his wagon wheel broke off a rock to reveal the ‘blue ground’.  The discovery soon became widely known and the difficulty then was to find the £20,000 in SA that was needed to purchase the 20,000 acre special survey.  Governor grey insisted on payment in gold sovereigns.  Neither of the rival companies in SA could raise this much and to forestall a Sydney company waiting in the wings, they united to get the survey.  Once the survey was made though, instead of combining, they drew lots to see who should have Streair’s find and who should have Pickett’s discovery.  In the long run the SA Mining Association obtained Pickett’s discovery and made £5,000,000.  The rival Princess Royal Mining Co. got Streair’s find and lost £5,000.  Streair made £8, which in the final analysis was not a bad result for a failed mine.  Pickett received a bonus from the SA Mining Association of £1 per week for life.  He continued as a shepherd on Gum Creek Run about eight miles north of the mine and a few years later was burnt to death.  He was buried at Kooringa, probably in the old cemetery across the creek from the present Burra Cemetery.  Perhaps the names of the shepherds will live on and Burra like Kalgoorlie with, Paddy Hannan, will have a statue to its discoverer.  When the mine was a success Pickett was sent for and asked what he desired as a reward and it was his choice to opt for £1 a week and a team of bullocks.  He ended tragically.  After buying a small keg of rum he went off in his dray and the next morning some drovers found the burnt fragments of the vehicle, the iron hoops of the keg and beneath it the charred remains of the old shepherd.

Redruth Gaol

The Burra Town Council has received a grant of $475 from the Government for the preservation of Redruth Gaol.  After a meeting between representatives of the Council and the National Trust it was decided to remove boxthorns and the present fences and then to re-fence the area granted to the Council, to renovate the façade and to give the building a facelift inside and out and to build an access ramp to the property.  The Tourist Bureau believes Burra has sufficient buildings to make it a first class tourist attraction.  Tours to Burra will be the next step to be organised.  The Corporation and the National Trust consider these moves are in the best interests of the town and deserve general support.

Redruth Gaol and Reformatory: Some Historical Notes by Ian Auhl.

The Gaol is important because it was the first to be erected in a country area.  This was because in the 1840s there were no other country towns of any size in SA.  The population of the Mine area rose to 5,000 between 1845 and 1850.  The population of Adelaide at the time was not much more than 20,000.  Redruth Police Station was erected in the late 1840s in the Government Town of Redruth, rather than in the SA Mining Association town of Kooringa.  A temporary gaol was built on the police block with stables for the police mounts and an exercise yard and cells.  This building still stands with a shingle roof, covered now with iron.  The new official gaol was built in 1856 at a cost of c. £3,800.  It included a residence for the Gaoler and two Turnkeys, with a kitchen, wash-house and storeroom.  There were three sells for males and three for females.  The cells were ceiled with four inch gum planks to prevent escapes.  The first Gaoler was Mr T. Perry (his wife was Annie).  (The present Tom and Anne Perry disclaim any relationship.)  The Gaol became known as Perry’s Hotel and this term was even used in the Law Court reports.  Mr Perry was keeper 1856-79 and he and his wife are buried in the Burra Cemetery.  Messrs Pollitt & Young were Gaol Keepers 1880-84 and Mr Criddle took over from 1885 till closure in 1894.  In 1858 Mr Perry complained that the Gaol was overcrowded with ‘prisoners and lunatics’.  Gaol sentences were handed out for offences that now would warrant only a fine and the court was always crowded to hear the details of the more horrible or salacious offences.  Court reports of the day were detailed and left nothing to the imaginations.  Today such reporting would bring action for libel.  When the Gaol closed in 1894 there were suggestions it could be used as an abattoirs and a freezing works.  For a few years it was occupied by the Woollacott family and Mr Stan Woollacott was born in it.  In 1897 it was renovated and became a Girls’ Reformatory.  The girls arrived in December 1897.  There was fist, second and third class accommodation.  The more incorrigible girls were sent from Adelaide.  About 30 girls were house, some as young as 15.  They worked in the garden, laundry, kitchen, rooms and the wood heap.  From time to time there were escapes.  The first matron was Mrs Holden and there was a sib-matron and a wards woman.  The cost was recorded as 17/5⅜ per girl per week.  The place was grim and forbidding as is its story.

Burra Hospital AGM

Chairman Mr R.K. Pearse reported that the general layout of phase three of the building project had been approved and tenders will be called soon for submission to the Chief Secretary.  Phase 3 of the original plan is expected to cost up to $100,000.  At present hospital funds are in credit $24,000.  Phase 2, the middle section of the building, was completed at a cost of $14,000 from the hospital’s own resources, as were the complete exterior repainting and repairs at a cost of $9,000.

Mr Baulderstone congratulated the Chairman and the Board on the improvements made over the last four years.

The Chairman reported a sound financial position.  The overdraft had been reduced by $2,142 to $5,991 and there is an overall credit balance of $24,114.

Repairs and replacements have risen by $6,743.

Patient fees have risen by $4,647 and Government subsidy and Council contributions are up by $1,304.

The daily average of Inpatients increased by 0.3 to 16.3.

This has helped keep average costs under control.

The collection of patient fees is 98%.

Births fell by 7 to 43.

[He then lists a number of items bought to improve the hospital’s equipment.]

A major program of maintenance cost $9,000.  [This is then detailed.]

The third phase is the building on the old Burra Hotel site of the theatre and casualty wing and turning the old theatre block into domestic quarters and a sewing room.  The Mining Company has been consulted before drawing up these plans.  When the new Theatre Wing – ‘which I recommend to the incoming Board be known as the Alice Collins Wing’ – is completed, we will have a most up-to-date hospital.  We must acknowledge the great help in planning given by the Director General of Medical Services, Dr Rollison and architects Stapleton, McMichael and Loveday.

In the cropping program this year there is only about 30 acres under crop, thanks to Don Stockman and land leased from the Burra Council.  Mr Tom Rogers has sown 50 acres of Hanson Reserve to clover.  Last year we received $1,416 from wheat sales.

The Auxiliary remains active and the maintenance of the linen and the stocking of shelves with preserves and jams owes much to them.

The Burra & District Fund Raising Committee raised $850 this year.

The high standard of service and efficiency has been maintained by Matron Fyfe, ably assisted by Sister Taylor and on a part-time basis by Sisters Leedham and Byles.

The trainee nurses have done their jobs well and the cleanliness of the buildings inside and outside is a credit to the domestic staff.

The financial stability of the Hospital has been strengthened by the work of our Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer.

National Trust.  The visitors from the city had a very interesting weekend as guests of the Burra Branch.  When they arrived in two buses at 12.30 on Saturday they were given a tour by Messrs Auhl and Woollacott.  Mrs A.D. Radford showed them around the Museum.  The tour covered the town and took them out to Breakneck and Moonlight Hills to give them some idea of the eastern plains and the Murray Scrub.  A special display was arranged at the Museum of maps, old newspapers and other items of interest.  Burra CWA prepared a buffet style evening meal at the RSL Hall.  Mr S.J. Woollacott welcomed the guests as President of Burra & District National Trust.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone welcomed the visitors on behalf of residents and spoke of the role of the Town Council in the preservation of the mine precincts and he predicted a great future for the tourist industry.  Mr Ian Auhl was guest speaker for the evening.  Films taken by Mr John Kingsford –Smith some months ago at Burra were shown.  On Sunday morning a visit was made to the Brewery Cellars and some of the group attended the 9.30 a.m. service at St Mary’s, having been shown through it by Rev. Sibly the previous day.  Adelaide and Waikerie members of the National Trust gathered with Burra members at Princess Royal at 11 a.m.  Misses Josephine Morphett and Alison Wood conducted visitors through the ground floor of the stately home and the garden was enjoyed by all.  After lunch at their respective hotels the guests departed for Adelaide at 2 p.m.  Waikerie visitors were shown over the town in the afternoon.

Ten O’clock Closing of Hotels was introduced on 28 September, bringing to an end the 6 p.m. closing introduced in 1916.  The change was greeted quietly at Burra where hotel proprietors report only a slight increase in sales in the few days since the change.  Normal day trade seems not to have been affected.  On Thursday night the drinking population appeared to go from one hotel to another and a few curious non-drinkers looked in for the occasion.  Friday and Saturday nights are expected to be the busiest when things settle down.

The Burra Show will be held next Saturday.  There are record entries in several sections.  It will be opened by Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR at 12.45 p.m.

90, 39, 10 Oct. 1967, pages 1 & 4

Burra Effluent Drainage Scheme

At a meeting in the Town Hall on 2 October Health Department officers gave an illustrated account of a drainage scheme to dispose of waste water.  Messrs Wilson & Smith were representatives at the well-attended meeting.  The first such scheme had been a success at Pinnaroo, after which they had been installed at places like Berri, Maitland, Nuriootpa and Barmera.  There are thirty more towns at present ready to go ahead with schemes.  Rates applicable to cover the original cost are less than the Government sewerage rate.  Costs vary from town to town due to varying soils, underground water, rock types, etc.  The Central Board of Health will design a scheme; prepare plans, specifications and estimates at no cost to the Council or ratepayers.  For Burra they have prepared a scheme designed to cover the business area from the old Post Office to the Hospital, with a capacity for fifty homes or buildings on the south side of Commercial Street.  The drain would run from the treatment area at the rear of the Bowling Green, up the lane behind the Post Office, through the lane by the Police Station to Chapel Street, along behind the Commercial Hotel and Hurley’s Road House to Kangaroo Street to the Hospital septic system on the north side of Commercial Street.  A connection from Chapel Street to the front of Bence’s premises would then run as far as Dr Miller’s in one direction and to the old Post Office in the other.  The treatment portion near the Bowling Green would comprise a biological filter and pond.  There would be no odour from the pond.  There are already two small biological filters in Burra; one on the creek side of the old Post Office and the other near the Red Bridge behind the Burra Motor Co.’s premises.  The stone in the filters lasted a long time – one at Glenelg had not been renewed in 30 years.  Mr Topsfield asked about the possibility of a double pond system to take raw sewage.  Mr Wilson said this was not recommended because it would cost three times as much.  In the unit under consideration it would be necessary to have septic treatment on the individual properties before connection to the main drainage.  It could handle laundry, kitchen and ordinary waste water without prior treatment – but would not handle storm water.  The cost was estimated at $12,000.  This would be a cost of $200 per premises for the initial scheme, which could be extended to the rest of the town later.  It was intended to site the drain under the footpaths.  Council would have to repair or replace the footpaths involved.  It would generally be about four feet from foundations and about four feet deep.

Mr Jacka moved a recommendation the system be enlarged for the whole town and the original treatment tank site be used as a pumping point with a larger oxidation pond further down the creek.  Seconded by Mr Topsfield.  It was pointed out that the extra surveys etc. would delay the scheme by three or four years.  The recommendation was withdrawn on the request of the Chairman E.T. Baulderstone and replaced by a suggestion that the proposed limited scheme be implemented, but the disposal unit be further downstream with a pump behind the Burra Bowling Green and the oxidation pond be large enough to take on the whole town drainage at a later time.  On E.T. Baulderstone’s request this was also withdrawn in the interests of not delaying the project.  After discussion L. Bence moved a recommendation be made to the Local Board of Health that the scheme as presented be adopted subject to the Central Board investigating the possibility of installing a pump in lieu of the biological filter and determining the availability of land at reasonable cost to install an oxidation pond which would eventually take the effluent from the whole town.  This was seconded by Dr Miller.

[Presumably this was carried, though it is not so reported.]

Burra Mine

The Minister’s reply to a question in Parliament.

Drilling operations by the Department of Mines and the ‘present company’ have not been encouraging.  Drilling has proved difficult because the porous nature of the ground has made it hard to keep water on the drill.  Both the company and the Mines Department drillers have found this a difficulty, which has threatened the diamond drills when they run hot.  At present only one drill is operating to test deeper possibilities.  Results so far have not been encouraging.  Several million tons of low grade copper have been indicated in the oxidised ‘leavings’ and a feasibility study into the commercial possibilities of treating this is expected to be completed soon.

Accident/Obituary.  Two elderly Mt Bryan East residents were killed instantly on Friday at about 2.30 p.m. some four miles north of Mt Bryan when their car collided with a truck laden with sheep skins.  The truck was driven by P.G. Dunn of Kilburn and was travelling south.  The small sedan was travelling west from the Mt Bryan East road to join the main road.  Mr Arthur E. Goodridge (67) a retired labourer was driving the sedan, which was practically destroyed on impact.  The driver and passenger, Mary Olive Jean McKay (53), also of Mt Bryan East, were both thrown from the car and are believed to have died instantly.  The truck driver swerved right to try to avoid the impact, but the truck rolled over completely after the collision and ended back on its wheels, facing west and blocking the roadway.  The driver and six-year-old passenger in the truck seem to have been saved from being crushed by the high load of skins.  The young boy received some lacerations and stayed in Burra Hospital overnight for observation.

Burra Hospital.  A start will soon be made on Phase 3 of the building plan and the Board is this week launching an appeal for funds.  In this phase a new operating theatre and facilities, casualty room and domestic quarters will replace the old theatre block and old hotel section of the building.  The Government has approved the plan and will, as in the past, offer a subsidy on a two for one basis and donations are tax deductible.  The approximate cost of the alterations will be $100,000.  Funds already held by the Hospital are insufficient to enable completion so an appeal is being made for $25,000.  Donations are acknowledged for $2,117.

Burra Races on Saturday proved more successful than in 1966.  Gate takings were up $70.  The weather was ideal and there were some exciting finishes.  CWA ladies provided lunch and afternoon teas.  [Results are printed.]

Burra Primary School.   Headmaster Mr Ian Auhl, has been transferred for next year to Para Hills west Primary & Infant School.  Mr Auhl has been a man most concerned with the welfare of the children in his charge.  His replacement will be Miss Marlene Spratt who has been Deputy Headmistress of Northfield Primary School for the past four years.  She is something of a pioneer, being the youngest of three women who have been appointed to head larger State Primary Schools.  Another change at the school sees Miss Meredith Satchell transferred and she will be replaced by Mrs Carpenter.  Mrs Carpenter regrets having to leave the Kindergarten, which she has pioneered through its teething troubles.

Burra Lutheran Church will be dedicated on 5 November.  It was transported on 18 August from Mansfield Park and has since been renovated and refitted.  There will be a special service at 2.30 p.m. conducted by Rev. G.O. Minge, President of the Lutheran Church of Australia, SA District, assisted by Rev. A.E. Thiele of Saddleworth, a former Pastor of the Burra Congregation and Rev. A.H. Schmidt, the present pastor.  Members have spent many hours setting up the church.  The porch had been removed for transportation and was rebuilt.  The whole building was repainted.  Fittings for the interior have come from other congregations.

The Clare Congregation presented furniture for the sanctuary, of the altar, pulpit, font and an organ.

The Blyth Congregation provided the sanctuary carpet, the aisle runner and the notice board.

Both these congregations are in the same parish as Burra.

The Palmer Congregation gave the pews.  These were old and had to be shortened, but are quite comfortable. Seating is provided for more than 80 people.

Robertstown Church donated a fine set of paraments [robes] in the five different colours and a clergy chair.

The history of the Lutheran Church in Burra goes back to 1847 when the mining company brought out a group of smelters from the Hanz mountains [sic: for Harz] in Germany.  These and other Germans, who hoped to make their fortunes in copper mining, formed a congregation in 1851 and built [actually began to build] a church near the courthouse.  Many of them left, however, in 1852 for the Victorian gold rush.  A struggling congregation remained for a number of years.  Later the church was rented to a Lodge and was destroyed by fire after one of their meetings on 20 July 1910.  [This is an inadequate and misleading summary of the history of the building, which was actually completed only in 1861.  It continued to have Lutheran services from visiting pastors as well as being used as the Wesleyan Sunday school for over twenty years, by the Aberdeen Oddfellows’ Lodge and as a general meeting place.]  The records show that from 1905 Lutherans living in Burra were served by different pastors.  Services were generally conducted in homes of members of the congregation and alternated between Booborowie and Mt Bryan.  Later services were commenced at Flagstaff.  In 1939 services were conducted at Burra when the congregation rented the old Copperhouse Methodist Church.  [Actually the Westbury Methodist Church.]  Then at the end of 1940 it moved to the old Westbury Church in Burra, where it worshipped till the building became unsafe.  [This is incorrect.  The church used in Burra North was Jubilee Hall, the former Primitive Methodist Chapel and later the Methodist Sunday school.  But the dates are also incorrect.]  The congregation then transferred to St Mary’s [Anglican] Parish Hall where the last service was held on 22 October.  The present minister is Pastor A.H. Schmidt who lives at Blyth.  It is planned to hold services fortnightly with lay readers on alternate weeks.  Chairman of the Congregation is Mr Edgar Pietsch and the secretary/Treasurer is Rupert Kleinig.

[A photograph of the church before it was moved from Mansfield Park is printed.]

[This account is rather inaccurate.  After the 1910 fire the places for services were:

1911-1921	Jubilee Hall, Burra North, formerly the Primitive Methodist Zion Chapel.

1922-27	At private homes at Mt Bryan & Booborowie

1927-34	At private homes at Mt Bryan & Flagstaff

1934-39	At a private home at Flagstaff

1939	From August 1939 to 1947 at the former Westbury Methodist Church (adjacent to Copperhouse).  The church actually in Copperhouse was a Primitive Methodist Church, which had become the Copperhouse School.

1947-57	The Oddfellows’ Lodge Hall at Burra North.

1957-67	St Mary’s Anglican Parish Hall

Please refer to the book History of the Lutheran Church in Burra 1851-2007, compiled by Ron Smedley, Barb. Secomb & Jack Kleinig and published in 2007 to mark the 40th anniversary of St John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church in Burra, for a more reliable account of the history of the Burra Lutheran Congregation.]

Obituary.  Mr Horton Joseph Barraclough Jennison

Mr H.J.B. Jennison died at Burra Hospital on 8 October at the age of 69.  He was one of the town’s best known and most respected businessmen, citizens and philanthropists.  He first came to Burra in 1914 when his father was appointed minister of the Redruth Methodist Circuit.  Later he married Miss Reta Thomas, daughter of Mr & Mrs H.H. Thomas of Aberdeen.  Mr Ray Jennison of Burra is a son and two daughters, Barbara and Josephine are married and living in Melbourne.  Another daughter, June, is deceased.  Mr Jennison established the firm of Jennison’s Tyre Service in Commercial Street and was an active partner in the firm up to the time of his death.  Mr Jennison loved his family, his town, his country, his church and his fellow men.  For two years in the 1940s he was Mayor of Burra.  He was always dignified, loyal and eloquent, making him a capable Mayor whose service will not be forgotten.  He was one of the forces behind the establishment of the Mar Memorial improvement Committee and rendered valuable service as a Justice of the Peace.

Mr Jennison was a volunteer for service in both World Wars.  The continued welfare of ex-servicemen was close to his heart and he was active in the local RSL sub-branch, serving as its President for some time.  He was also most dutiful in attending to the needs and education of Legacy wards.  He gave more than a fair share of his time to local schools.  For many years he was a member of the Primary School Committee and of the High School Council, being Chairman of the latter from 1953-64.  When the present House System was established at the High School in 1961 he consented to have one of the Houses named after him.  One of the last memories many students will have of him will be his presence at their sports day this year, urging on his House.

He was an ardent Lodge man, being a member of several.  He was Right Worshipful Brother in the Grand Mark Lodge and Lodges were well represented at his funeral.  He was a staunch member of the Redruth Methodist Church and since its amalgamation with the Kooringa Circuit, of the new Burra Circuit.  He was a Church steward and Circuit Steward for Redruth 1939-42 and Secretary of the Redruth Trust, which he served for many years, from 1951 till his death.  He was born on the Mission Fields of Fiji and was the local Secretary for Overseas Missions for a long period.  The funeral was held most appropriately at the Redruth Church, which he had loved so well.

[Horton Joseph Barraclough Jennison born 30 January 1898 Fiji: died 8 November 1967 Burra.]

90, 42, 31 Oct. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital: Work begins on Phase III

Local contractors, Hirschausen Bros., M.G. Wardle and D.T. Jacka & Co., are demolishing the old hotel building.

Mr Ian Auhl has delved into the history of the building.  Ninety years ago on Tuesday 27 February 1877 rain and nature seemed determined to upset the arrangements of humanity.  A half holiday had been declared and the town was looking forward to a day of celebration with ‘a grand blow-out’ to follow and a concert in the new Institute at night.  Eminent visitors arrived by train the night before for the double event of the opening of the Burra Hospital and the laying of the foundation stone of the new Model School. The old Burra Hotel had been acquired from the SA Mining Association ‘on very generous terms’.  It had been renovated and painted and a Wardsman and Matron, Mr Wright Heath and his wife, had been appointed at a combined salary of £100 with rations and accommodation.  The hotel had been erected in 1849, taking the placed of a wooden one on the same site in 1847.  In 1849 it was known as Wren’s Hotel and was the largest in SA.  It was owned by Mr Paxton who also owned, like a good Mine Director, the four inns in Kooringa.  The Burra Burra Hotel was the first encountered on entering the town and was patronised by the ‘quality’ and always used by the Mine Directors on their visits to the Burra Burra Mine.  Attached to it was a very spacious room 50 ft by 30 ft and 15 ft high, which had been more particularly built as a Freemason’s Hall, it being the largest room in the colony.  The spacious cellars held a large supply of wine, liquors and other tavern stores from Burra Directors’ Port to hams, loaf sugar, pewter pots, glass and crockery.  In this hall were held all the public and political meetings of the day and all the major functions of the town.  The hotel with its shingle roof closed as a hotel in the year before it opened as a hospital.  Now ninety years later it is being demolished to make way for a new wing of the hospital and for a few days its shingle roof was again exposed when the iron was removed.  There are few 120-year-old buildings as well preserved as this one.  Its cellars are still there.

The Burra Model School still stands and its foundation stone was laid on the same Tuesday.

After the hospital had been opened by Sir Henry Ayers the party went to the Institute where a procession was formed headed by the Burra Brass Band followed by some twenty Freemasons and then the Oddfellows, Foresters and Rechabites, each in full regalia and then the members of the Ministry present, the Mayor and Corporation and Mr Bath.  The stone was laid on 27 February 1877 by Thomas Bath, the oldest business resident in Burra.  The inhabitants turned out en masse and must have numbered nearly 1,500.  The building was intended to accommodate 800-900 children and was due to be completed by the end of 1877.  The cost was £6,976 including furniture.

During the National Trust weekend visit to Burra recently Mrs Halliday visited Burra and brought with her the silver trowel with which her grandfather, Mr Thomas Bath, had laid the foundation stone.  She has generously presented the trowel to the school and it will be displayed in a place of honour in the Primary School Library.

She has also stated that she might be persuaded to donate the wooden mallet given to her grandfather by the contractors for the building, Messrs Sara & Dunstan.  The mallet is hollow and inside has been stored a copy of the Burra News of 1877, giving an account of the events on that day.  Perhaps on the opening day of the new hospital a thought can be spared for the old Burra Burra Hotel and the hospital building that has now disappeared and also for the silver trowel that brought the story to light again.

Notes:

The old Mining Association Hospital became known as Bleak House.  It has recently been purchased by Mr Johnson Carpenter and is being renovated.  After 1877 it became a private school and was known as the Burra High School.

The present Burra Hotel was earlier called The Miners’ Arms and the name the Burra Hotel was given to it after the old Burra Burra Hotel had become a hospital.

Dedication of St John’s Lutheran Church, Burra.

Visitors from other mid-northern Lutheran Congregations combined with members of the Burra congregation, representatives of other denominations and other special guests for the dedication of St John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church at Burra North by Pastor G.O. Minge, President of the SA District of the Lutheran Church of Australia.  Incidentally, his first public sermon was preached on Christmas Day 1922 at Mt Bryan.  The church has seating for 80, or at a pinch 100, and about as many had to remain outside to hear the service over a loud speaker.  Participating in the service was Pastor Thiele of Saddleworth, a former pastor to the Burra congregation and Pastor Schmidt, the present pastor.  Mrs Zweck of Blyth played the organ and the small but effective Blyth Choir led the singing.  Pastor Thiele thanked the Anglicans for the use of their hall in recent years and Rev. Sibly of St Mary’s gave greetings from Anglican parishioners.  Monsignor Hughes spoke on behalf of the Roman Catholics and thanked the congregation for inviting him to be present.  Pastor Schmidt said members of the Burra congregation were overwhelmed by the attendance and that to date the undertaking was debt-free.  He thanked all helpers and donors very sincerely.  Afternoon tea was served in the RSL Hall.  The next service at St John’s will be on 19 November at 9 a.m.   [The photograph of the church before it was moved from Mansfield Park is reprinted.]
