A Tale of the Burra Smelters

[Charles Barber Griffiths (a grandson of John Barber Griffiths) was 83 in 1967 and wrote an article concerning an incident at the time of building the stack of the smelters chimney at Burra.]

In 1855-56 John Barber Griffiths came to Australia from Cardiff in Wales.  He was a stone mason who built and maintained furnaces.  He came to Burra as an employee of the English & Scottish Copper Co.

With him were his wife Sarah and son Charles Barber and five daughters: Sarah, Addie, Elizabeth, Prisilla [sic] and Polly.  Two more children, John and Francis, were born in Australia.  Charles Barber had been apprenticed in Wales as a stone mason at the age of 8 and was 12 when he arrived in Burra where he continued as an apprentice with his father.

Before telling of the incident, I would like to say something of the building of the smelting works.  It was a well-built place.  The front was about 200 feet long with one big arch after another and the height of the wall was c. 15 feet.  Inside, down the centre was another row of arches and the back was the same.  Both ends walls were, I think, without openings. The whole building had a big iron gable roof.  The furnaces were built at the back of the arches.  The smoke was taken from the earth furnace into a big tunnel, which ran along the back row of arches and then went underground for c. 20 ft before going up the chimney stack.  The tunnel had smoke boxes off the side of it about the size of a room.  I remember there were two of them.  They used to tell me they were used to stop the smoke from turning round and round and if there was too much smoke all at once it would go back into these boxes.  My father used to tell me about the building of this chimney, which was said to be 100 ft high.  It was c. 12 ft square at the bottom and my father said it was 4 ft 6 inches square at the top.

This is the incident about the building of the chimney.

It was built from the inside with all the scaffolding on the inside of it.  When the masons were building the cap to the top of the stack an inspector came and climbed the scaffolding to near the cap.  The masons were commenting on its great height, but the inspector said ‘You don’t call this stack high do you?’

One of them said it was the highest the inspector was every likely to get off the ground.

‘Tell that to the Marines.’ Said the inspector.

‘Why, I’d jump off this thing any day for a bottle of brandy.’

‘Well, jump,’ said one of the masons ‘and we’ll give you a bottle of brandy, but you had better drink it before you jump, for you will never drink anymore after you do jump.’

He accepted the dare and they accepted his wager.

The next day he returned with an umbrella and climbed to the top of the stack and asked if they had the bottle of brandy.  They said they had.

‘Well, I’m going to jump now; you can come down after me and give it to me then.’

His umbrella had chords attached to the top.  They crossed over the top and then were attached to the handle and he then fastened those chords to his wrist.  He then stepped onto the cap on the northeast corner and jumped off.  He landed on a heap of sand and was not hurt in any way.  He got his bottle of brandy.

My father said they all needed a bottle of brandy when they saw him jump, as they thought to see him get killed.

When I was a boy of 8 I used to play in this smoke tunnel.  After the mine closed the furnaces were pulled down and the tunnel where the smoke entered was opened up and another new hole made in the top of the tunnel.  At the foot of the stack we used to get inside and look up.  The stack would sway as all stacks do in the wind.  Looking up you would see blackness and then a thin strip of light would appear and gradually it would grow into a square before slowly narrowing again until all the light would be gone.

Burra’s Tourist Potential was assessed at a visit to Burra on Tuesday by the minister of Lands Hon. J.D. Corcoran and the Director of the SA Tourist Bureau Mr P. Pollnitz.  They were responding to an invitation from the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and his Council.  They were accompanied by Mr P.H. Quirke MP and had a tour of the town with the Mayor and Town Clerk, local historian, Mr I.L. Auhl and the Revs G.D. Sibly & M. Lind.  They visited the old Brewery Cellars, the Lock-up and Stables at Burra North, the Redruth Gaol, Bon Accord Waterworks, Miners’ Dugouts, the Mine and Aboriginal carvings in Stone Chimney Creek, etc.

They felt tourist interest in Burra had grown considerably in the past two years as a result of efforts by the National Trust and the Town Council.  Mr Pollnitz believes Burra has more tourist potential than any other SA town.  The party was conducted over the Museum by Mr S.J. Woollacott.  As a result of the visit the Tourist Bureau and Government have a better knowledge of the extent of the tourist area and any case for preservation will be given good priority.  As no Government money is available to the National Trust, the best approach will be through the Town Council.

Thomas Bath’s Letter

A letter written 116 years ago by Thomas Bath to his mother in England was recently discovered among family treasures in Bournemouth, Hampshire.  Mrs G.G. Halliday, a granddaughter of the writer gave permission for its printing.  Mrs Halliday recently donated to the school the silver trowel used by Thomas Bath to lay the foundation stone of the school in 1877.

Bath St. Kooringa

Oct. 25 1851

Dear Mother,

[Thomas apologises for not writing more often, but says a long letter of July 1850 must have miscarried and the fault is not one-sided, as he has not received a letter for nearly two years.  He then continues:]

A person, who came out in the unfortunate vessel the Naraion, by the name Jennings, told me he had brought a letter for me, but he lost everything but the clothes he was wearing when the vessel ran aground in our gulf.  All hands were landed safely though spread along 200 miles of coast.  One woman died when she fell from a dray on the road to town.

I heard from Jennings that you had heard from brothers John and Henry and that was the first I had heard of them since their arrival in San Francisco, though a great many people are coming back here that went to California about the same time as my brothers.  I hope you will write to me immediately on receipt of this and give me every information about my brothers etc.

I herewith enclose half a £5 note of Bank at East Cornwall.  The other half I will forward by next mail as a precaution in case one of the letters might miss.  I am still at Kooringa as the heading of this letter indicates and the town has gone ahead wonderfully with now a population of 6,000.  We have a church, 2 Wesleyan chapels, an Independent Chapel, Baptist, Primitive, Bible Christian, German Lutheran, Roman Catholic etc.

The Burra Burra Mines are still holding on as well as ever, though not quite as profitable to the shareholders, being unable to declare the usual quarterly dividend of 200% this time due to the long and wet winter.  There are 30,000 tons of ore accumulated at the mine with an estimated value of £120,000.

We have extensive Smelting Works in successful operation, but these too have been idle in winter on account of being unable to get firewood, the roads being in such a wretched state.  Now with the dry weather they are again in full work.  They have 16 furnaces at work.  They principally use coal, part of which comes from England and part from Newcastle NSW.  It is landed at Port Wakefield 60 miles from Kooringa and is carted here at 33/- per ton in winter and 25/- in summer each way, up and down – they take down copper and copper ores.

This summer they will employ all the drays they can get which will be I think about 400 besides their own drays, which is about 150 more.  Their circulation amounts to upwards of £161,320 p.a.

Kooringa has been much affected by the discovery of gold in NSW.  Some 300 persons have gone.  One party of five men left for the gold diggings and returned after ten weeks without any success.  On Friday I saw a man called Hall who left the smelting works when earning 30/- a week and on his return was glad to get the same place at 25/- per week.  Letters from men at the diggings appear very contradictory.

[He mentions as at Sydney diggings: William Dunstan, Willy & Benny Dunstan from Burra, Edward Moyle and William Dower.]

Within the last few days there has been nothing talked of but Port Phillip where gold has been found in immense quantities says the report.  A great many have left already with a great many more about to go.

I am carrying on business as before in General Store – my stock consists of Drapery, Grocery, Ironmongery, Glass and Earthenware etc.  I also have a Timber Yard and a banking [baking?] business here.  At my bakehouse I employ two men and a horse and cart to ??? the bread around town.  In my shop I have three shopmen besides myself and a clerk at the books.  I have another shop where I carry on business of the same kind as in Kooringa, where I keep two men, a draper and a grocer and am doing business in each place – except in timber.  There has not been much doing due to so many leaving for the gold diggings.  I sometimes get a whole cargo of timber consigned to me and my name has always been A1 since my arrival, or since I commenced business.

Benny Dunstan has returned from the gold diggings with about 30 others from this place and another of others since.  They say a great many there are doing well and hundreds not earning their salt and many who would return, but have not the means.  Pt Phillip is now all that is talked of and thousands are leaving this Colony for that place.  I expect they will be as much disappointed as those who went to Sydney.

Since the former part of this letter was written three of my hands have left me for the diggings.  In consequence I have sold my baking business, which I did not much care about, as the profit was not large and I find I have quite enough without it in my two shops.

I will write again in the course of a few days.  Mt respects to all my brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts, cousins and enquiring friends.

You Most Dutiful Son,

Thomas Bath.

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal raised $11,311, of which the committee raised $840.  The Board is gratified with this sum, given the poor seasonal conditions.  When subsidised this will give a total of $34,000, which when added to funds already in hand will enable the completion of the building.  Funds in hand include a bequest from the Alice Collins Estate of $11,000, or $33,000 when subsidised.  It has as a consequence been decided to call the new building the Alice Collins Wing.  It will house an up-to-date X-Ray Department, Operating theatre and Casualty Ward.  Although funds will cover the building operations the actual cost of equipping the various sections is not easily assessable.  The overall plan is expected to cost $200,000 and of this residents of the district have contributed $11,000 for Phase I and a similar amount for Phase III.  With a bequest of $11,000 this makes a total of $33-34,000, giving $100,000 with subsidy.  Towards this end the ladies of various district committees which combined to form the Fund Raising Committee are to be congratulated on their annual effort.

Burra town Council representatives visited the Renmark Effluent Drainage Scheme and said they were impressed.  The co-operation given by the Public Health Department was excellent said Mayor E.T. Baulderstone.  Representatives of seven Councils attended the field day.  Problems caused by underground water and cracking soil had been solved using Ceramiflex flexible plastic jointed clay pipes.  The scheme would cost ratepayers about $20 p.a. for the average property.  An impressive aspect was the way in which soil was removed from the trenches, carted away and returned when filling was needed.  The streets were thus kept free from unsightly heaps of soil and dust problems were reduced.  The speed of laying the pipes at up to 1,000 feet per day was also impressive.

The Bulk Store proved to be a most satisfactory place for Mr I. Allen to explain the 1968 catalogue of products and services.  The Mobil Agency and carrying service previously run by J.L. Allen & Son will continue under Burra Rural Supplies.  New services will be Bulk Super Spreading, Horwood Bagshaw Machinery franchise and agencies for Portagas and Charlicks Feeds (bulk or bagged).  Light refreshments were provided at the opening.

Christmas Eve.  Town Traders will offer late night shopping till 9 p.m. when they have arranged for Father Christmas to arrive.  A merry-go-round will offer free rides to children the whole of Friday.

Burra Primary School

Mr Ian Auhl was farewelled by students on Thursday afternoon at a ceremony at the Burra Primary School.  With his great knowledge of local history he proved to be a teacher to many adults as well as to his school pupils.  Mrs Perry spoke for students and staff and said that both students and staff were deeply sorry to be losing both Mr & Mrs Auhl.  Penny Miller made a neat little speech, and helped by Debbie Kirk, made a presentation of a silver jug.  Chairman of the School Committee Mr R. Moreland added his appreciation.  Mrs Carpenter spoke on behalf of the School Welfare Club and also as a staff member.  Rev. Geoffrey Sibly spoke for the religious instructors.  Mr Auhl replied saying it was hard to leave a school where he had a school and student to be proud of.  He paid tribute to the great assistance of his wife.  Prize-giving and presentation of Progress Certificates was also held on Thursday.

Alan Braendler & Robert Padbury shared the Andrew Tennant Award for Dux of Grade VII.

Burra CWA.  The Burra Branch awarded only its second Life Membership on Friday last when Mrs A.I.M. (Matty) Phillips was honoured for her tireless devotion to the Association.  Mrs W. Klem, the Warnes Group Divisional President, pinned the badge onto Mrs Phillips’ dress and Mrs R. Jeffery, Secretary of the Burra Branch, read the citation [which is printed]. Carols by the Pool were held at the Burra Swimming Pool on Sunday night.  The weather was mild.  Guest compere was Mr Ern Lawrie from Manoora.  Mr G.M. Characteristics of the paper in 1967

Generally quite a good coverage of local news, though a considerable amount of the material refers to more distant mid north centres like Spalding, Saddleworth, Manoora and Riverton.  After the first couple of page sport dominates the paper.

Page 1

This carries most of the news.

Page 2

For much of the year this was the familiar mixture of a few large advertisements with public notices, advertising for land sales and for district events.  This changed late in the year (from 24 October) when editorials reappeared for the first time in many years.  The page was then typically: Editorial, Cash Column, some larger advertisements and local news and sports, with the previous page two material moved on to page 3.

Pages 3-8 & from October page 2 & 4-8

Typically dominated by larger advertisements with perhaps 2 to 4 columns devoted to sports and some news.  Of the latter District Council reports comprised a large, but rather unedifying part.  Some non-local pieces were common, including a regular column on ‘Last Week in State Parliament’ by the local MP John Freebairn.

Out and About by ‘Mrs Maggs’ (Mary Woollacott) was an important and very useful column for local births, birthdays, deaths and other events.  This is a valuable help for local historian, even if the obituaries etc. are exceeding brief.  This varied in location, but was often on page 7 and varied generally from one to two column

Burra Mine.  Drilling operations continue.

About 70 holes have been put down, some to 300 ft and samples are being analysed and the results checked with small shafts to about 50 ft, ten of which are to be sunk over ten of the 70 drill holes.  Each will yield about 40 tons of material for checking at the Cobar facilities.  It is hoped to complete one shaft each week.  Bill Wiseman from Adelaide is in charge assisted by Supervisors Mr M. Corradini & Mr J. Boyce of Broken Hill.

Weather.  A severe thunderstorm with hail struck an area between Farrell Flat and Hanson at about 2 p.m. last Wednesday.  Hail as large as marbles fell and torrential rain for about 80 minutes with a total of about 320 points.  Homes were flooded at Farrell Flat.  The Burra Burra DC road gang was at work in the midst of it on the main road, which turned into a quagmire.  On the other side of Farrell Flat the road’s top metal was washed away, but six miles on, where a Clare Council gang was working only about 60 points fell.  The railway line was damaged and goods trains were delayed for some time.  Water ran into Porter’s Lagoon, which had been practically dry.  Water was a foot deep over the road at the Koonoona turn-off.  Fences were washed away in the vicinity.

At C.W. Neill’s property 150 points fell and on the section known as ‘Riggs’ half the area was too wet to inspect and the rest received almost nothing.  Piggott’s got an inch, but Ron Winders said he got nothing worth mentioning.  At Gum Creek Robert Neill was harrowing on Thursday morning with one section of paddock providing good working and the other two or three hundred yards away was too hard to work.  In all it did more harm than good except for the water catchment value.

Ernest Claude Allen JP, LCL Candidate for Burra is a farmer of Andrews who has served 12 years on the Spalding District Council; eight as Chairman. W.J. Ahern is the DLP Candidate for Burra.  He was born in Port Lincoln and educated there.  He served an apprenticeship as a carpenter and joiner at Whyalla.  For the last ten years he and a partner have established a business as building contractors.  He is a member of the Clare Hospital Board and a Committee Member of Nadjuri Lodge Home for the Aged and Chairman of Clare Inter-Church Council and President of the Clare Branch of the DLP.

Burra Swimming Pool.  There are rumours about the water treatment of the pool this year.  In fact the water is very clean and has been in excellent condition throughout the season.  There are, however, some dead algae on the floor of the pool, which vacuum cleaning alone cannot shift due to the rough surface.  After consultation with experts it is now being moved using stainless steel brushes, though a stain on the bottom will remain.  The pool is still open and has not been closed or condemned.

Fire.  A fire in the Koomooloo Station homestead on Tuesday last caused damage estimated at $12,000.  It began at about 7.45 a.m. in the domestic section of a building attached by verandah to the main homestead and occupied by Mr & Mrs Michael Avery and family.  Mr Avery was working at the woolshed drafting sheep when smoke was noticed coming from the house.  Mrs Avery tried to enter the kitchen, but was driven back by the heat.  She ran around the outside to an end entrance where Miss Davies, the governess, was called from the room.  Mr Avery tried to hose down the fire, but the pressure was inadequate and a thousand gallons tank and pump was brought by truck from a nearby paddock.  The connecting verandah was torn down to save the rest of the house.  Only a small part of the attached building was saved.  The source is unclear, but probably one of two kerosene fridges or a combustion type water heater was the origin.  Temperatures on the day were well over 100°F.  Sgt Orford and Constable K. Terry of Burra are preparing a report for the coroner.

Mrs Lorna Norris nee Bowen sent in a photo yesterday of the business premises of A.J. Hunt, saddler, now K.J. Murphy’s and before this the shop was owned by Mr Nicholls, the jeweller. The shops on either side of Hunt’s then were both owned by C.C. Williams, ironmonger.  (Now the Record office and J. Hill’s.)

M.G. Stockman reported on the 93rd show [It was nothing like the 93rd!] opened by Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR on 7 October 1967.  With a new record number of entries it was a great success.  Horse in Action Section was again the highlight. Wool entries were satisfactory despite the poor season.  The sheep pavilion was nicely filled.  Flowers were very good again despite the dry season.  The district schools put on a good display and the Industrial Displays were numerous and comprehensive.  The Agricultural Pavilion was well filled with produce, vegetable, cookery, art and needlework.  Poultry and birds were well represented and dog and goat entries are increasing each year.  Many thanks go to the stewards and convenors and to the new secretary, Julie Sara.  Financially it was a success and the overdraft is gradually being reduced.

The President reported on a successful year with better attendance.  The Anzac Day service was conducted by the Ministers’ Fraternal and was preceded by a march of ex-service personnel led by the Marananga Band.  Remembrance Day was also observed and badge days conducted for Legacy, Poppy Day and the Anzac Appeal.  With reduced income the Legacy Wards supported were reduced to one.  Four ex-servicemen of the club died during the year: S. Moore, Lindsay Hood, Horton Jennison and Roy Earle.  Three members left the district in Alick Ford, Jim Kelly & Vern Riggs.  A contingent from New Zealand was entertained at a Dinner Social in November when about 55 members attended.  The club rooms have been painted and a new iron façade placed on the verandah and a new fence erected.  The Pt Pirie Pipe Band will attend and lead the annual Anzac Parade this year.

Accident.  A semi-trailer loaded with cattle overturned at Hanson on Friday night.  The driver suffered broken ribs.  Two transports owned by Whittam Transport Pty Ltd of Strathalbyn were taking cattle from Strathalbyn to Broken Hill.  The second vehicle overturned at the Hanson corner.  The driver was Mr Darrell Malcolm Wray of Meadows.  Most of the 68 cows and calves were roaming around.  One calf was killed and another three cows had to be destroyed.  The lost animals were valued at $500.  Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $3,800.  Mr Tom Rogers and others helped round up the cattle.  The district Council grader and bulldozer were used to right the vehicle on Saturday morning.  Another prime-mover was brought in and the damaged one returned to Strathalbyn.

Burra Hospital

The new theatre and casualty block at the Burra Hospital is nearing completion.  The new building will have the same floor level as the remainder of the Hospital and its tiled floors, shining fixtures and fittings will lend itself to sterility and efficiency.  A diesel plant automatically comes into operation when a power fault occurs; the changeover takes fifteen seconds and this is covered by a battery operated second auxiliary, whose batteries are automatically kept charged.  As soon as the new theatre is ready the old theatre block will be reconstructed into domestic quarters, a board room and a sewing room.  Despite the difficult seasons lately the Departmental Inspector reports that the district has raised $12,565 to the 29 February.  The Hospital’s financial position is satisfactory.  Average costs have fallen because occupied bed strength has increased by 2.3 per day and this has resulted from the increased use of beds by pensioner patients.  Mrs G. Stanley Hawker and other members of her family have presented a painting The Bark Painter by George Chaloupka, which will hang in the main hallway.  It is a memorial to their mother the late Mrs E.M. Fetherstonhaugh.

Paxton Square

The Lewis Trust which owns historic Paxton Square has recently been expanded to include local trustees as well as two trustees from the Lewis family.  Mr Robert Lewis, former Master of St Mark’s College, Adelaide, resigned as Public Officer and Chairman of the Lewis Trust earlier this year when he went to become Master of Menzies College at Latrobe University, Melbourne.  He is a son of the late Essington Lewis.  Rev. G.D. Sibly was elected in his place as Chairman and Public Officer and five other prominent leading citizens were elected to the Board of Management.  Some tidying up has followed and the trustees now intend to evaluate the whole position of the buildings forming the square.  Paxton Square is unique in Australia, not only as a well-preserved example of Cornish architecture, but because it marks the first attempt by an employer to provide mass housing for its employees.  The employer was the SA Mining Assoc., which had established Kooringa as their private town on Section 1, which they had bought for $20,000.  Until the Mine closed in September 1877 all houses and shops in Burra were leased from the Mining Association.

[This is incorrect.  Initially SAMA granted only leasehold in Kooringa, but from 1868 freehold was granted and was encouraged through the 1870s, though SAMA remained a significant landlord well into the 20th century, with a final attempt to sell off remaining properties in 1912 in its winding up operations.]

Early in 1852 the bulk of the men employed in the Mine left for the Victorian gold-diggings and it was well into 1853 before they returned and work could be resumed at the Mine.  In the meantime the Association had taken steps to bring out miners from England and it was to provide homes for these underground workers that Paxton Square was built.

[This is also incorrect.  See Ian Auhl, Paxton Square Burra South Australia, Investigator Press, n.d. in which he cites the evidence for the construction of the cottages earlier than this.  A painting of 1850 by S.T. Gill shows 11 cottages on the western side and some on the southern side.  They are also marked on the 1849 plan of Kooringa.  There construction was a response to flooding of dugouts in the creek banks.  Of course, some of the miners mentioned above could well have been housed there.]

The 33 cottages were built by Cornishmen for Cornish miners.  In later years [1913] when the Mining Association was selling its properties in Kooringa, the Hon. John Lewis, father of Essington Lewis, purchased the Square and at his death [1923] the houses were left in trust to house the needy and poor of Burra.

[This had been his intention in 1913 and he had hoped to see nominal ownership vested in the Town Council.  They declined because they feared being saddled with the maintenance costs.]

In 1845 William Paxton was a young chemist living behind his shop in Rundle Street, Adelaide, when Burra copper was discovered.  Paxton with Bunce and other Rundle [& Hindley] Street shop-keepers subscribed the necessary capital.  Paxton invested $240.  Within a year the $10 shares were worth $200 and the dividend was 600%.  Paxton bought more shares and became a Mine Director and a wealthy man.  He acquired large properties in Kooringa, owning the two hotels and Paxton Square, where the cottages were later built.  He later ran for Parliament for Port Adelaide, but his interests in politics gave way to pastoral pursuits.  The cottages originally had dirt floors and no verandahs.  There have been few changes to them over the years.

Ivon Wardle JP was born in Burra and is now assistant Town Clerk of Murray Bridge.  He has just won the seat of Murray in the House of assembly for the LCL.  He was born at Burra 23 April 1919 to Stanley and Victoria Wardle, nee Smelt.  Mr Bert Wardle and Mr Lewis Gare are his uncles.  The family moved to Murray Bridge district in 1927.  He was educated at the Institute of Technology, the Adelaide Conservatorium and Wesley College.  After service in the RAAF he was ordained a Methodist Minister and served the Booborowie-Willalo Circuit 1949-53, while living at Spalding.  In 1953 he was appointed Immigration Chaplain and visited many parts of Europe and the UK.  Family health reasons compelled him to retire from the ministry.  He married Miss Dorothy Briggs and has three children.  The eldest, Malcolm, is a bank officer, Lynette is an infant teacher and Ian is a trainee teacher.

Shooting at Burra North.  On Tuesday night police were summoned to the railway camp train at Burra Station.  Mrs Bessie Emma Treloar, cook, had suffered multiple shots to the abdomen from a .22 rifle.  The shooting occurred in the cook’s sleeping quarters at the end of a carriage used as a kitchen.  After preliminary treatment at Burra hospital, the victim was rushed to the Adelaide Hospital accompanied by Dr L.G. Miller.  After an operation she is in a satisfactory condition.  Police have charged a 47-year-old SAR cook, Colin James Kavanagh, with attempted murder.

Weather.  In the last week there has been high wind and two heavy dust storms, but on Saturday steady soaking rain fell.  The dust has been worse to the east where some homesteads reported removing a wheelbarrow of dirt per room.  Some sheep have been weighed down by the weight of the dust followed by the rain.  At Mt Bryan East 120 points caused a medium flow in Dust Hole Creek.  Weekend falls in the agricultural areas varied from 46 points at Booborowie to 80 at Hallett.  Burra recorded 64 points.  Eastern falls were more varied: Quondong 32 points, Balah 26, Braemar 55, Woolgangi 40, J. Oates [Poonunda] 101, Hogback 68 and Old Koomooloo 26.

Burra North Street Numbering

Names and numbers are printed for all of Burra North.

Common Effluent drain for Burra

The Department of Public Health is drawing up final plans for Burra’s effluent drainage.  It will include Commercial Street, Market Square, Hill Street, Ware Street, Kangaroo Street, Queen Street, Chapel Street, Lloyd Street and Thames Street.  The proposed site for the biological filter is in Thames Street on land adjoining the Council Pound.  Because of the terrain in some streets only those on the high side will be connected.  Houses on the low side will have backyards to sink soakage wells, whereas many on the high side have no land on which to drain septic tank overflow.  The Corporation has requested the Department to install the drain in the water table rather than in the footpath, but that will be up to the Department.

Burra Hospital.  The new operating theatre became ready for use yesterday.  The equipment is fully up-to-date and the new radium theatre light, counterbalanced and moveable in any direction, comes directly from Germany and is the latest in design. The theatre is air conditioned and has anti-static floors and X-ray viewers for on the spot checks.  Gasses are automatically fed and water in the scrub-up room is pre-heated and sterilised by ultra-violet light.  The automatic back-up power and light system adds to the efficiency.  Work on clearing the old theatre block has commenced in preparation for renovations to produce an all purpose lounge, lecture, sewing and Board room.  The remaining section of the building will be converted into domestic quartes for live-in staff where necessary.

Burra Rural Youth has had a busy week, centred upon the Australian Stud Merino Tour, which was an outstanding success.  The tour gave 33 boys and 3 girls an opportunity to compare and inspect the local stud sheep breeding industry.  Most of the visitors were from the eastern states.  There was a social on Monday night in the Show Hall.  The event continued through Tuesday with farewells on Wednesday morning.

Burra Floral Art Club held its second floral display in the Town Hall on Friday.  This year there were fewer displays, but the standard was higher.  In the centre was a reconstruction of Burra’s entry in the Adelaide Flower Day display in March and Mesdames Lloyd and Pettet are to be congratulated for this.  The day’s takings of $94.70 will aid the Town Hall floor appeal.

Burra & District Ambulance Committee met on 22 May.  In the past 12 months Members’ subscriptions have fallen by $90.  Membership subscription is $2 or $1 for pensioners.  This gives free coverage for the district and for a trip to Adelaide a fare reduction of 50%.  Non-members pay $2 flagfall and 25 cents per mile.  Distance is calculated both ways, so a trip to Adelaide will cost a non-member at least $54.

Accident.  At about 9.50 p.m. on Saturday a small sedan overturned at Mt Bryan.  The car was driven by Miss Susan Jackson of Cawker’s Well Station, Broken Hill, who was travelling to Adelaide.  The driver suffered minor injuries and a passenger, Robyn Jackson, was not injured, but a second passenger, Howard Rolfe of Hove, sustained a fractured cheek bone, concussion and bruises.  The car was extensively damaged.

Accident.  A car driven by Robert Radford of Glenora was extensively damaged when it hit a fence about 19 miles east of Burra at 4.30 a.m. on Saturday.  The driver was not injured.

Burra Primary School.  A new prefabricated school room is expected to be in use in a fortnight.  The first occupants will be Grade VII pupils with Mr P. Lannan. It is hoped to convert that room to a larger staff room with some space taken up by the book cupboard, now standing in the corridor.

Fire/Obituary.  Mr Donald Simmons (46) a bachelor farmer of Whyte Yarcowie was a guest at the Burra Hotel on Thursday night.  He retired to an upstairs bedroom and apparently was smoking in bed when his bedding caught alight early on Friday morning.  At 6.25 a.m. the proprietor Mr King Grubb arose and found smoke in the building, which he traced to the upstairs room.  He groped his way to the bed and found it still occupied by Mr Simmons.  He pulled the man into the passage and called the fire brigade, the doctor and the police.  Both Doctors Kirk and Miller attended and found the man dead.  The bedding was not actually in flames, but the smoke had suffocated the victim and smoke damage to the room was estimated at $300.

[Born 5 September 1919 Terowie, died 7 June 1968 Burra, residence Whyte Yarcowie.]

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone wrote to the paper.  He called for more community effort and involvement in Burra.  He said that having been Mayor for 14 years he would do his best, but it gets harder as he gets older and he needs more help.  Burra lacks the assistance other places get from having a Progress Association, a Junior Chamber of Commerce, Rotary of Apex Clubs.  During the coming year he will be calling a meeting to discuss future arrangements for the Burra & District Swimming Pool.  He will also be seeking help later to form a Tourist Committee, which is important for the town.  He also flags his opinion that Local Government must get bigger to be more efficient and says that his Council has already commenced negotiations with the Burra Burra DC on the subject of a merger.

Obituary.  Keith Wesley Gare died on Tuesday as a result of an accident [near Balranald] when he was returning from judging at the Deniliquin Show in NSW.  He was born at Burra in 1926.  He received his primary education at Mt Bryan East School and his secondary education at Burra High School and Prince Alfred College.  As a member of the ATC he enlisted in the RAAF as soon as he was eligible by age and trained as a fighter pilot, serving until the end of WW II.  At the end of hostilities he returned to the family property ‘Glenview’ at Mt Bryan East where he worked with his father Mr Lewis Gare.  In 1952 he married Miss Shirley Seal and continued to work at Mt Bryan East until the family purchased ‘The Pines’ at Burra North, when he and his family took up residence there.  The scope of his interests and abilities is shown in the number of organisations to which he belonged.  A president of the Mt Bryan Cricket Club, he was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board, the Primary School Committee and the Burra Show Committee.  He was a keen supporter of the Rural Youth movement and the first President of the Hallett Agricultural Bureau after its transfer from Mt Bryan East and remained a member of the Hallett Branch.  He was a Past Master of the Hallett Masonic Lodge.  Mr Gare employed his wide knowledge of sheep breeding as a judge in the Merino Section of shows throughout Australia, in capital cities and country centres.  Although ‘Glen View’ Stud was registered in 1927, its development to the present high standard was largely due to the recent management of Mt Gare and his interest in breeding lines took him all over Australia.  He travelled long distances to assist breeders and growers in classing lambs bred from his lines.  In 1966 he became President of the SA Branch of the Studbreeders’ Association.  He was keen to have the embargo on Merino sheep export lifted.  At his funeral over 700 mourners paid their respects and with 80 Masons present it was one of the largest gatherings of the Masonic Lodge at any country funeral in SA.  He is survived by his wife Shirley, and children Kay, Lester, Julie and Gregory and by brother Donald and sisters Melva (Mrs A. McInnes) and Glenda (Mrs D. Bailey) and his parents Mr & Mrs Gare Senior.  [Keith Weseley Gare born 29 April 1926 Kooringa: died as Keith Wesley Gare 11 June 1968 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

Burra Swimming Pool.  At a public meeting called by the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone a management committee was formed to operate the pool and its facilities.  At first it was run by the committee which oversaw its construction. This was then replaced by the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee.  Over the years interest apparently waned and two years ago it was virtually forced onto the Council.  Since then, despite an operating profit, the pool has not made enough to meet the repayment of the loan incurred for the filtration plant.  The average attendance of 85 makes it clear that maintenance and operation of the pool has to be on a volunteer basis.  It would be disastrous to take the pool away from the youth of the town.  The committee of twelve will be elected annually.

John McDouall Stuart.  An Article by Mr Ian Auhl requested by the PMG Department, Canberra.

On 25 July 1860 John McDouall Stuart, in his third attempt to cross Australia, reached the north coast some 50 miles east of the present site of Darwin.  After raising the flag etc. he and his party set out on the 2,500 mile journey to Adelaide.  Four months later on 27th December they reached the edge of settlement at Mt Margaret Station, west of Lake Eyre.  A month later they reached Mt Remarkable and caught the mail coach to Burra.  Burra had the most northerly telegraph station in SA in 1862.  Stuart was anxious to let the world know that he had accomplished his task.  In Adelaide anxiety was being felt for his safety after not hearing from him for almost a year.  When the coach reached Kooringa at about 6 p.m. on 16 December Stuart sent the telegram:

John McDouall Stuart, Commander of the South Australian Northern Exploring Expedition, to the Commissioner of Crown Lands.

Kooringa, Dec. 16th 1862

‘Through you I beg to inform His Excellency the Governor-in-Chief and the Government that I have accomplished the object of the expedition.  Party all well.  I will be in town by the evening train tomorrow.’

This was followed by a second telegram by Chambers at 6.30 p.m. on the same afternoon.

Dec. 16th Kooringa

Telegram to Mr Finke from Mr Chambers.

‘Stuart, Auld and self home by last train tomorrow.  Party all well!’

The Register correspondent reported Stuart was greeted by a large crowd and presented with an address.

The last train referred to in Chamber’s telegram was from Kapunda, then the northern terminus and about 50 miles from both Adelaide and Burra.  Register correspondent again reported next day that Stuart had arrived accompanied by Mr Auld and his party, Capt. McKay of Mt Deception and Mr John Chambers.  Mr Stuart was enthusiastically received by a large crowd.  He appeared in a very low condition, having suffered from scurvy for a great part of the trip and alighted from the coach with difficulty.  Mr W.H. Wilkinson read the address.

[The address is printed together with Stuart’s reply.]

The correspondent also reported Stuart’s departure by the Adelaide Mail for the city.  Another large crowd assembled and another address was read and presented to Stuart.  Mr McDermott SM read this address.  He and Mr Mayne JP and Mr J.B. Anderson JP had escorted the explorer from his room in the hotel to the Mail bus.  Nine carts full of people followed the Mail bus for about three miles, where they gave three hearty cheers before returning to Kooringa.

[The address read by McDermott is also printed.]

Sir Frederick Holder has been remembered with the naming of a new metropolitan electorate for the House of Representatives after him.  He was closely connected with Burra.  He was born 12 May 1850, the son of Morecott Holder of Happy Valley and trained as a teacher.  He felt that journalism would hold greater opportunities and while still a young man secured possession of the Burra Record.  He was described as a ‘trenchant and graceful’ writer and contributed to the Adelaide Register and high class English newspapers.  He became Town Clerk of Burra from 1879 to 1884 and was Mayor in 1887. [And 1889.]  In 1887 he was elected to the House of Assembly and two years later was first Treasurer in Sir John Cockburn’s cabinet.  He was Premier of SA briefly in 1892 and for 1899-1901.  In 1901 he was made a Knight Commander of St Michael & St George.  When the Commonwealth was established he became the first Speaker of the House of Representatives.  He was a greatly respected Speaker, known for his fairness and the dignified way he carried out his duties. He collapsed at his post with an apoplectic seizure at 6.30 a.m. on 23 July 1909 following a strenuous all-night sitting on the subject of the old age pension.  He died at 4 p.m. the same day without regaining consciousness.  Thousands lined the route of his state funeral in Adelaide on 26 July despite torrential rain.

Arbor Day was held at Burra Primary School last Friday and more than 110 visitors attended.  The school was open for visitors and the theme for the day was Australian Trees.  Mrs M. Rayner of Hallett delivered the address after which 14 trees were planted around the school oval.  [Tree planters are listed.]

Advt.  Burra Pictures.  The secretary of the Burra Town Hall Picture Committee reports a drop in attendance for the past financial year of 416 or 9% and consequently a loss of $110.

Attendances:

If attendances do not significantly increase serious consideration will have to be given to closing down the Town Hall Pictures.  This would be a pity, but it is hardly worthwhile obtaining the better films available if the residents are not going to patronise them.  Three persons work voluntarily each Saturday night.  It costs $17 plus the film hire (average $24) to put on a show.  To cover this attendance will have to rise considerably from the present average of 87.  One need to lift attendance is the better behaviour of children and teenagers present.  Parents could help by coming along and keeping their own children under control.  The outcome is in the hands of the residents of Burra.  It is stressed that the aim of increasing attendance cannot be achieved without a great improvement in the behaviour of the children attending.  The committee has found it necessary to abolish the front stalls and charge 30c for children anywhere downstairs – they had been buying 20c seats and moving into 30c seats during the program.

Visit of the Minister of Local Government

The Hon M. Hill with Mrs Hill and Mr Claude Allen MP & Mrs Allen visited Burra as part of a two day tour of the area.  Members of the Town and District Councils and their wives met the visitors at the Town Hall.  The ladies visited the National Trust Museum and the CWA rooms for afternoon tea.  The Minister and Mr Allen joined the Town Council in the Parlour.  The main discussion centred upon reclaiming the central portion of the cemetery.  This discussion had gone on for some years and Mr Hill brought with him the complete file.  His explanation showed the reclaiming was not simple and could, in the future, have repercussions.  He felt the opening of a new section on the eastern side of the cemetery would be more satisfactory.  Grant monies were also discussed.  The large length of roads and small population and other difficulties in qualifying for grants were mentioned.  Mr Hill was sure there was no special grant for cemetery maintenance.  He agreed with Council amalgamations in principle, but it was up to individual Councils to come to terms.  Mr Hill then had afternoon tea with the District Council.  Again he heard of the difficulties the Council was having – especially the sealing of the Spalding-Morgan Road and of the Farrell Flat-Hanson Road.  Councils, he said, could do the work more cheaply than the Highways & Local Government Department.  He repeated his comments on Council amalgamations.  A deputation from Booborowie lobbied for sealing of town streets.

Burra Hospital

The Hon. R.C. De Garis, Chief Secretary and Minister of health opened the Alice Collins Theatre and Casualty Block on Friday.  The Vice-Chairman Mr A.J. Ashby introduced the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone, who gave a brief address in which he went through some of the recent history of the redevelopment of the Hospital.  Chairman of the Board Mr R.K. Pearse spoke, saying that since plans were formulated in 1963 $160,000 had been spent in capital outlay and $40,000 in maintenance. The work had been done in three stages.  Stages 1 7 3 had been accomplished through public subscription from appeals [subsidised by Government].  The second stage had been financed by a bequest from the estate of the late Miss Alice Collins who had spent her last four years as an inmate of the hospital.  Mr Pearse then asked Mr De Garis to declare the wing open.  A plaque bearing the words Alice Collins Wing was unveiled by Mr A.K. Hanlin of Burra.

Accident.  A car driven by Mrs A. Cullen and one driven by Mr P. Lockett collided at 7.45 p.m. on the Burra-Burra North Road.  Both vehicles were extensively damaged and Mrs Cullen received a neck injury.

The work of preparation, laying and two coats of Estapol has a quoted price of $810.  It is hoped an opening function will raise the $248 gap.

Hopgood (36) received severe chest and head injuries and died at the Burra Hospital about four hours later.  Mrs R.E. Dewhirst received head, facial and leg injuries and was taken to Riverton Hospital and later to Adelaide where her condition is now described as satisfactory. Obituary.  Mr J.B. (Jack) Rowe died at Burra Hospital on 12 July.  His death severs one of the last links with the sheep droving era of the pastoral lands east and north of Burra.  He was born in Burra on 12 January 1907, the eldest son of the late Jack and Helen Rowe.  He worked with sheep practically all his life and was a well known figure around the sale yards.  He was regularly sought when sheep had to be mustered for shearing and was employed on most of the properties in the eastern pastoral area.  He worked for over a period of thirty years or more on Mr J.R. Barker’s property at Baldina.  In his early life his dray, horse and several dogs were a familiar sight throughout the district.  Some droving trips took him as far away as Wentworth in NSW.  In more recent years the dray gave way to a motor vehicle and motor cycle.  He was a member of the RAOB Lodge.  He is survived by his widow, daughter Joan and son John and three grandchildren.  Also by three sisters and two brothers: Dorrie, Flora, Fan, Alf and Harry.  [Jack Birkenhagen Rowe born 21 January 1907 Redruth: died 12 July 1968 Burra.]

District Roads.  Answers to question in Parliament.

Traffic densities justify the sealing of Main Road 140 from Burra to Booborowie.  Preconstruction activities will mean this is not expected to commence before 1969-70.

The Burra-Morgan Road will be developed to open surface standard over a period of years.  $20,000 has been provided to begin work.  This is not a high priority and work on the Morgan end will now commence in 1970-71.

When the Burra section is complete work on the Robertstown section will begin, but this is not likely before 1970-71.  Over the next five years it is expected $20,000 will be available annually for work in the Burra District.  From 1969-70 $50,000 p.a. should be available for the Morgan area.

Burra Hospital.  Chairman R.K. Pearse’s Report 1967-68.  The 91st Annual Report

Capital assets increased by $78, 921 due to the extensive building program.  Liquid assets stand at $21,890; down $8, 215.  The general account overdraft is $1,649 compared with $4,342 last year.  The overall credit balance is $17,548.  The Government subsidy increased by #3,090 and patients’ fees rose $4,765.  At present there is no need to increase patients’ fees, which were last raised in November 1965.

The average number of in-patients rose by 2.5 to 18.5 – an all-time high.

The average cost of out-patients fell by 50c to $2.30.

Births at the hospital rose to 50.

The year saw the completion of the ‘Alice Collins’ Theatre and Casualty Wing and the domestic quarters.  These additions plus equipment will cost approximately $100,000, not all of which is subsidised.  Since the building program was commenced we have expended $160,000 on capital improvements and $40,000 on maintenance.  The new wing was opened on 2 August by the Chief Secretary Hon. R.C. De Garis.  There are now plans to modernise the Maternity Wing and the kitchen.  The equipment for the Intensive Care Ward has to be purchased and the Board hopes to standardise on St Andrew’s type beds throughout the hospital.  The cropping program is receiving little support unfortunately and this year wheat sales produced only $229.  The Ladies’ Auxiliary continues its good work in sewing and stocking jams and preserves and now operates in adequate facilities.  The Fund Raising Committee contributed $840 towards equipment purchases.

The Matron and nursing staff have given excellent service as have the domestic staff and handy man.  The appeal for building funds produced a generous $13,302 despite the dry season, and this was greatly appreciated.

The death of respected Board Member Mr Keith Gare was deeply regretted.  We thank Mrs A.D. Radford for her services and we lose her this year and welcome Mrs H. Treweeke and Mr W.A. Field to the Board.

Burra Mine.  The Minister of Mines in Parliament, Hon. R.C. Geddes:

Earlier in 1968 several shafts were sunk in the oxidised leavings to obtain a sample of copper lodes for testing.  Metallurgical difficulties have been encountered in doing so, but investigations are proceeding.  Drilling to ascertain deeper lodes has taken place, but is stopped at present due to discouraging results.

Major Peter Phillips was born at the Burra Hospital in 1935.  His father was Ray Phillips, who lived in the house which Goldsbrough’s managers have occupied for many years.  Ray Phillips was in partnership with his brother in a dental practice for many years before opening a practice at Kadina and Wallaroo, where he remained until enlisting in the AIF during WWII.  He died on active service in 1943.  Peter Phillips was educated at Rostrevor College and then went to Duntroon.  After graduation he served as a Lieutenant in Malaya and this year was awarded the Military Cross for bravery in Vietnam.

[Charles Leslie Phillips born 7 August 1903: died 1 October 1988 Daw Park.

Ambulance & EFS Building.  A tender was accepted on Monday last week for a building to be completed by 31 January 1969.  It will be situated opposite the Buffalo Lodge Hall on land leased from the Town Council by St John Council of SA and the Burra Burra DC.  The building will be approximately 40 ft x 38 ft and will comprised a Board Room, kitchen, storeroom, shower, toilet, two ambulance bays and an EFS bay.  A project committee will manage the project.  There were seven tenders and that of D.T. Jacka & Co. was successful.  Finance will come from Burra District Ambulance Assoc., St John Council Subsidy, Burra Burra DC and a subsidy from the EFS.  Building is expected to commence on 1 October.  At present the Holden Ambulance is based in a shed at the rear of the shops in Market Square and the VW Ambulance is in a building over the Red Bridge owned by E.T. Baulderstone.  The EFS Unit takes up valuable space at the District Council Depot.

Burra Swimming Pool.  The opening of the swimming season has been put back two weeks by lack of support for the working bee on 15 September.  Apart from committee members or their families only one other person turned up.  Preparation and painting will cost $300.  High School boys are helping preparations in their sports period and further working bees are called for 5 & 6 October to paint the surface.  If these are successful the plant should be able to be operated the following weekend and the pool opened on either 26 October or the 2 November.

Burra Mine

The Mine area was visited yesterday by the Minister of Mines the Hon. R.C. De Garis, the Director of Mines Mr Barnes, the Local MP Mr E.C. Allen and a representative of Mines Exploration Ltd Mr Roberts.  It is part of a familiarisation study by Mr De Garis of areas of the state with mineral resources.  Mr De Garis said studies had shown the presence in Burra of sufficient copper ore (something like 1½%).  There remains the problem of gaining the ore on a commercial basis.  Tests continue, but how long it will take to get a breakthrough is unknown.

Burra Swimming Pool.  There was a pleasing response for the working bee at the pool on Saturday.  While only three adults and ten children were there in the morning, about 32 people arrived in the afternoon.  The first coat (a sealer) was put on in just over four hours.  Unfortunately bad weather prevented further painting on Sunday and this has been postponed till next Sunday.  The opening of the pool is scheduled for the first Saturday in November.  The paint being used is an Epoxy Resin based paint, which should give a smooth finish and is hoped, will not lift with normal use.

Burra Show was held on Saturday in perfect weather.  Gate takings of $486 were up on the previous year and overall entries of 2527 were just under the 1967 record. Secretary Miss Judy Beinke had arrangements well in hand.  There were 900 entries in Horse-in-Action.  The opening was performed by Mr E.C. Allen MP.

[In his speech Mr Allen referred to activities at the Burra Mine.  He said drilling there had revealed approximately 3.4 million tons of ore, which could be mined by open cut, though there remained the problem of separating the copper from the rock.  At present they can recover 60%, but 80% is needed to make it a payable proposition and work on a process is continuing.  Id they are successful the Mine should employ 35-50 men directly for approximately 10 years.  This would be a great boost for Burra economically.]

Industrial stands were filled to capacity.

Sideshows were both more numerous and more varied than in past years.

Flower entries were down, but standards were maintained.

Needlework entries were well up with a good juvenile section, but the CWA section only had two entries.  The standard was very good.

School Displays were pleasing with entries from Burra High and Burra Primary Schools, Burra Kindergarten, Leighton, Farrell Flat, Mt Bryan and St Joseph’s Convent.

Art entries were down and the standard was not particularly high. Some sections were poorly represented.

Budgerigars were of a good standard and bantams a creditable display.

Poultry entries were not high, but included some nice birds.

The pigeon section was a big improvement on 1967.

The cooking standard was down.

Grain and fodder entries were good, but few.

Goats were of an exceptionally high standard.

Sheep entries were down, but quality was good.

Fruit and vegetable entries were few, but of good quality.

Flowers were good for late in the season, especially in pelargoniums, fuchsias, poppies, cinerarias, stocks and anemones.

Floral Art was good, with the flowers fresh and of excellent quality.

Horses-in-Action produced very high standard jumping.  Novelty events were keenly contested.

Wool entries were well grown with good character.

A History of Seven Mid-Northern Hundreds

The publishing committee of the Terowie Branch of the CWA advises its publication Deceptive Lands: a History of Seven Mid-Northern Hundreds, will be released before Christmas at a cost of $5.  The Author is Roma Mattey (now Mrs Hans Schultz).  It is an attempt to cover the early pastoral history of the Hundreds of Terowie, Whyte Yarcowie, Wonna, Gumbowie, Ketchowla, Yongala and Parnaroo.

All surveyed towns in the area except Peterborough have been described and there are many historic photographs in the book of over 250 pages.  The foreword is by His Excellency W.R. Crocker, now Australian Ambassador in Rome.  He spent his early childhood at Parnaroo.

Ian Auhl’s Address: Burra The Anatomy of a National Trust Town is printed.

[Auhl begins by talking about the problem of Burra’s name as a town and the Burra of the Five Towns – choosing as his five Kooringa, Copperhouse, Redruth, Aberdeen and Hampton.  He goes on to speak of how it is still in some ways three towns – Kooringa, Aberdeen and Redruth.  He goes along with the story of ‘the early separation of the towns upon distinct nationalistic lines – Cornish, English and Welsh.  For nearly 20 years there was no direct road for traffic between the northern and southern towns.  He then says that there was no Corporation or Council of Burra until after the mines closed in 1877.  This is such a bad error that it is hard to believe that Auhl would have said it and it casts doubt on the authenticity of the text – though it is early in the period of his historical research.  He also says that only two hotels were allowed to operate inside the Mining Association’s area.  This is another error which it is hard to believe Auhl would have made.  The Burra Hotel, the Miners’ Arms and the Pig & Whistle operated in Kooringa for a long period and for shorter periods there were also others.  The Commercial Hotel also began operation near the end of the mining period.  In addition the Smelters’ Home, while at Burra North, was still within the Mining Association’s area.  He goes on to discuss how the Mining Association kept the railway outside their section and to talk of the term ‘The Burra’, supposing it to be a contraction of ‘The Burra Mine’, given that the name did not then apply to the town properly speaking.

He considers that the focal point for Burra: an Historical Town is the old mining area and its destruction would destroy any prima facie case for Burra as an Historic Town.  The retention of the unity of the town is also important.  He draws a distinction between a place of the past and a place with a past.  Burra is definitely the latter.  Burra once saved a struggling SA from bankruptcy and he believes it is now time for SA to save Burra.

History, for Historic Towns, must be more than interesting, it must be important and to attract money that importance must be at the state level, not merely parochially.  Time, he says, is running out.  Auhl then goes on to acknowledge the National Trust Museum, but considers it more important to see the town itself as the museum.]

Burra’s claims, he considers, are:

Except for Kapunda it is the oldest mining town in Australia.  Kapunda began in 1842-43 and Burra two years later.  Coppermania was the predecessor of gold fever in the eastern states.  When gold was first discovered near Bathurst Kapunda had a population of 1,000 and Burra one of 5,000.  There were deserted mining villages in SA before there were any mining camps in NSW or Victoria.

Mere age is, however, not enough; the town must be capable of survival.  Kapunda the mining town, survived, but it has been much outgrown by Kapunda the agricultural centre.  Burra, unfortunately for its growth and development, remained isolated and its population declined from 5,000 in 1850 to 3,000 in 1877 to now 1,000 or so and it has tended to make use of what buildings it had.  When the mine closed it became a forgotten town, struggling to survive – almost a frontier town on the edge of Goyder’s Line, with empty saltbush plain to its east.  The district turned from mining to wheat and sheep and from that to stud breeding.

Another reason for its survival has been its physical solidity.  Knocking things down has been an Australian pastime.  Burra buildings are solidly built of a hard carbonaceous shale, which splits easily, but presents a face which withstands weathering.  The mine buildings at Burra have withstood neglect, time and weather much better that the limestone structures at Kadina and Wallaroo.  Progress which involves the modernisation of shop fronts etc. is not necessarily progress in a tourist town.

‘It is my firm belief that Burra’s biggest business lies in its possibilities as an historic town.  The destruction or radical alteration of its buildings to me constitutes the destruction of its assets.’

Auhl thought the Burra Town Council more far sighted in this respect than most others.  Of course Burra will need modern buildings and institutions, such as for its hospital and school and a motel, but it does not need modernisation of its existing buildings, which are the very assets of its future.

Happily Burra has largely used the buildings it had and its walls are largely intact, though some are sadly neglected.  Hardly any street of sector of the town lacks the sort of place which a visitor cannot find with delight.

The isolation of Burra has, in large measure, been responsible for its preservation, but this is at complete variance with its early history, when it was the economic heart of the colony.  Many towns on the Copper Road and from Gawler to Burra grew around the wayside inns marking the end of a day’s journey for the bullock teams to and from Burra.

The history of Burra is visual rather than written.  There are very few living in Burra who could remember even the closing of the mines.  Few locals know the story of their town and fewer realise its significance.  Since the visit of the Adelaide National Trust to Burra there has been some revival of interest and a subsequent tour for local people brought an almost overwhelming attendance.

Written History

When Burra’s history comes to be written it will almost be the history of SA for 1845-60.  It took ten years for SA’s population to reach 20,000, but in the following four years it jumped to 60,000.  By 1848 its mineral exports were £320,000 out of a total of £465,000.  Shipping increased from 10,000 tons in 1844 to 80,000 tons four years later.  At times the mine had 6,000 bullocks on the road, with at least 1,000 drivers and drays.  Burra’s population was 5,000 when Adelaide’s was 20,000.  This history remains to be told, though Geoffrey Blainey made a beginning in his book The Rush that Never Ended.

Vandalism

The slow vandalism of time and weather has had little impact on Burra’s native stone buildings. The vandalisms of individuals, often thoughtless, but sometimes deliberate or inspired by greed, or sometimes almost sadistic, have had their effect.  There is also the vandalism of indifference.  This is the most dangerous, as it allows the other forms to go unchecked.  This cannot be checked without the help of Acts of Parliament.

There is also the vandalism of snobbery, which believes a mansion is intrinsically more worthy of preservation than the houses of common people.  To me the preservation of the miners’ huts in the Burra Creek is as important as the preservation of Ayers’ House.  Let us remember that the former preceded and were responsible for the latter.  Country museums have a bad habit of beginning to look alike.

‘And a natural corollary of a museum in a town is plaques in the rest of the town.  Nothing to me is more pathetic than a plaque.  It is a symbol of defeat.’

‘Plaques are epitaphs.’

‘A book – a record of some kind – yes!’

‘This type of preservation is the basis of National Histories and the flesh of our National bones.’

‘Buildings lead to questions – and questions lead to research – and research leads to preservation.’

[Auhl then goes on to say he has been encouraged by the responses he has had to requests to Government Departments.  He says while the National Trust has as yet no access to Government funds, Councils and Corporations have, through Tourist Grants.  This means working with the Tourist Bureau.]

The Town Planning Act has yet to be tested as far as historic towns and their buildings are concerned, but the 1965 Aboriginal and Historic Relics Act is perhaps the most hopeful piece of legislation.  Local business organisations take even more convincing than politicians, but once convinced are the most useful and energetic of the lot.

‘If…as I believe that Burra did indeed save the young South Australia, surely it is not too much to ask South Australia to now save Historic Burra.’

Ian Auhl writes in response to remarks made by E.C. Allen MP when opening the Burra Show, when he mentioned the possibility of a short term re-opening of the old Burra Mine:

While the facts given by Mr Allen are no doubt correct, there are many unanswered questions in people’s minds.  Mr Allen does not know the town well enough to realise that the short term future he envisages is in direct conflict with its long term future role as a tourist town and Australia’s oldest mining area.  If what was being offered was another Mt Isa or even a new Burra Mine there would be no doubt about the benefits, though even then some would no doubt regret the passing of the old mine area.  Bur exactly what will Burra (or SA) gain by the destruction of the old mine area and all its buildings – by the destruction of an area unique in Australia and which is Burra’s central asset as a tourist attraction?  Mt answer is, it would be exchanging its unique heritage for a mess and not for any real gain.  Among the questions that need to be answered are:

What percentage of copper does the 3.4 million tons of ore body contain?  The correct answer, I believe, is an average 1%.

How much of this 1% can be extracted by present processes?  About 60%.  So the useful part of the ore is about 0.5%.  This would be unprofitable at present, even with the high price of copper.  An efficient metallurgical process would apparently make it profitable by managing to extract another 0.25%.  We are not told what the profits of the mine would amount to, but surely they would be marginal.

Who would profit?  Mainly the shareholders of Broken Hill South of which Mines Exploration Ltd is a subsidiary company.

What would Burra get out of this?  Extra trade as the result of employing some 35 or so men.  Other benefits have not been specified.

Where would they be housed?  Perhaps in company caravans or units, as they have been for the past few years or perhaps on Housing Trust land near the Redruth Gaol.

Past experience suggests they would be single men.

Would they be Burra men?  It is not stated.

What houses would be affected?  What area of the town would the open cut affect?  What would be the length and width of the open cut?  Would it be about ¾ mile long by ¼ mile wide and 500 ft deep?

What effect would the pumping have on the Burra watertable?

Would any of the ore body be processed in Burra?  Or would it be transported 600 miles to Cobar for processing?

Is there any indication that after a maximum of ten years mining there would be any permanent benefit for Burra?

Some twelve months ago I mentioned these questions to an officer of Mines Exploration Ltd and spoke of the relative value to Burra of such a small mining venture compared with the value of the town’s long term tourist possibilities.  The answer was ‘So what?’ as if this could be of no concern to the people of Burra and was evidently of little concern to someone chasing a quick quid.

Is Mr Allen aware that the Corporation of Burra owns the mine area and the mineral rights?

What compensation is likely to be paid whether the mine opens or not?

Is Mr Allen aware that Mines Exploration Ltd used the old powder magazine for storing bags of samples and this has resulted in the cracking of the roof of this, the oldest mine building in Australia?

Does Mr Allen know the company fenced around the chief tourist attraction – Graves’ Shaft and Engine House?  Was permission sought or given for these acts?  What compensation arrangements have been made for the loss of the mining area and its buildings or for damage done?  Is the establishment of a small mining venture in the heart of a town really wanted?  Id Burra needs a boost it is already getting one from the growing tourist traffic and the value to the town of thousands of tourists will be much greater than the value of an additional 35 men or so for a maximum of ten years.  Various Governments have spent a considerable sum in exploring the mine area, but the answer is a doubtful one and of comparatively little value to Burra itself.  This apparent boost could be more of a kick in the pants than a shot in the arm.  I would like to see a public meeting to give the people of Burra a chance to express their opinions and ask their own questions on the matter of Burra’s future.

E.C. Allen’s Bomb

On 27 September a parcel bomb was addressed to E.C. Allen MP for Burra at Parliament House, Adelaide.  It had been posted in a letter box in Adelaide in the afternoon of 27thand delivered to Mr Allen at Parliament House. Believing it to be a parcel of goods his wife had purchased at John Martin’s, because of a label on it, he took it home to Spalding without opening it.  Mrs Allen opened the parcel slowly and the bomb, which was exposed when she removed the lid of the box, failed to explode.  CIB members attended with the Army bomb disposal squad and rendered the bomb harmless.  It was in a parcel 6 inches x 2½ inches x 2½ inches.  It was rigged so that a Schermuly ‘Mars’ hand flare connected to a .243 Metallverken make cartridge would trigger gelignite.  Scientists discovered that dust on the wood in the bomb has come from the Burra North area.  Detectives have been conducting investigations in the area from 12 November and the Government has offered a $2,000 reward for information leading to the apprehension of the sender.

Burra Mine.

[E.C. Allen writes seeking to clarify the implications of the possible re-opening of the Burra Mine.]

Too many assumptions have been made by people not in possession of the facts.  On 10 January 1966 the then Minister of Mines Hon. S.C. Bevan MLC advised Mines Exploration Ltd of his acceptance of their proposal to explore the area.  Both the present and the previous Government have placed much emphasis on mineral exploration in SA to directly help state income.  Indicated reserves at Burra are 3.3 million tons of possible ore at an average 1.6% copper.  The problem of how much of this can be extracted is being investigated.  Consequently it is not yet possible to say how much the mine would be worth – a figure also affected by changing copper prices.  A rough estimate, however, suggests that 3.3 million tons yielding 1% copper at the present price of $1,000 per ton would realise $33 million.  Some 60-70 men would be directly employed with a payroll of about $5,000 per week or $260,000 per year.  As many local men as were available would be employed and housing would be built as needed – men would not live in caravans or units.  No homes would be affected by the possible open pits, the largest of which would finally be 1,100 feet x 750 ft and the smaller 800 ft x 300 ft, separated by some 300 ft and the deepest would be some 300 ft in depth.  Experience suggests the water table would not be affected except in the immediate mine area.  Ore would be treated to the concentration stage at Burra, as otherwise transportation cost would be prohibitive.  I asked a question in the House on 28 November to see if provision could be made when laying the natural gas pipeline through Gum Creek and Leighton areas, for a later connection to Burra.  Arrangements were completed some time ago with the Corporation to realign the fence in the Graves’ Shaft area to allow access to the shaft (the cost to be borne by Mines Exploration Ltd.) and this has been attended to.  It is expected the life of operations would be 10-15 years.  I have no doubt that both mining activities and tourist activities could work together.  The Department of Mines Exploration have expressed a keen desire to do everything possible to preserve the early relics of mining in this area and I have been given to understand they would be prepared to remove and re-erect any of the buildings considered to be of value.  I have supplied a map showing the extent of the proposed operations.

[Editor: the map will be displayed in the Record Office window.]

Burra Councils to Unite

A joint sitting of the Burra Burra District Council and the Burra Town Council was held in the [DC] Council Chambers in Commercial Street on 3 December.  DC Chairman G.R. Finch presided.  Cr B.A. Riggs moved and Cr T. Quinn seconded that the merged Council comprise eight councillors from the District Council of Burra Burra and three from the Corporation of Burra.  Carried.

It was also resolved that in the new Council the Corporation would be represented by three Councillors from one ward, to be known as Burra Town Ward and that the ward boundaries would be those of the present Corporation.  The New Council will be called the District Council of Burra Burra.

It was also resolved that the rates would be levied under the unimproved land value system.

Burra Mine

Mr Allen MP recently asked in Parliament whether there will be provision made for natural gas to be supplied from the pipeline to Burra.  Premier Hon. R.S. Hall undertook to bring the matter to the notice of the Minister of Mines and to get a reply.  The reply was that while technical problems re the economic recovery of the copper remain to be solved the question is somewhat academic, but there is no doubt that if the economics justify it, gas could be made available.

Obituary.  John Alfred Scott Fisher was born at Kilmore, Victoria, the youngest of three children.  He attended Moorabbin State School and later Rochester High School.  As a youth he worked at the Electricity Power House and the butter factory, where he gained a suction gas certificate.  He was a keen footballer and member of the Rochester Brass Band.  In Melbourne he joined Hume Steel Pipe Construction and came to Thevenard as a qualified welder on the Tod River Scheme.  Later he joined the E & WS Department and became second-in-charge of the Tod River Pumping Station.  In 1931 he married Irene Sheridan at Pt Lincoln.  He was later transferred to Burra as District Superintendent and was in charge of the gas engines used to pump the town water supply.  Here he was active in the Burra Rifle Club, Koonoona Cricket Club, Aberdeen Football Club, the War Memorial Committee, and the Burra Pictures.  (He held an ‘A’ class projectionist’s licence.)  He was an advisor to Rural Youth and was on the Burra Library Committee and a keen worker for St Joseph’s Church and School, Secretary of the High School Council and the Burra Racing Club.  He was a North Ward Councillor and was appointed a JP in 1950 and acted as local coroner for many years.  He retired due to ill health and died at the QEH 15 October 1968 [aged 63].  He is survived by his widow and three daughters: Joan Mrs Laredo, Margaret Mrs Deer and Helen Mrs Clark.  Mrs Hamilton of Tongala, Victoria is a sister and Mr H. Fisher of Christchurch, New Zealand is a brother.

Burra High School Speech Night was held last Monday night.  Headmaster Farrow expressed his concern at falling enrolments.  The Mayor and Mayoress, Mr Allen MP & Mrs Allen, Chairman of the District Council Cr G. Finch & Mrs Finch, Miss Sprat Headmistress of Burra Primary School and the religious instruction teachers attended.  The guest speaker was Mr White.

The post war boom and raising the school leaving age led to increased school enrolments, but now the increasing size of farm holdings and migration out of the mid-north to other areas is presenting the school with a period of stability, or even of decline.  The year started with 170 students and finished with 150 – the smallest for some years.  The loss of 20 students during the year is perhaps of more concern than the overall decline.  The 1967 exam results were particularly pleasing with 90% satisfying subject grades in PEB Intermediate and Leaving.  All candidates presenting for the Alternative Certificate (Internal Intermediate Course) were successful.  We congratulate Christopher Freeman who gained 7 subjects with 6 grade 1 passes.  He won an Intermediate Bursary.  Malcolm White and Andrew Ryan were awarded Intermediate Continuation Scholarships.

Recently three students were given Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships based on special examinations taken in July this year: Lynette Griffen, Angela Quinn and Chrystine Steele.  In 1969 the Intermediate Certificate, both internal and external, will be abolished.  The path to University matriculation will also be modified.  The new Junior Secondary Curriculum will provide a challenge to all.  We should guard against judging what a child is asked to do by some vocational yard stick.  Life is big and marvellous and to be enjoyed.  Our concept of it needs to be panoramic and not narrow and hazy.  But the school is not all hard work.  The extra-curricular life is rich and rewarding.  Burra High School has provided the breadth of sport, travel, club, social and involvement in other worthy causes.  I am concerned that on leaving school in country areas like Burra there is something of a dearth of such wider experiences in the community – a lack of cultural groups, of adult education, recognised community groups and projects.  Parents too have a role to play.  There have been instances this year of incidents of deliberate mischief.  If your child has access to a vehicle, make sure it is for legitimate purposes and is handled properly.  If the child has access to a phone at will, should they?  If a child is involved in an incident away from school premises don’t blame the school.  Nine times out of ten it is the parents’ upbringing of the child which is at fault.  And if you are the type to blame the school, don’t then turn around and blame the staff if they do take action.

We are once again very grateful to the Parents & Friends’ Association and the High School Council for all the amenities provided and improvements made.

The triennial election for the School Council in June saw Mr D.H. Field re-appointed as Chairman; Mr T.G. Perry as Secretary and Mr R.B. Jennison as Treasurer.  Thanks to Mr D. White, who has been Acting Secretary while Mr Perry has been overseas.  The Parents & Friends’ Assoc. has been led by President Mrs F. Matthews with Mrs B. Bevan Secretary and Mrs P. Carpenter as Treasurer.  It has sponsored the annual ball, catered for sports day and will on 18 December provide the usual annual banquet.  This year they have provided a portable amplifier, new tennis nets, additions to the library and a television receiver.  The Government has made improvements to school buildings and there is a project to have a recreation room for students.

Thanks are extended to Mrs Cockington for playing the accompaniment for the Girls’ Choir and to Mrs Carpenter for leading them.  Also to the religious instruction staff for doing so well a job that is all too often thankless.
