Burra National Trust held its AGM recently and elected: President, L. Moore; Vice-President, S.J. Woollacott; Secretary, Mrs C .O’Connor and Treasurer, R. Broad.

The retiring President S.J .Woollacott reported on a year when the Museum had been a success.  Thanks go to Ian Auhl for bringing Burra to the fore with his pen and the Mayor Mr Baulderstone, who has done so much to bring Burra’s tourist possibilities to the notice of those in authority.  The drive down Commercial Street to Market Square and thence to Burra North reveals a town that has more attractions than any other of a similar size.  Now we need to make the rest of the town as attractive.  Here the Council can assist in keeping the place tidy and in properly caring for the trees.  Success requires money and that requires an income from customers.  During the year the Museum had over 1,000 paying adults and received over $100.  We note with regret the passing of Mr Robert Fuss who was a good and practical citizen and we are grateful for the services he rendered the Trust.

After the business section of the meeting Mr Hans Mincham gave an illustrated lecture on the Flinders Ranges.

Weather.  Yesterday was hot and windy, but overnight 52 points of rain were recorded and reaping has had to be suspended for the time being.

Accident.  At about 11.30 p.m. on Friday a semi-trailer owned by S.E. Schulz of Renmark and driven by Peter E. Size of Renmark overturned on the Burra North-Morgan Road near Basin Farm.  It was taking 240 wethers for Elders-GM from Peterborough to Loxton.  Attending police worked till 3.30 a.m. freeing sheep from the bottom tray.  70 head of stock were killed or had to be destroyed.  The driver was kept in Burra Hospital over night for observation and was severely bruised.  Another truck picked up the sheep on Saturday morning and the District Council plant pulled the vehicle back onto its wheels.  Damage is estimated at $3,000.

Obituary.  William Joseph Lee was born at Marrabel 13 January 1883 and moved with his family to live at World’s End when 13 years old.  He began school at Marrabel and finished it at World’s End.  He then became a blacksmith and farrier’s apprentice at Riverton and later came to Burra to work for the late Sam Burns for 11 years.  When that business closed he worked for Mr Max Morton, after which he went into business on his own and retired after about 20 years.  In 1909 he married Miss Julia Barrow.  He became a member of the Foresters’ Lodge in 1911 and was its secretary for many years, retiring from the position at 80 years of age.  He became a member of the Kooringa Masonic Lodge in 1929 and was Grand Master [sic: for Worshipful Master] in 1945.  He became a member of the Grand Lodge in 1960.  He was a member of the Burra Brass Band, Burra Institute Library and foreman of the Burra Fire Brigade for several years.  He is survived by a wife and children: Cliff (Kalgoorlie), Ilene Mrs Campbell (Burra), Robert (Charters Towers, Qld), Ron (Townsville, Qld), Joyce Mrs D. Pexton (Poolaijelo, Victoria) and Phyllis Mrs McWaters (Melbourne).  [Died 27 November 1968 Burra.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1968

In general a good coverage of local news, though local extends to Spalding and Hallett and south towards Riverton.  Council matters are perhaps less revealing than in some periods, but a mostly reported adequately.

Page 1

Almost entirely local news with 1 or 2 advertisements.

Page 2

Usually dominated by large advertisements for perhaps one third and then by public notices and the like – but proportions fluctuate considerably and there is sometimes a news story as well.

Page 3

Important snippets of what is going on locally and news about past and present resident in very brief form in ‘Out & About’ column.  Births, deaths and marriages tend to get at least a brief mention, making this an important record, though often lacking useful details.  Large advertisements occupy about half the page or more.

Page 4

About half the page is occupied by large advertisements.  The rest is news and items of general interest.

Page 5

Large advertisements occupy perhaps three-quarters of the page with the rest the 50 years Ago Column.

But note that pages 4 & 5 are somewhat interchangeable in content.

Pages 6 & 7

Large advertisements and sports, which is the dominant news on this page, though not limited to it. The ‘Cash Column’ of small advertisements is usually on one of these pages, but can wander elsewhere.

Page 8

This is a mixture of advertisements of varying size for some 4 of the 7 columns.  The rest is the overflow of sport and general news and items of general interest.

Supplements were not frequent, but overflow was often accommodated by printing in the gutters.  This was usually in the 306 gutter, but sometimes in 4-5 gutters and occasionally in the 207 gutter and sometimes in more than one of them.

The supplement on 26 November was larger than a full-sized page and was an advertisement celebrating Sargasso’s 10th birthday – the Burra Agent was Guy Dollman’s Burra Motor Co.  It featured four colour printing and was folded into quarters.

Burra Silos wheat intake to yesterday equals the record 1966-67 season of 295,000 bushels.  It began a fortnight later, with the first delivery on 10 December when Mr Graham Heinrich of World’s End and then Mr Gordon Webster of Springbank delivered a load and deliveries here have been more concentrated this year.  A number of farmers have already delivered their quotas of 75% of their harvest.  Some have decided to bag the other 25%, while most have converted to bulk storage.  Burra has the capacity to stack 17,000 bags and Norm Maxted of Mt Bryan delivered the first bags on Friday.  Not much remains locally to be reaped.

Amalgamation of Councils

No objections have been received to the proposed union of the Burra Burra District Council and the Town Council and the period for objections has now passed.

The area of the proposed union will be divided into nine wards: Burra Town, Kooringa, Baldina, Booborowie, Leighton, Mt Bryan, Mongolata, Farrell Flat and Hanson.  Each ward except Burra Town is to have one Councillor, with Burra Town to have three.  Provision is to be made for the election of a Mayor as in the Corporation.  Assessments will be on the basis of unimproved land values.  There has been no call for a poll of ratepayers and so the petition has been drawn up and will be signed and sealed at a special combined meeting of the two Councils tonight.  It is hoped that the proclamation of the union will enable the combined Councils to sit as one commencing in April.  This would give time for the preparation of and the calling of nominations for Councillors for all wards to form the new Council to operate from 1 July 1969.  The February and March meetings of both Councils will remain divided.  A Bill to amend the Local Government Act 1934-67 to cover the election of a Mayor under circumstances similar to those which exist here will go before the Legislative Council when it sits next.  It is anticipated that a Mayor for the whole area will be elected by ratepayers and in turn be appointed Chairman of the Council.  Previously it had been understood the Mayor would be elected by ratepayers and a Chairman elected by Council.  With Mr T.G. Perry acting as Town Clerk all business of the Town Council is being conducted from the District Council Office in Commercial Street.

Weather.  A line of thunderstorms on Thursday dumped heavy falls across the district.  A half mile wide strip of North Booborowie was flooded when 2 inches fell in half an hour.  Terowie reported another deluge.  Leighton also received heavy rain.  At Hanson and Farrell Flat falls varied from 60-70 points.  Erratic falls are reported from the east; Old Koomooloo 15 points, Koomooloo 2 points at the homestead, but over 200 on the western end of the property.  Woolgangi received 40 points.  The Booborowie deluge included hail, some of which was the size of pigeons’ eggs and creeks ran eight feet deep.  Fencing was swept away.  Damage to fallow was extensive, but areas of flooded lucerne will benefit.  The trench for the gas pipeline became a flowing stream and quite a deal of clean-up is needed.  Booborowie post office officially registered 120 points.

[The Burra Railway Station sketch is reproduced.]

Burra Railway Station: the first train steamed into the station at 12.45 p.m. on 27 August 1870. [actually 29 August]  It carried eight carriages and 400 passengers, without distinction of class or other distinction.  Fifteen minutes later the select train bearing H.E. Sir James Fergusson, Lady Fergusson and other dignitaries arrived, hauled by a decorated engine.  The engine had made the 100 mile journey in five hours.  Three thousand locals were on hand to greet it and the town was enjoying a public holiday.  Welcoming archways had been erected.  The station and goods shed had been festooned with greenery, which must have occasioned havac [sic] on the trees for 15 miles around.  Feasting went on all day.    The official luncheon with speeches in the goods shed lasted so long that the Vice-Regal party had only time for a quick tour round the town before departing at 4.50 p.m.  On the return there was a delay at Farrell Flat when the train ran over [and killed] a signalman sho was to have waved the red flag at the crossing.

At Burra the celebrations continued with a concert in the Lodge Room of the Burra Hotel, followed by a ball till dawn.  The twelve hotels [?] remained open all night.  Bonfires were lit up and down the street.

The transportation of ores had been a problem for SAMA since the mine opened in 1845, when the colony had no railways.  Bullock drays at first took the ore to Pt Adelaide via Kapunda, for shipment to Swansea in Wales.  Later, from 1847, the road to Pt Wakefield shortened the journey by 30 miles, but was so difficult through the hills that the company tried replacing the bullock drays with pack mules – hundreds being brought from Montevideo with Spanish-American muleteers.  Towns grew up along the route, but both the route and the towns were abandoned by the Smelting Company in 1857 when the railway reached Gawler.  When the railway arrived at Kapunda in August 1860 the old copper road to Kapunda was resumed.  The Burra Burra Mine was almost exhausted by the time the first rain reached Burra in 1870.

Paxton Square was declared an Historic Reserve under the Aboriginal & Historic Relics Preservation Act 1965, on 9 January 1969.  William Paxton was a Hindley Street Chemist.  In 1845 he and three other Hindley Street businessmen formed a company to light Adelaide streets with gas.  The scheme was quickly shelved when one of them, Thomas Bunce, shared the news he had of the discovery of copper on the Burra Creek.  A shepherd named Streair had come to Adelaide and traded his knowledge of it for £8.  Paxton invested £140 in the get-rich-quick scheme and became one of the first directors of the new SA Mining Association.  The shop-keeping nobodies were wealthy men within two years and the Burra Burra Mine became a bonanza.

Paxton acquired a number of choice sites in the private town of Kooringa and soon owned the hotels: the Burra and the Miners’ Arms (now called the Burra Hotel).  One of his properties on the east side of the creek became known as Paxton’s Square, though when he sold it the only building on it was the Bible Christian Chapel, now Baulderstone’s storeroom.  The Mining Association acquired it from him in 1852 and engaged Cornish masons to erect 33 cottages on three sides.  The eleven cottages on each side enclosed common land for the tenants.  The cottages were erected to house Cornish deep miners brought out especially from Cornwall in the 1850s to work the deeper lodes where water was a problem.  Each had two or three rooms with floors of packed clay and cost 5/- a week.  When SA Mining Association went into liquidation in 1914 the cottages were acquired by John Lewis, then of the Burra stock and station firm of Liston, Shakes & Lewis.

[Note: the cottages were passed in at auction in October 1912 and Lewis purchased them towards the end of 1913.]

Lewis later became Hon. John Lewis MLC, Father of Essington Lewis the great industrialist.

[Actually Lewis was already an MLC, serving in the SA Legislative Council 1898-1923.]

Mrs Jane Melrose of Kadlunga, Mintaro, is a daughter.

In March 1923 Paxton Square was incorporated into a trust by Lewis who arranged for it to be managed by a Board of Management.  Hon. John Lewis died a few months later.  [25 August 1923]

The cottages were to house the poor and needy of Burra.  The trustees for many years were Stanley Kellaway, Isaac Warnes & Mrs Jane Melrose.  In 1968it was being administered by members of the Lewis family: Mr R. Lewis, Mrs Melrose & Mrs J. Gosse.  Until last year Mr Stan Kellaway Jnr acted as Curator for the Lewis Trust.

Following a meeting between representatives of the Burra Town Council and the Burra National Trust early in 1968 a common approach was made to the Lewis Trust to consider the appointment of local trustees.  The meeting was chaired by R.B. Lewis and considered ways of bringing the cottages up to an acceptable standard while still fulfilling the original purpose of the trust.  It was realised that Paxton Square could not be sold nor the trust dissolved without a special act of Parliament.

It was decided to bring some cottages up to standard while respecting their original external features.  New trustees were appointed, with Rev. G.D. Sibly as Chairman and the Board of Management was enlarged to include local trustees: Mr R. Jennison, Mr L. Phillips, Mr G. Finch, Mr S. Woollacott, Rev. G.D. Sibly and Mr E.T. Baulderstone.  A plan of modernisation was drawn up by S.J. Woollacott, who has already made substantial improvements to the living amenities of the cottages.  He is the present curator.

Realising their important significance in Australia’s mining story, Mr Ian Auhl submitted an application in 1968 to the Board administering the Historic Relics Act, asking that Paxton square be proclaimed an Historic Reserve.  He was supported by representatives of the Lewis family.  At a meeting of the Lewis Trust in Burra the Secretary of the Relics Board, Mr R. Edwards, acting on behalf of the Board and the Protector of Relics, Dr Inglis, asked the trustees to consider giving their support to the move and they agreed.  The application was also endorsed by Mr Dean Berry, President of the Sa National Trust.

Professor Geoffrey Blainey also lent his support.  Paxton Square is the first building in SA to be proclaimed an Historic Reserve under the Act.  The present trustees are appointed Wardens under the Act.  More and more people in Burra as well as those who study Australia’s pioneering past are realising that Burra has a whole series of buildings which make the town unique in SA.

Burra Mine

Through the efforts of Mr Ian Auhl, Mr Alister Colebatch, a surveyor for ETSA and Mr Claude Allen MP it has been confirmed that the Burra Town Council owns the mineral rights to the Mine site.  It has been understood for many years that the mineral rights were owned by Mr P.A.M. McBride, even after the purchase of the property by the Corporation in 1960.  Searches through various Departmental records have now satisfied Mr Auhl and Mr Colebatch that the rights lie with the Town Council.  It was arranged through the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone that they attend a meeting of Council to pass on the news of this discovery.  This was done on 27 May last year and it was then resolved that establishment of the ownership of the mineral rights be obtained from the Minister of Mines.  No answer had been obtained when Mr Allen spoke on the possible re-opening of the Burra Mine when he opened the Burra Show.  This prompted a letter to the Record from Mr Ian Auhl in which he asked among other questions whether the MP was aware that the mineral rights belonged to the Town Council and if so what compensation they could expect.  Mr Allen replied in a letter published on 3 December which addressed a number of the questions, but not that related to mineral rights; apparently because there remained some doubt about it.  We now have a letter from Mr Allen with a response from the Minister of Mines.

The area of rights so far as the Corporation is concerned covers the whole of the open cut section and area to the west and south.  Mr Allen has asked what progress has been made on the metallurgical problem.

Hon. R.S. Hall replied that for the period to 31 December 1968 three independent avenues of research are being pursued and the company (Mines Exploration Pty Ltd) said it would probably take six months to finalise these investigations and the Department is confident that the company is doing its best to find a satisfactory solution.

Mt Bryan & Hallett Water Scheme

Mr Allen MP undertook to look into the report on the proposed water scheme for Mt Bryan and Hallett made by the E & WS Department.  The Department found that such a scheme would not be practical.  The towns are too small to recover even the interest on the capital invested.  Clare for example used 90 million gallons in 1967-68 and the cost of getting water pumped from Farrell Flat to Clare was 75 cents per 1,000 gallons.  Burra receives water pumped from Hanson and used 41 million gallons at a cost of $1.05 per 1,000 gallons.  The Minister of Works states the cost of supplying River Murray water to Mt Bryan would be $175,000.  If all landowners between Mt Bryan and Burra paid the normal rate of 27c per acre on all land within one mile of the pipeline the revenue would be c. $3,456.  Rates from the town would not bring in more than $1,000.  This would represent 2½% interest on the capital cost and this does not include the actual cost of pumping or general maintenance.  Some landowners are not prepared to contribute so the Minister is correct in saying it is impracticable.  An alternative local source is also full of difficulties.  Good supplies of [bore] water are available, but are too poor for use in hot water systems.  Also, if supplied, all vacant blocks would be rateable for the minimum rates of $8 per year.

The Minister of Works said the matter had been investigated following a petition from landowners between Mt Bryan and Burra for Murray water to be extended to Mt Bryan with a pipe of sufficient size to enable later extension to Hallett.  Two pumping stations and two tanks would be needed.  The proposal needs 10 miles of 8 inch main and a 100,000 gallon surface tank at Mt Bryan.  Expenditure of $170,000 to reach Mt Bryan and a further $145,000 to include Hallett.  Three landowners indicated intention to irrigate lucerne.  All properties have adequate stock water supplies and it is unsound for the E & WS to provide Murray water for lucerne irrigation.  Neither scheme can be justified.  A report on the likelihood of obtaining supplies from bores in Mt Bryan area has been asked for.

Bob Crewes (K.R. Crewes) welcomed retired French Colonel Andre Gaugier to SA as reported in yesterday’s Advertiser.  Bob was a lieutenant in D Coy 27th Battalion AIF in WWI and was one of seven officers billeted in the French village of Le Grand Fayt late in the war.  Their billet was a partly wrecked factory and also living there were Madame Gauguir [sic] and her children Andre (11) and Paul (7) – a refugee family.  The officers became good friends with the Gauguiers [sic] sharing rations and playing games.  Andre and three of the officers met on Sunday at Outer Harbour when the Colonel disembarked from the liner Galileo for a few hours.

Mt Bryan Wheat Growers held a meeting in the Mt Bryan Hall on 10 February to press for the erection of silos at Mt Bryan.  Present also were Mr Venning of CBH Ltd and Mr Claude Allen MP.  It was resolved that some form of temporary storage be erected at Mt Bryan and more rail trucks be made available for Burra and Hallett to help the clearance of this year’s crop.  CBH says the bountiful harvest this year has added to the problem – the harvest is about four times the previous year’s and 30 million bushels over the highest ever delivery in SA of just over 50 million bushels.  There was also about 25% carry-over from the old season, as the Wheat Board was unable to sell all of last year’s crop before this year’s harvest and even at this time some 10% of last year’s wheat remains in the silo system.  It is not the policy of the company to erect temporary storage at non-silo stations, but we can say that extensions due to be finalised at Saddleworth next September will now be completed by next month and by 20 March we will have space for an additional 330,000 bushels of wheat at Saddleworth in these new cells.  A new steel structure at Hamley Bridge will have a capacity of 70,000 bushels at about the same time.

Mr Bill Mierke addressed a meeting of farmers at Burra last week at the Burra Town Hall on the subject of nitrogen fertilizer urea.  Mr Mierke is an agronomist with Australia Pacific Fertilizer Ltd.

World’s End Methodist Church was broke into in the early hours of Sunday morning.  It had been set up on Saturday night for its Thanksgiving Service.  A window was broken and some of the produce spattered over the walls.  Vases of flowers were knocked over and some boxes of produce were found outside the church.  Members cleared up as well as they could and the service went ahead, but it lacked the usual feelings associated with thanksgiving.  Windows in a nearby unoccupied house owned by Mr Ken Phillips were also damaged by rifle bullets.

Fire.  Following a burning off operation by the railway ganger that got out of control on 10 January a meeting was held by landowners at Hallett.  The meeting requested that all landowners be notified of burning off operations, that burning off be commenced as early is the season as possible and that farmers be allowed to plough breaks on railway land to add to their protection.  The Railway Commissioner Mr Fitch replied that landowners had been notified in writing of the intent to burn off.  Burning was done as soon as possible, but the ganger had a large area to cover and burning off could not be done when fewer than four men were present.  In the Burra District the burning is done as a joint operation and the railways would be happy to extend such co-operation to the Hallett area.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM 4 March.

Classrooms were open to inspection before the meeting.  Though it had spent over $900 for the year, it still held $450. Burra Primary School Headmistress’s Report

1968 was a busy year.  Several sporting fixtures were held.  In Term 1 the swimming carnival was held on 23 February when Hampton House won.  The School Sports Day was held on a 19 April which was variously dusty, wet, and windy.  Aberdeen won the Gebhardt Cup.  On 22 March we entered two teams in the State Schools Swimming Championship in Adelaide.  On 3 May we fielded two tennis teams in the District Sports Day at Hallett.  The Purple Team returned with the Open Aggregate Shield and the Green Team was runner-up in the Team Games.  Interschool basketball and football games were held in Term 2.

In 1968 there was a mid-year exam and a final exam for promotional purposes.  ACER tests in reading, spelling and number processes were given in Term 1.  End of year awards went to:

Deborah Kirk & Penelope Miller gained the Andrew Tennant Award

Deborah Brand won the Most Consistent Effort Award

John Brak gained the Service to School Award.

In April each class visited the National Trust Museum in Burra.  Grade I visited the Post Office, the bakery and the Fire Station and with Grade II had a train & bus trip to Hanson.  Grades V & VI visited the Town Hall Library.  Grade V went to a shearing shed.  Junior Red Cross was active in the year and held its own fete as well as having several visiting speakers.  Grade VII produced its own magazine ‘The Monthly Review’.

Special Days observed were: Anzac Day, Pioneers’ Day, Conservation Day, World Children’s Day (featuring an austerity meal of rice) and United Nations Day (featuring clothes from other lands).

The Gale Evening saw each class present an item.  Parents too had a busy year with the Welfare Club providing sports equipment, aids for teachers, curtains, fans, cupboards and a table cloth for the staffroom and an amplifier (not yet arrived).  The Welfare Club ran stalls on Gala Night, a library service roster and donated ice creams and drinks for the children’s parties and the Swimming Carnival.  Mrs Perry was away overseas for a term and a half.  At the end of 1968 Miss McKenzie left to get married and to live in NSW and Mr John Cain has come from Western Teachers College in her place.  This year numbers have decreased to 222 at present.

Local Government Amendment Act

Some changes made will affect Local Government procedure.  Certain District Councils will be able to ask the Government to proclaim that the chief elected member be a Mayor in lieu of a Chairman.  Wives of owners of rateable property are enfranchised.  Councils will be able to set revenue aside in Reserve Funds for certain projects.  Councils will be able to proceed with schemes of development or re-development providing the scheme has been approved by the State Planning Authority.  Postal voting procedures have been revised – in particular it will be easier to find authorised witnesses.

Burraite writes on Paxton Square.  Following your recent article on Paxton Square a visit to two of the modernised renovated cottages was certainly an eye-opener.  Each has a new bathroom with electric hot water system, shower, new toilet connected to a new septic system and the quite large rooms are in excellent condition.  These flats will enable an aged pensioner couple to enjoy good living conditions as a low rental in a solid, well insulated building, cool in summer and warm in winter.  Much credit goes to Mr Stan Woollacott for getting maximum results at minimum cost.  As Paxton Square is now an Historic Reserve, the buildings cannot be pulled down, so unless an effort is made to restore them to habitable conditions, they will deteriorate into unsightly ruins.  ‘Please Burraites show your pride in your town as it is today, and also in its unique history as an early mining town, as evidenced by its many fine old buildings.

Editor:

Mr Woollacott has carried out a great deal of work not only on four of the houses, which have had the attention mentioned above, but in cleaning up the central area at the rear of the houses.  Quite a number of old toilets have been removed.  Mr Woollacott has certainly shown that as far as he is concerned he is not going to let it deteriorate further.

Burra Burra Show Inc.  AGM

The President Mr Rex Stockman expressed pleasure at the results of last year’s show both with respect to exhibits and financially.  It was decided this year to ask the Premier Hon. Steele Hall to open the 1969 Show.  Cadell Training Centre will be approached to exhibit its produce.

The 1968 Show was opened by Mr E.C. Allen MP, Member for Burra.  The 2527 entries were just below the previous year’s record.  With 500 entries in the Horses-in-Action, the event ran throughout the day.  The Hack Section was among the best in the state.  Sheep entries were down, but quality was very good.  The wool display was good, but considering Burra’s position as the centre of a major wool district, it could be larger.  Industrial sites were filled and included a light aircraft display from Air Mist.  The agricultural pavilion had a good display of fruit, vegetable, needlework, grain and fodder, but lacked support in art and cooking sections.  The Rural Youth display was the same as was entered for the Royal Adelaide Show, and was of a very high standard.  Poultry and birds were well represented and although flowers and floral art entries were down by nearly half, the exhibits were up to the usual high standards.  Sideshows were very numerous and of greater variety than in previous years.  Thanks, of course, go to the convenors, stewards, judges and exhibitors and especially to our new secretary, Miss Judy Beinke.

Burra Rubbish Dump.  An anonymous invitation was extended to the Town Clerk and Councillors to attend a social gathering at the Council Dump.  The Council has long been aware of the untidiness of the dump, but it is due to ratepayers who insist on dropping their rubbish where they like, rather than in the designated place. The Council will cover the existing mess and appeals to people not to dump rubbish outside the official site.

Burra Town Hall interior has had a face-lift.  The interior has been painted, new lighting installed and shortly new carpet will be laid on the stairways to the lounge.  The ceiling over the lounge area has been replaced.  The new lighting should benefit balls in the coming season.

Council Elections

Mr T.G. Perry, District and Acting Town Clerk, advises that nominations for the annual elections for the two Councils should be called during April.  Owing to the amount of time necessary before the Combined Council can be proclaimed, the nominations will not be called until after 26 April 1969.  It is expected that nominations will be called for the now Combined Council, to close on the usual date; the second Friday in May – the 9th.  One member for each ward of the district and three members for Burra Town Ward will be required to give a Council of eleven members.  The position of Mayor is in doubt till the first meeting of the Combined Council.  To complete the official current term the two existing Councils will meet as a combined body for two meetings in May and June.  The new Council asked for a commencement following the first Saturday in July after the elections are completed.

Accident.  On Thursday afternoon a semi-trailer loaded with 117 bales of wool tipped over at Hanson, blocking half the road, which was busy with Easter traffic.  It was owned by Hi-Speed Transport of Broken Hill who sent two more vehicles and a forklift to reload the wool.  These arrived about 9 p.m.  Complications arose in trying to unload the forklift when the truck got bogged across the railway line when an attempt was made to unload the forklift onto the platform.  That delayed the northbound passenger train for 70 or 80 minutes.  Eventually the forklift had to be unloaded at the Burra Council Depot and driven to Hanson.

Another accident was luckily averted when a connecting bolt on a towbar broke and sent a caravan careering across the road at the scene above.  Fortunately no damage was done and repairs could be effected to allow it to continue.  Police eventually were able to leave the scene after 14 hours at Hanson.

Burra National Trust held a meeting in the CWA Rooms on Monday 14 April.  Mr Alexander from the National Trust in Adelaide spoke first, followed by Mr Ian Auhl.  He paid tribute to Mr A.E. Weekend School 9-11 May.  The Department of Adult Education at the University of Adelaide will run the school on The Historic Copper Towns of SA.  In their heyday these were the mainstay of the colonial and then the state economy and in the mid 19th century the main suppliers of copper to the world.  The aims of the school are:

To give an account of the fascinating social and industrial history of the copper towns.

To stimulate discussion and action on the care, understanding and preservation of their historic relics.

The school begins with lectures in the University of Adelaide’s Lecture Theatre No.5 Napier Building on Friday evening and Saturday morning and afternoon.  On Sunday there will be a guided tour to Kapunda and Burra.  You can enrol for the lectures only.

Friday 7.45 p.m. Copper SA by Dr John Tregenza, Senior Lecturer, History Department, University of Adelaide.

Saturday 10.30 a.m. The Geological Background to Copper Mining in SA by Mr Keith Johns, Supervising Geologist, Mineral Resources Division SA Department of Mines.

Saturday 2 p.m. Burra in Historical Perspective by Ian Auhl, Burra Branch of the National Trust.

Saturday 4-5 p.m. Panel Discussion: Preserving the Historic Copper Towns.

The excursion will depart the University of Adelaide 8.30 a.m. Sunday 11 May and visit Kapunda Copper Mines before having lunch at Princess Royal Station – members must take packed lunches.  Then a tour of Burra town, mine are, old gaol and museum.  After refreshments at the CWA Rooms the coach will depart for the city at 5 p.m.

Fees: for the lectures and refreshments and buffet luncheon $4 and for the coach excursion $3.50.

Burra Corporation Ceases to Exist

From 25 April 1969 the Burra Corporation has amalgamated with the District Council.  The last meeting of the Burra Town Council was held on Monday 21 April and ended at 12.45 a.m. on Tuesday 22 April.  The Town Council had existed for almost 93 years, with its first meeting being on 10 July 1876.  It had been established by a proclamation of the Governor on 28 June 1876 and published in the SA Government Gazette of Thursday 29 June 1876.  This established a Council with Philip Lane as the first Mayor with six Councillors:

North Ward	George Sara & August Bartholomaeus

Middle Ward	Robert Saunders [Sanders] & Edward Lipsett

South Ward	Joseph Roberts & John Snell

The last Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone served on the Council for 23 years, the last 15 as Mayor.  He has seen the service of eight Town Clerks, several of whom had no previous local experience, which did not help to make Mr Baulderstone’s term an easy one.  The old Corporation comprised an area of 3,015 acres with some 53 miles of roads.  The existing Town Councillors will see out the final two months of the term they were elected for, as members of the amalgamated body, except for Councillors Moreland and Kotz, who, as employees of the District Council, are not permitted to serve as Councillors.  At the last meeting of the Local Board of Health for the Corporation Dr L.G. Miller was thanked for his services to the Board.

The District Council of Burra Burra was formed in 1935 as a result of the amalgamation of the District Councils of Hanson, Mt Bryan, Burra and [part of] Booborowie.  The new Council will encompass an area of 800 square miles with over 1,100 miles of road.  The new Council will meet for the first time on 14 May.  Councillors are:

Chairman G.R. Finch

E.T. Baulderstone	S.T. Miller

B.A. Riggs	J. Burge

R. White	M.T. Kellock

District Clerk is T.G. Perry.

Because the first meeting of the new Council will be on 14 May this year’s call for nominations for Councillors has been delayed.  They will be called at this meeting with nominations to close 30 May.

Obituary.  Stella Floyd Hawker died suddenly on 15 April at the home of her brother Cuthbert Ford Featherstonhough at Hamilton, Victoria.  She was buried at Bungaree Church, Clare after a service at St Andrew’s, Mt Bryan.  She was born at Albany, WA on 19 February 1898, the eldest child of Mr & Mrs Percy Featherstonhough and she married George Stanley Hawker of Clare 21 October 1931 and resided in that district till February 1935 when Mr & Mrs Hawker made their home at ‘Belcunda’ Mt Bryan, where they resided till her death.  Mrs Hawker took an active part in community affairs at Mt Bryan and Burra.  She was a Director of East Bungaree Stud and kept the books and managed the stud for nine months while Mr Hawker was in camp.  During WW II she was leader and organiser of the Mt Bryan VSD.  She was made a Life Member of the Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL on 5 July 1963 for services to it, having retired as President of the branch in 1959 after years in that post.  She was a member of the Council from 1947-60.  Mrs Hawker was the foundation President of Mt Bryan CWA branch when it was formed after WW II.  She had also put in years of service for the Red Cross during the war.  She had earlier been active in the Burra CWA branch and many CWA garden parties were held at her home over the years.  Although she had no children of her own, she took an interest in the M & BHA.  She was a keen supporter of the Burra Show and exhibited in the Floral and Vegetable Sections.  She was responsible for many improvements to the two churches where she worshipped, most recently for the steps up the embankment from the street [at St Mary’s].  The Sanctuary Light and Litch [sic] gate [lych-gate] at Mt Bryan were the brain children of Mrs Hawker.  She believed strongly in improving the district one lived in.

Weekend School: Historic Copper Towns of SA

This began at the University of Adelaide on Friday evening with a seminar in the Napier Building addressed by men knowledgeable in the area and continued there on Saturday.  Ian Auhl spoke on the history of Burra.  On Sunday morning participants toured Kapunda and then over 100 people picnicked at Princess Royal lawns, where they were joined by local members of the National Trust.  Clouds gathered, but the rain held off till evening.  In the afternoon the group visited the dugouts, Paxton square, the Burra Mine, the Redruth Gaol and the Museum.  Guides were Ian Auhl and the President of the National Trust in Burra Mr Lewis Moore.  The CWA provided afternoon tea and the whole event was deemed a great success.

Burra EFS-Ambulance Centre was opened by Hon. C.R. Story, Minister of Agriculture on Sunday afternoon 1st June.  [The official party is listed.]  At 12.45 the St John Brigade Band played at the Hospital and at 1.20 it and the service personnel marched from Burra North to the Centre.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone was in charge of the ceremony and welcomed the official party and other guests.  The new centre was erected to give a home to the ambulance and units of the EFS and to the volunteers of both bodies.  Mr T.G. Perry thanked the contractors Messrs D.T. Jacka and Co.  Redruth Sunday School ladies provided refreshments.  G.R. Finch, Chairman of the Burra Burra DC said the ambulance had answered 52 calls in the past year and 17 of them had been trips to Adelaide.  There were four EFS units in the district – Burra, Mt Bryan, Booborowie and Farrell Flat.  Various others spoke.  Rev. J.H. Stephenson blessed the building.  Mr Story congratulated the members of the committee and the contractors on the project and declared the building open.  Mr Moreland on behalf of the EFS and Mr Ron Thamm on behalf of the Ambulance Service accepted the building and expressed their thanks.  After that those present inspected the building before adjourning to the Redruth Sunday School for afternoon tea.

Obituary.  William Percival Heinrich died suddenly at his residence in Farrell Flat on 12 May.  He was born at Burra, the eldest son of Mrs M.A. Heinrich of Black Springs and the late Mr C.A. Heinrich.  He spent his early life at Black Springs and began working there on his father’s property.  Later he was employed by Horwood Bagshaw & played football for North Adelaide.  After five years in the CMF he married Joyce Olds in 1945 and after his discharge from the army they lived at Porter’s Lagoon.  For the last 16 years he has lived at Farrell Flat.  He was a keen sportsman and active in the Vigilance and Institute Committees and with the tennis and football clubs.  He was also a foundation member of the Farrell Flat Golf Club and its secretary for five years.

[William Percival Heinrich born 25 December 1917 Redruth: died 12 May 1969 Farrell Flat.]

Mrs Reta Jennison has been awarded the British Empire Medal in the Queen’s Birthday Honours for dedicated community service over many years.  She has also received a congratulatory telegram from the PM Hon. John G. Gorton.  Mrs Jennison has lived in the Burra area all her life.  In 1947-48 she was Mayoress when her late husband was Mayor.  In 1947 she was appointed a JP.  She was foundation President of the Primary School Parents & Friends’ Association from 1939 for eleven years and was secretary for three years.  She was also a member of the High School Council for a number of years and during WW II was active in the Fighting Forces Comforts Fund and other patriotic committees.  She has been active in the Burra RSL Auxiliary, being its President and Vice-President for a number of years.  She joined the Burra North Red Cross in 1941 and remains a member, having been its President for 23 years as well as being a member of the Burra CWA for twenty years, its President for eight years and Secretary for four.  She has been a Vice-President and member of the Burra Hospital Women’s Auxiliary for many years and a Vice-President and member of the Burra Branch of the Adelaide Children’s Hospital Auxiliary.

She is a member of the Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust and of the Lewis Trust controlling Paxton Square.  She joined the Redruth Methodist Guild in 1926 and has been its secretary for 43 years and is also a member of the House Committee for the Methodist Manse.  She has been choir Mistress at Redruth church and served with the Burra Choral Society when it was active.  A member of the Burra benevolent Society for 27 years and its secretary for ten.  She has served on committees for Freedom from Hunger, the Swimming Pool, Town Hall and Carol Evenings.  We warmly congratulate her on being finally recognised for her services to the community.

Weather.  On 21 July an inch of rain with some hail and fairly heavy snow fell throughout the district.  The rain began about 5 p.m. Sunday and continued to about 3 a.m. when heavy hail fell.  Snow began to fall at about 7.10 a.m. becoming quite heavy by 7.30 a.m. and continuing until 8.15 a.m.  Burra and the surrounding hills were covered in snow. At Hallett it lay two to three inches deep for miles and also at Mt Bryan, where it remained on the Mount till late afternoon.  Snow was also reported at Clare, Mintaro, Whyte Yarcowie, Booborowie and Farrell Flat, where there was a further light fall at 2.30 p.m.

In the hills between Mt Bryan and Booborowie it lay six inches deep for some time. The main street of Burra was covered by three to four inches.  Mr George Fairchild reported heavy snow on the Booborowie mail run via Leighton.  Power failures were reported from Booborowie, Mt Bryan and Hallett.  Between Waterloo and Burra power interruptions have occurred in the past few days, but magpies were to blame, having been building nests with short lengths of fencing wire.  It was generally said to be the heaviest fall of snow for at least 40 years and possibly since 1901.  It will easily be remembered as occurring on the same day man first set foot upon the moon.  Burra’s 105 points of rain includes 21 points of snow.

Thefts.  In the past six months the theft of sheep from Burra properties has been prevalent.  The police are only now discovering that a large number of missing sheep have not been reported.

Burra Mine

The MP, Hon. G.J. Gilfillan made a statement and asked a question in Parliament, of the Minister of Mines.  He said that previously the lage low grade deposit of copper ore at Burra had been considered too expensive to treat to be a viable operation.  Now further experiments had taken place.  He asked: ‘Can the Minister say whether sufficient progress has been made to make the extraction of such ore a commercial proposition?’

The Hon. R.C. DeGaris confirmed the problem and said a process called the Glyserol Process had been shown by CSIRO to work in the laboratory.  The Government is examining the process at the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories to see if it is practical as a commercial operation and results are awaited.

Methodists from the Burra Circuit met in the Redruth Sunday School Hall on Sunday to consider the practical issues facing the local church.  The presence of two churches in Burra has been an issue since the 1957 Methodist Conference sanctioned the amalgamation of the Kooringa and Redruth Circuits.  It was now evident that enough people were convinced that a complete union in the circuit was needed and the discussion had to consider the closing down of one of the centres of worship.  64 people attended in the morning session and 50 in the afternoon.  The discussion resulted in four recommendations:

The church worship and Sunday school should be in one property and that should be the larger Burra [Kooringa] Church.

The other property would be the focus of all the fellowship groups – for all business meetings, educational meetings, adult and youth groups and the guild meetings.

The surplus church (whichever was ultimately decided upon) should be offered to the Lutheran Church, should they desire to take control of it.

The Burra Guilds should unite.

Rev. Milton Edwards was pleased with the growing sense of unity and of strengthening ties within the circuit.

A Burra Boy Scout Troop came a step closer when 13 parents visited Clare Troop on Friday as observers.  A parent committee was formed afterwards to advance the cause: Chairman, Rev. Milton Edwards; Secretary, Peter Mengersen; Treasurer, Rob Mason; Group Scout Master, Brian Ashdown.  Gordon Webster and Bill Barker have expressed willingness to be Scout Masters.  The Committee would like to hear from those willing to lead a Scout Troop or Cub Pack.  Women Cub Leaders are most acceptable.  Two possibilities for Scout Rooms are the old Methodist property at Hanson or the Burra Salvation Army Citadel.

Burra Boy Scouts

The Group Committee now numbers 12 adults.  The committee has decided the old Methodist Church property at Hanson is an ideal location and the ten minute drive from Burra is not considered significant.  Negotiations with the trustees are under way.  The advantages are that the Cubs and Scouts can each have a separate building and can meet simultaneously.  Equipment can be left in situ from one meeting to the next.  The distance will test scout and parent loyalty to the cause and the necessary roster to get scouts to the site will cement parent involvement.  The first meeting of the First Burra Boy Scout Troop and the First Burra Cub Pack is scheduled for Friday 26 September.  Parents are urged to attend.  Registered Scout Leaders to date are Mr G. Webster, Mr W. Barker, Mr W. Salter and Cub Leader is Mrs I. Tamassy.  Costs are 50 cents on nomination and 10c per night. Uniforms will not be required for four or five months, which is time enough to predict the success or failure of the venture.

The name Burra is still of doubtful origin, but much of the evidence suggests a Hindustani origin.  The name was first used in 1843 by Captain Charles Frome, Surveyor General of SA – two years before copper was discovered.  In his Northern Expedition sketch book he has a water colour entitled ‘Shepherd’s Hut on the Burra Creek’.  The hut is undoubtedly that of William Streair, who first found copper on the present Princess Royal property.  He worked for James Stein, who in 1843 held a lease along the Burra Creek and Indian coolies worked for him and gave the name Burra Burra to the creek – it being Hindustani for big-big or great-great.  Streair’s hut was near the present Princess Royal homestead.  The directors of Sammie first called their mine Wheal Grey after the Governor, but soon changed it to the Burra Burra Mine.  The directors always assumed it to be a Hindustani name without giving a reason.  Later it was suggested it was of native origin, but the early evidence points to the Hindustani origin.  The collection of towns around the mine gradually came to be called ‘The Burra’, though the name was not used officially until after the opening of the railway station in 1870 and did not come into local use until after the foundation of the Corporation in 1876.

Mr E.C. Allen today announced plans for the mining of copper at Burra, as advised him by the Hon. Minister of Mines Mr R.C. De Garis.

A consortium of companies comprising Broken Hill South Ltd, North Broken Hill Ltd, E.Z. Industries Ltd & McPhar Geophysics Pty Ltd, advised they were relinquishing interest in the area after almost four years examining its prospects.  The Minister then accepted a proposal from another group, which was prepared to start mining copper at Burra within a few months.  Details of this new group are not yet finalised, but the technical staff will be headed by Mr B.H. Lewis, until recently Chief Geologist with Broken Hill South Ltd.  The company will be mainly Australian, but Mc Phar Geophysics Pty Ltd of Canada has expressed an interest.  The operation will centre upon the recovery of copper by ammoniacal leaching of oxidised ore in and near the old open cut where reserves of c. three million tons of 1.6% copper have been established.  Initially they would treat 200 tons per day and would have a labour force of about twenty men.  This would be scaled up to 500 to 700 tons per day over 18 months and stabilize at 180-200,000 tons per annum to give the known reserves a life of at least 20 years.  This would require a labour force of about 50, which the company would hope to recruit locally.  The Minister was delighted with this development.

The re-opening of the mine has long been sought and although this was a comparatively small operation, it would give the town a boost and continued exploration could reveal greater reserves.

Ore would be mined, taken to the crushing plant and then leached with ammonia in 500 ton vats.  The process would take about one week per vat.  Two vats would be used initially to handle 100 tons per day.  The product would be copper oxide.  The production of copper sulphate is also being investigated.  It is hoped to use natural gas as the heat source required – the nearest connection is 15 miles away.

The open pit operation would involve moving about 700 tons of ore and 1,000 tons of waste per day, or a total of between 1,500 and 2,000 tons of material daily.  It was hoped local operators could do this. The aim was for a long-life operation.

The company has been incorporated in the name of SAMIN Ltd.  It is a public company formed for the purpose of mining Burra copper ore and having also interests in other states in perhaps lead and tungsten production.  As income permits it is intended to continue exploration in the mine area as well as north and south of the deposit.  When work began it was expected extraction of ore for four or five days would be followed by seven days of processing using three shifts a day.

Burra High School

When asked by Mr Allen whether she would consider a new school for Burra in the light of the expected boost to the town from the re-opening of the Mine, the Minister the Hon. Joyce Steele said yes.  The High School shares the old building with the Primary School, plus a number of temporary classrooms.

Mr W.A. White, President of the SA Institute of Teachers, spoke in the Burra High School Hall on 30 September on the crisis in SA education under the heading Deficiencies in Education.  Mr N. Brand, Senior Master at the High School, also spoke on the local problems with make-shift specialist rooms, lack of science facilities, overcrowding in temporary buildings, lack of planning in the yard and poor physical education facilities.  Mr Wood, Head Teacher at Booborowie, also spoke, saying he thought Primary Schools were the ‘Cinderella’ of the Education Department and small schools fared worse than larger ones.  Other problems were the stresses of multi-grade classes, the need to be teacher-drivers and accommodation difficulties.

Burra Mine

A meeting at Burra Town Hall on Friday was arranged by the Burra Burra DC to consider the implications of the re-opening of the mine and the impact on historical buildings there.  The Directors of the new company were anxious to give information to the district as soon as possible.

Mr Claude Allen said that on 10 January 1966 the then Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan accepted a proposal from Mines Exploration Ltd to commence test drilling. The present Minister gave them till 16 September 1969 to decide on continuing.  They declined and SAMIN will commence preliminary operations shortly.  With respect to Mr Ian Auhl’s concerns expressed in the Advertiser about the protection of historic buildings he said several years would pass before decisions had to be made, but every care would be taken to preserve whatever was possible.  It is the opinion of those concerned that tourism and mining operations can work together.

It is anticipated the company is likely to pay about $50,000 per annum to the Council in royalties.  Mr E.T. Baulderstone asked about what would happen to waste water.

Mr Lewis said it would be recirculated or run into the creek as pure soft water. With 70-80,000 gallons used each day, the creek could be dammed to hold water six to ten feet deep and it could also be used to beautify the banks with lawns and shrubs etc.  Jobs would be offered to locals, but outsiders could be brought in if needed.  It was thought only two or three female workers would be required.  (Probably in laboratory work.)

It was likely the mine would hasten a decision on building a new High School.

T.G. Perry writes.  [He is responding to an assertion apparently made on a Channel 9 Newsbeat program on 14 October that NOTHING was being done about developing Burra’s tourist potential.]

In 1959-60 the Corporation of Burra purchased the Burra Mine Paddock.  With the drive of the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and the then Town Clerk Mr R. W. Fullgrabe and the co-operation of the District Council the area was provided with access roads and the mine workings were fenced for safety.  On Friday 17 November the area was opened as a tourist attraction by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz.  At the same time a souvenir brochure was produced giving historical details.  This was followed by investigation of the ore at the site by the Department of Mines and Mines Exploration Ltd.  In the time in question the Corporation developed a Caravan Park and a swimming pool.  Burra Creek has been improved by the Council and a picnic ground developed on the bank opposite the Caravan Park.  A brochure outlining the town’s items of interest is in its second printing.  Rev. G.D. Sibly developed a Historical Room at St Mary’s Church.  The National Trust has assisted with historical matters in the town and maintains a Museum in the town.  It has also helped to restore Redruth Gaol with a subsidy from the Tourist Bureau.  Colour slides and gift cards of historic buildings have been made available.  The National Trust and Mr Ian Auhl produced one of the National Heritage films presented on ABC TV, dealing with Burra and its historic buildings.  Work is presently being done to preserve Burra Miners’ Dugout Homes.  With much work from Mr S.J. Woollacott Paxton’s Cottages have begun to be restored.  The RAA has improved signage.  Improvements have been made to the golf course, bowling green etc.  To say nothing is being done is a wild statement born from a lack of investigation.  Requirements for the preservation of historic sites and buildings in the re-opening of the mine are being supported.

Obituary.  Keith John (Peter) Hammat died suddenly at Clare Hospital on 13 August after a short illness.  He was born in Burra 12 August 1915.  He attended Magill Boys School and Scotch College.  In 1941 he married Gladys Piggott of Spalding.  He worked in his early life on family properties of Bundaleer and Cutana Stations and then settled on land north of Bundaleer.  He was an active member of Spalding Amateur Swimming Club, timekeeper with the SA Amateur Swimming Association and officiated at many country carnivals.  He was a keen supporter of and a donor to many district projects.  In 1966 he was appointed a JP.  He is survived by a wife and three sons: Glenn, Robert and Phillip and also by his father J. Hammat of Clare and two sisters, Mesdames Bowman & McPherson.

Obituary.  Mr John Robert Barker was born 6 November 1895 at Baldina Station nine miles east of Burra.  His grandfather Alfred Barker has taken up this property and it had been carried on by his father, William Pitt Barker.  When W.P. Barker died in 1914, Mr Barker assumed responsibility and ran Baldina and Grassville stations until his sudden death at Baldina on Friday 31 October.  He was associated with many town and district activities.  He served as a Councillor on the Mt Bryan DC prior to its amalgamation with the Burra DC, on which he then served for many years. As Councillor for Mongolata Ward.  He was for 52 year a trustee of St Mary’s Church, a position his father had held before him.  He was keenly interested in sporting bodies and played golf and tennis and was a member of the Burra Sports Association for many years.  He continued the family’s long standing active support of the Burra Hospital.

Council appreciates State Government support through the Department of Mines and the project is a practical application of continued support for country areas.  Councillors are in touch with local opinion, which supports the new project.

Burra Hospital has been advised by the trustees in the estate of the late John Robert Barker that there is a bequest to the hospital of $70,000 for the purchase of land and the erection of cottage homes for the aged.  They are to be known as the Barker of Baldina Cottage Homes and are to be erected on land adjoining the hospital.  The suggested model to accommodate 16 persons is ten motel type single units comprising a bed-sitting room, small kitchen, bathroom and private verandah.  Two motel type single units slightly larger with the possibility of an additional bed or divan and two double units for couples with a bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom and private verandah.  Communal facilities will include recreation-living room, laundry, storage and boiler rooms etc.  Each unit would have a small flower garden and there would be seven vegetable plots.  There would be areas of lawn with shrubs and concrete paths.  Each unit would have reticulated hot water radiators and air conditioning.  The estimated cost of the project is $108,000.

$90,000 for land and construction costs, eligible for a two for one subsidy.

$14,000 for furnishings and equipment, eligible for a one for one subsidy.

$4,000 for lawn and paths, which would not receive a subsidy.

Of the total the subsidy would amount to approximately $60,000 and the cost to the Hospital would be approximately $50,000.  The late Mr Barker’s will also provides for a special donation of one nineteenth of the balance of his residuary estate after certain bequests, to be made available to the Hospital for building or an addition to such Hospital property.

The Burra Benevolent Society has also been advised it will benefit from the J.R. Barker estate.

St Mary’s will hold an advent carol service next Sunday.

RSL Snooker Tournament.  In the second semi-final Ron Wuttke defeated David Bednall.  Ron then went on to defeat Les. Phillips in the final.

Burra Schools were visited by the Hon. Minister for Education Mrs J. Steele.  At the Primary School Mr E.C .Allen MP introduced the Head Mistress Miss M. Spratt who introduced Mr R. Jeffery Chairman of the DC and others, including staff.  There was an assembly of the students from Grades V, VI & VII.  Mrs Steele spoke to students of her visits to schools in the NT & SA after which the Minister visited the classrooms of the remaining students.  After morning tea Mr R. Moreland chaired a discussion which aired many questions including the future of the Primary School.  At the High School Mrs Steele addressed the students and inspected the grounds, where the lack of yard facilities and of room for further buildings was recognised.  She inspected the site for the proposed new school.

Mrs Steele also visited the Convent School of St Joseph and received a deputation from the Lewis Trust.

New Burra Police Station.  The Hon. D.N. Brookman has advised that tenders for the new police station will be called in January 1970.  Work can be expected to begin in March 1970.

Kooringa Christmas Amusements taken from the SA Register for Friday 4 January 1856.

Wrestling matches in front of the Miners’ Arms Hotel on Friday.

On Monday a fine bullock was roasted whole by Mr Watts & Mr Stevens near the Burra Hotel.  Some fine slices were cut at noon and by 6 p.m. it was considerably diminished.  J. Pearce then gathered about 40 natives together and after three cheers for the Queen, three for Prince Albert and three for the Royal Family, he helped them to the roast beef so that in a short time only bones remained.

Several foot races were run between men, boys, girls and blackfellows.

Jingling and jumping in sacks concluded the sports.

On Tuesday rifle shooting at a target was held for a first prize of a revolving rifle and second of a revolving pistol.

There were also horse races at the Cross Roads Inn (Nankervis’s).  [For which details were printed.]  After the races the usual sports continued.

Outside the Miners’ Arms wrestling continued on Sunday morning.

Notes.  The Miners’ Arms is the present Burra Hotel, then a single storey building.  It was Burra’s second hotel, built in 1847 with H. Chandler as the first licensee.  The Burra Hotel was the old wing of the Burra Hospital.  It was demolished in 1967.  Erected as Burra’s first hotel in 1846, its licensee was Abraham Wren.  In 1856 the licensee was A. Barker, grandfather of the late John Barker.  Cross Roads Inn, a few miles west of the Mine on the bullock road to Pt Wakefield, stood from 1853 to 75 on the ‘site of the present home of Glen Finch’s old home’.  [Sic.]

Burra Town Hall Pictures

In recent months efforts have been made to improve the hall and a good deal of money has been spent.  At the pictures, unfortunately, good programs are being spoiled by children tracking in and out at any odd time and youths making a nuisance of themselves.  The police have been advised and in future those who disturb the theatre risk being removed.  Parents are asked to exercise control over their children.  The program regularly runs at a loss.

Booborowie Town Streets will all be sealed by the end of the week.  Some sealing has been done in Farrell Flat last season and a similar program is planned for Mt Bryan in the near future.

Accident/Obituary.  Julie Kathleen Cullen (3), the daughter of Mr & Mrs Henry Cullen, died on Thursday after being run over by a truck being prepared for one of its regular trips to eastern stations.  At about 10.25 a.m. it ran forward and passed over her as Mr Cullen was about to enter the cab.  She was taken to Burra Hospital with internal injuries and died within half an hour.

Burra Oval.  The bore has not been able to supply a sufficient flow to water the oval adequately in a reasonable time.  Now a 22,000 gallon tank will receive bore water continually and this will then be delivered to the oval at an adequate rate by pump.

Boy Scouts & Cubs.  The investiture of the boys was held at the Scout Hall in Hanson on Friday night when 18 Scouts and 25 Cubs were invested.  Mr Maurice Davies invested the Cubs and Mr Bill Barker conducted the ceremony for the Scouts.  The movement now goes into recess till 6 February.

Carols by the Swimming Pool drew a large crowd on Sunday evening in perfect weather.  Chairman of the Burra Burra DC Mr Roy Jeffery delivered his Christmas message.  The greatest event of the year was the amalgamation of the Town and District Councils.  The opening of the Burra Mine is expected to be a reality within a few weeks.  Rev. John Stephenson compered the evening.  A highlight was the tableau presented by the children of St Joseph’s Convent School.  About $XX? Will be forwarded to the Crippled Children’s Association from the evening’s collection.

The Headmaster presented the school’s 57th Annual Report.

[He welcomed the guest speaker who was Senior Lecturer in Education at Salisbury Teachers College and also Mr E.C. Allen MP.]

The year opened with 180 students, an increase of 12 and there were eleven staff members, of whom seven were newly appointed to Burra.  I came from being Deputy Headmaster at Kadina.  Mr Moyle came from Murray Bridge, Mr West, Mr Salt, Miss Russell, Miss Pfitzner and Miss Strahan were appointed from college.  Mrs Brand was part-time librarian from the start of second term.  At the end of second term we lost the services of Miss Strahan due to illness and she was replaced by Mr Fisk, a recent arrival from Canada.

Paving of the school grounds remains in a shocking state, but we hope for improvement shortly.  Work was begun on a retaining wall around two of the tennis courts, but although begun in September, it is yet to be completed and in the meantime half of the court surface is broken and useless.  The grassed area is in good condition.

The Parents & Friends’ Association has been active and very helpful this year and many thanks go to the President Mrs Matthews.

[School visitors and speakers are then listed, followed by a report on internal sporting activities.]

Last year’s Leaving results were disappointing.  The average result of Grade IV or better was 63.4% compared with a state average of 75%.

The Intermediate Examination was held for the last time and Burra did very well with a Grade IV or better result reached by 85.9% of subjects compared with a state average of 75%.  Especially noteworthy were:

Lynnette Griffen	7 subjects and six at Grade 1 level

Neville Hyde	7 subjects and five at Grade 1 level

Angela Quinn	8 subjects and four at grade 1 level

David Francis	7 subjects and four at Grade 1 level.

In this year’s Leaving Class seven students held scholarships and recently it was announced that Ann Brak has won a Commonwealth Scholarship.

The failures would seem to be less a lack of ability than a lack of drive.

[The Headmaster then went on to discuss the division of students into different tracks corresponding to differing abilities and interests.  He also discussed promotion for the first three years of High School on the basis of continuing assessment.]

Staff changes at the end of the year:

Mr Brand has been promoted to Deputy Headmaster of Willunga High School.

Mrs Day has decided to resign.

Mr Johnson has been transferred to Taperoo High School.

Mrs Fisk (formerly Miss Wilkinson) has been moved to Nailsworth Girls Technical High School.

Mr Fisk also leaves.

[The Headmaster then thanked the Prefects, the Clergy, the Choral Group and the cleaners.]

Railway Timetable Changes

With delayed opening of the new standard gauge railway line there is also news that the rail service to Broken Hill via Burra will depart Adelaide over one hour later.  Mr Allen MP said passengers at Peterborough had to rise at 3 a.m. to catch the morning train and could not return till 11.47 p.m.  Departure from Adelaide at 7.10 was long after shops had closed.  He felt that at least on nights other than the Broken Hill express the train could depart at 6.10 p.m.  The answer was that the fast goods train had to depart at 5.30 p.m. and it was essential it keep ahead of the passenger train all the way to Peterborough.  The changes also affected mail closing times.

Burra National Trust held its AGM.  President W.L. Moore summarised the year’s work in the 6th annual report.  With the opening of the Mine proposed, the Trust has been working to preserve the Engine Houses.  Mr Lewis, General Manager of the enterprise, assures us he is as interested in the history of the area as we are and every effort will be made to preserve the buildings.

[Mr Moore said he would like to see a meeting between the Branch and Samin.]

Early in the year the National Trust acquired the land containing the two remaining dugouts and it will now be the task of the trust to restore them.  The proposed visit to Princess Royal Homestead has had to be postponed due to Mr Andrew Tennant’s ill health.  The visit in November would have coincided with the release of the book Historic Homesteads of Australia in which Princess Royal is featured.

In conjunction with the District Council the dugouts area has been cleaned up and the Trust now awaits prices for the restoration work.

Adult Education ran a School on Historic Copper Mines of SA early in May with Mr Ian Auhl giving a paper on Burra.  The climax of the school was a bus trip to Kapunda and Burra with lunch at Princess Royal.  The Burra Branch of the National Trust supplied afternoon tea for the visitors.

In August we were requested to roster people at the Museum in the absence of Mr Woollacott.  This will also be needed next year when Mr Woollacott and family are abroad.  This year the Museum had 1,530 visitors compared with 1,140 last year.

In November two members, Mr O’Connor and Mrs Radford attended on Adult Education School on Folk Museums and we look forward to making use of new ideas from them.

We are indebted to Mr & Mrs S.J. Woollacott for opening the Museum on Friday and Sunday afternoons.

In the year a plaque has been made in memory of Thomas Pickett and it is now ready for erection near the site of his shepherd’s hut on the bank of Diprose Creek.

The Museum also now has a tinted photographic copy of the Bentley painting recently presented to Head Office.  With the permission of the District Council many of the relics from the mining era were moved from the mine to the area adjacent to the Museum.

This year we printed another set of five cards making ten in all.  Thanks to Mr Maurice Perry for permission to draw on his splendid drawings.  A sketchbook of Burra is in the process of being printed at present and we thank Mr Auhl for transferring his royalties to the Branch.

We have had a visit from the Renmark Branch and an exhibition of paintings by a group of artists who previously spent a week in the town.

A two vehicle head-on accident occurred at about 5 p.m. on the Manoora-Burra Road [19 January] and as a result two men, two women and two young girls from four different families are dead.  The only survivor is a ten-year-old girl [Leanne Affolter] who suffered a broke leg.  She is the daughter of Mr & Mrs Colin Affolter of Booborowie. Merino Ram Embargo Relaxed

On 15 January the ban on the export of Merino Rams was relaxed.  Mr W. Brown of ‘The Grove’ Burra is President of the SA Merino Breeders Association.  He said it was a step towards the unity of the wool world.  The rest of the world had resented the embargo.  There can still be no export of semen or ewes and only 300 rams can be exported.  Mr Brown doubted whether that number would be reached.  There will be only one auction sale in each state in the twelve months before the policy is reviewed.  Mr Brown thought that 300 rams would not affect the Australian Stud or Commercial Breeder.  In 1967 he said from 1,850 registered Merino Studs 202,000 rams were sold.  In that year 1½ million Merino Ewes were mated.  Unsold rams that year totalled 294,000.  Given this scale of operation the 300 will have little impact.  He does, however, think the change might encourage breeders to produce more top sheep as has occurred with other breeds.  He also thinks it will foster the International Wool secretariat in obtaining support from all wool producing countries.

Burra School will soon have better water pressure.  A 4 inch main is being run across the bridge in front of the Town Hall.  The work has been delayed by fire bans hampering the use of hot lead at many connections along the way, but the project should be completed before school resumes.

It will take 24 hours to fill the tank and a line of 11 sprinklers can empty it in 5-6 hours; delivering the equivalent of an inch and a half to the irrigated area.  A complete watering once a fortnight will now be possible.

Obituary.  Mrs Bridget Eileen O’Dea, wife of the late John Charles O’Dea died 16 November 1969 aged 71.  She was born at Cavenagh, the second daughter of Mr & Mrs T.F. Kilderry, late of Peterborough and pioneers in the Northern Areas.  Mrs O’Dea was educated at Peterborough Convent School and Convent of Mercy in Angas St, Adelaide. Accidents

On Saturday at 8.30 p.m. about a mile the Burra side of Klaebe’s Creek near Studholme a fully laden semi-trailer bound for Queensland overturned.  It landed upright with the trailer straddling the creek.  The driver Kenneth Payne of NSW was transferred from Burra hospital to the Adelaide Hospital suffering from a broken arm, lacerations and concussion.  The load of aluminium chairs, personal goods, data processing paper, children’s school shoes, drums of grease and cow hides was scattered about.  Four trucks were used to convey the salvaged goods to the Burra Police Station.  About 95% of the load was saved.  The Council grader and front end loader salvaged the damaged vehicle.  Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $3,500.

A car driven by Alan Day of Burra overturned on the Spalding-Burra Road yesterday near North Bungaree.  The driver and passengers Ashley White, Philip Byles and Andrew Phillips escaped with a shaking and bruises.  They were returning from a cricket match.

Redruth Methodist Church

About 150 people crowded into the church on Sunday morning for the service which marked the discontinuance of weekly worship there.  State Secretary of the SA Methodist Conference Rev. A.R. Medson preached the sermon.  Brian Thamm, who is Circuit Steward and Secretary to the Redruth Trust, read a statement outlining the reasons for the ending of services at Redruth and outlining the history of the church.  The decision ‘was made in the good faith that a unified congregation and a centralised witness of Methodism to the town and district, was the only attitude which could be rightly adopted by an authentic twentieth century church.’

The Past.  [Based on an article compiled in 1961 by Rev. Harry Alvey.]

The first mention of Redruth appeared in the minutes of the Kooringa Circuit in 1850.

Later in that year Redruth received from the Government 20 acres of glebe land and half an acre in the township.  The foundation stone of the first chapel was laid in February 1851.  Soon afterwards the gold rush began and the chapel was deserted except for a few women and children and in 1854 it was dismantled, to be reconstructed when the men returned in 1857.

In August 1873 the Trustees resolved to build a chapel on the present site.  It ultimately cosy £1,340 and was later extended to become the building it is today.  Kooringa Circuit was divided in 1889 with Redruth becoming a separate circuit with Rev. T.M. Rowe as its minister, living at Aberdeen.  When Methodist Union took place in 1900 the Primitive Methodist Chapels at Redruth, Ironmine and Copperhouse became part of the Redruth Circuit.  As the town’s population declined it could not support two Methodist ministers and the SA Conference approved the amalgamation of the Kooringa and Redruth Circuits in 1956.  For the past 14 years the two churches have been continuously used and maintained for weekly worship.  It is now acknowledged that the church in Burra must now become a united family.  The Trustees do not want to see the buildings stand neglected and unused.  The best solution would be for Christians of another Communion to take over and to this end a delegation will confer with the local Lutheran Pastor.

Solar Activity Research Station

A field station as part of a triangle of radio telescopes is nearing completion on the property of Don. White.  The other two sites are at Buckland Park (Two Wells) and at Kadina.  The work is being carried out by the University of Adelaide and will study the outflow of gases from the sun. Burra Show Society AGM

Elected were: Patron, Mr Rex Warnes; President, Mr R. Mason; Vice-Presidents, Mr G. Kellock & Mr M.G. Wardle.  A secretary is required following the resignation of Miss Judy Beinke after two years.  Retiring President Mr R.H. Stockman reported on a successful 1969 show held on 11 October in perfect weather.  Gate takings were $681-16, which was up $200 on 1968.  The 2,986 entries were a record.  The Mid North Sheep Shearing Competition was a very successful innovation.  There were 432 Horses-in-Action entries.  Wool display was up to its usual high standard and though sheep numbers were down, the standards were well maintained.  Industrial displays were numerous.  The pavilion displays contained good quality in all sections and flowers and floral art entries had increased.  The school displays were pleasing.  Sideshows were down in number and less varies.  Financially the success of the show means the Society is without debt for the first time in years and there is a credit balance of $73-08.

The Tourist Promotion Committee is active and will approach the Tourist Bureau re publicity for the town.  The question of a large scale street directory to help tourists find sites was raised.  A letter from the Railway Historical Society said they intend to run a vintage train to Burra on 29 August to mark the centenary of the opening of the line.  If the Governor can make the journey the SAR has approved the addition of the Vice-Regal carriage.  Only three steam locomotives are operational and they are maintained by the society for their exclusive use.  Two are Rx class locomotives, which is fortunate as they can be turned on the small turntable at Burra.  SAR has approved a double headed steam train for this occasion.  500 people are expected to travel by this train and about 200 of them could be expected to be interested in a town tour.

Princess Royal

Last Sunday the Princess Royal homestead was open for inspection.  Mr Tom Downer of Woodside took a full load of passengers out on his drag drawn by five black horses.  On the day Mr Downer made c. $140 for the Horse Drawn Vehicles Exhibition at Magill.  Many people picnicked in Burra or at Princess Royal or along the road.  A highly appreciative crowd streamed into the house from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. to appreciate the historic building, exquisite furnishings and carefully tended garden.  For the day over 1,100 people visited the property.  Many of the visitors also toured Burra itself.  Over $900 was raised for the dugouts restoration project.  A contract has been let to a local tradesman for the rebuilding.  The Woods and Forests Department is advising what trees and shrubs grew in the area so they can be replaced.
