94, 39, 10 Oct. 1972, pages 1 & 3

Burra Copper Festival

Burra Show

The gate takings reflect the increased number of visitors.  $1,075 compared with $655 last year.  Door takings at the Ball in the Town Hall were $875 and for the teenage dance in the RSL Hall $165.

The Show was opened by the Governor of SA Sir Mark Oliphant in fine weather.  Show President, Mr R. Mason, introduced the Governor, whose speech is printed.

The display of farm machinery and cars was much larger than usual.

Art attracted a great diversity of entries with a strong junior section.

Budgerigars attracted entries of varying standard.

Cookery was of high standard and the children’s section was very pleasing.

Flowers were a poorer standard than usual, but the children’s entries were good.

Goat entries were larger this year, but of varying quality, though the best were excellent.

Needlework was of a higher standard than usual.

Pigs were revived as a section this year and all the exhibits were good types.

The Sheep Section produced good commercial sheep in both the restricted and poll sections.  The Champion Poll Ram was outstanding.  Entry numbers should have been better.

In the strong wool section the ewes were much stronger than the rams.

94, 39, 10 Oct. 1972, page 2

Copper Festival

Unveiling the Peacock Chimney Plaque

Burra people were staggered by the numbers present.  Thousands of people gathered for the event.  Gusty winds whipped round the small yellow curtain covering the plaque and around the long dresses, capes and bonnets of the ladies and young girls in nineteenth century costume.  Men and boys in clothes of the miners added authenticity.  A number of veteran cars and horse drawn vehicles added to the scene and the Police Band gave a martial flavour to the procession.  After the unveiling the procession was reformed and followed the band back to Market Square where it played for the afternoon.  At the chimney Sir Mark & Lady Oliphant were met by National Trust President, Mr G. O’Connor, who welcomed than and the large crowd.  Mr O’Connor told the story of the reconstruction.  They had not at first realised the size of the task, but that had been compensated for by the degree of satisfaction at its completion.  During the resiting some of the massive stones had been broken and new ones had to be cut.  The bricks had crumbled to dust and had to be replaced.  The new brickwork had not quite the grace and charm of the old, but a century of Burra winters will mellow it.  He called on Sir Mark to perform the ceremony.

[Sir Mark’s speech is printed.]

A vote of thanks was moved by Major General G.W. Symes, Vice-President of the National Trust of SA.

Decentralisation of the Post Office Telecommunications Management Authority

Burra is one place being considered as a possible headquarters for this move.  Unfortunately its geographical position counts against it.  As 150 persons would be employed, it would mean the influx of 400-500 people.  Mr R.T. Prior, an old Burra boy has been appointed to the position of Area Manager Telecommunications for the Mid North, Upper North, Far North and Eyre Peninsula of SA.  Mr Prior (Ray) called on the Chairman of the District Council, Mr R.J. Jeffery, and the District Clerk, Mr T.G. Perry, on 25 October to discuss the proposal as part of his familiarisation with the vast area concerned.

[The article runs in all for some 3½ columns, but as nothing eventuated and most of it is about changes in general in telecommunications, it is of no great consequence.]

Ray Prior was born on his father’s farm in the Springbank-Hanson area and educated at Copperhouse School and Burra High School, where he was a House Leader and Prefect.  He has 36 years experience with the department.  For some years he was in charge of the Planning & Development of Telecommunications across SA and later was Superintendent of the Service Branch – a branch he entered some 25 years earlier as a trainee telephonist.  His most recent post was Metropolitan Manager of Telecommunications Division.  He served at sea in the RANVR in WWII, but was a telegraphist at Darwin in 1942 when the Post Office was bombed.  A more enjoyable experience was serving as Communications Officer on the State Royal Visit Committee for a number of Royal Visits to SA and the NT.  As a result he and his wife (nee Miss Maisie Peters of Riverton) have been presented to royalty on a number of occasions.  He has also for many years been associated with the Postal Institute, of which he is a Life Member.

Samin Ltd’s Stage 2 Program

The commencement of stage 2 is scheduled for September 1973.  The copper ore body at Burra was worked over by hand picking as a high grade deposit between 1845 and 1877, contributing valuable wealth to the state at a critical time.  It was later worked on a small scale by the Burr [Burra] Copper Co. 1901-07.  No further work of importance was undertaken till December 1961 when the SA Department of Mines began investigation.  By December 1961 they had discovered interesting reserves of oxidised copper ore.  Late in 1969 Samin Ltd acquired the leases and with State Government assistance in providing necessary infrastructure, it commenced to develop the property.

Samin and Australian Mineral Development Laboratories in Adelaide (Amdel) designed a plant utilising an ammonia leaching process capable of treating 250 tons of ore per day.  The plant, which commenced operation as the first stage of the development, is producing c. 90 tons of copper concentrate per month.  The plant has also been used to provide the metallurgical information needed to design the stage 2 plant.  This will considerably increase throughput and recovery.  The mining rate will increase to 400,000 tons of ore per year and production to about 6,500 tons of copper concentrate.  The new plant involves roasting in a roaster 64 feet high, with 12 hearths, fired by natural gas, before treatment.  Santos is supplying the natural gas from the Moomba-Adelaide main via a 14 mile branch line commissioned from the Natural Gas Pipelines Authority.  Tenders for this line are expected to be called in January with construction in February-April 1973.  The heat from the waste gases and from the hot material leaving the roaster will generate steam for other process work.  The waste gases will be filtered to be completely clean before discharge.  After roasting the ore will be ground to a fine powder in a 9 ft diameter x 17 ft long ball mill driven by an 11,000 volt motor.  The diameter of this 1,100 h.p. motor is over 12 ft and it weighs nearly 20 tons.  This is one of the largest motors connected to the ETSA system and special provisions have been made to protect other consumers from interference.  ETSA will also be installing two 1,500 KVA transformers to cope with the increased load from other plant motors.  After grinding the copper will be extracted from the calcined ore by agitation leaching instead of the present percolation leaching method.  The new tanks for this have been installed and are set in the ground to eliminate possible spillage.  Stainless steel pressure filters will ensure all ammonia fumes are contained.  Most other sections of the existing plant will also be extended.  A.L. Clode & Son have already enlarged the maintenance workshop.

Employment will not be greatly increased by this development.

Burra Progress Association was formed on 1 August 1939.  The late F.T. Sara was Chairman and Mr John Bowles was Secretary.  Its last meeting was on 1 December 1955 when it had a credit balance of £75-4-7.  This has grown with interest to be now $232.60. Ian Auhl writes:

It was with mixed feelings that I read in the Sunday Mail of 5 November 1972 the disappointment of an overseas tourist who drove to Burra and expected to see the old open cut and wander freely around the old mine area.  None of the brochures he said indicated that people could not get near the old buildings or the old mines.  This highlights the need for more up-to-date publicity.  A somewhat misleading impression could be given by the current Council brochure, the National Trust-Ampol film and the Burra Sketchbook.  These date from 1967, 1967 and 1968 respectively and at that time the re-opening of the mine seemed a very remote possibility.  This year the Council is to bring out an up-to-date tourist brochure.  Also in 1973 I hope a new Burra book called Burra in Colour will be available.  Rigby Ltd has given a young photographer Peter Finch and me the contract to produce the book.  This will bring the Burra story up-to-date.  The film cannot be up-dated and is now an historic record in colour of the mine area prior to the present mining operations.  What is needed is a new film.  One can understand the visitor’s disappointment and it is a pity Dr McKinnon was not referred to Mr Rich or Mr O’Connor, as I am sure he would have been shown around the mine area.  In any case most of the mine buildings are still accessible.  Graves’ Pump House has been spared and the [Peacock’s] chimney resited – a reasonable compromise.  I, like Mr Baulderstone, felt a keen disappointment at the loss of the old mine area and some of the mine buildings.  I have also been disappointed that other historic buildings in the town have been bulldozed without knowledge or consideration of their tourist value.  Samin has shown goodwill and the National Trust and Council have, I believe, come to respect each other’s points of view. Tourism and mining cannot be separate developments; it is no longer practicable.  Such statements as those made by Dr A.J. McKinnon are fair comment and must be taken into account.

Deputation to the Minister of Local Government

Following the public meeting at Booborowie over the increase in rates, a deputation has waited on the Minister, the Hon. G.T. Virgo.  They pointed out that grants to the Burra Burra Council have decreased by $50,000 over three years.  They sought increased funding to enable the budget to balance without the current increase in rates.  The increase in rates was a response to the sharp decline in Government grants for road works.  As a result of the previous Government policy the Council had built up an efficient plant and staff and incurred debts in the purchase of equipment, which had to be serviced.  The deputation had complete confidence in the Council, but could not accept the hardship caused by the rate increase. They provided figures to support their claims:

Money collected in rates 	1971-72	$80,370

1972-73	$99,276

Government Road Grants	1969-70	$141,976

1970-71	$131,512 (difference is a carry forward)

1971-72	$107,415

1972-73	$81,990

Comparison of different Council rates within a ten miles radius for similar land:

Burra Burra DC	890 acres	rates $259.76

Adjoining Council	868 acres	rates $134.40

Another adjoining Council	875 acres	rates $265.14

This shows our rates are equal to one and well above the other, showing we are pulling our weight as ratepayers.  The town is awakening to tourism and visitor numbers are growing, but a great need exists for a sealed road in an east-west direction.  There has been a general increase in the revenue allotted to the Highways Department, but the debit orders to the northern areas have remained constant and to the Burra Burra Council have been reduced.  Rate income must be reduced by $20,000.

This can only be done by:

Reducing the rural activities of Council.

Disposal of plant and equipment.

Retention of plant and equipment, but operating on a reduced scale with retrenchment of five or six men.

Highways Department provides grant allocation to enable the Council to meet loan and operational commitments until the rural community recovers from the restricted fiancé that has been and largely still is in place.

The Government supports the Council to provide for tourist activity in Burra as the rural sector has provided the present facilities and services.

Burra Mine

Work at the mine so far has been of a preparatory nature.  De-watering of the open cut will start some time in June 1973, or perhaps in the following year.  The water level will probably be lowered to 1,540 ft above sea level or 60 ft below the present level and would not then be lowered further for two years.  Once started, pumping will continue for the life of the operation.  The equipment will be capable of handling 1,000 gallons per minute.  Notification of the decision to commence pumping will be given in due course.

Centenary of the Burra Burra DC

At the Centenary Dinner at the Town Hall last week the Chairman Mr Jeffery welcomed guests and introduced the Minister of Local Government Hon. G.T. Virgo, who presented long service certificates to R.J. Jeffery (17 Years), E.T. Baulderstone (24 years) and R.J. White (10 years).  [Three photos are printed.]

[Mr Virgo began his speech with the usual thank yous for the invitation and to the ladies providing the dinner.  He moved on to make the usual references to Burra’s past role as a mining centre which had saved SA’s economy in the mid 19th century.  He said the re-opened mine is expected to run for 15 to 20 years and to generate some $119-$120 million.  He then went on to consider the role of tourism.]

Burra has a very important role to play in tourism.  In a quick look around to see the old miners’ cottages I was very pleased to see the standard of preservation.  I think these cottages mean something as far as Burra is concerned and as far as tourism is concerned.  You may think it worth while pooling your tourist resources with adjoining areas so that the region can provide more than just a one or two day trip.  Today the tourist is looking for more than coming to Burra to see mine workings and cottages and the National Trust Museum.  They are looking for a package of things to do perhaps over four or five days or a week.  A portion of the growing tourist expenditure in Australia can come to Burra provided Burra people are prepared to display the necessary initiative and encourage people in the area to advertise the fact they have tourist potential.  With respect to ‘that road’ which must receive serious consideration.  While it is acknowledged that it is essential as far as this region is concerned, it is also acknowledged that the Highways Department funds are allocated on the needs of the whole state and so the Department may not give it the same priority as it sifts through the pleas and requests of 157 local governing bodies in SA.

Concerning local government boundaries.  If local government by a majority want to have a commission to look into boundaries, I am prepared to have one.  If not, then one will not be established.

Mr Brian Riggs responded.  As well as thanking Mr Virgo he introduced Mr Ian Auhl’s booklet on the Council’s Centenary and thanked the Floral Art Club for the floral arrangements, the ladies [listed] for the catering and the Clerk, Tom Perry, for making the co-ordinating arrangements for the dinner.

Mr Virgo then presented the long service awards as stated above.

[Photo of the unveiling of the plaque.]

Ian Auhl spoke of the booklet on the Council’s Centenary and pointed out the difficulties Burra had in getting local government – it took twenty years for a District Council and another four for the town to get a Corporation.  You, [Mr Virgo] made the remark that Burra once upon a time saved South Australia.  I say that it is high time that South Australia saved Burra.  My final comment is that if you want to save Burra build that bloody road from Morgan to here!

Headmaster’s Report for 1972

I welcome Inspector Mr Louis Kloeden, to the platform along with Mrs Kloeden, a Senior Mistress and Art Teacher.

The year began with an enrolment of 160 and we expect it to be 200 by 1975.

The students have been co-operative and responsible and the prefects and house captains most conscientious in their duties.  Students have done well in helping with the upkeep of the grounds.  A Valedictory Service was held last Sunday in the Anglican Church.

We congratulate Commonwealth Scholarship winners Paul Hogan, Jennifer Holmes, John Lewis, Grant Maxted, Necia Mickel, John Bishop, Helen Beare and Kathy Edwards.

[He then went on to thank the staff and the High School Council.]

Next year Miss Baron and Mr Costello are both getting married and will be transferring to Dover Gardens and Findon respectively.  Miss Lintern has resigned to take a Social Science course at Flinders University.  Mr Allen has been promoted at ASM at Millicent High School.  Their replacements are not yet known.

The Parents & Friends have helped the school with a number of purchases including a photo-copying machine ($850) and library books ($400).

[He then spoke briefly of sports and extra-curricular activities.]

In 1973 there will be no ‘2’ track students and only ‘0’ and ‘1’ track.  All 1st year students will be offered Art as an alternative to French.  1973 will see the introduction of a Hire Book Scheme.

A new Commonwealth Grant next year will see the school receive some $2,750 worth of equipment including books, films, cassettes etc. over three years.

With respect to the new school.  New plans have been drawn up and approved.  It is likely the boys’ craft block and the science block areas will be the site for the new school and Wardle’s paddock the recreation area.  No commencement date has yet been set.

Characteristics of the 1972 paper.

There was quite a reasonable coverage of local issues and with a fairly wide interpretation of ‘local’; ranging from Saddleworth to Hallett and Robertstown.

There are quite a few mistakes in setting, however, and not all are subsequently corrected, which leaves some puzzling items.  Some of the major news items are general interest, rather than local.

Allocation of material to pages is rather elastic, but the following is typical.

Page 1.

Solidly devoted to news.

Page 2.

Some large local advertisements with sports results,

Sales notices and public notices are sometimes here and sometimes on page 6 or split between the two.

Page 3.

Typically a heavy dose of large advertisements with perhaps one column of news.

Pages 4 & 5.

Generally little news except for sports results and often a large section of 50 and 25 years ago.

Page 6.

Large advertisements for about half the page.  The Cash Column (small classified advertisements) for at least one column.  Some public notices and other small advertisements.

Page 7.

‘Out and About’ – small snippets of local news.

Further local news and sports.  At least half a page of advertising.

Page. 8

Large advertisements for about four columns.  Reports from various District Councils and perhaps some other news.

New Burra Buildings in 1973 will be worth c. $4 million.

Stage 2 of the treatment Plant at the Burra Mine is estimated to cost over $3 million.

The Burra Hospital will get 40 beds and a new maternity floor, all on one level, at a cost of $220,000.

Barker of Baldina Cottage Homes on the western side of the Hospital are expected to cost c. $90,000.  The late Mr J.R. Barker bequeathed $70,000 and there was a Commonwealth subsidy.

Burra Mine.  Envirotech Australia Pty Ltd is building the multiple hearth furnace for Samin Ltd for the reduction roasting plant and the first two sections of four are being positioned.  [Photograph.]  The plant will cost $1.2 million; will be c. 26 ft in diameter and 85 ft high.  It will be a 12 hearth, multiple hearth type furnace and will be equipped for recovering heat from the furnace flue, gases and roasted ore, together with cyclonic and bag type dust collection and should be operational this year.  It will calcine 1,000 tons of crushed ore per day, using natural gas as fuel.  Parts of the roaster came from Adelaide by two low loaders operated by J.W. Bourne Ltd.  The width forced a roundabout route via Snowtown, Gladstone, Crystal Brook, Jamestown and Hallett and took two days with lifting of overhead wires taking much of the time.  The third and fourth sections arrived on Wednesday after a similar journey.

Barker Cottage Homes are progressing satisfactorily.  So far seven applications have been received by the Board of Management and this leaves two vacant units.  Construction is by the local firm of D.T. Jacka & Co. and it is expected that the units will be ready for occupation by the end of March or early April.  One advantage will be the nearness to the Hospital.  [Photograph.]

Burra Hospital extensions will incorporate a new Maternity Wing, kitchen and staff dining room, as well as three additional share wards and a children’s ward for the General Hospital.  All will be on the same level.  [The old hospital had always been plagued by different levels throughout.]  The new wing will include three private wards, a share ward, nursery and a TV room for patients.  The existing verandah on the front of the building will be extended on the eastern end to link with the new building and on the western end a new sunroom for patients will be erected.  Kennett Bros of Adelaide are expected to complete the work in April or May.  The area under the built-up building will house rain water tanks.  [Photograph.]

Burra Mine - Samin Ltd now has the four sections of the new roaster in position, though further equipment is yet to be mounted.  There are twelve square holes running vertically up the tower, which are entries to each of the roaster hearths.  The hearths will be constructed in special refractory bricks and castable materials and work on this began yesterday.  It is expected to take about three months.  On the top there will be a safety stack and four ‘cyclones’.  The latter will separate grit from the exhaust gases.  These will then pass through a large filter to remove any remaining dust, which will then be recycled into the furnace.

R.E. Mason presented the President’s Report for 1972:

The show was held on 7 October and was opened by the Governor of SA, Sir Mark Oliphant, accompanied by Lady Oliphant.  This was the first activity of the Copper festival weekend and attendance almost doubled that of last year.  The weather was unsettled, with dust at first, but it improved later.  The new sections for pigs and cattle were a success and ring events were popular, as were the dodgem cars at the sideshows.  Sheep shearing was popular too and the Agriculture Pavilion was filled to capacity.  School exhibits were popular and the industrial displays were well patronised.  The wool display was of a high standard, but sheep numbers were very low.  The Flower Pavilion was a picture.

A New Golf Course is taking shape in the racecourse area.  The land was offered to the Burra Burra DC by the Burra Sports Syndicate and the Council has acquired the adjoining land known as Elders and the Quarry Paddocks to develop a sports and recreation ground.  The Golf Club enlisted the aid of Murray Crafter of Glenelg Golf Club to design a new gold course.  His plans were accepted in November 1972.  Work began in December on the north face of Quarry Hill.  Putting surfaces were laid in the new positions at a working bee on 25 February except for three still under preparation.  Thanks go to Lyell Quinn of Roche Bros. for grading Quarry Hill and carting material etc., to the DC for making earth-moving equipment available, to Bill Byles & Gino Santella for driving the machinery and to Ron Moreland for ensuring its availability when required.  Thanks also go to Ivan Hirschausen for the use of equipment and to Mike & Ray Wardle for time and equipment as well as to club members generally.

President’s Report

The dominant item for the year was Peacock’s chimney.  Last year the stonework had been completed and the brick top begun.  After months of frustratingly slow progress the brickwork was topped, but so badly executed as to be totally unacceptable.  Eventually the contractor agreed and the brickwork was removed.  Before rebuilding commenced the contractor went bankrupt.  The services were then obtained of O’Neill & Clayton, who did a first class job.  Sir Mark Oliphant unveiled the plaque [at the completed chimney] on 8 October 1972.  In the year visits were made to Tanunda and Renmark branches.  Jamestown has given us a complete railway signal tower and signal.

Burra Mine – Samin Ltd.

E.C. Allen MP asked the Premier, Mr Dunstan, about the possible effects on ground water levels of the second stage operations of Samin Ltd at Burra.  This is estimated to pump 1½ million gallons of water a day from the mine to keep water levels below operating levels.  Landowners would like to see it replaced underground if possible.

Mr Allen asked if the water level at the Bon Accord shaft was falling – it being the present source of water for the mine’s operation.

Mr Bakewell, secretary to the Minister of development and Mines, advises that a survey of bores within 8 km is being undertaken so that drawdown can be determined during a test later in the year.  It is believed unlikely bores further away will be affected.  Of the 91 bores located, 22 are not in use, 8 provide domestic supplies, 59 are for stock and 2 are for irrigation.  The mine is expected to have a relatively short life and the artificial recharge of the aquifers is not considered to be beneficial.  No significant fall in the level of water at the Bon Accord shaft has been noted.  The level in the open cut has fallen about 12 inches in the summer and this is considered normal.

Booborowie Water.  The Department of Mines has been monitoring levels and salinity in 53 bores since May 1971 in the Booborowie Valley. 1972 levels are about one metre lower than 1971 levels, as a consequence of reduced winter rains.  No drastic depletion of the aquifer is evident.  It is expected further boring this year will determine more precisely the hydrological limits, rate of recharge and the capacity of the valley.

Burra Primary School Council AGM

The primary school headmaster Mr S. Allan feels teachers need conferences and observation days because of rapidly changing educational ideas and improved methods.  About 35 parents and teachers attended the meeting.  The new council members are Mr J. Ayliffe, Mrs M. Alderson, Mr S. Allan, Mrs P. Buckton, Mrs E. Carpenter, Mr G. Nourse, Mr C. O’Connor, Mr R. Shipard, Mrs C. Stockman, Mrs J. Tiver, Mrs Betty Thamm and Mr Brian Thamm.

At their first meeting after the AGM the Council elected Mr I. Allen as Chairman, Mr A. Baulderstone as Vice-Chairman and Mr D. Lloyd as Secretary-Treasurer.

The Chairman’s report covers the Sports Day and Combined Sports Day at Hallett.

Rhe combined sports this year will be held on 13 April.

Swimming meets have been held twice at Riverton; on 24 March 1972 and 16 March 1973.  Burra won the first meet by 19 points and the second by 3.  The school competition at the Burra Pool was held on 6 December.  Fund raising for 1972 saw the men’s group raise and sell an onion crop for $159.  Snacks for visitors to the Copper Festival in October were a community service rather than a fund raiser.

Not as much has been spent on the school this year because the High School is to be relocated and the Primary School will be recast about the existing High school and Primary School buildings.  Also further clarification is needed about the division of responsibilities between the Department and the parent body for the supply of equipment and teaching aids.  Some additional sports equipment was erected.

Three new teachers were welcomed: Miss Dargie, Miss Abbot and Mrs Henderson.  Mrs Shattock, Mrs Keller and Mrs Short have helped during periods of staff shortage.

After six years as Secretary-Treasurer Lewis Moore was transferred from Burra and we thank him.  Don Lloyd has taken his place.  Committees have worked well and merit our thanks.  Mr Allan spoke on the planned activities for the coming year.  The full staff is now 8 teachers, 1 typist, 1 librarian and 2 teacher-aides.  The acquisition of two teacher-aides has been a tremendous help, especially in the Infant Section.  This year I intend to set up the old book room as an area for extra help lessons and as a room for group reading to teacher-aides.  Changing ideas and methods mean teachers need to go to conferences and observation days.  Children should have at least one excursion a year.

Bulk Super

660 tons of bulk super was off-loaded and distributed between Burra & Hallett over the weekend.  It came direct from Wallaroo per 8 rail trucks for Burra and 5 for Hallett.  Unloading was by a super lift hydraulic grab.  The operation involved close co-operation between Adelaide & Wallaroo Fertilizers, SAR and Hirschausen Bros of Burra.

The Anzac Day Dawn service last Wednesday drew about 40 persons.  Rev. John Stephenson conducted the service. Tennis Clubs

Separate meetings of the Aberdeen and Kooringa Tennis Clubs to discuss amalgamation have resulted in a recommendation to go ahead and a meeting is consequently scheduled for the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms at 8 p.m. tomorrow.  Last season Aberdeen had six teams: Two ‘A’, 3 ‘B’ and a Junior.  Kooringa had four teams: 1 ‘A’, 2 ‘B’ and a Junior.  Aberdeen has its own five courts, while Kooringa has been renting courts from the school.

It is thought the amalgamated club would be likely to ask Council permission for three more courts adjacent to their present courts at Burra North.

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes have been occupied now for a few weeks, but they will officially be opened by Miss Priscilla Brown, step-daughter of the late J.R. Barker, at 2.30 p.m. next Sunday.  There is sufficient land available for a further nine units and it is the intention of the Board to proceed immediately with site preparation and erect the additional units as finance permits.

Burra Mine

The new ore roaster being constructed by Envirotech Australia Pty Ltd for Samin Ltd’s Phase 2 extension at the Burra Mine is nearing completion.

[Photo of Roaster Shell, showing ‘portholes’ indicating the spacing of the 12 hearths inside.

Photo of centre column and form work prepared for constructing one of the hearths.]

Some 400 tons of refractory fire bricks have been bought from Kaiser Refractories Plant at Uandarra, NSW.

The work on the hearths is expected to be completed by the end of May.  The ore enters at the top of the roaster and is circulated by means of rake arms from hearth to hearth to reach the floor at 1,200°F.  It is then carried by means of a heat resistant stainless steel screw conveyor to a 65 ton rotary unit to be cooled to 250°F in preparation for further processing.

[Photo of trees in front of Samin’s Administration Building.]

Barkers of Baldina Aged Cottage Homes were opened by Miss Priscilla Brown, step-daughter of the late J.R. Barker.  Mr R.B. Jennison, Vice Chairman of the Board of Management, welcomed those present.  The Chairman of the District Council Mr Roy Jeffery addressed the meeting.  The late John Robert Barker had taken over the running of ‘Baldina’ on the completion of his education [and had bequeathed the bulk of the funds that enabled the construction of the cottages].  Mr Max Gilgen, Assistant Director of Social Security in SA, also spoke, welcoming this addition to the services to the Burra Community.  He spoke on the role of the Department and the various types of accommodation it helps to fund.  The Commonwealth granted $47,600, which represented the maximum available for the project.  Mr Ron Pearse, Chairman of the Board of Management, outlined Mr Barker’s wishes in planning the cottages.  There is sufficient money in hand to level a site for a further nine units, which will be built as soon as finance allows.  Miss Brown then gave a short address expressing her satisfaction with the building and furnishing of the homes, before declaring them open.  [Photograph of J.R. Barker.]

Tennis.  The Final report of the Aberdeen Tennis Club.

The club started about 50 years ago and at the end of the 1972-73 season has amalgamated with the Kooringa club to form the Burra Tennis Club.  The season began with a fresh coat of paint on the Clubhouse.  We fielded 2 ‘A’ teams, 3 ‘B’ teams and a junior team.  The White ‘A’ team were premiers.  The ‘B’ Purple team lost their final to Spalding and the Juniors also lost to Kooringa.  The Easter Tournament was again a success, as were fund-raising efforts throughout the year.  There was also a successful junior tournament.  We were sorry to farewell our President, Dennis O’Reilly, his wife Rona and family, at the end of the season, when they relocated to New Zealand.  We thank them for their hard work.  The season ended with a tea at the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms on 14 April.  During the season we paid the balance owing on the No. 5 court and so had five good courts to use.

95, 22, 12 June 1973, pages 1 & 4

Martin Dunstan writes a letter re his grandfather, John Dunstan and his links with the town.

He enclosed a photo of the Steam Saw Mills in Aberdeen c. 1880 in which John Dunstan was part owner.

John Dunstan was born at Gwenap in Cornwall 4 March 1851 and arrived at Port Adelaide on the Calabar before he was two years old.  With his father and mother and baby brother, he made the trip to Burra in a bullock dray in a fortnight.  After five years Captain Dunstan took over the Whealsara [sic] Copper Mines north of Bundaleer Station.  When a school was established there it was in a dugout in the side of a creek and it was there that John Dunstan learnt spelling and reading in the morning and sewing in the afternoon.  At these mines John Dunstan began picking copper ore when nine or ten years old.  After three years the family moved back to Burra, where John took night school and later attended F.R. White’s Commercial Academy.

[The above is copied from a story he gave the News in 1923.]

He went dispensing for Dr Nutt and then became clerk of the Redruth Court and later book-keeper for Dr T.H. Mayne.  In 1869 he started work with S. Drew & Co. as an accountant and corresponding clerk and stayed for seven years, also acting as clerk for the Burra District Council and auditor later of the Burra Corporation, the Mt Bryan District Council and several mines.

In 1876 he joined forces with G. & W. Sara as timber merchants, builders and contractors.  From practically nothing they built a wonderful business with activities all over the colony.  Among the notable buildings they erected were the Burra Model School, Gladstone Gaol (£21,640), Corny Point Lighthouse, Roseworthy College, the Adelaide Railway Goods Sheds and most of the railway stations on the northern and hills lines.  In a few years the firm was employing 220 men.  After W. Sara retired, the firm continued to prosper as Sara & Dunstan.  John Dunstan also worked on the Black Hills mining venture and was a part owner of the Burra Record.  [Presumably in the period before F.W. Holder gained full control.]

At 30 he was a JP and soon became a Councillor and later Mayor of Burra.  Against strong opposition he instituted tree planting.  With Cr John Lewis he acquired land for a recreation ground with a 999-year lease from the Burra Burra Mines.  He was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board, the Institute Committee and the Burra School Board of Advice.  He joined with Mr Lewis in bringing the Burra children down to Adelaide for the Adelaide Exhibition, against strong opposition.  In this he was assisted by the late W.B. Rounsevell.  The money left over was used to erect the fountain standing near the Anglican Church.

He was also President of the Burra Literary Society.  In 1891 he left Burra for Broken Hill, where he carried out similar works and became Mayor in 1899.

On 1 September 1953 the Record referred to Mr Ben Dunstan of Mt Bryan, who was a brother to John Dunstan.

[Martin Dunstan then goes on to say he is something of a fanatic on scrapbooks – in particular on Willunga and he appeals for any information relevant to that.  He also says he has his grandfather’s writing books, used at the Academy and two framed farewell messages from the town and the Literary Society, that were presented to his grandfather and he offers to lend his family relics for historic occasions in Burra.]

Ian Auhl repeats the report from 15 December 1909 of:

The Grand Balloon Ascent at Burra Oval on 11 December 1909.

Oddly Australia’s first powered flight had been a 5½ second event at Victoria Park, Sydney on 9 December 1909 by Colin de Fris in a Wright bi-plane.  The first balloon flight in SA was from North Terrace in 1871 and in 189o the two sisters Gladys & Val van Tassell had ascended and then returned to earth by triple parachute.  When the article was being researched Ian Auhl asked Mrs Mary Walker, widow of the late Oswald Walker, who was then 90, if she remembered the 1909 event.  She did, clearly, and even recalled that the pilot Rinaldo had landed on a woodheap at Killicoat’s (Abberton Park.)

Viceroy Tea Carnival

A great crowd assembled on Victoria Park on Saturday to witness the balloon ascent arranged by Messrs Wilkinson & Co. of Adelaide as a novel way of advertising their Viceroy Tea.  It created a big sensation.  The inflation of the balloon was watched with great interest.  At the report of a pistol shot, it was released and rose quickly some hundreds of feet, carrying with it Rinaldo, seated comfortably on a trapeze. At the climax he hung by his toes on the fast drifting balloon and then, hanging by his hands, he turned a complete somersault before taking his seat again.  The crowd cheered.  Another pistol shot was the signal for him to drop from the balloon and his body fell towards the earth rapidly, but suddenly a parachute opened and Rinaldo was seen seated on the trapeze, from which he saluted the crowd with a cheery wave of his hand.  Eventually he landed somewhat uncomfortably in P.L. Killicoat’s woodheap at Abberton Park, sustaining a shaking and several cuts, but with his grit and determination undiminished.  W.J. Richardson brought Rinaldo back to Victoria Park in his motor car.

Legislative Council Reform.  There have been major changes to the Legislative Council.

All persons qualified to vote for the House of Assembly will now automatically be on the Legislative Council roll and be entitled to vote.  (Though voting for the Legislative Council remains voluntary.)

The five electorates will be replaced by a single state-wide electorate returning 22 members – each serving six years with half retiring every three years.  They will be elected on the basis of proportional representation using optional preferential voting.

The minimum age for candidates for election has been lowered from 30 to 18.

Mid North Tourist Development Association AGM

Chairman D.E. Wilsdon said tourist was Australia’s ninth largest industry and has the fastest growth rate; but if we were complacent the opportunity to benefit would pass us by.  He reported on their Emblem Competition, won by Miss Eunice Mosey and on the ANTA Convention in Sydney.  Moves to amalgamate with the Southern Flinders Indian Pacific Development Association are reported and reasons given why it was decided not to proceed. Attractions which have been developed in the last 12 months are: Rail Tours to Burra, Swaggie Tours, Burra Mines (old & new), Wolta Wolta, Cumberlandvale, Wineries, Geralka Rural Farm, Motel extensions and the National Trust.  He felt Burra was poised to make the most of its attractions with the Copper festival being an encouragement for further developments, but that Clare was ambivalent, with some residents feeling that tourists may upset their already comfortable existence.  Some people in Clare are ready to act on the area’s great potential, but many are prepared to let the opportunity slide.

95, 30, 7 Aug. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The general rate has risen to 1.6 cents in the dollar to bring in $11,720 more.  Rising wages will add $8,000 a year in costs.  New plant is also needed – approval from the Minister will be sought to purchase a new D6 Dozer, 212 Power Grader and Low Loader.  (Hiring out of these will offset the costs and negotiations have already begun for hire of the ‘Dozer’ for work at the Mine.)

With a further $6,400 Rural Relief Scheme grant to be spent on uncompleted projects, work at the Town Hall is proceeding.  The roof is on the toilets and ceiling and wiring is installed.  Floors and plastering is to be done this week.

Aberdeen Football Club

Trevor Wall, on behalf of his family, presented a shield for the best and fairest junior in memory of Robert Wall.

A clock in the club rooms was also unveiled by Bruce Stockman, Vice-President of the Mid North League and a Past President of the club.  It is in memory of Robert Wall and Phillip Elliott, both of whom played for the club.

Burra Hospital

The new wing is completed internally, with just a few finishing external details to come.  It brings the Hospital into line with some of the best in the state.  The sunroom on the western end will be a useful addition.  In the wards new beds have replaced old and they can be raised and lowered.  Children’s Ward has large observation windows from the corridor.  The whole has been designed to be light and cheerful.  A sunken area alongside the Children’s bath allows a staff member to wash a child without uncomfortable bending.  Several new share rooms have been built.  The staff dining room opens into a small courtyard.  The kitchen is large and modern with stainless steel equipment.  A small room adjacent is provided for Meals on Wheels helpers and communicates with the kitchen through hatches.  Large incinerators have been placed in the old kitchen.

The Labour Ward and its satellite rooms are business-like and can deal with any emergency.  General patients can be placed in unoccupied midwifery wards if it is necessary.  The whole appearance is of hotel-like comfort combined with every consideration of practicality from emergency lighting to the 2,000 gallon rainwater tank beneath the floor and the whole now being on one level makes life much easier for those working there.

95, 36, 18 Sep. 1973, page 1

Burra Hospital.  96th Annual Meeting of the Board of Management

The Chairman said the recent $250,000 improvement made the hospital one of the most up-to-date in country SA.  The financial position improved despite salary increases of some $11,000.  Patient fee increases have resulted in a surplus of $29,547.  The long awaited rebuilding has occurred.  In July the new Maternity Wing, Private and Share Wards, Children’s Ward and new kitchen were taken over and a room has been built for Meals-on-Wheels.  The laundry has been moved to the old kitchen.  Grounds and roadway will be improved and a new retaining wall will be erected around the lawn area.  All kitchen crockery and utensils have been renewed and linen and some furniture.  Costs have been met from our own funds.  The coming year will see painting and renovation to the exterior including the secretary’s residence.  Matron’s residence will get a large sitting-dining room and a carport.  The Nurses’ Home has a new oil heater.  In the past year patients have average 20.1 and 40 babies were born at the hospital.  The hospital has land under crop from Tom Rogers and Don Stockman and would welcome further offers of land from ratepayers.  The Hospital Auxiliary continues to provide welcome assistance under Mrs S. Scroop.  The Burra & District Fund-Raising Committee contributed $1,000 for new furnishings.  Last October Matron Fyfe resigned after 13 years to take effect from 7 December 1972.  She was much involved in the detailed planning of the new hospital.  Matron Phillips was appointed, assisted by Sisters R.Z. Brown, R.M. Lucas, R.B. Seaford, E.A. Oates, J.E. Wall and J. McBride.  Sister I.J. Byles left the district after 10 years of valuable service.  Sister Good has carried out her duties as tutor.  The Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer has kept the administration at a very high level.  The Ambulance Service intends to install a radio base at the hospital.

95, 37, 25 Sep. 1973, page 4

Mackerode Stud Dispersal Sale will be held at the Burra Stockyards on 17 October 1973.

The stud was established in 1882 by G.A. Gebhardt, beginning with ewes and rams from Sir J. Lancelot Stirling’s ‘Napla’, Lake Alexandrina and from William Jervois’s ‘Wellington’ River Murray.  Later rams were introduced from ‘Koonoona’ and ‘Cappeedee’ and in the early 1900s from NSW, with rams from ‘Boonoke’ and ‘Bundemar’.  The early 1930s saw Collinsville blood introduced and all subsequent breeding has been on Collinsville and Mackerode blood.  In the early years the Mackerode rams were small and wrinkly bodied.  Early 1900s rams cut 30-35 lb of wool with 12 months’ growth.  A difficult task was selecting for wool weight and against body wrinkle.  Wrinkles began to disappear by the 1920s and now rams carry an even three-fold front, with no body wrinkle and little tail wrinkle.  The aim has been for large format, plain bodied sheep carrying a heavy cutting, soft-handling fleece of 58s-60s quality.  Fleece testing has been used in the top 20% of young rams each year to select the best 50% of those tested for potential workers.  Testing has shown that rams with 58-60s on count of crimps per inch usually have a fibre diameter of only 21-23 microns (60-64s) which is an advantage and is a result of breeding for soft-handling wool.

Mackerode ewes have a very high fertility rate.  The stud has been lambing twice a year for some years – half the ewes lamb in autumn and the other half in spring.  Ewes that fail to lamb in spring are culled and the success can be seen in the few that now have to be culled.

The dispersal of such a stud is a rare event and offers breeders a unique opportunity.

Burra Floral Art Group hosted a meeting to aid Red Cross on 26 October.  Mrs R. Lloyd demonstrated making a sheaf of flowers.  Paintings and needlework by Miss Geake were on show.  She was born in Burra and lived here all her life.  Her father was a grocer and later worked in Edwin Harris’s shop.  The family lived in East Street and later in Ayers Street (the house is now Mr Broad’s).  Miss Geake took lessons from Rene Crewes (now Lady McBride) at Kooringa and in 1923 in Adelaide under the late James Ashton.  In 1925 she exhibited an oil painting in Adelaide and won a gold medal.  Paintings sent to London for examination were awarded meritorial certificates.  She taught painting at Kooringa in oil and water colours and also taught the use of pastels and black and white.  Students included Mr L. Bence and the Warner twins from Hallett.  She has always been interested also in needlework, crochet and knitting.  She was a member of the Burra [Cheer-up] Ladies’ Band in WWI, playing the tenor horn. For many years she worked at Wilkinson’s, was connected with the Kooringa Methodist Church and taught at the Sunday school.  We are all pleased to learn that Miss Geake has returned to Burra and wish her well.  The sheaf made by Mrs Lloyd was later delivered to Miss Geake in the Burra Hospital with a card signed by those who came to view her work.

[Doris Minette Edith Geake born 25 January 1891 Kooringa: died 13 April 1974.]

St Edmund’s Church of England at Booborowie celebrates its golden jubilee on 9 December.  The Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier will preside at Holy Communion and will preach.  The celebrant will be the Rector of Burra Parish, Rev. J.H. Stephenson.  The foundation stone was laid on 5 December 1923 by Mrs A. Affolter, who with a band of helpers provided a large part of the funds needed for the building.  The nave was dedicated on 20 July 1924.  It cost $2,680 and the chancel was added at a cost of $540 in 1928.  The building was consecrated on 8 November 1929.  Before this Anglicans met in Beavan’s homestead at Booborowie for 16 years and from 1921-24 worshiped in the Memorial Hall.  Structural repairs to two places in the nave were made some years ago and a thorough external repainting is now being done.  A large attendance is expected and a basket luncheon will follow the service.  The congregation is now small due to removal after removal of Anglican families from Booborowie.

95, 46, 4 Dec. 1973, pages 1 & 8

EFS Officers and others met in the Burra Town Hall on 28 November from Burra, Farrell Flat, Mt Bryan, Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie to plan their co-ordinated reaction to fires this season.  They discussed the three divisions of fire fighting:

Field operations

Service to supply the needs of the Fire supervisor

Planning – tactics and operations control

Each Council has at least one EFS station with control rooms and premises suitable for use as a district control centre, bur equally important are trained personnel to staff such centres.

Sgt Haynes cited the problems unique to the Eastern Stations Area.  This area covered 6,871 square miles in which there are 15 occupied homesteads and of which only two have a radio link with the Broken Hill Flying Doctor.  Of the remaining 13, seven are virtually connected to the outside world only by a party-line telephone; three on one line and four on another.  Both lines connect only to the Burra exchange.  The greater part of these lines is old private lines and the majority is carried on mallee posts, often white ant eaten, which would burn like kindling.  Another problem he discussed was the incompatibility of the various radio systems then in use.  Radios capable of DSB, SSB & HF operation were needed.  Sgt Haynes thought Burra was the logical co-ordinating centre.  In the 1951 fire in the Eastern Stations area some units travelled 300 miles chasing smoke and never saw a fire.  There was no co-operation or direction.  Maps have now been prepared at 1 inch to 16 miles, showing all homesteads, occupied and unoccupied and all dams and waterholes and major roads and tracks.  Supervisors should have lists of names, addresses and phone numbers, with particulars of equipment available.

Mr J.N. McBride, Supervisor of the Eastern Districts Fire Fighting Organisation, also addressed the meeting about the present situation and expectations for the fire season.  Negotiation between the two Council areas represented will continue.

St Edmund’s Anglican Church, Booborowie

The golden jubilee celebrations were held on Sunday in prefect weather.  Extra chairs doubled the capacity to 120 or more and a further 60 people had to remain outside and listen on a public address system.  97 people received Holy Communion.  The church has been undergoing restoration for the event.  The painters finished the exterior on Friday morning and the ladies of the church gave it a thorough clean and polish on Friday.  The Tr Rev. S.B. Rosier, Bishop of Willochra, preached.  A luncheon followed in Booborowie Hall.  Former parishioners came back from across the state and members of the local Methodist and catholic congregations also attended.  The Rector, Rev. John Stephenson, welcomed the congregation.

In its early days the congregation met in the home of Mr B.H. Beaven, until the present church was built.  Mrs D.H. Campbell decorated the cake with its 50 candles, which were lit by Mr T. Bailey, a member of the original building committee.  Mrs L. Farrelly, who had been present at the laying of the foundation stone, extinguished the candles.  The collection of $323.37, when put with donations on hand, will make a total of about $700.  Since then the sum has increased to $879.  Repairs and painting may cost about $690, so there will be some over for repainting the interior.

Characteristics of the paper for 1973.

There was a fair coverage of Burra news, but with the service area of the paper extending from Robertstown to Spalding and Saddleworth, quite a bit of space was devoted to news from the other towns in that area.  Errors in setting sports results sometimes make interpreting them difficult or even impossible.

Page l

Solid news items with little or no advertising,

Page 2

Larger advertisements dominate, with 2-3 columns of sports results.

Page 3

Similar to page 2.

Page 4

Larger advertisements and a mixture of sports and news for a couple of columns.

Page 5

Typically dominated by the 50 & 24 years ago column and large advertisements.

Page 6

Smaller advertisements, Cash Column, Public Notices and Entertainment.

Page 7

Dominated by larger advertisements and the ‘Out and About’ column featuring snippets of personal news.

Page 8

Typically half news and half larger advertisements.  It is often dominated by District Council reports, but the news is quite varied in content.

96, 1, 15 Jan. 1974, page 1

Burra High School Presentation Day (December 1973)

Mr John Halbert, Senior Lecturer in Physical Education at Adelaide Teachers’ College was the guest speaker.

Headmaster D.W. Calder presented the 61st Annual Report.

The year began with 175 students; 100 girls and 75 boys.  In Leaving there were 20 girls and 3 boys.  The prefects have set a fine example and have been conscientious in their duties.  Parent bodies have been co-operative and helpful in enabling the purchase of many sporting and classroom items.  The school canteen proved a great success.  The High School Council has been concerned at the high rate of staff turnover each year; over 50%, and it ahs sought more stability.  It has also been concerned over the standard of school accommodation and the progress of the new school.

St Peter’s Cathedral Choir is coming to Burra again for their annual holiday.  They came three years ago.  They will camp at the Redruth Methodist Memorial Hall, but need three more beds, 12 mattresses and 29 pillows.  If you can help, contact Mr R.R. Reed as soon as possible.  The Choir will lead the singing at St Mary’s for a Confirmation and Holy Communion Service on 27 January, when the Bishop of Willochra, Rt Rev. Bruce Rosier will officiate.

Burra Carols Evening at the Burra Swimming Pool the Sunday before Christmas was the best for years.  Attendance and proceeds were up.  ($67 compared with c. $50 for several years.)  Burra Methodist Choir led the singing.

Burra Rainfall totalled 2,434 point for 1973, which is 670 points above the average.  From 1 January 1974 measurements will be in millimetres (mm).

96, 4, 5 Feb. 1974, page 1

Weather.  January was the wettest on record with 179.6 mm or 7 inches of rain in a week.  Four days of heavy rain brought floods, but not havoc.  It began late on Saturday night or early Sunday morning and continued to Wednesday evening.  A dry spell on Thursday morning was followed by more rain Thursday afternoon and night and on Friday.  The creeks all flowed strongly.  The whole area of the stockyards and beyond turned into a lake of brown water.  Part of the Copperhouse Road Bridge gave way and became unsafe.  At Gully’s Wharf in Young Street the water came within a foot or so of the top. [Top of what?]  The water roared over the Pig and Whistle crossing, creating a foaming whirlpool.  Fencing was damaged along watercourses throughout the district.  Damage to culverts is extensive, with Springbank Road particularly herd hit.  The Burra Creek crossing at World’s End has also been badly damaged.  The flow down the creek from Springbank to the Bon accord was perhaps the greatest ever.  The total rainfall for January in Burra was 192.4 mm and for the year has reached 224.4 mm or 881 points.

The previous highest rainfall in January was 365 points in 1941.

[Given the nature of the fall described this report is surprisingly limited and brief.]

Burra National Trust AGM

President G.R. O’Connor.  The year has been one of consolidation.  With the aid of three amazing young women from the Salisbury College of Advanced Education the restoration of the dugouts was completed after a long delay.  As a fund raising effort a fence building job was undertaken on behalf of Samin Ltd and resulted in a nett profit of $780.  The Bon Accord residence bathroom was rebuilt and better facilities installed – much of the rebuilding was necessitated by white ant damage – a problem which has re-appeared elsewhere in the house and must be addressed immediately.  The museum continues to be a success and to attract many visitors.

Early in the year an old horse works was purchased and this presents members with the task of making it operative. Three haulage skips in very good repair were also bought and brought to the chimney site.

Due to difficulties associated with mining the area, we have not been able to remove much of the old haulway tunnel, which includes the remarkably preserved wheel.  A serious fault in the rock structure has made the area dangerous.  Roche’s will do their utmost to retrieve as much as possible.  I am concerned that membership remains static.  This is common to most branches, but is nevertheless a concern.

Miss Tanya Moiseiwitsch visited Burra on Saturday.  She is in the state for the Arts Festival production of Moliere’s The Imaginary Invalid.  Her mother was Miss Daisy Fowler Kennedy who was born in a bedroom of the Commercial Hotel in Burra in 1893.  Joseph Kennedy, Daisy’s father, was a headmaster and the headmaster’s house was not ready, so the family stayed at the hotel until the house in Kangaroo street was available.  Daisy Kennedy became a well known violinist who went to Vienna to study when aged 15.  She later married the famous concert pianist from Odessa, Russia, Benno Moiseiwitsch.

Fire.  The north bound bus of Mortons of Broken Hill caught fire at Hallett on Sunday about 7.30 due to an engine fault.  Some lady passengers suffered shock, but all 45 passengers escaped along with most of the luggage.  The bus was completely burned out and damage is estimated at $24,000.  The EFS put out the fire.

Burra Red Cross

The March meeting was attended by 50 ladies to hear an address by Matron G. Siegele.  She was Matron at the Burra Hospital 1923-37.  During that time she went to Sydney to study the Truby King Baby Nursing Methods and on her return established the first Infant Health Clinic in Burra.  After leaving Burra she went to Port Pirie and Broken Hill, before going to Royal Perth Hospital, where she spent 19 years before retiring 12 years ago.  At the age of 80 she is an active worker for her church and a member of the Embroidery Guild in Adelaide.  While here she visited the Hospital and Barker’s Cottages, where she knew several of the residents.  She had lunch with Mrs Roy Jeffery, who also drove her around the town and Mine area before she returned to the city.

Fifty-three Grade IV & V students had a six-day camping excursion to Mt Barker Chalet.

Burra’s evidence to the Local Government Boundaries Royal Commission will be taken on Friday.  The submission by the Council was formulated in July 1973 and the Council opposes the formation of Regional Councils on the basis that:

It will mean added costs to ratepayers.

Such a council would carry out the same duties that the present Council does.

There would be unnecessary duplication of work and administrative costs.

The Council can see some merits in bigger Councils in some cases and in boundary adjustments.  This Council was formed five years ago by the amalgamation of the DC and the Corporation of Burra.  Its income is about $100,000 p.a.  It employs a Clerk, Overseer, Part-Time Health and Building Inspectors and combines with two other Councils for a Full-Time Weeds Inspector.  There is a concern over rising costs of maintenance and administration and it feels its boundaries should not be retracted.  In the event of a decision that some adjacent Councils should cease to exist, a map is enclosed showing the area that could be incorporated into the Burra Burra DC.

Burra Floods

Thunderstorms on Tuesday evening brought 24.8 mm in less than one hour.  On Saturday came a heavier downpour.  Outlets were unable to cope and some minor flooding of streets occurred.  At about 1 p.m. the creek past the hospital overflowed at the Commercial Road Bridge.  Commercial Street was rapidly covered in muddy water, which flooded parts of Chapel, Queen and Thames Streets.  Some Commercial Street premises were flooded and others escaped.  The rainfall for the week was 68.8 mm.  The rainfall for April so far is 164.6 mm or 650 points and the highest ever was in 1889 when 830 points were recorded.

96, 16, 30 Apr. 1974, pages 1 & 5

Burra School

The Public Works Standing Committee has accepted the need for improved school accommodation at Burra and construction has been recommended.  The loans allocation will be decided in August and construction will depend on this decision.  The decision to redevelop the existing site is based on the fact that it is a pleasant setting for attractive landscaping.  It is also near the town centre and will preserve the close relationships of the school with the community and give ready access to the Burra Town Swimming Pool and football oval.  The school will be able to offer facilities for the community in terms of the library and art and craft and music facilities and a multi-purpose sports hall.  It is envisaged that the school will become a focal point for educational, recreational and cultural interests.  There will be a staff block, administration, canteen, sports, music & drama areas and changing rooms as well as a library, recreation areas and car park.  Parents will have a continuity of involvement as their children move through the school from primary to secondary years.  There is the possibility of a unified administration under a single headmaster.

The size of the planned accommodation has been based on primary enrolments in Burra and district schools.  Secondary enrolments should exceed 200 by 1975, which justifies providing for 220-250 students, which would allow for the possibility of a 5th year class in the future.  The existing Burra School is a well-known landmark and is among the finest buildings of its type in SA.  It has, however, outlived its usefulness for modern educational conditions and needs extensive modifications to meet the requirements of modern educational programs.  The large rooms with high ceilings are hard to heat and cool and also present acoustic problems.  Little has been done in recent years to modify the original accommodation.  Administration facilities are inadequate.  The library is far below modern standards and the classrooms do not accommodate modern teaching methods.

The site has made development difficult and the outdoor areas fall far short of requirements.  Sports facilities are limited and in need of upgrading and development.  The site has also become cluttered by the erection of a multitude of wooden classrooms, a canteen and toilet blocks for both schools.  Many of these buildings have outlived their economic usefulness.  The plans prepared provide for upgrading of the main building to house a primary school of 350 in modern open-space accommodation.  This provision anticipates the eventual closure of Leighton (28 children), Farrell Flat (17 children) and Mt Bryan (36 children).  The plan groups buildings around a central courtyard at the rear of the old building and they are functionally linked by the resource centre, while the existing building will be extensively remodelled internally.  Planning and design is based on the open space principle.  All new buildings are single storey and are stepped up the rising ground so as not to distract from the appearance of the existing building, especially as seen from the town.  The relationships of the buildings and their uses allow for the separation or integration of the two schools as required.

Weather.  With 23.2 mm to 9 a.m. yesterday and 81.0 mm for the week, the January-May period becomes the wettest on record; 508.6 mm or 20.02 inches.  The previous highest was in 1889 with 13.41 inches.  The continuously flowing water courses and flooding have made access to many paddocks virtually impossible.  Many gutters have become creeks and shallow creeks have been deepened.

The Burra Creek yesterday was a rushing torrent of muddy water for the sixth time this year.  Mt Bryan was flooded again on Thursday; the earth is so saturated that it cannot absorb even a slight shower.

Further rain has fallen, with 94 points to 1.30 p.m.

Booborowie received 25 mm in ten minutes at lunch time.

Buildings have been flattened at Eudunda in a cyclonic storm [i.e. a tornado].

96, 18, 14 May 1974, pages 4-5 gutter

Obituary.  Allan Donald Sellars died 12 March. He has been described as ‘a friend to all who had the pleasure of knowing him’.  He was born at Burra North in 1908 and educated at the Burra School.  He married Daphne Hirschausen in 1927 and together they commenced and operated a general carrying, grain agency and wood merchant’s business.  From the mid 1930s Mr Sellars conducted a mail run for six years, travelling each weekend to the outlying stations east of Burra, covering a distance of 300 miles over unmade roads, with some 180 rates to negotiate.  Declared unfit for war service, he opened a service station and garage in conjunction with his other business to release the owner for war service.  On medical advice he gave up his business and purchased ‘Emu Flat’ at Keith in 1945.  This proved unsuitable for family needs at the time and he then spent six years on dairy farms at Murray Bridge and Jervois before returning to Keith in 1953.  In 1958 he founded the General Agency business of A.D. Sellars & Sons – later including all six sons in premises at Keith.  Ill health forced him into semi-retirement in 1966.  He was always interested in the community and was the founder of the ‘Burdett’ Agricultural Bureau at Murray Bridge.  He was a director of the Jervois Co-op Milk Factory and assisted in getting it included in the city milk area, thereby receiving extra bonuses.  He was on the committees of the Keith Agricultural Bureau, Keith War Memorial Community Centre and the Keith & District Show Society.  He was of a cheerful disposition and ever ready to help his fellowman.  He is survived by his daughter, Roma Mrs C.A. Davis and sons, Colin, Brian, Graham, Dean, Ian and Kevin.

Father John Morley was born in 1924 and lived with his family on a small orchard and vineyard at Williamstown.  The family moved to Adelaide in the 1930s and John attended Urrbrae Agricultural HS and Pulteney Grammar School.  After school he went jackerooing for Mr Chris Wade on Thistle Island for a year, before working for Sir Philip McBride on Conmurray Station in the South East.  He joined the RAAF as air crew in 1942 and was commissioned in 1943, eventually becoming Radar Leader for 102 Squadron, flying in Liberators.  After discharge he returned to Conmurray for a time and in 1946 bought a virgin property on the Avenue Range, which he named ‘Dingley’.   He developed 1,300 acres before selling it in 1957.  He ran 1,500 to 2,000 sheep and Aberdeen Angus cattle.  He studied for the ministry at St John’s College, Morpeth, from 1958 for three years.  He has been a keen sportsman, playing football and cricket for more than 20 years and now plays golf and a little tennis.  He used to show horses in the South East and also played polocrosse.  He is married with three children and three grandsons.  His son, John, is married and works at G.H. Michell & Sons.  Rosemary is married and Susan is still at school at Woodlands, doing matriculation this year.

Hanson Post Office was closed on Friday after serving the community for 84 years.  Hanson will now be served by private boxes at Burra or Farrell Flat or by the Mail Run.  Hanson was a non-official office.  The first office was at the Hanson (then called Davieston) Railway Station and was opened in December 1890.  Mr I. Rippin was the postmaster with a daily mail service by train.  E.S. Blunt was postmaster 1897-1902.  A telegraph worked by telephone was installed in 1913.  Local residents built the next post office by the schoolteacher’s residence and until 1947 postmasters were the schoolteacher’s wives or immediate relations.  E. Dawson was the schoolteacher in 1915, Hester Oakley was schoolteacher 5 January 1916 and Miss Janie H. Fedd from 1 July 1916 was the sister of the schoolmistress.  Lilian Mabel Bishop was a temporary appointment 25 March 1920 and Margaret Ellen Marshall was the teacher from 15 April 1920.

Allison Barckey, an exchange student from Riverton, New Jersey, who is at Burra High School and staying with John & Bev. Dewhirst at Booborowie, makes some observations:

At home we learn to be more independent and here the teachers outline what is important.  At home we are given more assorted material and each must judge for himself or herself what is important.  At home I go to a private co-ed school drawn from a select group of the community.  At BHS there is a wider range and variety of people.  At home it is usual to change rooms and class levels for every class.  Here there seems to be little academic pressure among fellow students.  Living in the country is different too.  The atmosphere is relaxed, but with a quiet air of growth and change.  It has all been very fascinating and exciting and I cannot discover all I would like in my ten week stay.

The Royal Commission on Council Boundaries

The first report recommends reducing the number of Councils from 137 to 72 with boundaries based on community of interest.  The recommendation does not envisage there being fewer officers employed.  In the last 40 years almost all the changes have been the amalgamation of a rural Town Council with surrounding District Council.  Very few boundary changes have been made.  The mergers of Town Councils and District Councils have all proved to be satisfactory.  [Details are given respecting the District Councils of Robertstown and Eudunda, which it is proposed to merge and also the District Council of Saddleworth & Auburn, which it is proposed to merge with the DC of Riverton and of the Clare DC, which it is recommended should be enlarged by absorbing parts of the DCs of Georgetown & Spalding together with all of Blyth.]

The Burra Burrs DC and the Clare DC boundary would remain as it is, but it is recommended that the southern three Hundreds of the Hallett DC (Anne, Hallett & Tomkinson) be merged with the Burra Burra DC.  The Burra Burrs DC has not yet had time to consider this recommendation.

95, 30 (3), 6 Aug. 1974, pages 1 & 8

Burra & District Ratepayers’ Meeting on Thursday night was well attended.  The main concerns expressed covered road deterioration and the lack of grant monies.  A petition to the Minister of Roads, followed by a deputation is to be arranged.  The Chairman said there have been many changes and proposals for change in local government in the past year and this has created a rather confused outlook.  At the start of the year the Council was in a difficult financial position, though this had improved somewhat now.  The Council has had to increase staff since January 1973 due to the increased complexity of its work.  In the year Rural Unemployment Relief Grant work was completed, resulting in improved recreational facilities at Farrell Flat, Booborowie, mount Bryan and Burra.  Some renovation of Paxton Square and the Redruth Gaol was also done.  A smoke lounge and toilets were constructed at the Burra Town Hall.  Council administration includes Town Hall hire and management, caravan park maintenance, Burra Swimming Pool maintenance and management and two sports grounds at Burra.  The projected plan for a dam on Burra Creek has been delayed by weather conditions, but is expected to proceed in early summer.  Councillors continue to promote the development of the town and district.  Rising costs will be a major factor in the coming year.  The EFS has attended several small fires this year.  A main theme to appear during the meeting was the deterioration of unsealed roads and some sealed sections within the district.  The Booborowie-Spalding Road attracted a lot of comment.  The Minister says he is going to look at the matter of road funding, but comes back with a negative result.  There seems to be no alternative, but to cut Council costs.  Perhaps we must cut staff and rely on outside contractors if and when money becomes available.  The petition and deputation will stress the need for road funds, the threat of retrenchment to Council staff and the need for a higher priority to be given to the Booborowie-Spalding Road.

The possible control of water sports on Porter’s Lagoon was also raised and a meeting will be called to discuss this further.  At present six fences have been covered by water in the lagoon areas.  Weed control was another issue that received some attention.

Burra Burra DC

The rate has been increased by 0.2 cents in the dollar, but the extra $11,700 in revenue will not solve the Council’s financial problems and if Government aid does not increase then retrenchment of the workforce will have to be undertaken.  The attitude of the Federal Government is particularly deplorable.  Through traffic from the eastern states is considerable and the wet year has also increased the damage to surfaces.  Burra has been changed from a zoning of Region 8 to Region 7, to its detriment and is seeking reinstatement.  Council has decided to accept the boundary changes as recommended by the Local Government Royal Commission.  There has been no real progress on the common effluent drainage system pending a decision whether the Government will provide the necessary subsidy.

Porter’s Lagoon

A Progress Committee was formed at a meeting at Farrell Flat Hall on 12 August.  Mr Leo Robinson of Burra chaired the meeting and was later elected President of the new Porter’s Lagoon Progress Committee.  The Vice-President is Gordon Webster.  The aim is to promote water safety for swimmers, skiers and boat owners.  Boat owners will be asked to pay a $2 membership fee to the committee which will control the foreshore.

Locusts and Grasshoppers were around in large numbers last April-May.  Locust hatchings are expected in September and indications are that this could be a bad year.  A state-wide control program is being organised.

96, 35, 10 Sep. 1974, page 1

Rx 207 hauled a special steam train to Burra on Saturday.  About 250 steam enthusiasts came for the journey.

Mr B. Gollin started a humble shop in Burra in 1850 and in 1974 Gollin Holdings Ltd is a business with an annual turnover exceeding $134 million.  The Advertiser of 8 December 1874 reported the death of Mr B. Gollin at an early hour on Monday.  [Bezaleel Gollin died 7 December 1874 Adelaide.]  He had been suffering from a complaint requiring great care for some time, but it had not prevented his continued business dealings.  On Sunday he felt unwell and about 11 a.m. he lay down.  When he was seized with great pain a doctor was sent for and he died at 2 a.m. on Monday morning.  He had been in business in a big way for many years in Burra and Adelaide.  He was a successful broker and played a prominent part in the affairs of the Synagogue.  He left a widow and a large family of sons and daughters.  The Australian International Trading Company that started in Adelaide 125 years ago has commissioned the author Osmar White to write its history.

Gollin Holdings traces its origins to the arrival of Bezaliel Gollin in Adelaide in 1848.  He is first recorded as a store owner in Burra in 1850 and when he died in 1874 was said to be a commercial broker in business in a large way.  His sons George and Walter expanded the operations and in partnership with two cousins had branches in NZ, Sydney and Melbourne by 1900.  They were largely involved in importing foodstuffs, textiles and raw materials and in a902 opened a London purchasing centre.  When George Gollin died in 1946 he bequeathed $20,000 to establish the George Gollin Professorship of Economics at Adelaide University.  The early days remain very sketchy and Mr White will visit Burra this week on Thursday.

96, 36, 17 Sep. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra Hospital Board

Cr R.B. Jennison has retired after 16 years service to the Board and Mr L.A. Beinke was appointed in his place.  Chairman R.K. Pearce delivered the 97th Annual Report.  This year had been very successful financially.  Reserves had been built up sufficiently to enable the alterations to the hospital to be made without a public appeal.  They cost $253,926 of which $169,225 was Government subsidy.  Expenses have been controlled.  Wages have risen $18,787 and a corresponding increase in fees of $50,716.  It is likely wages in the coming year will be $150,000.  The average bed cost rose $1.11 to $17.40, but we still showed a surplus of $26,617 and there is a credit balance in all accounts of $30,000 on deposit.  The building program for now is complete.  We have a new Maternity Wing including an Emergency Labour Ward, store rooms, Children’s Ward and kitchen and this brings the hospital to a high standard.  The laundry and incinerator rooms have been modernised.  Nearly all the rooms and passageways are now air conditioned and the other parts of the hospital and the Matron’s and Secretary’s residences have been renovated and painted.  Gardens and Lawns have been re-sown.  In the next year we will bituminise the car park and erect a car park for nursing staff.  The Secretary’s residence will be renovated inside.  This will only leave the painting of the old private rooms and wards to be done.  A new X-ray plant has been purchased for $4,600.  Daily occupancy is 24 and 33 babies were born.  The Hospital Auxiliary continues its important support.  The Burra 7 District Fund Raising Committee this year donated $1,000.  Matron Phillips has been quietly efficient.  Sister Good has been an able Tutor Sister.  The Meals On Wheels continues to carry on with great success.

[Mr Pearce concludes with the usual widespread acknowledgements of support and gives special mention and thanks to retiring Board member Mr R.B. Jennison.

96, 36, 17 Sep. 1974, page 7

Bezaliel Gollin – information from Ian Auhl.

Gollin seems to have arrived in Burra in 1848 and joined the firm of Marks, very early storekeepers in Burra.  The firm became Marks & Gollin.  Gollin appears as foreman of nearly every court case from 1848 to 1851, including a murder or two.  The Register reports Queen Victoria’s 31st birthday when Gollin hoisted the City of London banner from his flagpole and soon flags were flying everywhere in honour of the sovereign.  On the 1849 map Mr White noticed Marks and Gollin on a couple of blocks.  Mr Marks lived between Kangaroo and Ware Streets where the Walkleys now live.  Bezaliel Gollin lived on a block on Ayers Street where Les Broad & family now reside.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 1

Osmar White, the author who visited Burra recently researching the history of Bezaliel Gollin, considers that Burra has by far the best collection of mid-Victorian buildings in the whole of Australia.  He cannot understand why they are not being exploited.  There should, he says, be hundreds of thousands of tourists annually.  A tumbledown stone cottage could produce more wealth for the community than any modern shop or service station that could be erected on its site.  People may consider that history is bunt – ‘but these days it’s gilt edged bunt and it brings the money into communities with the common sense to cash in on an historical heritage.’

[Check this use of ‘bunt’.  If it is noted correctly, it is probably an incorrect reference to Henry Ford’s famous comment ‘History is more or less bunk.’  This was said in an interview with Charles N. Wheeler and reported in the Chicago Tribune 25 May 1916.]
