96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, pages 1 & 5

The Eastern Fire Fighting Organisation held its annual meeting at Koomooloo Station last Wednesday.  With the wettest year on record and the country at its best in living memory, the potential for fire is huge.  Forests of spear grass are already drying off.  Unless summer rains come it will be a tinderbox.

Luncheon was served in the shearers’ quarters and the meeting was held in the woolshed.  John McBride was Chairman & Supervisor of the Organisation.  The main visitor was the Director General of the EFS Mr Fred Kerr.  The Chairman’s report stressed the tremendous growth of this exceptional season and its potential to make the east the most fire prone district in the state.  He suggested the need again for the area to be declared a total fire ban area.  He outlined the negotiations which resulted in their having four radio transmitting licences for Single Side Band Receivers on a call sign VL5EM, but at present, while awaiting delivery; they were using the radio on loan from the Traeger Company.  He also reported on his visits to other allied organisations at Mannahill and Gladstone.  The problem of plague locust hatchings was also referred to.  Mr McBride declined to continue in office and Mr Don Lord was elected in his place.  Mr Kerr then gave his address.  Mr Brian Menadue, a police officer, also spoke and said the pilots who flew to Moomba six days a week would be actively looking for fires.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 2

Obituary.  Monsignor Patrick Valentine Hughes died on 18 September.  After his retirement he lived at Port Pirie for a year with the Bishop, before moving to ‘Villa Beovich’ at Myrtle Bank, a new home for retired priests conducted by the Little Sisters of the Poor.  The funeral was at Burra on Friday at 11 a.m. when Bishop Gallagher of Port Pirie was the Principal Celebrant at the Requiem Mass, assisted by Father Kevin Matthews of Burra, Mons. Thomas Horgan, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of Adelaide and twenty-eight priests.  Place of honour was given to Archbishop Beovich of Adelaide, who studied in Rome with Monsignor Hughes.  Friends came from Renmark and Barmera where he had been Parish Priest as well as from elsewhere in SA.  He was a gentle and frugal man with a great zeal for his faith and a love for children.  He was born in 1891 and educated at St Augustine’s Geelong, Victoria, Mt Melleray Seminary, Ireland and at the Propaganda Fide College in Rome.  After ordination in Rome by Cardinal Pompili in 1926 he went to SA and the then Diocese of Port Augusta.  He served as assistant priest in Peterborough, Port Augusta and Port Pirie and was locum tenens at Carrieton before becoming Parish Priest at Renmark and later at Burra, where he was a familiar and respected figure until his retirement several years ago.

Miss Gertrude Williams will be 90 on 30 September.  She was born in Burra, the second daughter of Mr & Mrs C.C. Williams.  Her mother, then Miss Watson, came to SA in 1876, employed on the voyage as a nurse.  Thirteen babies were born en route.  She became the Matron of the Burra Hospital during an epidemic of typhoid fever, which saw many patients there in very primitive conditions.  Some patients were accommodated in the old bar of the Burra Hotel and others on the floor.  Nurse Watson was dismayed to find many patients using tin pannikins to drink from and with her first pay bought them china cups.

St Joseph’s Catholic Church Centenary

Bishop Brian Gallagher of Port Pirie consecrated St Joseph’s Burra exactly 100 years from the day it was officially blessed and opened on 8 November.  The celebrations continued over the weekend.

On Friday the church was consecrated.

On Saturday there was a special Mass of thanksgiving and a Parish Picnic at Aberdeen Oval.

Seventeen priests from the Diocese of Port Pirie and the Archdiocese of Adelaide attended the consecration ceremony.  One was Monsignor W.H. Nesdale who was parish priest of Burra 52 years ago and is still active as Parish Priest of Georgetown.  Monsignor T. Toal of Jamestown is a brother to Dr M.F. Toal, who was a former Burra priest.  Fr Laurie Quinn came from Loxton.  Fr M. Kineavy, the priest previous to Fr Kevin Matthews, was also present [and the other visiting priests are listed.]

Two aspects of the consecration of interest were the taking possession of the church and the sealing of relics into the altar.  In taking possession the Bishop wrote the Greek and Latin alphabets in sand spread in the centre of the church.  The idea is that Christ’s possession of the church can be so symbolised, as he is the beginning and end of all things, the alpha and omega or in the Latin alphabet the A and Z.  The relics of saints are enclosed in every consecrated altar.  The new altar was consecrated and then Mass was celebrated.  The Altar, Lectern, President’s Seat and Tabernacle Stand have all recently been constructed from local stones, copper ore, pieces of malachite and azurite, to give a typical local flavour.  The design is the work of Fr Kevin Matthews and was done by David Loffler with Fr Matthews as labourer.  Ross Drew and Mike Warde laid the new carpet over the extended sanctuary and the candlesticks on the walls were made and donated by Darius Ross of Ross Lighting in Adelaide.  Ross and Dianne Drew presented a cushion for the seat to match the new carpet.  After the consecration there was a reception in the Town Hall.  Mr Jim Quinn, as Master of Ceremonies, gave a brief summary of the early history of the parish.  He pointed out the connections with the Austrian Jesuits who founded Sevenhill and the early foundation of a church-school in Commercial Street in 1857.  The ruins can be seen on the corner of Kangaroo Street.  He mentioned the great work of the Sisters of St Joseph and others over so many years.  Bishop Gallagher responded and pointed out that owing to the illness of one of the priests Fr Matthew would now also have responsibility for the Parish of Spalding-Booborowie as well as Burra.

Fr John Morley of St Mary’s [Anglican] Parish spoke on behalf of local clergy.

On Saturday evening St Joseph’s was filled again for a Mass of Thanksgiving.

On Sunday a Parish Picnic was held at Aberdeen Oval and an altar had been erected there for an open air Mass, celebrated by Fr Matthews.  Special mention was made of Brother Shutz [sic] SDB, an old identity of Burra and Sister Helen, who had taught at St Joseph’s School for many years.  John Fahey of Hallett, with the help of others, conducted a program of sports and competitions for children and parents.

Obituary.  Philip Bampton aged 73 was buried at Holy Cross Church, Goodwood, on 4 November.  Mr Bampton and his wife and family – Basil, Isabelle (Mrs Jim Hasse), Anne and Derek – came to Burra from India in the early 1950s.  They worked for St Joseph’s Church and Anne and Derek attended the Convent School.  His brother, Dr Bampton and his wife and family followed them, but Dr Bampton died soon after arriving.  The first of Mrs Bampton’s relatives to come to Burra in the late 1940s were the gentle Mr & Mrs Jim Elder (hairdressers at Burra and Burra North) and their parents, Mr & Mrs McKenna Senior and Eric, who were in business here before moving to their successful antique business on Unley Road.  (Jim Elder Jnr is also an antique dealer in North Adelaide.)  All these people will be remembered for their refinement and love of life. The change of life style from India to Burra could not have been an easy one, but Philip Bampton was sad when he left Burra to live in Elizabeth North.  He cycled around Burra & Burra North daily for many years as the postal delivery man.

Characteristics of the 1974 paper.

There was not a very comprehensive news coverage of Burra.  Sports get a reasonable coverage and reports from many societies’ AGMs are frequent, but anything actually written by the paper itself is sparse and often inadequate.  The reports on the two floods in Burra for the year are typical of this, being quite brief and lacking in detail.  Even the ‘Out & About’ column is less comprehensive than in earlier years.  There are many articles that act as ‘fillers’ and many items of general interest (particularly to primary producers), but also fillers giving hints to the handyman (on painting for instance).

After page 1 the layout of the paper varied from week to week, but the following outline is quite typical.

Page 1	Typically full of news, but frequently little of it relating to Burra.

Page 2	Large advertisements and sports.

Page 3	Large advertisements – typically more than half page – plus public notices and sports.

Page 4	Large advertisements and a mixture of sports, news and articles of general interest.

97, 1, 21 Jan. 1975, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool

The pool has now been fibre-glassed, renovated and filled.  It will open on Tuesday or earlier depending on the cleaning of the water.  The wading pool has also been fibre-glassed and the dressing rooms renovated, following an Australian Government grant towards costs.  Season tickets cost $12 for a family, $X single and $3 child.  $250 has been transferred from the canteen fund to the Council.

Fire.  A fire at the end of December burnt 350 acres at Burra North.

[A thank you notice on page 3 reveals that it entered the properties of Stan Edith & Mary Woollacott, Brian Riggs, and Frank, Dorrie and Robert Reed at Abberton Park.]

Burra Golf Club plans a new Club House and intends to borrow $9,000 from the Savings Bank of SA.  The site has been levelled.  A meeting of ratepayers to endorse the choice of site has been called for 10 February.  The total cost is estimated at $25,000and part payment of $9,000 will be made by the Minister of Local Government under Parks & Reserves grants.

Burra Pictures.  Pictures at the Town Hall are likely to close at the end of the year as there is only one licensed operator, Mr Wally Nankivell, and another will then be required to allow the show to carry on.

Obituary.  Mr John Harold Torr aged 76, formerly of Farrell Flat, died 22 December 1974 in Adelaide.  In the district he farmed ‘Torlnga’; land first taken up by his grandfather.  He was born in Farrell Flat and spent most of his life there.  He was the son of Sydney and Ann Torr and was educated at Mintaro School.  Later the family moved to Gawler and Harold then attended Prince Alfred College.  In 1922 he married Clarice Denton of Farrell Flat.  The eldest of their five children, Glen, lost his life on Pathfinder operations with the RAAF in WWII.  Harold was interested in sports and served on many community committees.  He retired to Glenelg six years ago and spent much of his time there fishing.  He is survived by his wife and daughter Enid, Mrs Blieschke (Leighton); Brian Adelaide; Peter (Sydney) and Ern (Farrell Flat).  [Born at Farrell’s Flat 4 June 1898.]

97, 5, 18 Feb. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The Council is concerned with the untidy appearance of the town caused by blocks littered with weeds and rubbish and especially with derelict car bodies.  Council is to make an effort in the next twelve months to eliminate unsightly areas of weeds and rubbish.

Children riding bikes on footpaths are seen as posing a hazard for pedestrians.

Prosecutions for straying sheep are expected soon.

The swimming pool renovation has now been successfully completed and it has since been well patronised.

The ratepayers’ meeting on 10 February drew a representative gathering.  A resolution was passed approving the lease of a site for the planned new club house.  The procedure of the club borrowing money through the Council can now go ahead.

Over twelve months ago the Council received a loan of $7,000 for the purpose of constructing a dam across the Burra Creek.  The questions of possible flooding and of pollution have been taken into account by the E & WS Department and work has now been started on creating a shallow lake stretching from the Caravan Park to just north of the Burra Hotel.  Pumping from the Mine is expected to begin soon at the rate of about 2 million gallons per day.  The dam should be an attractive addition to the beauty of the town.

Following a deputation to the Minister of health it seems that the Burra Common Effluent Drainage Scheme will be constructed in 1976-77.

The Grants Commission has invited applications for funding to upgrade sports facilities.

BHS.  The year began with 172 students, slightly down on 1974 due to fewer 1st year students.  A new staff member Mr Colin Baker was welcomed.  Art teacher Mrs Schultz is unfortunately still on sick leave.  From now on year levels will be referred to as Grades VIII, IX etc.

The Meaning of STOP SIGNS will change on 1 March.

From that date you must stop and give way to all traffic from the right and the left.

Obituary.  Hartley Harris, formerly of Burra, died in Melbourne 9 February aged 84.  He was a son of the late Frank Harris and left Burra in 1923, keeping up a subscription to the Burra Record ever since.  His first job about seventy years ago was with the Burra Record at 5/- a week.  After two years he went to Adelaide and entered the grocery trade.  In the Great War he saw service at Gallipoli and in France, after which he married and returned to Burra to be employed as a grocer by Drew & Crewes.  In 1923 he went to Lilydale in Victoria to an apple orchard and dairy farm.  With difficult times and the onset of the Great Depression he returned to grocery, where he remained until he retired.  For the last 25 years he lived in the Melbourne suburb of Reservoir.  He is survived by his son Bruce and his brother Arthur, now of Adelaide.  He spent his last three months at the McLeod Repatriation Hospital.  The occupant of an adjacent bed was another man who spent his early years in Burra; Mr Peter Gebhardt.  [Hartley Pascoe Harris born 10 August 1890 Kooringa.

Peter Gebhardt would seem likely to have been Adolph Peter Gebhardt born 30 September 1905 at Port Wakefield, though if he was at a Repatriation Hospital it suggests he was a WWII veteran.]

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes

$17,000 more is required to erect three more units.  The cost of the three units is now $70,000.  Government subsidy will bring in $37,000, but only if all the necessary money is in hand before work starts.  Cash in hand is $19,000, leaving a shortfall of $17,000 to be raised.  The proposed units will be the same standard as the existing ones.  The No. 6 Social Club (Masonic) has also handed $657 to the appeal as the result of Friday night’s cabaret.  The hotels of the district have all made generous donations, as have Moyles, Coca Cola Bottlers, Snack foods Pty Ltd and Jackie Kleinig’s Dance Band.  A gift of $300 has come from ‘Mackerode’ Mt Bryan*.  Money must be raised quickly before costs soar even higher.

[* This was corrected in the next issue page 2 to read ‘The Mackerode Gift $300.’]

Burra Show Society held its AGM 11 March.  Ron Shipard of Hanson replaced Graham Kellock as President.  Other officers: Patron, Rex C. Warnes; Senior Vice-President, Neil Hurst; Junior Vice-President, Peter Stockman and Secretary-Treasurer, Darrell H. Field (re-elected).  The society was in credit $122.50 after having new toilet facilities erected.  The toilet project was made possible in large part due to the Rural Youth, who ran a Lottery Cabaret to assist.  D.T. Jacka & Co. erected the new toilets.

The show was held on the Saturday of the October long weekend and coincided with the Burra Copper Festival.  As a result gate takings were a near record.  Mr Bert Kelly MHR opened the show.  The day began with showers, but cleared as the day progressed.  Entries were good in most sections.  More entries in shearing would be appreciated.  Miss show Girl was a huge success.  The Dog Section was not held for lack of a convenor.  A pony club has been formed in Burra in the past year and has been given permission to use the grounds.  The Boy Scouts have permission to use the halls for their meetings.  Thanks to Roy Humphrys for keeping the grounds weed free and to Secretary D.H. Field and his wife and to other members of committees.

Tennis.  With so many tennis players in town there is a shortage of courts.  There are eight senior and two junior teams and at times local teams with scheduled home matches have to play away; for example at Leighton.  Five courts are available at Burra North as well as those at the school.  Planned building operations at the school are likely to deprive players of the use of four of these.  It is planned therefore to lay down six courts on the area of the former lawn courts.  An application has been made to the State Committee of Regional Employment Development for $13,000 to cover the cost and for two netball courts – one at Aberdeen Oval and one at Burra War Memorial Oval.  With the building of the new clubhouse for the Burra Golf Club the present clubhouse will meet the needs of tennis players.

Burra Golf Club has decided to sign the contract with D.T. Jacka & Co. for the new clubhouse.

Stockowners Association of SA.  The Burra & District Committee held its annual meeting in the RSL Hall and elected: President, J.G. Duncan; Senior Vice-President, J.T. Drew; Junior Vice-President, R.J. Ashby.  The address was given by M.I. McTaggart.  The President reported on the year’s activities.

The wool sales in September saw values slide a further 15-17½% with the average bale fetching $176 at the last sale – a slight improvement.  There was a year of record rainfall resulting in huge losses in pastoral areas due to blowfly attacks and more recently from grass seeds and worms.  Some producers say this combination has been more worry than a drought.  The bushfire hazard has been extreme.

Cattle prices have been low, but stable and with an estimated backlog of 2 million cattle to be slaughtered, the outlook is grim.

Pig meat and grain fed lamb prices have been quite good.

Rising costs in the sector in wages, workers’ compensation, fuel, payroll tax, super bounty and depreciation, along with depressed markets are forcing producers to the wall.

97, 14, 29 Apr. 1975, page 1

Aberdeen Football Club held a meeting on Wednesday and decided that owing to a lack of playing members it would be forced to go into recess for the 1975 season.  The President Mr M. Broad informed the secretary of the Mid North League, Mr M.A. Bannear, that they would be unable to field any teams for the season.  He asked that clearance of players to take positions with other clubs be expedited.  The Mid North League will now have five rounds of matches with no byes.  Mr Bannear felt that this could well be the last year of the Mid North League, with every possibility of joining with the North Eastern League in 1976.

E.C. Allen MP Member for Frome objects to plans to close all polling booths with under 50 voters average in the last three elections.  Places affected around Burra would be Black Springs av. 46.  [Though how 54, 48 & 51 averages 46 is not explained!]  Also Bright (41), Hanson (40) and Willalo (50).  His complaint is not so much about closures in the settled areas as the effect in more remote locations.  The result would be only one booth in the whole area north-east of Peterborough; at Yunta.  In the far north, if Oodnadatta closed (50) the nearest booth would be Marree 274 miles away.  With mail deliveries once a fortnight postal votes are also not an option in such remote areas.  The system would have to be changed.

Mrs Margaret Goyder Kerr of Somerton Park writes seeking information on the life of James and John Chambers who came to SA in 1837 and who pioneered postal and coaching services in SA.  They also took up vast areas of land for cattle and sheep and went in for breeding horses.  With William Finke they discovered copper on their Oratunga station.  They employed John McDouall Stuart to move further into then unknown territory.  They were among the founders of Adelaide’s early hunt and racing clubs.  Their sister Priscilla married the adventurous Alfred Barker, who came to SA with Colonel Light before the colony was founded.

Obituary.  Mary Williams was the fourth daughter of the late Charles and Elizabeth Evans of Riverton.  The family of five daughters was cared for by their kindly father after Mary’s mother died when she was nine.  Mary was educated at Tothill’s Creek, Tothill’s Belt and Riverton High School and then went to Adelaide Teachers’ College.  She was gifted at needlework.  She taught at small schools in the vicinity of Pinaroo, Frances, Hawker, Warooka and Kadina until her marriage in 1936 to Maurice Williams of Carrieton at St Agnes Church, Marrabel.  The couple lived at Baldina Downs and later in Burra.  There were three daughters and four sons, but only the eldest lived beyond very early infancy.  Mary was a relief teacher at Burra Primary School in the 1950s and assisted when health and family commitments allowed in Burra Rural Youth and at St Joseph’s Church and School.  Her husband died in 1866 and two of her sister, Essie Evans and Olive Hansbery, also predeceased her.  She became incapacitated in august 1974 and was cared for at Burra Hospital until her death on 31 May 1975.

97, 22, 25 June 1975, page 1

Burra Community School

The Minister of Education Mr Hugh Hudson has released plans for SA’s first Community Complex School to be built at Burra.  This involves rebuilding the present Burra Primary and High Schools and integrating them into a community facility.  The original school building, which is a structure of historic interest classified by the national Trust, will be preserved.  The interior will be converted into modern open space, leaving areas for primary students.  There will be five additional buildings and a library will be built at the rear of the old building.  The separate building for secondary classes will include science and commercial studies facilities and a third will provide for art and craft activities.  A fourth building will house a drama workshop, activity hall and canteen, while an administrative block will house offices, staff accommodation and a sick room.  The area between the buildings will be developed into an amphitheatre.  The landscaping of the site will provide a new hockey field, an additional oval for primary students and an adventure playground.  The tennis courts in front of the building will remain, while those at the rear will be replaced.  The present impressive façade of the school will be preserved.

Ruth Trevivian nee Glenister1 contributes an article: ‘Memories of Burra’.

She was born in Darton Cottage – formerly Dr Sangster’s [Sen.] residence and her sister was born in ‘Bleak House’, the former Mine Hospital.  She recalls Granny Howell2 living in a cottage a few yards from Darton Cottage, who said she had originally come from England as a lady-in-waiting to someone of high rank.

She remembers getting fitted for shoes at Pederson’s.  Her father was the Choir-master at St Mary’s; he had sung in St Paul’s Cathedral in London before leaving England.  Mr Graham Dow was then organist at St Mary’s and the ministers were Revs Hopton3 and Hewitson4.  A small boy pumped the organ.  She recalls being taken over the Black Bridge to the Chinaman’s Garden5 for vegetables [in Kingston Street] and also being taken for an afternoon walk by a girl from the Reformatory (when Miss Bubb was Matron) and how the girl dumped her on a windowsill of a stock firm for a moment’s rest and the window breaking.  The girl flew along the wide street with her and she can’t recall the outcome.  She remembers the Misses Ethel and Lily James behind the haberdashery counter at Drew & Crewes and Miss Tiver in the dresses and hats department.  Miss Gert Pearce was a reporter and Mr Marston the editor at the Burra Record.  Mr Parks the baker looked like a ghost, standing in his doorway with a big white apron and hair and eyebrows white with flour.  The boys rocking the swing bridge made the journey home uncomfortable and swaggies asleep on the creek banks frightened her when she was on her own.  The creek ran and they caught frogs to release in shop doorways – unbeknown to her mother.  She recalls Mr Wicklein the jeweller, Mr Walker the shot outfitter [sic-?] and Mr Stan Lane the saddler. Mr Streicher’s waxed moustache fascinated her.  She recalls Mr Pearce’s furniture shop with its smell of sawdust and a cat snoozing in the sun and old Mrs Pearce sitting inside the doorway.  She recalls also Pompey Pederson6 and his speedy entrance into Burra after racing from Adelaide.  And the earthquake.  And the tragic death of Mrs Lafsky, who did their washing and was killed at a railway crossing on her way home from one of the stations7.  Other names she mentions include Killicoat, Hann, Dane, Winnall, Jarrett, Pickering, Maundrell, Murphy and Mr Hogg, whose wife was a Belgian.

[1Ruth Grace Glenister born 31 August 1915 the daughter of Herman John Glenister (formerly Schneider) and Doris nee Dollman.

2Mrs Annie Howell nee Lewis; see Burra Record XV, 460, 27 Mar. 1901, page 2-3; XV, 464, 24 Apr. 1901, page 2; XV, 632, 1904, 29 June 1904, page 3; XXII, 1940, 14 Apr. 1915, page 2; XXXXV, 25, 13 June 1923, page 3 and XXXXVII, 46, 25 Nov. 1925, page 3.

3Henry Hopton was Rector of St Mary’s 1918-21.

4Frank Hewitson was Rector of St Mary’s 1921-27.

5The Chinaman was Luke Day c. 1867-1962.  He came to Burra c. 1893 and lived there till his death.  For many years he had a shop on the corner of Kingston and Thames Streets and later in the former Bible Christian Chapel in Paxton Square, living in the adjacent house in Kingston Street. See Colin T. Branford Luke and Hester Day 1966, and E.R. Fuss Burra Chinese 2004, both in the Burra Library.

6Percival Morton Pederson 1867-1945.  See Noel & Geoff Pederson The Boy from Burra they called “Pompy”2012 in the Burra Library.

7 Bridget Joraslafsky nee Nugent c. 1967-1923.  See Burra Record XXXXV, 27, 4 July 1923, page 4 for a report of the inquest.]

Burra Bowling Club AGM

The report by retiring President Brian Riggs.

Two members died during the year: Lance Phillips and Hedley Pearce.  Financially the year was a success, due in considerable measure to the bar manager Neil Hurst.  The new watering system is now working well after a few initial hitches.  Membership numbers leave a little to be desired.  Facilities are being constantly improved.  Keith Phillips was the Club Champion and also won the Mid North Champion of Champions at Auburn.  The open tournaments in January and at Easter were a great success despite mediocre weather.

The Associates are an essential part of the club and their catering has been especially capably handled.  The greens were reasonably good throughout and were good for Easter and the inter-divisional championships of the women’s Bowling Clubs.  The purchase of a new mower will make the job of the Greens’ Manager Edgar Pietsch easier.  Andrew Phillips had done good work preparing them for play and Wally Fridd is thanked for attending to the watering.

Obituary.  Arthur L. Bence was born at Hampstead, London in 1892, the eldest of three children.  Both parents died when he was about eight.  His brother and sister went to live in Acton and he lived for the next three years with his maternal grandparents at Chiswick.  When his grandfather died he applied in 1903 to become a Bernado’s Boy and was taken to a home near Whitechapel.  He was trained as a bell-ringer and mandolin player and went on tour with fellow boy musicians to Southern England, Wales and the Channel Islands.  On one tour when he was fourteen he met Olive Stringer and eleven years later they were married in Singapore Cathedral.  
In June 1908 a small party of Barnardo’s Boys led by Rev. W.J. & Mrs Mayers, with Mr Aarons as Musical Director, toured Australia to raise money for the Barnardo’s Homes.  They arrived at Fremantle on 8 August 1908.  They visited each state and New Zealand.  A few weeks before the end of the tour Arthur, with the consent of Rev. Mayers, accepted the offer of a home and job in Melbourne.  A few weeks later his employer lost the agency he had been running and Arthur had to fend for himself.  He worked in Sydney for two years and then answered an advertisement to become a trader in the Solomon Islands in 1912.   At that time he did not see another white face for months.  Eventually a passing schooner picked him up from Guadalcanal when he was seriously ill from malaria, having been deserted by his native helpers, who said he had ‘devil-devil’.  He was returned to Australia, where he recovered.  Over the year he had kept in touch with the Stringer family and on his recommendation they had migrated to Victoria, where they had a grand reunion.  He was still in no position to become engaged to Olive and he returned to the Solomon Islands in 1913 and continued to trade and recruit labour there till 1916.  He then received news that his brother had been severely wounded in the war and he joined the Australian Forces.  He arrived in Egypt early in 1916 and later went on to fight in France.  In 1917 he was badly wounded and convalesced in England before being returned to Australia.  On returning he became engaged to Olive Stringer.  His wound had left him with only one usable arm.  Being used to handling native labour, he decided to become a rubber planter in Malaya and sailed to Singapore in 1918.  He got a plantation manager’s job with control of 250 coolies.  He soon sent for Olive and they were married on Easter Saturday 1918.  About eighteen months later, soon after the birth of their daughter Lotus, the rubber price plummeted from 5/- per pound to 6d per pound.  Mrs Bence and Lotus returned to Australia and three months later Arthur followed.  They settled in Burra where he became an auctioneer.  He also travelled the eastern country selling goods and was soon able to start the business Bence’s Ltd, which still flourishes.  The first sale at the Burra Auction Mart was on 7 September 1921.  The Record reported that this innovation would be a boon to many people, as Mr Bence would be ‘prepared to submit to auction on any Friday, anything brought in from a sucking pig to an elephant’.  They expected it to be an unqualified success.

By 1924 Bence’s – Burra’s Cash Drapery Store was established and they had a second child, Len, the store’s present manager.  During WWII Len was stationed in England where he flew Wellington Bombers, returning safely with an English wife.  Lotus married an Australian flying officer, who was killed by the Japanese in the Solomon Islands after his Catalina crashed.  She remarried and now lives in Norway.

Through good and harsh times the store survived and both Arthur and Olive put much time and effort into its continuing success.  Stories of personal generosity in the supply of clothing etc. to struggling families come from the depression days.  They were both workers for charity.  Despite the disability with his arm, Arthur was an accomplished tennis player and golfer.  Many people will remember the beautiful Pearly King and Queen costumes Mr & Mrs Bence wore to fancy dress functions at times.  Arthur also appeared as Father Christmas and made one novel entry to the RSL Hall when he descended to the floor hand over hand on a rope suspended from a skylight.

[This was a neat trick for a one-armed man!]

They retired in the early 1960s to Glenelg and remained there till Olive’s death a few years ago.  [1971] Mr Stringer, her father, lived to be over 100 and only died in the last couple of years.  Arthur returned to Burra to live in one of the Barker Cottage Homes before going to an Adelaide Nursing Home for a short time and dying there on 3 July.  [2 July according to a previous report.] Father John Morley conducted the funeral in St Mary’s on 5 July.  He is survived by a son, a daughter, four grandsons and one great-grandson.

[Arthur Leonard Bence born 15 October 1892 Hampstead, London: died 2 or 3 July 1975 Adelaide.]

The Centenary of Parnaroo Hall will be celebrates by a ball there on 16 August, sponsored by the Hall Committee and the Parents & Friends’ Association of Peterborough’s St Joseph’s Convent School.  The hall is a section of the previous Parnaroo Wool Shed, erected in 1875 of stone from the surrounding hills.  It is on a section of Paratoo Station and Pandappa Station, leased by Thomas Elder – 719 square miles with 40,000 sheep.  A portion of the homestead still stands about 400 yards northwest of the Hall.  Local residents bought the Hall from the SA Government in 1904 for £400, since when it has been used for wedding receptions and dances.  It was originally the wool room of the Parnaroo Station Shearing Shed, where 60 stands once operated.  Shearers then started at 6 a.m. with breakfast at 8.30 a.m. by which time 1,000 sheep were shorn.  The pay in 1875 was 20/- or £1 for 100 sheep.  In 1880 the land was subdivided and sold for £1 per acre, but the land proved difficult for farming and finally the Government auctioned off 23 farms in 1893 and the 15,000 acres brought up to 2/4½ per acre.  Descendants of early settlers who remained in the area are the late William Just, August Hennig, William Neil, John O’Toole, Sam Saunders, Albert Gericke, Gustav Gruel, Martin O’Dea and Roland Betty.  Two large families of old were Albert Gericke’s 13 children and John O’Toole’s 12 children.  Early farmers reaped up to 40 bushels per acre and carted it to Ucolta to the train.  In the early 1900s it is said up to 30,000 bags of wheat could be stacked there.  Now there are just two remaining families; Mr & Mrs Roland Betty of Blue Hills Station and Mr & Mrs Flank Polomka of Parnaroo Pastoral Company.  Government grants have enabled the installation of toilets in the hall and an annex on the front.  The Centenary Ball will also feature entertainers from Peterborough and District, and will include the well known country singer Allen Graham of Terowie.

97, 29, 12 Aug. 1975, page 1

C.M. Lewis & Sons’ shop at Hallett closed on 31 July, ending a life which had begun in 1912, when Fred Lewis, the father of the last owner, Mr Alf Lewis, began the Lewis Bakery.  Mr Lewis Sen. was an Englishman who migrated from Malmsbury in Wiltshire in 1910 and after working in Farrell’s Flat, Broken Hill and elsewhere, arrived in Hallett in 1912.  After his marriage in 1913 he and his English wife spent the rest of their lives in the business.  At first the break etc. was sold from the bakehouse, but in the 1920s the old coaching stables, where the northern coaches changed horses in the early days, were demolished and the present substantial shop and attached house was constructed.  Lewis’s delivered bread to the four shops that were then in Mt Bryan and also two or three times a week to Petherton, Canowie, Willalo and North Booborowie.  In the 1920s there were several grocery stores in Hallett, including Harris’s General Store (later W. Phin’s and now part of the Hall’s family residence).  On the site of the present road-house was a saddler’s shop owned by Alex Davy of Terowie and the grocery shop of John Doyle.  Drew & Crewe’s were in the property now held by Seigert Bros.  Mrs McCrae kept a greengrocer’s shop and refreshment rooms on the property of Mr & Mrs Bill Reed.  There was a butcher shop owned by George Trussler, recently deceased, on the site of the present fire station.  South of the crossroads was Statton’s Blacksmith, Welding & Wheelwright’s business, employing seven men.  It closed in the late 1950s.  Near the railway station was another butcher’s owned by the Carpenter family, adjacent to the first Hallett Hotel, demolished in the early 1970s.  In the 1930s Depression Lewis’s delivered ration bread to the gold miners at Ulooloo.  After the death of Mr Fred Lewis his widow and sons Alf and Arthur took over.  As the Hallett township declined and it became increasingly difficult to get relief bakers, the family ceased baking in the mid 1960s and obtained its bread from Burra.  Alf continued to make pasties and cakes until ill health forced him to close his business.  In recent years he has been assisted by his sister Gladys Mrs Bob Slatter and his brother Arthur and his family.

The rate was declared at 2c in the dollar compared with 1.8c for 1974-75.  This was largely to accommodate inflation.  The minimum rate payable for a property in the Townships of Burra, Mt Bryan, Booborowie and Farrell Flat is $40.  Outside those the minimum rate payable is $15.  The differential rate has been declared at 10c in the dollar for all towns including Hanson, bringing town rates to the maximum possible 12c. Burra Burra Hospital Inc. AGM

Frank Ford and Allan Baulderstone were welcomed as Members of the Board of Management.

Chairman R.K. Parse read the 98th report of the hospital.

Financially the hospital is very sound.  A credit of $60,000 is invested.  Expenses rose 71% and receipts by 63%.  Bed cost rose by $5 to $22.46.  We were able to show a surplus of $59,298.

Improvements included air conditioning the Nurses Home and a carport there and a new piano.  TV sets were placed in private rooms and handrails in toilets and bathrooms.  The Secretary’s residence was renovated.  The hospital’s interior was renovated and repainted.  Average daily patient numbers rose to a record 27.8 and 24 babies were born.  The auxiliary has maintained linen etc. and restocked the storeroom with jams and preserves.  In the year we lost the services of Sister Goode as tutor, to be replaced by Sister Wall.  After ten years the Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer resigned on 30 June and his place has been taken by Mr Hank Heitbrink.

Meals on Wheels has continued to operate efficiently.

Eastern District Fire Fighting Organisation held its annual meeting at Koomooloo on Wednesday.  Chairman Don Lord welcomed visitors, especially Fred L. Kerr Director of the EFS and his Assistant Tony Kaye and National Parks & Wildlife Officer John Fitzgerald.  He said the fire risk is high this year.  The meeting supported the recommendations of the working party on country fire service re-organisation.  From 1 November 1974 to 25 February 1975 thirteen fires were attended to though only five were in the immediate area.  Radios had proved effective.  Don Lord was re-elected Chairman.  Two Traeger SSB 50 radio transceivers will be bought to give greater coverage.  At present the district covers 30 properties and 25 members.  It was recommended that the organisation becomes incorporated.  Ironically it was raining during the meeting, but the accompanying lightning reminded all that most of last season’s fired had been caused by lightning and in SA such fires had burnt out nearly 31,000 km2.

97, 34, 23 Sep. 1975, page 8

The Tiver Reunion

A reunion of descendants of James Tiver, who was born 11 June 1929, will be held at Burra 12 October.

James was the son of a baker, Hugh Tiver and his wife Rebecca of Bristol, England.  Hugh died young and James received little education, going to work aged 8 as an apprentice mason.  He married Elizabeth South of Newport and with a young son, James Hugh (then under 2) sailed from Plymouth in the David Malcolm.  A daughter, Margaret Malcolm Tiver, was born on the voyage.  They arrived at Port Adelaide in April 1855 and were met by an uncle, James Rosser.  They came to Burra by bullock dray and James erected a wattle and daub hut near the ford1 where Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery now live.  Elizabeth died in 1856 and in 1858 James married Emma Price, who had come to SA in 1856 in the Alloquis.  From this marriage there were ten children.  James did contracting work and also did carting to and from Port Adelaide.  He built the middle house in Tiver’s Row in Redruth and it was there that most of the children were born.  Later with Emma’s help he added the houses either side to create Tiver’s Row.  In 1870 he built the house and store at Aberdeen2 and the family then lived there.  Emma and step-son James Hugh Tiver kept the store and James continued with contract work, employing as many as 100 men.  He participated in the construction of the Wallaroo Smelting Works.  James said it was cheaper to cart beer from Port Adelaide than water for the men at Wallaroo.  With Mr Thomas Burgoyne MP and Mr Aaron Cole he built the first macadamised roads in the district, the Aberdeen Ford, the Redruth Bridge3, the original Burra Institute, Burra Railway Station and Yards, the Stationmaster’s residences, from Tarlee to Farrell Flat and many private homes.  When the railway was extended to Hallett in 1876 he opened a branch store there and James Hugh then ran the Hallett Store and became a Councillor and Chairman of the Hallett DC at various times.  James Hugh Tiver died aged 434.

Later James had a large plant at Terowie for building the new railway yard there for the line to continue to Petersburg.  James also bought land; first Mt Cone at Mt Bryan for £1 per acre.  He sold this and bought country at McVitties Flat near Hallett, which he later sold and bought Harry’s, Opie’s and Gare’s farms at ‘Banbury’ Hallett.

In 1888 and later James and his sons purchased and were allotted pastoral leases when the Government cut up the old Paratoo Run and so they founded ‘Pats Well’, later to become ‘Tiverton’.  James was a member of the Kooringa5 Corporation, a Superintendent of the Sunday School and office bearer in the Methodist Church for many years.  He was also a JP and member of both the Masonic and Oddfellows Lodges for many years.  Despite a long hard struggle against drought, James eventually became a prosperous pastoralist.  He died 12 March 1909.  Emma lived until 1926 and died aged almost 90.  She was always a very active support for James and once when he urgently needed supplies at Wallaroo, she packed quickly and made the journey there in a bullock dray with some of the young family.  With no accommodation on arrival they erected an ‘instant cottage’ in one day.  The children of Emma and James were:

Mary Ann (Mrs [Edward Francis] Opie)	Albert Joseph (who died as a child) [aged 3]

Charles Godwin	George Samuel

Emma Price [Mrs John Sara]	Charlotte Dunn [Mrs Arthur Stock]

Edgar	Henry (Harry)

Emily Price6 [Mrs Arthur Sara]	Harold Walter

[Notes:

1In Young Street.

2Tiver’s Railway Store, later known as Sara’s Store on the corner of Young and Morehead Streets.

3This was the 1861 timber bridge.  Tiver & Cole contracted for the masonry abutments.  By 1878 the timbers had rotted and it was replaced by a steel bridge in 1879.  It is possible that the original abutments were retained, but further research would be needed to verify that.

4James Hugh Tiver 3 June 1853-10 April 1896; making him 42 at death.

5This was actually the Burra Corporation or Town Council of Burra.  James Tiver was the Councillor for North Ward December 1883 to November 1887.

6The ‘Price’ is probably an error; it is not added in any of the birth, marriage or death registrations.]

The new clubhouse was opened on Sunday when about 300 people attended in fine weather.  A large field of 116 players took part in Foursomes prior to the ceremony.  Mr Baulderstone welcomed visitors and said the services of the SA Gold Association Architect Mr Murray Crafter were obtained for the design of the new course opened at the start of the 1873 season. Mr Claude Allen MP said a few congratulatory words and Mr W. Brown as Chairman of the District Council opened the clubhouse.  The State Government had made a grant of $12,300 and the Savings Bank of SA had given a loan of $9,000 repayable by the club and the club had contributed $4,000 and a great deal of time in planning and much voluntary labour. Burra’s 98th Show was a Success.  [If was in fact far short of the 98th Show; The first show was in 1877, but the society had gone into recess from 1886-93 and during WWII 1940-45 and was also cancelled in 1897 and 1914 due to seasonal conditions.]

The 1975 show was a success with gate takings of $856, which compared well with 1974’s $1,046, when it coincided with the Copper festival.  President Ron Shipard introduced Hon. Dr Hopgood to open the event.  Much of the success is due to the Secretary Mr Darrell Field.  Entries were good, especially in Horses in Action, Wool, Fruit & Vegetables, Flowers and Birds.  The Sheep Pavilion was full.  Dogs were re-introduced and attracted good entries.  The food and drink stalls have been updated.  The display of modern farming equipment was bigger and better than ever.  In the Miss Show Girl Contest the Open Winner was Miss Susan Kotz of Burra, the Junior Winner was Susan Towle and the Sub-Junior Winner was Janet Durling.

Page 5 reviews the following sections with judges’ comments: School Work, Sheep Shearing, Sideshows, Horses in Action, Art, Bantams & Budgerigars, Cattle, Cooking, Dogs, Flowers, Floral Arts, Goats, Grain & Fodder, Handicrafts, Needlework, Fruit & Vegetables, Produce Preserves, Pets, Sheep, Pol Rams, Medium Wool, Wool and Lapidary.

The licensed dance at night was arranged by the Rural Youth Club in the Town Hall with music by the ‘Tremulos’.  The Motor Cycle trials were cancelled due to insufficient entries.

The Council and the Eastern Districts Fire Fighting Organisation are both concerned about increasing fire danger and have been discussing the problems. Riverton said it had decided to seek affiliation with Barossa & Light and if not accepted there it would seek to join the North Eastern League.

Robertstown wished to stay with the Mid North League.

Mintaro-Manoora had not changed its decision to seek affiliation with the North Eastern League.

Saddleworth-Marrabel United wished to remain with the Mid North League.

97, 45, 9 Dec. 1975, page 1

Hallett & District Schools Athletics Association

An article outlines the Association’s history at some length.  The inaugural meeting was of teachers only on 14 April 1928.  A later meeting resolved that each school committee appoint two persons to assist the teachers.  The first meeting at the Hallett Oval on 3 October 1928 arranged sports for those from under 7 to under 15 and included novelty events as well as conventional athletics.  A special train came from Terowie and the schools represented were: Whyte-Yarcowie, Terowie, Mt Bryan, Booborowie, Willalo, Ulooloo, Hallett, Booborowie North, Petherton, Narrowie and World’s End.

In the early years a dance was held in the evenings.  This became a concert and dance and continued till 1950.

The exhibition component of the gathering began in 1929.  Meetings continued till 1941 when petrol rationing caused the only postponement of the event.  Over the years team events became increasingly important.  Over time other schools participated including, Mt Bryan East, Ucolta, Sunny Brae, Yongala Vale, Hundred of Whyte and in later years, Burra.  For some years there were special events for Correspondence School children.  The last Executive Meeting of the Association was held on 19 August 1975 when it was resolved to present the balance of money in the account to the St John Ambulance Centre in Burra.  Trophies were distributed to schools and written records were donated to the Burra National Trust.  Of the seventeen school at some time involved, only three were affiliated at the time of the last sports day on 18 April 1975; Hallett, Mt Bryan and Burra.

[Note that this article is lengthy and includes many names of people and families involved in the long history of the Association.]

Tiver Family Reunion.  272 signed the family book at the Burra Town Hall and at least 300 were present.  James Tiver helped to construct the main Hall 100 years ago.  Bad weather prevented the planned gathering at the racecourse.  People brought their own lunches and there was a thanksgiving service.  Hedley Thomas of Mundulla took family group photographs and there was a display of old photographs and family documents.  12 December was the 109th anniversary of Edgar Tiver’s birth.  The oldest descendant present was Netley Sumner of Hallett aged 79 and the youngest was the baby Luke Tiver a great grandson of Charles Godwin Tiver.  A few days later a letter was received from Raymond George Tiver in the UK where he has lived for many years.  He is a grandson of James Hugh Tiver and nostalgically recalled memories of Burra and Hallett districts from 50 or 60 years ago and of relatives.  [The report names many of those present.]

98, 1, 28 Jan. 1976, page 1

Burra Community School

Mr Christopher J. McCabe has been appointed Principal of Burra Community School.  He was previously Deputy Principal of Penola High School.  He is the first principal of a Country Community School in SA.  The comprehensive rebuilding of the existing Primary and Secondary Schools provided an integrated educational facility.  The original building, which is of historic interest, and has a National Trust classification, has been preserved.  Mr McCabe will be responsible for the successful introduction of the concept of community education in Burra.  In 1973 Mr McCabe took up a Rotary Foundation award to the USA and studied for his MA at Ball State University, Indiana.  A significant part of his study was community education.  He has taught at Findon and Port Pirie and Mt Gambier High Schools and was appointed Deputy Principal at Penola High School in January 1975.  In the rebuilding process the shell of the original building will be retained, while the interior is converted into modern open space learning areas for the Primary School students.

Adelaide Wool Sales.  Prices were generally 2½% firmer.  [Local district prices are printed.]

Porter’s Lagoon will be the site for an Aquatic Spectacular on 22 February, sponsored by the Gilbert Valley Lions Club.  The Club’s money-raising this year is principally aimed at making a significant contribution to the provision of an Orthopaedic Workshop at the new Crippled Children’s Centre at Regency Park.  This will design and make all manner of clothing and aids to make affected persons more mobile.  The club is supporting Mrs Denise Benger of Saddleworth in the Miss Personality Quest.

Football

The Mid North Football League has been dissolved.  Mr A.E. Bannear, Secretary of the League, has advised of the steps in the dissolution of the League.  Notice of the intention of member clubs for the 1976 season was required by 24 December 1975.  It was:

Auburn FC: withdrawal from the League and to remain in recess for 1976.

Aberdeen FC: no response, but remaining in recess for 1976.

Mintaro-Manoora: withdrawal from the League and joining the North Eastern Football League.

Riverton FC: withdrawal from the League and joining the Barossa & Light League.

Robertstown FC: withdrawal from the League and joining the Barossa & Light League.

Saddleworth-Marrabel United FC will amalgamate with the Riverton FC with the new team to enter the Barossa & Light League.

As a consequence the AGM of the Mid North Football League will be held on 2 February 1976 at Saddleworth, when it will discuss and act on clause 6 of the constitution, to dissolve the League.  In the next two months all players will be transferred either to the Barossa & Light League or to the North Eastern Football League and in the case of the Riverton and United players, transferred to the new club and then to the Barossa & Light League.  A wind-up dinner will be held at a date to be fixed.  A history of the League from its foundation, possibly in 1911, to its dissolution is in hand.  Clubs are asked to give consideration to setting aside certain funds for this purpose.

BCS Parents and Friends met at the school last Thursday.  Edith Carpenter as Co-ordinator for the Community School addressed the meeting.  The Principal Mr Chris McCabe introduced the new staff and addressed the meeting.  Ron Thamm chaired the meeting and steered the discussion smoothly through questions of open space teaching, fund-raising priorities etc.  Ian Allen outlined the achievements of 1975.  Tenders have been called for the painting of the exterior of the main building.  Nine parent representatives were elected to the School Council.  Mr McCabe stressed the need for community involvement if the concept of a Community School is to work.  An Open Week will be held 15-19 March when many different subjects will be offered to people interested in taking part.  Year 12 student Anne Carpenter also addressed the meeting, urging community support for the new school concept.

Football

The Mid North Football League held its AGM 2 February.  President Mr S. Noske read the report for 1975.  There was a credit balance of $1,354.14.  G. Hirschausen & P. Reed moved that the Aberdeen FC be allowed to withdraw from the League and the Club to remain in recess.  It was then unanimously resolved to dissolve the League.  It was resolved to have a Mid North Football League Dinner. And to have the History of the Mid North Football League recorded by the League secretary and published.  $150 was retained to cover the basic publishing costs with one copy to go to each club and a further decision to be made on other copies.

Funds are to be divided $170 each to Riverton, United, Mintaro-Manoora and Robertstown, with $130 each to go to Aberdeen and Auburn.  Money from the disposal of assets is to be divided equally between the six clubs.  Shield are to be returned to the Secretary at the end of the 1976 season and then to be given to the club with most names thereon.  Other final arrangements were made and the records will go to SA Archives.

Polo

After an absence of 37 years the Clare Polo Club returned to their old ground, with Stanley Hawker officially opening it before a large crowd on 25 January.  Since being reformed in 1971 practices and tournaments had been held at Anama Park and then at Anama.  Now the field within the racecourse has been levelled and drained and sown and should be an ideal playing surface.  Practices are held every Saturday afternoon with a season from January to Easter.

98, 5, 24 Feb. 1975, page 1 [Note wrong year used throughout this issue; should be 1976.]

Burra National Trust held its AGM on 9 February.

Retiring President G.E. O’Connor reported.

The Federal Government’s National Estate program provided $12,000 in a grant, but it had to be spent in two months, which meant it could not be used to best advantage.  Work done was:

The Bon Accord Engine Shop was half re-roofed and the building repainted satisfactorily after Mr Cockington had condemned the contractor’s first efforts.  Drainage was improved on the southern side.

Restoration of the second dugout was commenced as a voluntary project, but when $2,500 became available it was contracted to G. Nourse and D. Cockington.  Some work remains to be done.

$3,800 was allocated for the restoration of the old Powder Magazine.  The first contractor withdrew over a dispute concerning the quality of work and it was completed by Don Villis.  The western wall (previously dismantled) was rebuilt and the eastern wall of the magazine itself was removed.  The building is secure, but much more needs to be done.  After we had spent the money it was discovered that the Powder Magazine was not National Trust Property, which upset National Estate authorities because the funds were only to be spent on Trust owned properties.  It was finally resolved by the Council giving the Trust control of the property by means of a covenant.

We have found that local contractors give greater satisfaction than outsiders.

Ian Auhl published two beautiful books during the year.

Late in the year the Diamond T fire engine that served the town from 1937-75 was offered for sale by the Fire Brigade Board and was snapped up by the District Council who sold it to the National Trust.

Our first ever organised dinner in December 1974 at the Kooringa Hotel was well attended and very satisfactory.

[The retiring President G.R. O’Connor also acknowledged the support of all volunteers, Mr Woollacott, the District Council and the Federal Government for their respective support.]

BCS will launch the first Community School Week 15-19 March.  For that week the normal program will be suspended.  Special student courses related to the curriculum will be held from 9-11 a.m. and for the rest of the day mini-courses on a wide variety of subjects will be held for both students and adults.  Courses are free except for any materials used.  Courses are being supported by Sturt CAE and the Clare Further Education Centre as well as by the school staff and community volunteers.  For the students work experience has also been arranged.  Added to the student program are the Year 8 camp at Barmera and a Year 12 visit to Adelaide tertiary education centres and some Festival of Arts productions.  Unfortunately this week clashes with Field Day Week and in future this will be avoided.

New Electoral Boundaries

Mr Claude Allen MP has decided not to contest the seat of Frome at the next election.  Following the redistribution based on the one vote one value principle the electorate will become much larger and he says it could not be represented by one person and have the sort of representation the electors are entitled to.  The redistribution has been passed with Liberal Movement support.  Mr Allen was elected first as successor to the late P.H. Quirke in 1968.  In 1970 the Electorate of Burra was abolished.  The western half went to the electorate of Rocky River and the eastern half went into Frome.  Mr Allen won Frome and has contested and won four elections in just over seven years.  The present Electorate of Frome covers 38% of the state and could become larger with the redistribution.  Mr Allen will retire to Spalding on the completion of his parliamentary term.  Before becoming a politician he was a farmer for forty years.

Basketball

The North-Eastern International Rules Basketball Association was formed on 28 October 1970.

There were then five men’s teams: Clare, Torreston, Hallett, Burra Blue and Burra White.

And three women’s teams: Hallett, Torreston and Burra.

For 1971-72 Burra added a further men’s team and another women’s team.

In 1972-73 the men’s teams were Hallett, Torreston and three Burra teams.

The women’s teams numbered five.

On 20 June 1973 the North-Eastern and the Spalding Associations merged.

For the 1973-74 season Burra supplied one men’s team and one women’s team and in all the Association comprised 6 men’s teams and 4 women’s teams.

The line-up for 1974-75 was unchanged and in 1975-76 season Burra High School added a men’s team.

This season Burra entered three men’s teams and one women’s team.  Letters have been sent out to see if a Burra Association could be formed.

St Mary’s has been desecrated by vandals.

Altar vessels, the cross and candlesticks were removed and shoved under the altar in the Lady Chapel.  Pieces of candle were strewn around and the wires of the public address system were broken.  Water was poured on the carpet; glass in historic photographs was broken.  Sunburn cream was applied to a glass case and a door.  Books and magazines were thrown around and some were torn.  The Reserve Sacrament was removed from the Aumbry.  The adjacent hall was also entered and coffee and tea were mixed with the children’s sand tray.

St Joseph’s was visited by vandals about a week ago.  The vandals have since been apprehended.  The church will now be locked when not in use.

Monsignor T.F. Toal, Parish Priest of Jamestown and his brother Dr M.F. Toal celebrated their Golden Jubilee of Ordination at Jamestown this week.  They were ordained in Genoa, Italy, 29 May 1926.  There was Mass at St James’ Church at 11 a.m. followed by luncheon at the Jamestown Town Hall.  Monsignor Toal studied at Mungret College, Limerick, and then at Collegio Brognole Sale, Genoa.  After ordination he came to Australia and served in the Perth Diocese before coming to SA.  He then served at Jamestown, Streaky Bay, Pt Pirie and at Whyalla for 31 years and in 1967 returned to Jamestown.

Dr Toal served at Jamestown and then at Burra and Pt Pirie.  While at Burra in the 1930s and 1940s he was an interpreter at Loveday Prison Camp in WWII because of his multi-lingual abilities.  He was a Professor at St Patrick’s College, Manly, and at St Francis Xavier’s Seminary, Adelaide.  He went to Rome 23 years ago.  He has been engaged in translating and publishing the homilies of the Fathers of the Catholic Church.  Four volumes have already been published.

19, 16 June 1976, pages 1 & 4

A History of the Burra Record by Ian Auhl

The paper began on 30 June 1876 as the Northern Mail

Six months later it changed its name to the Burra News and Northern Mail.

In July 1878 its new editor, Frederick William Holder announced its new title would be the Record.

On 4 October 1878 the name changed again to the Burra Record.

It had taken a long time for Burra to get a local paper.  Compare its starting date with the Kapunda Herald (1864), the Kadina & Wallaroo Times (1865) and the Northern Argus (Clare, 1869).

Burra had to make do with printed handbills for advertising and a town crier.  Other local news was occasionally to be found in the Adelaide papers the Advertiser or the Register or the weekly Observer.

The first editor, Henry Pether, ascribed this lack to opposition to a paper from the SA Mining Association, which had also been against local government.

The first editor of the Burra Record was Frederick William Holder.  He had come to the town in 1875 as a bachelor to take charge of the Burra Public School.  He became an active member of the Burra Parliamentary Club and discussion in this club led to the proposal for a local paper.  A committee was formed to establish one.  The cost originally of 3d made it too expensive for many and kept its circulation low; 600 by the end of 1876.  Pether left in June 1878, soon after Jarman’s departure.  The Government school opened in January 1878, leaving Holder without a job.  When the editorship became available the committee of eight co-proprietors appointed Holder in his place.

In October 1878 Holder became the sole proprietor.

Under Holder the paper flourished.  He became Mayor of Burra in 1886 and again in 1888, having been elected to Parliament in 1887.  He was later Premier of SA on two occasions.

The paper has had three homes.  The first seems to have been on what is now the eastern corner of Bence’s store.

In September 1880 Holder announced they would move next door because the original office was about to be demolished to make room for two new shops to be built for Messrs Drew & Co.

Three years later on 6 January 1883 four shops on Market Square were destroyed by fire: Lane’s Saddlery, Geake’s store, Packard’s Solicitor’s Office, Doe’s Hairdressing Salon and the Burra Record Office.

Despite the complete destruction the Burra Record appeared later that week, having been printed in Adelaide.  The shops were rapidly rebuilt.

Late in 1883 the paper was issued twice a week and the price fell to 2d.

In 1890 Holder sold the paper to Mr P. Murrie Jnr.

In January 1891 the paper reverted to being a weekly.

In September 1891 W.J. Davey took over as editor.  [And later became the proprietor.]

Davey reduced the size of the paper and in 1904 increased the pages to 8.

Davey sold out to Ernest Frederick Marston in March 1913.

In 1945 E.F. Marston sold the paper to his son Frank Teare Marston.

In 1942 the paper was reduced to four pages, but increased again to 8 from 1945.

E.E. & R.E. Angel acquired the paper in June 1954.  The Marstons had printed the paper for 41 years.

Eric Angel must be the person with the longest association with the paper.  He came to Burra from Eudunda in 1929 and was employed by Mr Marston Sen. and then by his son before taking it over in 1954 with his son, Bob, the present editor.

[Auhl fails to mention the move from Market Square to Commercial Street and its date.  I have not ascertained when it moved to Commercial Street, but the Market Square premises were destroyed by fire again in April 1910, but were rebuilt on the same site.  In January 1935 they were in Commercial Street when a fire that began in an adjoining shop again burnt out the office, but this time the press was saved.  See also 98, 21, 29 June 1976, page 7 for corrections to this history.]

Corrections to last week’s History of the Burra Record.

E.F. Marston who took over the paper in 1913 did not run a photographic studio.  His predecessor Mr W.J. Davey did.

Mr Davey’s sons Harold and Billy continued to work for the Record until they went elsewhere.

The Record was then printed in premises occupied by Matthews in a section nearest Bence’s.

It was later burnt out.

We have a photo of the premises in 1913 with E.F. Marston, W.J. Davey Jnr and H.J. Davey standing outside with Arnold Gravestocks, another employee.  This has come from Ian Auhl on loan from Mrs Miriam Davey, widow of the late W.J. Davey Jnr.  We hope to publish it next week.  [They didn’t.]

Lyle Quinn, Roche Bros’ manager, is leaving Burra.  He came to the town in 1970 when Roche Bros. won the contract for earth moving at the Burra Mine for Samin Ltd.  He has been involved in other jobs outside the Mine, including site preparation for the new Golf Club.  He was responsible for starting Roche Bros. Social Club, which bought the Oddfellows’ Hall for its use and was also involved in the annual Miners’ Cabaret.  Now after 24 years of earthmoving and 20 years with Roche Bros. he is leaving Burra and the company.  He will go to manage a caravan park at Rushworth in Victoria; his hometown.  He has worked on a huge range of job types in earthmoving in NSW, ACT, SA and Tasmania (including King Island).  Dave Ball will take over his position in Burra as temporary manager.  The social club will continue with David Thamm as the new President.

Mr Simon Newell of Newell’s Travel Agency in Falmouth, Cornwall, contacted Mr Ian Auhl recently on behalf of a client, Mr John Gill aged 72.  Mr Gill had read the Burra Sketchbook and it prompted the contact.

Mr Gill came to Australia in 1921 as a sponsored emigrant and returned to the UK in 1928.  While in Australia he drove a 1904 Sunbeam Talbot for Mr Jim Gallagher of Quondong Station and later a f-ton International truck and trailer for the Burra firm of Drew & Crewes.  On the delivery run for the firm Mr Gill took three days for the round trip and was paid £4 for a seven day week.  There were 90 gates to open and close on the route, still served by a Burra contractor.  Mr Gill claims that he and a companion brought in the first load of wool from the ‘outback’ by mechanised transport.  Soon after arriving back in the UK he set out on a round the world tour on a motor bike with sidecar. (A Vincent HRD)  This took over a year.  He married and has two daughters.  For many years he was chief engineer for the Admiralty and moved to Falmouth about 33 years ago.

Hockey.  The second semi-final was a protracted affair.  At the end of normal time the match between Burra and Roseworthy was drawn at 3 goals each.  Two extra five minute halves left the scores unchanged.  Five penalty strokes followed and brought the scores to 4 goals each.  After a further five penalty strokes Burra 6 eventually defeated Roseworthy 4 and so moves into the grand-final.

BCS will hold its first Annual Ball on Friday 20 August in the Burra Town Hall.  The ball will be attended by Mr Claude Allen MP, who will launch the ‘Buy a Brick’ campaign.  This is to raise funds for the School Community Hall.  Years VI & VII students are planning an end-of-year social.

Lutheran Sunday School Rooms at Burra North will be dedicated on Sunday 15 August with a special service at which Pastor Kuchel and previous Pastors A.H. Schmidt and P.A. Scherer will officiate.  Luncheon will follow in the Redruth Memorial Hall.  The first Lutheran Church was built opposite the Court House at Burra North.  This later was burnt down and the deeds were lost.  Services were then held in a variety of places, served by the Pastor from Kunden Parish, Waterloo.  Among places used were the Copperhouse Methodist Church [actually Westbury Methodist Church, adjacent to Copperhouse] the Oddfellows’ Hall Burra North and the Church of England Hall at Burra.  There is little evidence of Sunday school activity during this period.

In 1967 parishes were re-aligned and Burra joined with the Clare-Blyth parish.  Colin Heinrich is then noted as the first Sunday school teacher.  On 21 August 1967 the existing Burra Lutheran Church arrived on a low loader from Mansfield Park.  The building was placed on newly acquired land at Burra North and dedicated on 5 November 1967.  In 1968 David Munzberg was elected Sunday school superintendent and Mr Kleinig as a teacher.  At times lessons were held in the back seat of a car until the late Mr P. Beinke kindly lent his house.  This became unsatisfactory when numbers increased to make three classes.  Classes were then held in the vestry, porch and hall of the church.  Eventually it was possible to obtain a four-roomed building at Milang for $650.  It arrived in Burra in January 1976 and was sited north of the church.  The building required considerable repairs and repainting.  This work has now been completed.  There are presently 27 children on the roll with three helpers, three relief teachers, four teachers and a Sunday school superintendent.

Date Stamps.  New regulations requiring date stamping of short-life perishable foodstuffs [or as the paper says ‘footstuffs’] will come into force in 12 months time and will apply to all pre-packaged perishable foods with a life up to 90 days or less.  They will have to carry a date as to when they should be used.  Break and milk bottles will be exempt because of labelling problems.

98, 31, 31 Aug. 1976, pages 1 & 7

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild celebrated its 50th Anniversary last Thursday.  Mrs Reta Jennison has been the secretary for those 50 years and Mrs A.B. Riggs and Miss C.A. Reed were two of eight foundation members present.  Luncheon was held in the Redruth Memorial Hall where beautiful flower arrangements were done by Mrs Les White.  Olive Oates and Jan Cockington played light music.  Several former ministers attended with representatives from the town’s other guilds and the Catholic Women’s League.  Miss Clarice Reed gave the gold-iced birthday cake.  Mrs A.B. Riggs, who was the first treasurer, came from Adelaide with her daughter Lois and cut the cake.  Mrs Venning, formerly Mrs Dyer, the wife of the late Rev. Dyer, came to Burra in 1937 and she lit the candles.  After lunch there was time for reminiscences and performances from many with long associations with the church at Burra North.

Lindsay Thomas sang I shall not pass this way again and Lucky ‘ole Sun accompanied by his wife Joyce at the piano, who also played two pieces by Greig.

Dorothy White, nee Woollacott sang Early in the morning and Faith can move mountains, accompanied by Jan Cockington.

Netta McIntosh, nee Thomas sang If I can help somebody and May the good Lord bless and keep you.

Her husband, Howie McIntosh gave two stories: The three little pigs and Cinderella in the manner of Dr Spooner.

Mavis Satchell, nee Fairchild, sang Her name is Mary and Little Jack Horner in the style of Handel.

The Guild had been founded in 1926 by the late Rev. Harry Alvey with the strong support of his wife.  The minutes of the first meeting were read again with the names of the ladies who had joined in the first year.  Other speakers were Rev. Don Haydon (President elect of the Methodist Conference), Rev. George O’Neill (Chairman of the Middle District), Rev. Pitman, Rev. Clem Christopher, Mrs M. Odgers, Mrs Boyce and Mr Colin Fuller.

Other visitors included: Joyce Pearce, May Cox, Nellie Benger & her husband Alan, Sheila & Joyce Fairchild, Jean Humphrys, Barb Thompson nee Jennison and her daughter Marian, Norma Reed, Mrs F. Przibilla, Joyce Greig nee Jefferies and Shirley Fuller.

Burra Burra Hospital Inc.  Annual Report

The Board of Management will have to rely on public support for the next 12 months even more than it has in the past year if standards are to be maintained.  Thanks are extended again to the sewing ladies and other donors for their continued support.  The Government has indicated a strict budget for the coming year.  Average bed costs have risen by $7.76 to $30.22.  During the year there were 386 patients admitted and 355 were discharged.  There were 703 out-patients and 101 operations were performed.  During the year a new boiler was installed and air-conditioning placed in the Nurses’ Home and in the remaining private rooms.  New beds and a new deep freeze unit have been purchased.  We regret losing the services of Sister Oates, who took a position as Matron at Kimba Hospital.  Matron and the other nursing and domestic staff have done excellent work.  Meals on Wheels has continued to operate efficiently from the hospital.

The Burra Show [Incorrectly cited as the 99th.]

The day dawned frosty and remained fine, but became intensely cold as the day progressed.  A fair crowd attended.  The gate amounted to $615.  There were record entries for horse in action.  Michelle Burton was Miss Show Girl and A. Talent won the open shearing contest.  Show President Mr Ron Shipard welcomed guests and thanked exhibitors and all those who worked so hard to put the show on.

Mr Ray McCallum, President of the Northern Show Societies, from Orroroo opened the show.

Junior Miss Show Girl was Mary-Anne Shipard.

Sub-Junior Miss Show Girl was Carolyn Armstrong of Burra.

In the open shearing contest L. Hughes and A. Talent both scored 187 points and there was a shear-off to decide the winner, with Arthur Talent coming out on top.  The judges were Tony Ryan and Graham Heine.

Greg Germein won the Novice Section.

Art entries were of a very high standard.

Budgerigars were of a good standard with some excellent young birds.

Pigeons were a big improvement on last year’s display.

Poultry were well staged, but the number of shows held on the same day made it hard to get a large show of top birds.

Children’s pets were well displayed and covered a wide range from a goat to a white mouse.

Cattle had some good heifers, but generally carried less condition than in 1975.

Cooking was of a good standard with notably good cheesecake, boiled fruit cake and chocolate cake entries.

Junior entries were impressive.

Flowers were down a bit due to the season, but there was a fair display and some very good blooms.

Floral Art was good, with outstanding entries under ‘Á Song Title’.  The children’s section was a pleasure to judge.

Grain entries were down, but of good quality.

Fodder entries reflected a dry season.

Goat entries showed good potential in the young stock.

Needlework entries were down, but work on the whole was good, especially in the Crochet Cloth.

Produce entries were few.  The winning sauce entry was excellent.

Vegetable entries were down due to the severely cold winter.  Quality was, however, a little better.

Poll sheep were of excellent quality and the Champion Ram was excellent.

The Champion Ewe was an excellent breeder with a thick covering of strong wool.

In the medium wool section the entries were of a high standard and numbers were high.

The Champion Strong Wool Ram carried a good bulky 58’s fleece.

The ewe section was particularly strong in both numbers and quality.

Wool:

The fleeces shown were particularly well grown and many fleeces weighed in excess of 10 kg.

Saddleworth Show is reported in c. 3 columns.

Leighton Basketball Club has been disbanded.  It had been formed on 4 May 1946 and with the Spalding, Hallett and Booborowie Clubs formed the North-Eastern Basketball Association.  They played on a ground at the Leighton Recreation Ground, which had been already graded for a tennis court.  The Leighton team was premier in its first year.  Nelda Bruce (Kleinig) was Club President 1946-55.  Elvyn Collins took over for 1956-58 and 1966-68.

In 1956 permission was given to play on asphalt courts at the Recreation Ground.  Jacie Bruce was President 1959-61 when Mr F. Goodridge became President.  Due to lack of players the club went into recess until 1963, when it entered a team in ‘C’ Grade in the North-Eastern Association.  In 1965 & 1966 ‘B’ and ‘C’ Grade teams were entered.  In 1967 ‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’ Grade teams played.  In 1968 ‘B’, ‘C’ and ‘D’ Grade teams were fielded and three teams continued to play until 1973.

Amalgamation with Booborowie and Hallett was discussed in 1972, but it was decided to continue.

Circumstances prevented it entering teams in the North-Eastern Association in 1974 and it then joined the Stanley Netball Association and in 1974 entered two teams.  The senior of these was premier in ‘C’ Grade in 1975.  The Stanley and Mid-North Associations amalgamated in 1976 and distances became too great.  The players joined the United Club.  [Details of the Club occupy about ¾ column.]

The Chairman of the Burra Burra DC sent telegrams yesterday to the Premier Mr Dunstan, the Leader of the Opposition Dr Tonkin and the Minister of Mines Mr Hudson.  They expressed the hope that some action could be taken to save 62 jobs directly involved at the Burra Mine following the concern of people in the town and district towards Samin Ltd being in receivership. 98, 40, 9 Nov. 1976, page 1

Burra Mine

The Burra community became worried when the Poseidon receiver and manager Mr Buckley and Professor Rudd visited the town and inspected the Mine.  The business people and the town generally grew concerned and telegrams were sent to the Premier, the Minister of Mines and the Leader of the Opposition.  Professor Rudd says the Mine is presently operating with a small profit and it is not intended to close it.  But we all know that if the price of copper drops much more it could cause the Mine’s closure.  At present the Mine employs 62 people and when in full production, 100.  Samin owns several houses in the town.  In Parliament the Hon. Hugh Hudson said that discussions with Samin had been going on for some time and would be continued with the receiver.  Poseidon, Samin’s parent company is in difficulty and if Samin needed cash to sustain a period of insufficiency there would be a problem.  The difficulty is greater for Burra because it produces a specialty product for which appropriate markets had to be developed.  The Government certainly wishes to keep the Burra Mine going if it can reasonably be achieved, but it cannot support an operation if it is likely to continue to be unprofitable.  There are hopes the copper price will recover by the end of June and hopefully the Government will be able to reach an agreement with the receiver to ensure the Mine can continue so that the market can be tested.  We cannot, however, say with any certainty that this will be achieved.
