BCS.  The Management Committee has been looking at the possibility of the BCS Library becoming a Community-School Library.  The present library is set up to serve the needs of the school students.  If it became a Community-School Library it would be funded in three ways; through the Education Department, through the State Government vis the State Library and through the local District Council.  As well as books there would be periodicals and cassettes available.  Access would be given to all State Library resources.  It would normally have 14 books per head of population and the annual replacement would be about one seventh of the stock.  Institute libraries in the district would have to be dissolved and in return the Community-School Library would set up branches, which would provide books and periodicals and change the stock regularly by means of the school bus service.  Books of historical or local significance would be retained by the local branch.  The whole arrangement was discussed by representatives of those involved at a meeting on 11 November.

Each Council and Institute must now make its own decision. So far the Burra District Council has come out enthusiastically in favour and the Booborowie Institute has also agreed.  Other decisions are eagerly awaited.

BCS Year 7 students recently went for a camp at Christie Downs from Monday to Friday.

Students reported on the experience in an article of a little more than 2 columns.

Monday

The group travelled by train to Adelaide and then by train to Christie Downs before walking for 20 minutes to the camp site.  The rest of the day was spent in the local area.

Mr Perth Collins passes on a little information compiled by the late Miss Alice Collins, concerning the late Henry Collins of ‘Lucerndale’ Mt Bryan.

Henry Collins came to SA with his parents in 1839 from Devonshire.  He was then aged 6.  His first job was to mind a mob of sheep.  When the family came to Burra they had to construct dug outs in the bank of the Burra Creek.  At an early age he went to work in the Burra Mine and when his father went to the Victorian gold rush he was the sole support of his mother.  Later they were able to buy a couple of bullock teams and began carting between Burra and Port Adelaide.  Henry was so small that he had to use a stool to enable him to place the yokes on the bullocks.

Ratepayers’ Meeting

About 30 people attended the meeting called by the Burra Burra DC Chairman Cr R.B. Jennison last Wednesday night.  The Council had felt the impact of a slowing inflation rate.  While Government grants for road works are decreasing, the no-strings Federal Grants increased to $45,000 from $20,000 in 1975-76.  Council has budgeted for a planned program of district road works.  Nominated streets in Burra will be reformed and sealed.  Council assisted with the site works at the new Burra Community School and the go-ahead for this $3 million project will stabilise Burra as an important district centre.  The improvements to the Burra Creek in the town in conjunction with the Tourist Promotion Committee, Apex and BCS and the National Trust is another significant project.  We hope drainage problems in the business area will be addressed with funding for the Effluent Drainage Scheme in 1977-78.  Plans are under way to give the district a superior library service.  Council will join in the Pest Plants Control and Vertebrate Pests Act projects.

[The report then lists a number of subjects about which questions were asked, but does not report any answer given.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1976

It was a rather disappointing paper for local coverage.  Some events that are foreshadowed are not reported when they occurred.  There are many general interest items, which, while relevant to local farming or grazing, were not local news.

The District Council reports are mostly useless and frequently indicate that a question was raised, but not what it was or what resulted.  An example would be:

‘Mines Royalty – Dept. of Mines re royalties Burra Mines.’

As in 1975 AGM material is printed, but there is no evidence that the paper itself was doing much in the way of collecting material.

Page 1

News

Page 2

Largely advertising in some months with perhaps an article from the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries or a Bowls Club report.

Page 3

Large advertisements and sport.

Pages 4 & 5

Large advertisements, sports results and items from other centres like Saddleworth.

Page 6

Cash column, large advertisements, public notices and entertainment.

Page 7

Out and About column – a major source of local news, but in very brief snippets.  Some general interest items.

Page 8

Large advertisements and the 50 & 24 years ago column.  Occasionally a small sports result or small news item.

99, 3, 2 Feb. 1977, page 1

Bence’s Ltd Drapery & Clothing Store has changed hands after operating for 56 years.  Proprietor-Manager Mr Len Bence has conducted the business since the early 1960s following the retirement of the late Arthur and Olive Bence.  Arthur started life in Burra as an auctioneer, holding sales of furniture and sundry items.  This followed a period of trading in the Solomon Islands around 1913.  He saw active service in Egypt and France in 1916.  He also travelled around the eastern country selling goods and was soon able to start Bence’s Ltd, which has flourished ever since.*  The first sale at the Burra Auction Mart was advertised on 7 September 1927.*  The editor commented that it should be a boon to many people.  By 1924 the columns of the Record were advertising Bence’s Cash Drapery Store.  The store has kept its doors open through hard times and times of plenty.

Now Mr Len Bence intends to devote more of his time to a life-long interest in painting.  Many of his fine works already adorn the walls of homes in the area.  Len and Muriel intend to stay on in Burra.  The new proprietor is Mr Arnold Earnshaw who intends to carry on business with the same staff and will trade under the name of Bence’s.  He previously had a similar business at Leigh Creek and has been associated with the trade for many years, including the management of several of C.J. Coles’ Variety Stores.

[*Some of these dates and statements are not quite true.  The following references from the Burra Record may clarify the history of the enterprise:

XXXXIII, 35, 31 Aug. 1921, page 2: Advt.  A.L. Bence (late AIF) Auctioneer & Commission Agent sets up the Burra Auction Mart opposite Eyes & Crowle’s in Commercial St.  Furniture, Poultry and all classes of goods every Friday from 9 September.

XXXXIV, 38, 20 Sep. 1922, page 3: Advt.  ‘Bon March’  Burra’s new shop will be opened by A.L. Bence in that portion of the Auction Mart previously occupied by Mr Woollacott on 21 September.

XXXXV, 4, 24 Jan. 1923, page 3: A.L. Bence will be moving into the premises formerly occupied by Miss Snell and will open the shop as a general cash drapery store with occasional auction sales.

XXXXVI, 1, 9 January 1924, page 2: Advertisement for Bence’s Burra Cash Drapery Stores & Agent for Alston’s Windmills

52, 5, 4 Feb. 1931, page 2: Advt.  This issue carried the last advertisement for Bence’s.  It announced the last week of their Summer Sale.  [For the continuation of the business as Bence’s Ltd see 52, 11, 18 Mar. 1931 page 2.]

52, 11, 18 Mar. 1931, page 2: Advt.  The formation of Bence’s Ltd is announced.  It was financed by certain local people and managed by A.L. Bence.  Bence’s Ltd has purchased the entire assets in the assigned estate of A.L. Bence at a huge discount.  [There location is not stated, but probably the west side of Market Square.  In any case by August the former SAFU store that had been the location of Bence’s Cash & Carry Department was vacant and available for a dance.]

52, 33, 19 Aug. 1931, page 3: Shell Co. Dance.  The Shell Co. is to hold a dance in every town in Australia on 29 August and Mr T.H. Woollacott has been tireless in making arrangements.  The Institute Hall is engaged and so the SAFU store, now vacant, (but late [Bence’s] Cash & Carry Store) will be used.]

Allen has resigned as Chairman of the Primary School Council, a member of the Community School Council and as Chairman of the Community School Management Committee after years of dedicated work.  A minute of appreciation was recorded.

A Council Levy of $500 per family, which in comparison to many schools was very modest, was added to the booklist this year.  It will be used for administration costs, insurance fees, maintenance of Council property and for school amenities.  [This must surely be a misprint?]

Mrs E. Carpenter, Community School Co-ordinator reported on programs and services offered.

In 1975 there were four DFE Classes and in 1976 there were 9.  There were 7 voluntary classes in three centres; Burra, Hallett and Booborowie and 4 voluntary evening classes.

In October Community School Week saw 292 adult enrolments.

There was a Vacation Recreation Centre run each holiday.

Youth Club attendance varied from 40 to 80.

The Burra Community Entertainment Group put on Salad Days.

Support was given to Arts Council Productions and to the Art Gallery Travelling Exhibition.

A Junior National Trust Branch had been established.

Horse riding was organised in vacations.

A Dog Obedience Club was run.

There were ballet classes and a DFE class in Leather Embossing.

A Toy Library had been set up.

The Management Committee has taken on the establishment of the Community School Library as a major operation and has instituted a comprehensive list of all organisations and clubs within the district.

Burra Traders’ Association has decided to be more active in trying to bring trade back to Burra.

E.C. Allen MP, Member for Frome writes:

When Mr Jennison greeted the Premier recently he suggested that the Burra District had little or nothing to show by way of benefits from many years of Liberal Party Government.  I cannot speak for the period of the Playford era, but this assertion is not true for the time of the Hall LCL Government 1968-70.  The efforts of the Minister of Mines Hon. R.C. De Garis MLC in that Government had much to do with the re-opening of the Burra Mine by Samin Ltd.  A program of sealing portions of main roads each year was commenced and the sealing of the Hanson-Clare Road was commenced – it has still not been completed after seven years of a Labor Government.  The Hall Government also investigated a site for a new Burra High School and had plans drawn up.  There was then a desire to move to another site and the Hall Government was defeated at that point, but it had much to do with the progress towards a new school for Burra.  Construction work which was begun on the Morgan-Spalding Road by the Hall Government has been discontinued under Labor.

Hallett Institute.  President Mr B.H. Richards spoke at the AGM on 17 February of problems associated with a lack of interest and support and of financial woes.  The closure of the National and ANZ Bank branches has reduced income for the Institute and the M&BHA has also closed its fortnightly clinic.  Only essential maintenance could be carried out.  The committee recommended joining the Burra Community Library, but a public meeting pressed for the retention of the Institute Library.

Burra Library AGM elected President, Mr R.J. Steele, Vice-Presidents, Mrs Ben Kotz and Mrs I. Hirschausen; Secretary, Mr Ben Kotz & Treasurer, Mrs E. Carpenter.  Support this year was appreciated from the Burra Burra DC and from a raffle.  A special meeting in December resolved to join the Burra Community Library, but the present arrangements will continue until the new library is established.

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, page 1

The final issue as the Burra Record.

The Burra Record will amalgamate with the Peterborough and Orroroo based paper, the Review Times, which in future will be the Review Times Record and which will be printed in Port Pirie by the latest offset process by Independent Newspapers Ltd.  This will be the final issue as the Burra Record.

The price of the enlarged paper will rise from 8c to 10c a copy.  R.E. & A.J. Angel will continue with their job printing and act as agents for the new paper, accepting advertsing, copy and photographs for it.  Representatives of the publishers will make periodical visits to Burra to assist advertisers with copy and layouts, in which photos and drawings will be more readily incorporated.  Advertisers should benefit from the larger circulation and more modern printing facilities.  The cost of production at Burra has been rising and it is increasingly hard to get replacement parts for the old machines.  Another reason for amalgamation is the retirement of the linotype operator Eric angel, who came to the office in 1929 and has been setting the type here for 45 years.  The office is not closing as a job printing service.

Booborowie will celebrate the centenary of its proclamation as a township on 29 March 1977.  A committee has been formed to make arrangements for celebrations on 30 April and 1 May 1977.  There will be a Back to School and a tea at the Hall followed by an Old Style Dance.  Sunday will begin with a combined church service in the Hall and the unveiling of a commemorative plaque and there will be a barbecue lunch.

‘King’ Broad was guest of honour at the Commercial Hotel on Friday night and he received a 35-year service medal on his retirement from the SAR.

Frank Slatter of Spalding says today is the 25th anniversary of his arrival in SA.  He and a mate, Bert Poole, came to Adelaide on the Omar having been sent from Balliol College Boys Club in Oxford to learn Farming.  They commenced at the Booborowie Experimental Farm.  Frank put in six years there, ending up as head stockman.  Bert Poole returned to England in the depression, but Frank thinks there are a number of the lads who worked on the Booborowie Farm still in Australia.  He would be glad to hear from any.

The Cabaret at the Gaol on Saturday had a somewhat disappointing turnout.  The place was well prepared with the Stimulus Band and a portable dance floor and the supper was superb.  Profits have yet to be finalised.
